content.definition: The Abducens Nerve (CN VI) is a somatic motor cranial nerve that originates from the pontomedullary junction and exclusively innervates the [[f7b5ee5d|Lateral Rectus muscle]], which is responsible for abduction of the eye (looking laterally).
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Motor innervation to the ipsilateral [[f7b5ee5d|lateral rectus muscle]], enabling abduction (lateral eye movement).
  • Pathway: Exits the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction, traverses the subarachnoid space, passes through the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]] near the internal carotid artery, and enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure.
  • Palsy Presentation: Damage results in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a medially directed strabismus at rest and horizontal [[9914d433|diplopia]] that worsens on attempted lateral gaze toward the side of the lesion.
  • Vulnerability: Its long intracranial course makes it highly susceptible to downward traction from increased intracranial pressure ([[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]], tumors, hydrocephalus).
  • USMLE Tip: An isolated CN VI palsy is often a "false localizing sign" of elevated ICP rather than a direct brainstem lesion. It is the most commonly affected cranial nerve in [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus syndrome]].
content.takeAway: The Abducens Nerve has the longest intracranial course of all cranial nerves, making it uniquely vulnerable to stretching and compression from increased intracranial pressure, often presenting as a nonlocalizing palsy that signals a generalized brain pressure problem rather than a specific brainstem lesion.
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[PPRF] --> B[CN VI Nucleus]; B --> C[Ipsilateral Lateral Rectus]; B --> D[Contralateral MLF]; D --> E[Contralateral CN III Nucleus]; E --> F[Contralateral Medial Rectus];

content.definition: Abnormal motor posturing refers to involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs, indicating severe brain injury. It occurs in patients who are comatose and reflects damage to motor pathways between the cerebral cortex and the brainstem.
content.atAGlance:
• Decorticate (Flexor) Posturing: Characterized by flexion of the arms, wrists, and fingers with adduction of the upper extremities, alongside extension, internal rotation, and plantar flexion of the lower extremities. Mnemonic: Hands are near the 'cor' (heart).
  • Decorticate Lesion Level: Indicates damage above the red nucleus in the midbrain, such as in the cerebral hemispheres or internal capsule. The rubrospinal tract (flexor tone) is intact and overrides the vestibulospinal tract.
  • Decerebrate (Extensor) Posturing: Characterized by extension, adduction, and internal rotation of the arms with extension of the legs.
  • Decerebrate Lesion Level: Indicates damage at or below the red nucleus (e.g., midbrain tegmentum, pons). The loss of the rubrospinal tract leads to unopposed extension tone from the vestibulospinal tract.
  • USMLE Tip: Decerebrate posturing generally indicates a more severe brain injury and carries a worse prognosis than decorticate posturing.
content.takeAway: The type of abnormal posturing provides a crucial clue to the anatomical level of severe brain injury; decorticate posturing implies a lesion above the red nucleus preserving flexor pathways, whereas decerebrate posturing signifies a more caudal lesion below the red nucleus, leaving only extensor pathways unopposed.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cerebral Cortex] --> B[Red Nucleus]; B --> C[Rubrospinal Tract Flexion]; A --> D[Vestibular Nuclei]; D --> E[Vestibulospinal Tract Extension]; F(Lesion Above Red Nucleus) --> G{Decorticate}; B --x F; H(Lesion Below Red Nucleus) --> I{Decerebrate}; C --x H;

content.definition: Absence seizures, formerly known as petit mal seizures, are a type of generalized seizure characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness without loss of postural tone, typically lasting for seconds. They are most common in childhood and are often mistaken for daydreaming or inattentiveness.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Sudden cessation of activity with a blank stare, lasting about 10 seconds. May be accompanied by subtle automatisms like eyelid fluttering or lip smacking. There is no postictal confusion; the patient immediately returns to baseline.
  • EEG Hallmark: The pathognomonic finding is a generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharge on EEG.
  • Provocation: Seizures can often be triggered by hyperventilation.
  • Treatment: First-line treatment is [[ethosuximide]]. [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]] is also effective and used if tonic-clonic seizures are also present.
  • USMLE Tip: A classic vignette describes a child whose teacher complains of 'daydreaming' or 'not paying attention' in class. The diagnosis is confirmed by a 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG, often induced by having the child hyperventilate.
content.takeAway: Absence seizures are unique among generalized seizures for their brief, non-convulsive nature, lack of postictal confusion, and a pathognomonic 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG pattern, making [[ethosuximide]] the specific and preferred treatment.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Thalamic T-type Ca2+ Channels] -- Overactivity --> B(Absence Seizure); C(Ethosuximide) -- Blocks --> A;

content.definition: Absence seizure anticonvulsants are medications specifically effective in treating [[a0c128f4|absence seizures]], primarily by targeting the T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, which are implicated in the generation of the characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges.
content.atAGlance:
• First-Line Agent: [[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]] is the first-line and most specific drug for treating isolated absence seizures.
  • Mechanism of Ethosuximide: Blocks T-type Ca2+ channels in thalamic neurons, disrupting the oscillatory rhythm between the thalamus and cortex that generates absence seizures.
  • Alternative Agent: [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]] is also effective and is preferred if the patient has concomitant generalized tonic-clonic seizures. It works by blocking T-type Ca2+ channels and increasing [[5aa5cb91|GABA]] levels.
  • Contraindicated Agents: Certain anticonvulsants, such as [[eddd2bc5|carbamazepine]] and [[5aea213f|phenytoin]], can worsen absence seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: For a child with staring spells and a 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG, the answer for treatment is almost always [[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]]. If tonic-clonic seizures are also mentioned, consider [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]].
content.takeAway: The treatment of [[a0c128f4|absence seizures]] is highly specific, with [[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]] being the drug of choice due to its targeted blockade of thalamic T-type calcium channels, while other common anticonvulsants like carbamazepine are paradoxically contraindicated.

content.definition: Acalculia is an acquired neurological deficit characterized by the inability to perform simple mathematical calculations, resulting from damage to specific brain regions, most notably the dominant (usually left) parietal lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Acalculia is a key localizing sign for a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus of the parietal lobe.
  • Associated Syndrome: It is one of the four classic components of [[38f3ed1f|Gerstmann syndrome]].
  • Gerstmann Syndrome Tetrad: The full syndrome includes Acalculia, Agraphia (inability to write), Finger Agnosia (inability to distinguish fingers), and Left-Right Disorientation.
  • Vascular Territory: These symptoms often result from a stroke in the territory of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]] that supplies the dominant parietal lobe.
  • USMLE Tip: When a patient presents with difficulty with calculations along with any of the other components of Gerstmann syndrome, immediately suspect a lesion in the dominant parietal lobe.
content.takeAway: Acalculia is more than just 'bad at math'; it is a specific neurological sign that strongly points to a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus, often as part of the clinically distinct [[38f3ed1f|Gerstmann syndrome]].

content.definition: The Accessory Nerve (CN XI) is a motor cranial nerve that provides innervation to the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and trapezius muscles, which are crucial for head turning and shoulder shrugging, respectively.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Innervates the ipsilateral Sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle, which turns the head to the contralateral side, and the ipsilateral Trapezius muscle, which elevates and stabilizes the scapula (shoulder shrug).
  • Pathway: Uniquely arises from both the brainstem (medulla) and the spinal cord (C1-C5). The spinal root ascends through the foramen magnum to join the cranial root, and the combined nerve then exits the skull via the [[jugular_foramen|jugular foramen]].
  • Lesion Presentation (SCM): Weakness in turning the head away from the side of the lesion. (e.g., Left CN XI lesion causes weakness turning head to the right).
  • Lesion Presentation (Trapezius): Shoulder droop, weakness in shrugging the shoulder on the ipsilateral side, and winging of the scapula.
  • USMLE Tip: A common iatrogenic cause of an isolated CN XI lesion is injury during procedures in the posterior triangle of the neck, such as lymph node biopsy.
content.takeAway: The Accessory Nerve (CN XI) is unique in its dual origin from both the medulla and cervical spinal cord, and a lesion presents with the distinct combination of weakness turning the head to the contralateral side and an ipsilateral shoulder droop.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CN XI Nuclei Medulla & C1-C5] --> B(CN XI); B --> C[Exits via Jugular Foramen]; C --> D[Innervates SCM]; C --> E[Innervates Trapezius];

content.definition: Accommodation is a reflex action of the eye in response to focusing on a near object, involving a coordinated triad of changes: ciliary muscle contraction, pupillary constriction (miosis), and convergence of the eyes to maintain a clear image on the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: It is a parasympathetic response mediated by the [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]].
  • Ciliary Muscle Contraction: Contraction of the ciliary muscle relaxes the zonular fibers, allowing the lens to become more convex (rounder), which increases its refractive power for near vision.
  • Pupillary Constriction (Miosis): The sphincter pupillae muscle contracts, narrowing the pupil to increase the depth of field.
  • Convergence: The medial rectus muscles contract to direct both eyes medially toward the near object.
  • USMLE Tip: Loss of accommodation with age is called [[presbyopia]]. A pupil that accommodates but does not react to light is an [[08cb577f|Argyll Robertson pupil]], a classic sign of neurosyphilis.
content.takeAway: The accommodation reflex is a parasympathetically driven process via [[68c66997|CN III]] that allows for clear near vision by increasing the lens's refractive power through ciliary muscle contraction, a mechanism that becomes less effective with age, leading to presbyopia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Focus on Near Object] --> B[Visual Cortex]; B --> C[CN III Nucleus Edinger-Westphal]; C --> D[Ciliary Ganglion]; D --> E[Ciliary Muscle Contraction -> Lens rounds]; D --> F[Sphincter Pupillae Contraction -> Miosis]; B --> G[CN III Motor Nucleus]; G --> H[Medial Rectus Contraction -> Convergence];

content.definition: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used as a diuretic and to reduce pressure in the eye and brain by decreasing the formation of aqueous humor and cerebrospinal fluid, respectively.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Inhibits the enzyme carbonic anhydrase in the ciliary body epithelium and choroid plexus, which reduces the formation of bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) and subsequently decreases fluid secretion (aqueous humor and CSF).
  • Clinical Use (Ophthalmology): Treats [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]] (both open-angle and acute angle-closure) by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis.
  • Clinical Use (Neurology): Treats [[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]] (pseudotumor cerebri) by decreasing CSF production. Also used for altitude sickness.
  • Adverse Effects: Causes a hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis (non-anion gap), paresthesias, ammonia toxicity in liver disease, and promotes calcium phosphate kidney stones (due to alkalinization of urine). It is a sulfa drug, so watch for sulfa allergies.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic 'ACID-azolamide' to recall that it causes a metabolic ACIDosis.
content.takeAway: Acetazolamide's therapeutic effect in both [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]] and [[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]] stems from the same core mechanism: inhibiting carbonic anhydrase to reduce the production of bicarbonate-driven fluids, namely aqueous humor and cerebrospinal fluid.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Acetazolamide] --|Inhibits|--> B(Carbonic Anhydrase); B --|Blocks|--> C(H2O + CO2 <--> H2CO3 <--> H+ + HCO3-); C --|Leads to|--> D[Decreased Aqueous Humor/CSF Production];

content.definition: Acetylcholine (ACh) is a major excitatory neurotransmitter synthesized from choline and acetyl-CoA that functions at the neuromuscular junction, in all autonomic ganglia, at parasympathetic postganglionic nerve endings, and at various sites within the central nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Synthesized by Choline Acetyltransferase (ChAT) from choline and acetyl-CoA.
  • Degradation: Rapidly broken down in the synaptic cleft by Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) into choline and acetate.
  • CNS Role: Crucial for memory and cognition. Levels are significantly decreased in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] due to degeneration of neurons in the [[361438f2|Basal nucleus of Meynert]]. Levels are also decreased in [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].
  • PNS Role: Neurotransmitter at all preganglionic autonomic synapses (nicotinic), all parasympathetic postganglionic synapses (muscarinic), sympathetic postganglionic synapses to sweat glands (muscarinic), and the neuromuscular junction (nicotinic).
  • USMLE Tip: Diseases affecting ACh are high-yield. [[77ae6148|Alzheimer's]] (↓ CNS ACh), Myasthenia Gravis (antibodies to ACh receptors), Lambert-Eaton (↓ presynaptic ACh release). Drugs targeting AChE (e.g., [[47d0372e|donepezil]]) are used to treat Alzheimer's.
content.takeAway: Acetylcholine is a versatile neurotransmitter whose function is critically dependent on its location; its depletion in the [[361438f2|Basal nucleus of Meynert]] leads to cognitive decline in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], while its blockade at the neuromuscular junction causes paralysis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choline + Acetyl-CoA] --ChAT--> B(Acetylcholine); B --AChE--> C[Choline + Acetate]; B --> D{Receptors}; D --> D1[Nicotinic]; D --> D2[Muscarinic];

content.definition: The Achilles reflex, also known as the ankle jerk reflex, is a deep tendon reflex that involves plantar flexion of the foot in response to tapping the Achilles tendon, testing the integrity of the S1 and S2 spinal nerve roots.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: Primarily tests the S1 nerve root, with contribution from S2. Mnemonic: S1, 2, buckle my shoe.
  • Pathway: Tapping the tendon stretches the gastrocnemius muscle, activating stretch receptors. The afferent signal travels via the tibial nerve to the S1/S2 spinal cord segments, synapses, and an efferent motor signal returns via the tibial nerve to cause plantar flexion.
  • Diminished/Absent Reflex: Suggests a lower motor neuron lesion, such as a herniated disc compressing the S1 root, or peripheral neuropathy.
  • Exaggerated Reflex (Hyperreflexia): Suggests an upper motor neuron lesion, such as a stroke or spinal cord injury above the S1/S2 level.
  • USMLE Tip: An absent Achilles reflex is a classic finding in [[71daebd6|Tabes Dorsalis]] and [[lumbosacral_radiculopathy|S1 radiculopathy]].
content.takeAway: The Achilles reflex is a simple yet powerful clinical tool that specifically assesses the integrity of the S1 spinal nerve root; its absence or exaggeration can help differentiate between lower and upper motor neuron pathologies.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Tap Achilles Tendon] --> B(Stretch Gastrocnemius); B --> C(Afferent Signal via Tibial N.); C --> D[S1/S2 Spinal Cord]; D --> E(Efferent Signal via Tibial N.); E --> F(Plantar Flexion);

content.definition: A neuron action potential is a rapid, all-or-none electrical signal that propagates down an axon, caused by the sequential opening and closing of voltage-gated ion channels, which temporarily reverses the membrane potential and allows for long-distance communication in the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Resting Potential (~-70 mV): Maintained by the Na+/K+ pump and high resting permeability to K+ (K+ leak channels).
  • Depolarization: A stimulus reaching threshold potential (~-55 mV) triggers the rapid opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels, causing a massive influx of Na+ and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  • Repolarization: Voltage-gated Na+ channels inactivate, and voltage-gated K+ channels open, leading to an efflux of K+ that brings the membrane potential back down.
  • Hyperpolarization: K+ channels are slow to close, causing the membrane potential to briefly dip below the resting potential.
  • USMLE Tip: Many neurotoxins and drugs target these channels. [[tetrodotoxin|Tetrodotoxin]] (pufferfish) and [[lidocaine|local anesthetics]] block voltage-gated Na+ channels, preventing action potential propagation.
content.takeAway: The neuron action potential is fundamentally a precisely orchestrated sequence of ionic movements: a rapid influx of Na+ causes the rising phase (depolarization), and a subsequent efflux of K+ causes the falling phase (repolarization), enabling high-speed signal transmission.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A(Resting State) --Stimulus--> B(Threshold); B --Na+ Influx--> C(Depolarization); C --Na+ Inactivation & K+ Efflux--> D(Repolarization); D --Slow K+ Channel Closing--> E(Hyperpolarization); E --> A;

content.definition: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a rare, acute, immune-mediated inflammatory and demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system that typically occurs following a viral infection or, less commonly, a vaccination.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Believed to be caused by molecular mimicry, where an immune response against an infectious agent cross-reacts with myelin antigens (e.g., myelin basic protein).
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapid onset of multifocal neurological symptoms, including encephalopathy (altered mental status, confusion, coma), which is a key feature distinguishing it from a typical [[45dd6d19|Multiple Sclerosis]] flare. Other symptoms include fever, headache, seizures, and focal deficits.
  • Timing: Symptoms typically appear 1-2 weeks after an antecedent infection (e.g., measles, varicella) or vaccination.
  • Imaging: MRI shows multiple, bilateral, asymmetric, poorly demarcated white matter lesions of similar age, often involving both the brain and spinal cord.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate ADEM from [[45dd6d19|MS]]: ADEM is monophasic and presents with encephalopathy, whereas MS is typically relapsing-remitting and rarely presents with encephalopathy in its initial flare.
content.takeAway: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis is a post-infectious autoimmune attack on CNS myelin, distinguished from [[45dd6d19|Multiple Sclerosis]] by its monophasic course and the prominent presence of encephalopathy alongside multifocal neurological deficits.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Viral Infection/Vaccination] --> B(Immune Response); B --Molecular Mimicry--> C[Attack on Myelin]; C --> D[Perivenous Inflammation & Demyelination]; D --> E[Multifocal Neurologic Deficits + Encephalopathy];

content.definition: Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common subtype of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, an autoimmune condition characterized by the rapid onset of symmetric, ascending muscle weakness or paralysis and destruction of myelin sheaths of peripheral nerves by Schwann cells.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Often triggered by an antecedent infection (classically Campylobacter jejuni, also CMV, EBV, Zika). It is thought to be due to molecular mimicry between microbial antigens and peripheral nerve myelin or axons.
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapidly progressive, symmetric ascending weakness/paralysis starting in the lower extremities. Patients often have absent or depressed deep tendon reflexes.
  • Key Complications: Respiratory failure due to diaphragmatic weakness is a life-threatening complication. Autonomic dysfunction (tachycardia, arrhythmias, BP instability) is also common.
  • Diagnosis: CSF analysis shows albuminocytologic dissociation (high protein with a normal cell count). Nerve conduction studies show slowed nerve conduction velocity.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of recent diarrheal illness (*C. jejuni*) followed by ascending paralysis and high protein in the CSF with normal cell count is a classic vignette for Guillain-Barré Syndrome.
content.takeAway: AIDP (Guillain-Barré Syndrome) is an acute, post-infectious autoimmune attack on peripheral nerve myelin, leading to a characteristic ascending paralysis; the hallmark diagnostic finding is albuminocytologic dissociation in the CSF, reflecting widespread inflammation of nerve roots without direct infection.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Antecedent Infection e.g., C. jejuni] --> B(Molecular Mimicry); B --> C[Immune Attack on Schwann Cells/Myelin]; C --> D[Peripheral Nerve Demyelination]; D --> E[Ascending Paralysis & Areflexia];

content.definition: Opioid-induced acute pulmonary edema is a form of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that can occur as a life-threatening complication of opioid overdose, characterized by increased pulmonary vascular permeability and subsequent alveolar flooding.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The exact mechanism is multifactorial but is thought to involve direct toxic effects on the pulmonary capillary endothelium, hypoxia-induced vascular injury, and a massive sympathetic surge following transient hypoxia, all leading to increased vascular permeability.
  • Clinical Presentation: Occurs shortly after an opioid overdose. Patients present with severe dyspnea, hypoxia, frothy pink sputum, and diffuse crackles on auscultation, often after being resuscitated with [[naloxone]].
  • Radiology: Chest X-ray shows bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates, consistent with pulmonary edema, but with a normal cardiac silhouette (distinguishing it from cardiogenic pulmonary edema).
  • Treatment: Management is supportive and includes supplemental oxygen, non-invasive or mechanical ventilation, and addressing the underlying opioid overdose. Diuretics are not effective as the cause is permeability, not fluid overload.
  • USMLE Tip: Be aware of the patient who is treated for an opioid overdose with [[naloxone]] and subsequently develops severe respiratory distress; this points towards non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema rather than a cardiac cause.
content.takeAway: Unlike cardiogenic pulmonary edema which is caused by high hydrostatic pressure, opioid-induced pulmonary edema is a permeability problem where opioid toxicity and hypoxia damage the alveolar-capillary barrier, leading to leaky vessels and flooded lungs that do not respond to diuretics.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Opioid Overdose] --> B(Hypoxia & Direct Toxicity); B --> C[Pulmonary Capillary Endothelial Damage]; C --> D[Increased Vascular Permeability]; D --> E[Alveolar Flooding]; E --> F[Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema];

content.definition: The Adenohypophysis, or anterior pituitary, is the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland, an endocrine gland of ectodermal origin (from Rathke's pouch) that synthesizes and secretes six major peptide hormones in response to releasing and inhibiting hormones from the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]].
content.atAGlance:
• Embryology: Arises from an upward evagination of the oral ectoderm called Rathke's pouch. Remnants can form a [[7048db1e|craniopharyngioma]].
  • Hormones Secreted: The anterior pituitary hormones can be remembered with the mnemonic FLAT PiG: FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH (Tropic hormones), and Prolactin, i(ignore), GH (Direct hormones).
  • Cell Types: Somatotrophs (GH), Lactotrophs (Prolactin), Corticotrophs (ACTH), Thyrotrophs (TSH), and Gonadotrophs (FSH/LH).
  • Vascular Supply: Receives blood from the superior hypophyseal artery, which forms a portal system (hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system) that transports hypothalamic releasing/inhibiting hormones directly to the anterior pituitary.
  • USMLE Tip: The most common tumor of the pituitary is a [[5f3188bd|pituitary adenoma]], which is most frequently a prolactinoma. Its connection to the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] is vascular, in contrast to the posterior pituitary's neural connection.
content.takeAway: The Adenohypophysis is the hormonal powerhouse of the pituitary, controlled by the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] via a unique portal venous system, and its diverse cell populations are responsible for regulating growth, stress, reproduction, and metabolism throughout the body.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] --Releasing/Inhibiting Hormones--> B(Hypophyseal Portal System); B --> C(Adenohypophysis); C --> D[FSH, LH]; C --> E[ACTH]; C --> F[TSH]; C --> G[Prolactin]; C --> H[GH];

content.definition: Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus that is a common cause of various infections, including pharyngitis, pneumonia, hemorrhagic cystitis, and notably, viral conjunctivitis (pink eye).
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Non-enveloped, icosahedral capsid with a linear dsDNA genome.
  • Transmission: Transmitted via respiratory droplets, fecal-oral route, and direct contact with contaminated surfaces (fomites). Highly stable in the environment.
  • Ocular Manifestation: The most common cause of viral [[c4d08c09|conjunctivitis]], presenting with a watery discharge, red eye, and often a swollen preauricular lymph node.
  • Other Clinical Syndromes: Causes febrile pharyngitis, acute hemorrhagic cystitis, and pneumonia (especially in military recruits).
  • USMLE Tip: In a question describing a patient (often a child) with red, watery eyes and a recent history of a cold or attending daycare, Adenovirus is the most likely pathogen. The watery discharge is key to differentiating it from bacterial conjunctivitis.
content.takeAway: Adenovirus is a highly resilient DNA virus responsible for the majority of viral conjunctivitis cases, characterized by a watery discharge that distinguishes it from the purulent discharge of bacterial causes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Adenovirus] --> B{Transmission}; B --> B1[Respiratory Droplets]; B --> B2[Fecal-Oral]; B --> B3[Fomites]; A --> C{Clinical Syndromes}; C --> C1[Conjunctivitis]; C --> C2[Pharyngitis]; C --> C3[Pneumonia]; C --> C4[Hemorrhagic Cystitis];

content.definition: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, leading to impaired β-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in peroxisomes. This results in the accumulation of VLCFAs in the adrenal glands, testes, and white matter of the brain, causing adrenal insufficiency and progressive demyelination.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: X-linked recessive mutation in the ABCD1 gene.
  • Pathophysiology: Defective peroxisomal β-oxidation leads to the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in various tissues.
  • Neurologic Manifestations: Progressive demyelination of the central nervous system, leading to cognitive decline, behavioral changes, spasticity, and vision/hearing loss.
  • Endocrine Manifestations: Adrenal insufficiency ([[addison_disease|Addison disease]]) is a common feature, presenting with fatigue, hyperpigmentation, and electrolyte abnormalities. Testicular atrophy and infertility can also occur.
  • USMLE Tip: A classic vignette involves a young boy with new-onset behavioral problems or declining school performance who also shows signs of adrenal insufficiency (e.g., hyperpigmentation, low cortisol).
content.takeAway: Adrenoleukodystrophy is a dual-system disease combining progressive CNS demyelination with adrenal failure, all stemming from a single X-linked genetic defect in peroxisomal fatty acid metabolism.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[ABCD1 Gene Mutation] --> B(Defective Peroxisomal β-oxidation); B --> C[Accumulation of VLCFAs]; C --> D[Adrenal Cortex] --> E(Adrenal Insufficiency); C --> F[CNS White Matter] --> G(Demyelination & Neurodegeneration);

content.definition: Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease of the macula, the central part of the retina, leading to the gradual loss of central vision. It is the leading cause of irreversible blindness in older adults in developed countries.
content.atAGlance:
• Dry (Atrophic) AMD: More common (~80%). Characterized by the slow breakdown of photoreceptors in the macula and the deposition of yellowish extracellular material called drusen between Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium. Causes gradual vision loss.
  • Wet (Exudative) AMD: Less common but more severe. Characterized by rapid vision loss due to choroidal neovascularization. Abnormal blood vessels grow under the retina, leak fluid and blood, and can cause scarring.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients report painless, progressive loss of central vision, leading to scotomas (blind spots). A key early symptom of wet AMD is metamorphopsia (straight lines appear wavy).
  • Diagnosis: Fundoscopy reveals drusen (dry AMD) or hemorrhage/exudates (wet AMD). An Amsler grid is used to detect metamorphopsia.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the key difference: Dry AMD = Drusen and gradual loss. Wet AMD = Neovascularization and rapid loss. Central vision loss is the hallmark for both.
content.takeAway: Age-related Macular Degeneration specifically targets central, high-acuity vision by damaging the macula. The distinction between the slow, drusen-associated 'dry' form and the rapid, neovascular 'wet' form is critical for prognosis and management.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Aging & Genetic Factors] --> B{Macular Damage}; B --> C[Dry AMD]; C --> D[Drusen Deposition & Atrophy]; D --> E[Gradual Central Vision Loss]; B --> F[Wet AMD]; F --> G[Choroidal Neovascularization]; G --> H[Hemorrhage & Exudate]; H --> I[Rapid Central Vision Loss];

content.definition: Agraphia is an acquired neurological disorder characterized by the loss of the ability to communicate through writing, stemming from damage to specific brain areas involved in language processing and motor control of the hand.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Agraphia is a key localizing sign for a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus of the parietal lobe.
  • Associated Syndrome: It is one of the four classic components of [[38f3ed1f|Gerstmann syndrome]].
  • Gerstmann Syndrome Tetrad: The full syndrome includes Agraphia, [[8558c64b|Acalculia]] (inability to perform calculations), Finger Agnosia (inability to distinguish fingers), and Left-Right Disorientation.
  • Alexia with Agraphia: When a patient can neither read nor write, the lesion is typically in the dominant angular gyrus. This is distinct from [[fcf30c1b|alexia without agraphia]].
  • USMLE Tip: If a question describes a patient who suddenly cannot write but has no other motor deficits in the hand, and also has trouble with math, think of a dominant parietal lobe lesion, likely from an [[143bb23d|MCA stroke]].
content.takeAway: Agraphia is not simply poor handwriting; it is a specific neurological deficit in the production of written language that, when paired with [[8558c64b|acalculia]], strongly points to a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus, a hallmark of [[38f3ed1f|Gerstmann syndrome]].

content.definition: Akathisia is a movement disorder characterized by a subjective feeling of inner restlessness and a compelling urge to be in constant motion, most commonly seen as an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by dopamine receptor antagonists, particularly first-generation (typical) antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol). It can also occur with second-generation antipsychotics and some antidepressants.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients describe an inability to sit still, feeling like they need to 'jump out of their skin.' Objective signs include pacing, shuffling feet, and shifting from one foot to another.
  • Timeline: It is a subacute extrapyramidal symptom, typically developing days to weeks after starting or increasing the dose of an offending agent.
  • Treatment: Management involves reducing the dose of the antipsychotic, switching to an agent with a lower risk (e.g., quetiapine), or adding medications like propranolol, benzodiazepines, or benztropine.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate akathisia from psychotic agitation. Akathisia is a drug side effect causing restlessness, while agitation is a symptom of the underlying psychosis. Mistaking one for the other and increasing the antipsychotic dose will worsen akathisia.
content.takeAway: Akathisia is a distressing, drug-induced state of motor restlessness that must be distinguished from psychiatric agitation, as the treatment involves reducing or counteracting the offending antipsychotic, not increasing it.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dopamine (D2) Receptor Blockade] --> B(Disruption of Nigrostriatal Pathway); B --> C[Subjective Restlessness & Compulsion to Move]; C --> D(Akathisia);

content.definition: The Alar Plate is the dorsal part of the neural tube in the developing embryo, which differentiates into sensory neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem under the influence of signaling molecules like bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Dorsal (posterior) region of the developing spinal cord and brainstem.
  • Function: Gives rise to sensory components of the central nervous system. Mnemonic: Alar is dorsal, like the dorsal fin of a shark which senses things in the water.
  • Inducing Signal: Development is induced by signaling molecules from the overlying ectoderm, primarily Bone Morphogenetic Proteins (BMPs).
  • Counterpart: The ventral counterpart is the [[253e3efb|Basal Plate]], which develops into motor neurons under the influence of Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) from the notochord.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the simple orientation: Alar = Sensory = Dorsal, and Basal = Motor = Ventral. This organization persists in the adult spinal cord.
content.takeAway: The Alar Plate is the embryonic foundation for the sensory pathways of the CNS, establishing the fundamental dorsal-sensory and ventral-motor organization of the neural tube that is maintained throughout life.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Neural Tube] --> B(Alar Plate - Dorsal); A --> C(Basal Plate - Ventral); D[Ectoderm] --BMPs--> B; B --> E[Sensory Neurons]; F[Notochord] --SHH--> C; C --> G[Motor Neurons];

content.definition: Albuminocytologic dissociation is the pathognomonic finding in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of patients with [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome]], characterized by a significantly elevated protein concentration in the presence of a normal or near-normal white blood cell count.
content.atAGlance:
• Classic Association: This finding is the hallmark of [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)]], specifically the AIDP subtype.
  • Pathophysiology: Widespread inflammation of the nerve roots (radiculopathy) disrupts the blood-nerve barrier, allowing protein (mainly albumin) to leak from the plasma into the CSF.
  • Cell Count: The cell count remains normal (typically <10 cells/mm3) because the inflammatory process is primarily in the peripheral nerve roots, not within the CSF space itself (i.e., it is not meningitis).
  • Timing: The protein level may be normal in the first few days of GBS and typically peaks 1-2 weeks after symptom onset.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient presenting with ascending paralysis after a recent infection (*C. jejuni* or viral URI) and a CSF report showing high protein but a normal cell count is a classic vignette for [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome]].
content.takeAway: Albuminocytologic dissociation is a powerful diagnostic clue for [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome]], reflecting the unique pathophysiology of nerve root inflammation that increases blood-nerve barrier permeability to proteins without causing a significant cellular infiltrate into the CSF.

content.definition: Alexia is an acquired neurological disorder characterized by the inability to read or comprehend written language, resulting from a lesion in the brain's language or visual processing centers.
content.atAGlance:
• Alexia without Agraphia (Pure Alexia): A specific syndrome where the patient can write but cannot read what they have just written. This is a classic disconnection syndrome.
  • Lesion Location: Caused by a lesion in the dominant (usually left) occipital lobe that also damages the splenium of the corpus callosum.
  • Mechanism: Visual information from the intact right occipital lobe cannot cross over to the dominant hemisphere's language areas (Wernicke's area, angular gyrus) for interpretation because the connecting fibers in the splenium are damaged. The dominant visual cortex is also damaged, so no visual information can be processed on that side.
  • Vascular Territory: This specific lesion is classically caused by a stroke in the territory of the [[b6a2cc31|Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)]].
  • USMLE Tip: The vignette of a patient who can write a sentence but is unable to read it back is pathognomonic for alexia without agraphia, pointing directly to a left PCA stroke affecting the occipital lobe and splenium.
content.takeAway: Alexia without agraphia is a quintessential disconnection syndrome where visual information is stranded in the non-dominant hemisphere, unable to reach the language centers in the dominant hemisphere because the connecting bridge (splenium of the corpus callosum) has been destroyed, typically by a PCA stroke.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Written Word] --> B(Eyes); B --> C[Right Visual Cortex]; C --x D(Splenium of Corpus Callosum); D --x E[Left Language Areas]; B --> F(Left Visual Cortex); F --x G[Lesion];

content.definition: Alprazolam (trade name Xanax) is a potent, short-acting benzodiazepine used primarily for the management of anxiety disorders, especially panic disorder, and for the short-term treatment of anxiety associated with depression.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A positive allosteric modulator of the [[gaba_a_receptor|GABAA receptor]]. It increases the frequency of chloride channel opening in response to GABA binding, leading to enhanced CNS inhibition.
  • Pharmacokinetics: It is short-acting. Mnemonic for short-acting benzodiazepines: ATOM (Alprazolam, Triazolam, Oxazepam, Midazolam).
  • Clinical Use: Primarily for [[panic_disorder|panic disorder]] and [[generalized_anxiety_disorder|generalized anxiety disorder]].
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal symptoms. Additive CNS depression with other depressants like alcohol and barbiturates. Has a higher addictive potential due to its short half-life.
  • USMLE Tip: Because of its rapid onset and short duration, alprazolam is highly effective for acute panic attacks but also carries a high risk of dependence and severe withdrawal. Overdose is treated with [[flumazenil]].
content.takeAway: Alprazolam is a high-potency, short-acting benzodiazepine that provides rapid relief for panic and anxiety by enhancing GABAergic inhibition, but its pharmacokinetic profile also contributes to a significant risk of dependence and withdrawal.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Alprazolam] --> B(Binds to GABA-A Receptor); B --> C(↑ Frequency of Cl- Channel Opening); C --> D(↑ Cl- Influx); D --> E(Hyperpolarization of Neuron); E --> F(CNS Depression/Anxiolysis);

content.definition: Alzheimer Disease is the most common cause of dementia in older adults, a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the extracellular deposition of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and the intracellular accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau tangles, leading to widespread cortical atrophy and a significant cholinergic deficit.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathology Hallmarks: Extracellular senile plaques (composed of Aβ) and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein). The number of tangles correlates with disease severity.
  • Genetics: Risk is increased by the ApoE4 allele for the sporadic, late-onset form. Early-onset familial forms are associated with mutations in APP (chromosome 21), presenilin-1 (chromosome 14), and presenilin-2 (chromosome 1).
  • Clinical Presentation: Insidious onset of progressive short-term memory loss, followed by language deficits (aphasia), visuospatial difficulties, and executive dysfunction. Personality and behavioral changes are common in later stages.
  • Neurotransmitter Deficit: Marked decrease in [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] due to degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the [[361438f2|Basal nucleus of Meynert]].
  • USMLE Tip: Patients with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) have a greatly increased risk of early-onset Alzheimer's because the APP gene is located on chromosome 21, leading to a gene dosage effect and increased Aβ production.
content.takeAway: The core pathology of Alzheimer Disease involves a dual-proteinopathy of extracellular amyloid plaques and intracellular tau tangles, which together trigger synaptic dysfunction and neuronal death, manifesting clinically as a progressive decline in memory and cognition due to widespread cortical and hippocampal atrophy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[APP Gene on Chr 21] --Abnormal Cleavage--> B(Amyloid-β Monomers); B --> C(Oligomers & Plaques); D[Tau Protein] --Hyperphosphorylation--> E(Neurofibrillary Tangles); C & E --> F(Synaptic Dysfunction & Neuronal Death); F --> G(Cortical Atrophy); G --> H(Dementia);

content.definition: Amantadine is a medication with multiple mechanisms of action, used primarily in neurology to treat [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms, and historically as an antiviral agent for influenza A.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism (Parkinson's): Increases dopamine availability by enhancing dopamine release and inhibiting dopamine reuptake in the CNS. It also has some anticholinergic properties.
  • Clinical Use (Neurology): Used for mild [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] to improve tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. It is particularly useful for reducing levodopa-induced dyskinesias in advanced disease. Also used to treat acute dystonia caused by antipsychotics.
  • Antiviral Use: Previously used for prophylaxis and treatment of Influenza A by blocking the M2 proton channel, but is no longer recommended due to widespread resistance.
  • Adverse Effects: CNS effects like confusion, hallucinations, and dizziness. A characteristic side effect is livedo reticularis (a mottled, purplish skin discoloration) and peripheral edema.
  • USMLE Tip: For Parkinson's, amantadine is a 'weaker' drug but can be useful early on or for managing side effects of more potent therapies. The association with livedo reticularis is a classic board question clue.
content.takeAway: Amantadine serves a niche role in managing [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] by modestly increasing dopamine levels, but its utility is limited by CNS side effects and the unique dermatologic finding of livedo reticularis.

content.definition: Amaurosis fugax (from Greek for 'darkening' and Latin for 'fleeting') is a painless, transient monocular vision loss, classically described by patients as a "curtain coming down over one eye." It is a form of [[623ba776|transient ischemic attack (TIA)]] affecting the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by an embolus to the [[3334840f|central or branch retinal artery]], which temporarily obstructs blood flow.
  • Source of Emboli: The most frequent source is an atherosclerotic plaque in the ipsilateral carotid artery. It can also be cardiogenic (e.g., from atrial fibrillation).
  • Clinical Significance: It is a critical warning sign of underlying cerebrovascular disease and portends a high risk of a major [[c5da3c57|stroke]].
  • Workup: Patients require urgent evaluation, including a carotid ultrasound (duplex) to assess for stenosis and an EKG/echocardiogram to rule out cardiac sources.
  • USMLE Tip: A vignette describing a patient with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who experiences a sudden, painless, temporary "curtain-like" vision loss in one eye should immediately point to amaurosis fugax secondary to carotid artery disease.
content.takeAway: Amaurosis fugax is not just an eye problem but a neurological emergency; this transient 'curtain' of vision loss is a TIA of the retina, most often signaling significant atherosclerotic disease in the ipsilateral carotid artery and a high impending risk of stroke.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Carotid Artery Plaque] --> B(Embolus); B --> C[Ophthalmic Artery]; C --> D[Retinal Artery Occlusion]; D --> E[Transient Monocular Vision Loss]; E --> F(Amaurosis Fugax);

content.definition: Amblyopia, commonly known as "lazy eye," is a neurodevelopmental disorder of vision characterized by decreased visual acuity in one or both eyes that is not correctable by refractive means and is not due to any structural eye pathology. It results from abnormal visual experience during early childhood.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: During a critical period of visual development (birth to ~7 years), the brain suppresses or ignores the input from one eye, leading to maldevelopment of the visual cortex corresponding to that eye.
  • Common Causes:
    1. [[cdcda821|Strabismus]] (Misalignment): The brain ignores the image from the deviating eye to avoid diplopia.
    2. Anisometropia (Unequal Refractive Error): The brain favors the eye with better focus.
    3. Deprivation: An obstruction like a congenital [[85f03b02|cataract]] or ptosis blocks a clear image from forming.
  • Diagnosis: Detected during pediatric vision screening. The key finding is a difference in visual acuity between the two eyes.
  • Treatment: Must be initiated early in the critical period. Treatment involves correcting the underlying cause (e.g., glasses for refractive error, surgery for strabismus/cataract) and then forcing the brain to use the amblyopic eye, typically by patching the good eye or using atropine drops to blur its vision.
  • USMLE Tip: Early detection and treatment are crucial. If not treated before the end of the critical period (~age 7-8), amblyopia can result in irreversible vision loss.
content.takeAway: Amblyopia is a 'brain' problem, not an 'eye' problem; it is the failure of the visual cortex to develop properly due to abnormal input from an eye during a critical developmental window, leading to vision loss that can only be reversed by forcing the brain to pay attention to the 'lazy' eye before that window closes.

content.definition: Amino acids are organic compounds that serve as the building blocks of proteins and as precursors for many neurotransmitters. In the central nervous system, their passage from the blood into the brain is tightly regulated by the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
content.atAGlance:
• Blood-Brain Barrier Transport: Amino acids are generally lipid-insoluble and cannot diffuse freely across the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]]. They require carrier-mediated transport proteins to enter the CNS.
  • Transport Systems: There are specific transporters for different classes of amino acids (e.g., large neutral, basic, acidic). These transporters can become saturated and exhibit competition.
  • Neurotransmitter Precursors: Many crucial neurotransmitters are synthesized from amino acids that must be transported into the brain. Examples include Tyrosine (precursor to [[90adc821|dopamine]], norepinephrine) and Tryptophan (precursor to [[5d3c2089|serotonin]]).
  • Clinical Relevance: In disorders like [[phenylketonuria|Phenylketonuria (PKU)]], high levels of one amino acid (phenylalanine) can saturate the large neutral amino acid transporter, impairing the transport of other essential amino acids (like tyrosine and tryptophan) into the brain, contributing to neurological dysfunction.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that both glucose and amino acids require specific carrier-mediated transport to cross the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]]; they do not diffuse freely.
content.takeAway: The brain's supply of essential amino acids, critical for both protein synthesis and neurotransmitter production, is entirely dependent on specialized carrier proteins at the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]], a system that can be competitively inhibited in certain metabolic diseases.

content.definition: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that works by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Due to its significant side effect profile, its primary use has shifted from depression to treating neuropathic pain and providing prophylaxis for [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. Also has potent antagonistic effects at muscarinic, α1-adrenergic, and H1-histamine receptors, which account for its side effects.
  • Clinical Use (Neurology): Used for prophylaxis of [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]] and for the management of chronic neuropathic pain (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, postherpetic neuralgia).
  • Adverse Effects: Strong anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, confusion), orthostatic hypotension (α1 blockade), sedation (H1 blockade), and weight gain.
  • Cardiotoxicity: Overdose is life-threatening, causing QRS widening and ventricular arrhythmias due to Na+ channel blockade. Treat with sodium bicarbonate.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the 'Tri-C's' for TCA toxicity: Convulsions, Coma, Cardiotoxicity. Amitriptyline is a tertiary amine TCA, giving it more potent anticholinergic and antihistaminic effects compared to secondary amines like nortriptyline.
content.takeAway: Amitriptyline, a classic TCA, is now more valued for its role in migraine prevention and neuropathic pain than for depression, but its use is always tempered by a significant burden of anticholinergic, antihistaminic, and anti-adrenergic side effects, with cardiotoxicity being the most dangerous in overdose.

content.definition: Amnesia is a deficit in memory caused by brain damage, disease, or psychological trauma. It can be categorized based on the temporal nature of the memory loss relative to the causative event.
content.atAGlance:
• Anterograde Amnesia: The inability to form new memories after the event that caused the amnesia. Long-term memories from before the event remain intact.
  • Anterograde Lesion Site: Classically caused by bilateral damage to the hippocampus, a key structure in the medial temporal lobe for memory consolidation. Seen in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and [[herpes_simplex_encephalitis|herpes simplex encephalitis]].
  • Retrograde Amnesia: The loss of memories that were formed before the onset of amnesia.
  • Korsakoff Syndrome: A classic example of a syndrome causing both anterograde and retrograde amnesia, along with confabulation. It is caused by thiamine (B1) deficiency, often in the context of chronic alcohol use, and involves damage to the mammillary bodies and thalamus.
  • USMLE Tip: Bilateral hippocampal lesions (e.g., from an anoxic brain injury or HSV encephalitis) are the classic cause of profound anterograde amnesia. The patient can remember their childhood but not what they had for breakfast.
content.takeAway: The hippocampus is the brain's 'save button' for new memories; therefore, bilateral damage to this structure results in profound anterograde amnesia, leaving the individual unable to consolidate new experiences into long-term memory.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brain Injury/Disease] --> B{Amnesia}; B --> C[Anterograde Amnesia]; C --> D(Inability to form new memories); D --> E[Lesion: Hippocampus]; B --> F[Retrograde Amnesia]; F --> G(Loss of past memories); G --> H[Lesion: Widespread Cortex];

content.definition: The Amygdala is an almond-shaped set of neurons located deep within the medial temporal lobe of the brain. It is a key component of the [[73ace357|limbic system]] and plays a central role in processing emotions, particularly fear, anxiety, and aggression, as well as in memory formation and decision-making.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: The amygdala is the brain's emotional center, responsible for processing fear, pleasure, and anger. It links emotions to memories and influences social and sexual behavior.
  • Location: Situated in the medial temporal lobe, anterior to the [[a0590674|hippocampus]].
  • Lesion Effects (Bilateral): Bilateral destruction of the amygdala results in Klüver-Bucy syndrome.
  • Klüver-Bucy Syndrome: Characterized by disinhibited behavior, including hyperorality (tendency to examine objects with the mouth), hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and visual agnosia. Patients also exhibit placidity (loss of fear response).
  • USMLE Tip: The classic cause of bilateral amygdala damage leading to Klüver-Bucy syndrome is [[herpes_simplex_encephalitis|Herpes Simplex Virus-1 (HSV-1) encephalitis]], which has a predilection for the temporal lobes.
content.takeAway: The Amygdala acts as the brain's alarm system and emotional processor; its bilateral destruction unleashes primitive behaviors by removing the normal emotional filters, resulting in the dramatic and disinhibited presentation of Klüver-Bucy syndrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Sensory Input] --> B(Amygdala); B --Fear/Emotion Processing--> C[Hypothalamus & Brainstem]; C --> D(Autonomic & Behavioral Response);

content.definition: Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA) is a condition in which amyloid-β protein deposits in the walls of small to medium-sized arteries of the cerebral cortex and leptomeninges, weakening the vessels and increasing the risk of spontaneous, recurrent lobar intraparenchymal hemorrhages.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Deposition of amyloid-β (the same protein found in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer's]] plaques) in the tunica media and adventitia of cortical and leptomeningeal vessels.
  • Clinical Presentation: Most commonly presents with recurrent, spontaneous lobar hemorrhages in older adults (>65 years). These hemorrhages are typically located in the superficial cortex (lobar) rather than deep structures like the basal ganglia.
  • Location: Hemorrhages are characteristically lobar (frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal lobes), contrasting with hypertensive hemorrhages which are typically deep (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons).
  • Association: Strongly associated with [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], although it can occur independently.
  • USMLE Tip: An elderly patient with no history of significant hypertension who presents with a spontaneous, superficial (lobar) intracerebral hemorrhage should raise high suspicion for Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy. Recurrent hemorrhages in different lobes are a key feature.
content.takeAway: Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy is a major cause of lobar intracerebral hemorrhage in the elderly, resulting from amyloid-β deposition that makes cortical blood vessels brittle and prone to rupture, distinct from the deep brain hemorrhages typically caused by hypertension.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Amyloid-β Deposition] --> B(Vessel Wall Weakening); B --> C[Cortical & Leptomeningeal Arteries]; C --> D(Rupture); D --> E[Recurrent Lobar Hemorrhage];

content.definition: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a relentless and fatal neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the progressive loss of both upper motor neurons (in the motor cortex) and lower motor neurons (in the brainstem and spinal cord).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Degeneration of corticospinal tracts (lateral sclerosis) and anterior horn cells (amyotrophy). The exact cause is unknown in most cases (sporadic), but some familial cases are linked to a mutation in the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene.
  • Clinical Presentation: A hallmark of ALS is the combination of both upper motor neuron (UMN) signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs (fasciculations, atrophy, flaccid weakness).
  • Symptoms: Can present with asymmetric limb weakness (e.g., foot drop, hand weakness), dysarthria (difficulty speaking), and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Sensation, cognition, and eye movements are typically spared.
  • Bulbar Involvement: When LMNs in the brainstem are affected, it leads to [[901f3180|bulbar palsy]], causing dysarthria, dysphagia, and tongue fasciculations.
  • Treatment: [[riluzole|Riluzole]], a glutamate antagonist, may modestly increase survival. Management is largely supportive, focusing on respiratory support and nutrition.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of UMN and LMN signs in the same patient is the key to diagnosing ALS. Look for a patient with weakness and atrophy in one arm (LMN) but hyperreflexia in the legs (UMN).
content.takeAway: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is uniquely devastating because it attacks the entire voluntary motor system, from the brain to the muscle, combining the spasticity of UMN lesions with the muscle wasting of LMN lesions, while cruelly sparing the patient's intellect and senses.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[UMN Degeneration - Motor Cortex] --> B(Spasticity, Hyperreflexia); C[LMN Degeneration - Anterior Horn] --> D(Fasciculations, Atrophy); A & C --> E(Progressive Motor Weakness);

content.definition: The Anal Wink Reflex is a superficial reflex involving the contraction of the external anal sphincter upon stroking the skin around the anus. It is used to test the integrity of the S3 and S4 spinal nerve roots and the pudendal nerve.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: Tests the integrity of the S3-S4 spinal cord segments. Mnemonic: S2, 3, 4 keep the penis off the floor (for erection), and S3, 4 are for the anal wink.
  • Pathway: Stroking the perianal skin stimulates afferent fibers of the pudendal nerve. The signal travels to the S3-S4 spinal segments, synapses, and an efferent signal returns via the pudendal nerve to cause contraction of the external anal sphincter.
  • Clinical Significance: An absent anal wink reflex is a key sign in [[2904b5c8|Cauda Equina Syndrome]], a neurosurgical emergency. It indicates damage to the S3-S4 nerve roots.
  • Other Conditions: The reflex may also be absent in other conditions affecting the sacral nerve roots or spinal cord, such as spinal cord injury or spina bifida.
  • USMLE Tip: In a patient with severe low back pain, saddle anesthesia, and bowel/bladder dysfunction, checking for the anal wink reflex is a critical step. Its absence strongly supports the diagnosis of [[2904b5c8|Cauda Equina Syndrome]].
content.takeAway: The Anal Wink Reflex is a simple but vital physical exam maneuver for assessing the function of the lower sacral nerve roots (S3-S4); its absence is a red flag for [[2904b5c8|Cauda Equina Syndrome]].
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Stroke Perianal Skin] --> B(Afferent Signal via Pudendal N.); B --> C[S3-S4 Spinal Cord]; C --> D(Efferent Signal via Pudendal N.); D --> E(External Anal Sphincter Contraction);

content.definition: Anencephaly is a severe and lethal congenital malformation, classified as an open neural tube defect, resulting from the failure of the rostral (anterior) neuropore to close during the 4th week of embryonic development. This leads to the absence of the forebrain and a large portion of the skull (calvarium).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Failure of the rostral neuropore to close leads to an open calvarium and absence of the forebrain. The remaining brain tissue is exposed and degenerates.
  • Clinical Presentation: Incompatible with postnatal life; infants are stillborn or die shortly after birth. The fetus has a characteristic "frog-like appearance" due to the absent cranial vault.
  • Maternal Findings: Associated with polyhydramnios due to impaired fetal swallowing, as the neural control for swallowing is absent.
  • Diagnosis: Can be detected prenatally via ultrasound. Maternal serum screening will show markedly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). Amniotic fluid will also have elevated AFP and acetylcholinesterase (AChE).
  • Prevention: Risk is significantly reduced by maternal folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy.
content.takeAway: Anencephaly represents a catastrophic failure of early neural development, where the absence of the forebrain and skull results in a condition incompatible with life, and is prenatally indicated by elevated maternal AFP and polyhydramnios.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Failure of Rostral Neuropore Closure] --> B(Absence of Forebrain & Calvarium); B --> C(Polyhydramnios); B --> D(Lethal Outcome);

content.definition: Anesthetics are drugs that induce a reversible loss of sensation. They are broadly classified into general anesthetics, which cause a reversible loss of consciousness, and local anesthetics, which block nerve transmission in a specific region of the body.
content.atAGlance:
• General Anesthetics: Induce a state of unconsciousness, analgesia, amnesia, and muscle relaxation. They can be inhaled (e.g., sevoflurane, desflurane) or intravenous (e.g., propofol, ketamine, etomidate). Their potency is measured by the Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC).
  • Local Anesthetics: Block nerve conduction by inhibiting voltage-gated Na+ channels. They are classified as esters (e.g., procaine, cocaine) or amides (e.g., lidocaine, bupivacaine). They are weak bases and are less effective in infected (acidic) tissue.
  • Neuromuscular Blockers: Often used with general anesthetics to achieve profound muscle relaxation (paralysis). They can be depolarizing (e.g., succinylcholine) or non-depolarizing (e.g., rocuronium).
  • Malignant Hyperthermia: A rare, life-threatening hypermetabolic state triggered by inhaled anesthetics (except N2O) and succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals. Treated with [[dantrolene]].
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the key pharmacokinetic properties of inhaled anesthetics: low blood solubility (low blood:gas partition coefficient) leads to rapid induction and recovery, while high lipid solubility (high oil:gas partition coefficient) corresponds to high potency (low MAC).
content.takeAway: The field of anesthesia relies on a combination of drugs to achieve a balanced state of unconsciousness, analgesia, and muscle relaxation, with general anesthetics acting on the CNS to induce sleep and local anesthetics acting on peripheral nerves to block pain signals.

content.definition: Cerebral aneurysms are localized, abnormal dilations of blood vessels in the brain, which carry a significant risk of rupture, leading to life-threatening intracranial hemorrhage.
content.atAGlance:
• Saccular (Berry) Aneurysms: Most common type. Thin-walled outpouchings, typically occurring at arterial branch points in the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]]. Most common site is the junction of the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery]] and anterior cerebral artery. Rupture causes [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
  • Associations with Saccular Aneurysms: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD), Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, hypertension, smoking.
  • Charcot-Bouchard Microaneurysms: Aneurysms of small, penetrating arteries (e.g., lenticulostriate arteries) associated with chronic hypertension. Rupture causes [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhage]], typically in deep brain structures like the basal ganglia or thalamus.
  • Rupture Presentation: Rupture of a saccular aneurysm classically presents as a sudden, severe "worst headache of my life" (thunderclap headache), indicating a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with ADPKD who develops a sudden, severe headache should be immediately evaluated for a ruptured berry aneurysm. A PCom aneurysm can compress CN III, causing a 'down and out' eye with a 'blown' (dilated) pupil.
content.takeAway: Cerebral aneurysms are focal weaknesses in brain arteries; the larger saccular (berry) aneurysms at the Circle of Willis rupture into the subarachnoid space, while the smaller Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms in deep brain structures rupture due to hypertension, causing intraparenchymal bleeds.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cerebral Aneurysm] --> B{Types}; B --> C[Saccular/Berry]; C --> D(Circle of Willis); D --> E[Rupture -> Subarachnoid Hemorrhage]; B --> F[Charcot-Bouchard]; F --> G(Small Penetrating Arteries); G --> H[Rupture -> Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage];

content.definition: Angle-closure glaucoma is an ophthalmologic emergency characterized by a sudden, severe increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the physical obstruction of aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Occurs in individuals with a pre-existing narrow anterior chamber angle. Pupillary dilation (mydriasis) causes the peripheral iris to bunch up and block the trabecular meshwork, acutely halting aqueous humor drainage.
  • Triggers: Any event causing mydriasis can trigger an attack, such as entering a dark room, stress, or administration of sympathomimetic or anticholinergic drugs.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden onset of severe, unilateral eye pain, headache, nausea/vomiting, and blurred vision with halos around lights.
  • Physical Exam: The eye is red and hard to palpation ('rock hard'). The pupil is typically mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. The cornea may appear hazy or steamy.
  • USMLE Tip: This is a true ophthalmic emergency. The classic presentation of a painful, red eye with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil and halos around lights is pathognomonic.
content.takeAway: Angle-closure glaucoma is a mechanical plumbing problem of the eye where pupillary dilation in a predisposed individual causes the iris to act like a drain plug, leading to a rapid and painful spike in intraocular pressure that threatens vision.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Predisposing Narrow Angle] --Pupillary Dilation--> B(Iris bunches at periphery); B --> C(Blocks Trabecular Meshwork); C --> D(↓ Aqueous Outflow); D --> E(↑↑ Intraocular Pressure); E --> F(Acute Pain, Vision Loss, Red Eye);

content.definition: Anhidrosis, the inability to sweat normally, is one of the three classic signs of [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]], resulting from the disruption of sympathetic innervation to the sweat glands of the face.
content.atAGlance:
• Horner Syndrome Triad: The full triad is Ptosis (mild eyelid droop), Miosis (constricted pupil), and Anhidrosis (decreased sweating).
  • Mechanism: Disruption of the oculosympathetic pathway prevents the release of acetylcholine from postganglionic sympathetic neurons that innervate sweat glands (a sympathetic exception).
  • Localization Value: The distribution of anhidrosis can help localize the lesion in the three-neuron sympathetic chain.
  • Lesion Localization:
    - 1st Order (Central): Lesion in hypothalamus or brainstem/spinal cord. Anhidrosis affects the entire ipsilateral half of the body.
    - 2nd Order (Preganglionic): Lesion in the chest (e.g., Pancoast tumor). Anhidrosis affects the ipsilateral face and neck.
    - 3rd Order (Postganglionic): Lesion above the superior cervical ganglion (e.g., carotid dissection). Anhidrosis is often minimal or absent, affecting only a small patch on the forehead, because fibers to most facial sweat glands travel with the external carotid artery.
  • USMLE Tip: A painful Horner syndrome (especially with neck pain) should raise suspicion for a carotid artery dissection, a 3rd order neuron lesion where anhidrosis is often absent.
content.takeAway: While part of the classic triad, the presence and distribution of anhidrosis in [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]] is a subtle but powerful clue for localizing the lesion along the long oculosympathetic pathway, with widespread anhidrosis suggesting a central lesion and absent anhidrosis pointing towards a postganglionic (3rd order) problem.

content.definition: The Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) is a major artery of the brain that branches from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, as well as the corpus callosum.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Arises from the bifurcation of the internal carotid artery. The left and right ACAs are connected by the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery]].
  • Territory Supplied: Supplies the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres. Based on the motor and sensory homunculus, this corresponds to the lower extremities.
  • Stroke Syndrome: Occlusion of the ACA results in a characteristic stroke syndrome with contralateral motor and sensory deficits predominantly affecting the lower limb (leg > arm/face).
  • Other Stroke Signs: May also cause urinary incontinence due to damage to the paracentral lobule. Frontal lobe signs like abulia (lack of will/initiative) or personality changes can occur.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to identifying an ACA stroke is the disproportionate weakness and sensory loss in the contralateral leg compared to the arm and face. This contrasts sharply with an [[143bb23d|MCA stroke]].
content.takeAway: The Anterior Cerebral Artery is responsible for the medial brain territory, meaning its occlusion uniquely manifests as a stroke that 'kicks the leg out' from under the patient, with motor and sensory deficits primarily affecting the contralateral lower extremity.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Internal Carotid Artery] --> B(Anterior Cerebral Artery); B --> C(Supplies Medial Cortex); C --> D(Motor/Sensory Homunculus for Leg); B --Connects via AComA--> E(Contralateral ACA);

content.definition: Anterior circulation strokes are ischemic events caused by occlusion of the internal carotid artery or its major branches, the [[830c856c|anterior cerebral artery (ACA)]] and the [[143bb23d|middle cerebral artery (MCA)]], leading to deficits related to the cerebral hemispheres.
content.atAGlance:
• Vessels Involved: Internal carotid artery (ICA), [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]], [[830c856c|Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)]].
  • MCA Stroke: The most common type of ischemic stroke. Presents with contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss affecting the face and upper limb more than the lower limb. If the dominant (usually left) hemisphere is affected, it causes [[6bc9a567|aphasia]] (Broca's or Wernicke's). If the non-dominant hemisphere is affected, it causes hemineglect.
  • ACA Stroke: Presents with contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss affecting the lower limb more than the upper limb. May also cause urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs (e.g., personality changes, abulia).
  • Distinction: The key differentiator is the distribution of weakness based on the homunculus: MCA strokes affect the face/arm, while ACA strokes affect the leg.
  • USMLE Tip: Aphasia is a 'cortical sign' that strongly points to an MCA stroke in the dominant hemisphere. Leg weakness greater than arm weakness is the classic sign of an ACA stroke.
content.takeAway: Anterior circulation strokes produce deficits that can be precisely localized by understanding the functional anatomy of the cerebral cortex and the homunculus; MCA strokes paralyze the contralateral face and arm, while ACA strokes paralyze the contralateral leg.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Internal Carotid Artery] --> B(MCA); B --> C(Contralateral Face/Arm Deficits, Aphasia/Neglect); A --> D(ACA); D --> E(Contralateral Leg Deficits, Incontinence);

content.definition: The Anterior Communicating Artery (AComA) is a short blood vessel that connects the left and right [[830c856c|anterior cerebral arteries]], forming the anterior aspect of the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Provides collateral blood flow between the two anterior cerebral circulations.
  • Clinical Significance: It is the most common site for the formation of saccular (berry) aneurysms in the brain.
  • Aneurysm Complications:
    1. Rupture: Leads to [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]], presenting as a "worst headache of my life."
    2. Compression: A large, unruptured aneurysm can compress the adjacent optic chiasm, causing a [[6c3a980e|bitemporal hemianopia]] (tunnel vision).
  • USMLE Tip: When a question mentions a saccular aneurysm, the AComA should be the first location you consider. If the patient has visual field defects, especially bitemporal hemianopia, an AComA aneurysm is a very likely cause.
content.takeAway: The Anterior Communicating Artery, while small, is clinically significant as the number one location for berry aneurysms, which can either rupture catastrophically into the subarachnoid space or compress the optic chiasm, causing tunnel vision.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Left ACA] -- AComA --> B[Right ACA]; C(AComA Aneurysm) --> D(Rupture -> SAH); C --> E(Compression -> Bitemporal Hemianopia);

content.definition: The Anterior Nucleus is a region of the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] that plays a primary role in thermoregulation, specifically in dissipating heat to cool the body. It is part of the parasympathetic nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Mediates heat dissipation (cooling). Mnemonic: The A/C (Anterior Cooling) is in the front of the house.
  • Mechanism: Senses when the body is too hot and initiates parasympathetic responses like cutaneous vasodilation and sweating to promote heat loss.
  • Lesion Effect: A lesion in the anterior nucleus results in hyperthermia, as the body loses its ability to cool itself down.
  • Counterpart: The [[posterior_nucleus_of_hypothalamus|posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus]] is responsible for heat conservation and production (heating).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the functional pairing: Anterior hypothalamus = Cooling (parasympathetic), Posterior hypothalamus = Heating (sympathetic). A lesion in the anterior nucleus leads to an inability to cool down.
content.takeAway: The Anterior Nucleus of the hypothalamus functions as the body's thermostat for cooling; its destruction leads to uncontrolled hyperthermia because the primary mechanism for heat dissipation is lost.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Body Temperature] --> B(Anterior Nucleus); B --Parasympathetic Output--> C(Cutaneous Vasodilation & Sweating); C --> D(Heat Dissipation);

content.definition: The Anterior Spinal Artery (ASA) is a major artery that supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord. It originates from the vertebral arteries in the cranium and descends along the anterior surface of the spinal cord.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Formed from the union of two branches of the vertebral arteries.
  • Territory Supplied: Supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, including the anterior and lateral corticospinal tracts, the spinothalamic tracts, and the anterior horns. It notably spares the [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]].
  • Stroke Syndrome (Spinal Cord): Occlusion causes [[b48b54d7|Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome]], characterized by bilateral loss of motor function (flaccid paralysis at the level, UMN signs below) and pain/temperature sensation below the level of the lesion, with preserved proprioception and vibration sense.
  • Stroke Syndrome (Medulla): Occlusion of paramedian branches of the ASA or vertebral arteries causes Medial Medullary Syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to identifying an ASA stroke is the dissociation of sensory loss: pain and temperature are gone, but vibration and position sense are intact because the dorsal columns are spared.
content.takeAway: The Anterior Spinal Artery is the lifeline for the motor and pain/temperature pathways of the spinal cord; its occlusion creates a devastating syndrome of bilateral paralysis and sensory loss, sparing only the dorsal columns' functions of vibration and proprioception.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Vertebral Arteries] --> B(Anterior Spinal Artery); B --> C(Anterior 2/3 of Spinal Cord); C --> D[Corticospinal Tracts]; C --> E[Spinothalamic Tracts]; C --> F[Anterior Horns];

content.definition: Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome is a spinal cord infarct resulting from occlusion of the [[1430f5b4|anterior spinal artery (ASA)]], which leads to ischemia of the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, causing a distinct pattern of neurological deficits below the level of the lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by occlusion of the ASA, which can result from aortic surgery (e.g., repair of an aneurysm), severe hypotension (watershed infarct), or thromboembolism.
  • Structures Damaged: Corticospinal tracts, spinothalamic tracts, and anterior horns.
  • Structures Spared: The [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]] are spared due to their separate blood supply from the posterior spinal arteries.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    - Motor: Bilateral flaccid paralysis at the level of the lesion (LMN signs from anterior horn damage) and bilateral spastic paralysis below the lesion (UMN signs from corticospinal tract damage).
    - Sensory: Bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion (spinothalamic tract damage).
    - Sensation Preserved: Proprioception, vibration, and fine touch are intact because the dorsal columns are spared.
  • USMLE Tip: The dissociation between loss of pain/temperature and preservation of vibration/proprioception is the pathognomonic feature of this syndrome.
content.takeAway: Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome creates a stark neurological divide, paralyzing the body and eliminating pain and temperature sensation below the lesion, while leaving the sense of position and vibration completely intact, a direct reflection of the spinal cord's vascular territories.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[ASA Occlusion] --> B(Infarct of Anterior 2/3 of Spinal Cord); B --> C[Damage to Corticospinal & Spinothalamic Tracts]; B --Spares--> D[Dorsal Columns]; C --> E[Bilateral Paralysis & Loss of Pain/Temp]; D --> F[Preserved Vibration/Proprioception];

content.definition: Anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies are a class of medications used for the prophylactic treatment of [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]]. They work by targeting either calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) itself or its receptor, which are key players in the pathophysiology of migraines.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: These monoclonal antibodies bind to either the CGRP ligand (e.g., eptinezumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab) or the CGRP receptor (e.g., erenumab), preventing CGRP from mediating its effects of vasodilation and pain transmission in the trigeminal nervous system.
  • Clinical Use: Used for the prevention (prophylaxis) of episodic and chronic [[c8833bae|migraines]]. They are not used for acute treatment.
  • Administration: Administered via subcutaneous injection or IV infusion, typically on a monthly or quarterly basis.
  • Adverse Effects: Generally well-tolerated. The most common side effects are injection site reactions. Constipation is notably associated with the CGRP receptor antagonists (e.g., erenumab).
  • USMLE Tip: Recognize these drugs by their '-mab' suffix and their specific use for migraine prophylaxis. They represent a targeted therapy based on the modern understanding of migraine pathophysiology involving CGRP.
