content.takeAway: Anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies represent a major advance in migraine prevention, offering a highly specific mechanism that directly neutralizes the CGRP pathway, a key driver of pain and inflammation in migraine attacks.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Trigeminal Nerve Activation] --> B(Release of CGRP); B --> C(CGRP Receptor); C --> D(Vasodilation & Pain Transmission); D --> E(Migraine); F[Anti-CGRP mAbs] --x B; G[Anti-CGRP Receptor mAbs] --x C;

content.definition: Anticonvulsants, also known as antiepileptic drugs (AEDs), are a diverse group of medications used to treat epileptic [[64c08e92|seizures]]. They work by various mechanisms to suppress the rapid and excessive firing of neurons that initiate a seizure.
content.atAGlance:
• Major Mechanisms:
    1. Na+ Channel Blockade: [[5aea213f|Phenytoin]], [[eddd2bc5|Carbamazepine]], [[0d37e045|Valproate]], [[08d19a8f|Lamotrigine]].
    2. Enhancement of GABAergic inhibition: Benzodiazepines, Barbiturates, [[valproic_acid|Valproate]].
    3. Ca2+ Channel Blockade: [[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]] (T-type), Gabapentinoids.
  • Spectrum of Activity:
    - Broad-spectrum: [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]], [[08d19a8f|lamotrigine]], [[2341f9c0|levetiracetam]], [[e1f5066c|topiramate]]. Effective for both focal and generalized seizures.
    - Narrow-spectrum: [[eddd2bc5|Carbamazepine]], [[5aea213f|phenytoin]], gabapentinoids. Primarily for focal seizures. [[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]] is for absence seizures only.
  • Other Uses: Many anticonvulsants are also used for bipolar disorder, neuropathic pain, and [[c8833bae|migraine]] prophylaxis. Some are used in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]] for symptomatic treatment.
  • Adverse Effects: Common side effects include sedation, dizziness, and ataxia. Many carry a risk of serious skin reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), especially lamotrigine and carbamazepine. All are potentially teratogenic.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the first-line treatments for specific seizure types: Absence -> [[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]]; Tonic-clonic -> [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]], [[2341f9c0|levetiracetam]]; Status epilepticus -> Benzodiazepines.
content.takeAway: Anticonvulsants primarily work by either dampening neuronal excitability (e.g., blocking Na+ channels) or enhancing neuronal inhibition (e.g., potentiating GABA), with the choice of drug critically depending on the type of seizure being treated.

content.definition: Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, is a peptide hormone synthesized in the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] and released from the posterior pituitary. Its primary functions are to regulate plasma osmolality by increasing water reabsorption in the kidneys and to regulate blood pressure via vasoconstriction.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis & Release: Synthesized primarily in the supraoptic nucleus of the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]], transported down axons, and stored/released from the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis).
  • Regulation: Release is stimulated by increased plasma osmolality (detected by osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus) and, to a lesser extent, by decreased blood volume/pressure.
  • Renal Action (V2 Receptors): Binds to V2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of principal cells in the renal collecting ducts. This activates a Gs-cAMP pathway, leading to the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical membrane, increasing water reabsorption.
  • Vascular Action (V1 Receptors): Binds to V1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle, activating a Gq-IP3/DAG pathway that causes vasoconstriction and increases blood pressure.
  • USMLE Tip: Pathologies are key: Deficiency of ADH or its receptor causes [[diabetes_insipidus]]. Excess ADH secretion causes [[syndrome_of_inappropriate_antidiuretic_hormone|SIADH]].
content.takeAway: Antidiuretic Hormone is the body's primary regulator of water balance, acting on the kidney's collecting ducts via V2 receptors to conserve water when osmolality is high, and on blood vessels via V1 receptors to raise blood pressure when volume is low.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Plasma Osmolality] --> B(Hypothalamus); B --> C(Posterior Pituitary); C --Release ADH--> D; D --V2 Receptor--> E[Kidney Collecting Duct]; E --> F(↑ Aquaporin-2 Insertion); F --> G(↑ Water Reabsorption); D --V1 Receptor--> H[Vascular Smooth Muscle]; H --> I(Vasoconstriction);

content.definition: Antimuscarinic drugs, also known as anticholinergics, are a class of medications that act as competitive antagonists at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, thereby blocking the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Competitively block [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] at muscarinic receptors (M1, M2, M3). They do not affect nicotinic receptors.
  • Clinical Effects (Mnemonic): "Hot as a hare, dry as a bone, blind as a bat, red as a beet, mad as a hatter."
    - Dry: ↓ Salivation, lacrimation, sweating.
    - Blind: Mydriasis (pupil dilation) and cycloplegia (loss of accommodation).
    - Hot & Red: ↓ Sweating leads to hyperthermia and compensatory flushing.
    - Mad: CNS effects like delirium, confusion, hallucinations (especially with drugs that cross the BBB).
  • Neurologic Use: Used in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] (e.g., [[383f6fbe|benztropine]], trihexyphenidyl) to treat tremor and rigidity by rebalancing the cholinergic-dopaminergic systems. Also used to treat drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Other Uses: Atropine (bradycardia), scopolamine (motion sickness), ipratropium (COPD), oxybutynin (overactive bladder).
  • USMLE Tip: Be cautious using antimuscarinics in the elderly due to increased risk of confusion, hallucinations, and delirium. They are contraindicated in [[9c80344d|angle-closure glaucoma]].
content.takeAway: Antimuscarinic drugs function by blocking the 'rest and digest' functions of the parasympathetic nervous system, leading to a predictable constellation of side effects that are essentially the opposite of a cholinergic toxidrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Acetylcholine] --x B(Antimuscarinic Drugs); B --x C(Muscarinic Receptors); C --x D(Parasympathetic Effects);

content.definition: Antispasmodics, or skeletal muscle relaxants, are a group of drugs used to alleviate symptoms associated with muscle spasticity or acute muscle spasms by acting either on the central nervous system or directly on the muscle.
content.atAGlance:
• Baclofen: A [[gaba_b_receptor|GABAB receptor]] agonist that acts on the spinal cord to suppress hyperactive reflexes. Used for spasticity in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]] and spinal cord injury.
  • Cyclobenzaprine: A centrally acting muscle relaxant, structurally related to TCAs. Used for acute muscle spasms from musculoskeletal conditions. Has significant anticholinergic side effects and causes sedation.
  • Tizanidine: A centrally acting α2-adrenergic agonist that inhibits motor neuron activity. Used for spasticity. Can cause hypotension, sedation, and dry mouth.
  • Dantrolene: Acts directly on skeletal muscle by blocking Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (inhibits ryanodine receptor). Used to treat malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the uses: [[baclofen]] and tizanidine for chronic spasticity (MS, spinal cord injury), cyclobenzaprine for acute muscle strain, and [[dantrolene]] for life-threatening hyperthermic syndromes.
content.takeAway: Antispasmodics reduce muscle hyperactivity through diverse mechanisms, ranging from central GABAergic and adrenergic modulation (baclofen, tizanidine) to direct interference with muscle contraction machinery (dantrolene), the latter being crucial for treating hyperthermic emergencies.

content.definition: Anxiety disorders are a group of mental health conditions characterized by excessive and persistent fear, anxiety, or worry that is disproportionate to the situation and impairs daily functioning. They are associated with altered activity in brain circuits involving the [[d220fc3f|amygdala]] and prefrontal cortex.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurotransmitter Imbalance: Associated with decreased levels of [[5d3c2089|serotonin]] and [[gaba|GABA]], and increased levels of norepinephrine.
  • Common Types:
    - Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): Chronic, uncontrollable worry about multiple issues.
    - Panic Disorder: Recurrent, unexpected panic attacks.
    - Phobias: Intense, irrational fear of a specific object or situation.
    - Social Anxiety Disorder: Fear of social situations and scrutiny.
  • First-Line Treatment: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and/or SSRIs/SNRIs are the first-line treatments for most anxiety disorders.
  • Second-Line/Adjunctive Treatment: [[14464617|Benzodiazepines]] (e.g., [[083094db|alprazolam]], lorazepam) are used for rapid relief of acute anxiety or panic attacks but are not preferred for long-term use due to dependence risk. Buspirone is a non-sedating anxiolytic used for GAD.
  • USMLE Tip: For long-term management of anxiety, SSRIs/SNRIs are preferred. Benzodiazepines are for short-term or 'as-needed' use.
content.takeAway: Anxiety disorders represent a dysregulation of the brain's fear and worry circuits, driven by an imbalance of key neurotransmitters. Modern treatment focuses on long-term modulation with SSRIs/SNRIs and CBT, reserving fast-acting benzodiazepines for acute, short-term management.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Amygdala Hyperactivity] & B[Prefrontal Cortex Hypoactivity] --> C(Dysregulated Fear/Worry Circuit); C --> D(Anxiety Disorder);

content.definition: Aphasia is an acquired language disorder resulting from damage to the language centers of the brain, typically in the dominant (usually left) hemisphere. It affects the ability to produce and/or comprehend spoken or written language, and is distinct from dysarthria (a motor speech disorder).
content.atAGlance:
• Broca's Aphasia (Expressive): Lesion in the inferior frontal gyrus ([[a3bbace2|Broca's area]]). Characterized by nonfluent, telegraphic speech with intact comprehension. Patients are often frustrated by their inability to speak. Mnemonic: Broca's is Broken Boca (mouth).
  • Wernicke's Aphasia (Receptive): Lesion in the superior temporal gyrus ([[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]]). Characterized by fluent but meaningless speech (word salad) with severely impaired comprehension. Patients are often unaware of their deficit (anosognosia).
  • Conduction Aphasia: Lesion of the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. Hallmark is poor repetition despite fluent speech and intact comprehension.
  • Global Aphasia: Large lesion affecting both Broca's and Wernicke's areas, typically from a large [[143bb23d|MCA stroke]]. All language functions (fluency, comprehension, repetition) are severely impaired.
  • USMLE Tip: The most common cause of aphasia is an ischemic [[c5da3c57|stroke]] in the territory of the left [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
content.takeAway: Aphasia is a disorder of language, not speech mechanics, with distinct subtypes that can be precisely localized within the dominant cerebral hemisphere: Broca's area for production, Wernicke's area for comprehension, and the arcuate fasciculus for repetition.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Left MCA Stroke] --> B{Aphasia Types}; B --> C[Broca's - Nonfluent, Good Comprehension]; B --> D[Wernicke's - Fluent, Poor Comprehension]; B --> E[Conduction - Poor Repetition]; B --> F[Global - All Impaired];

content.definition: Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is a highly regulated and controlled process, essential for normal tissue turnover, embryonic development, and removal of damaged or infected cells. In the context of neurology, it is the primary mechanism of neuronal death in many neurodegenerative diseases.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Features: Characterized by cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation (pyknosis), membrane blebbing, and formation of apoptotic bodies, which are then phagocytosed. It is an ATP-dependent process and does not induce inflammation.
  • Pathways:
    - Intrinsic (Mitochondrial): Activated by cellular stress (e.g., DNA damage, misfolded proteins). Regulated by the Bcl-2 family of proteins. Pro-apoptotic proteins (Bax, Bak) create pores in the mitochondrial membrane, releasing cytochrome c, which activates caspases.
    - Extrinsic (Death Receptor): Activated by external ligands (e.g., FasL, TNF-α) binding to death receptors on the cell surface, directly activating caspases.
  • Caspases: The central executioners of apoptosis are a family of cysteine proteases called caspases, which orchestrate the degradation of cellular components.
  • Neurologic Relevance: Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is a key feature of [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]]. It is also the mechanism of neuronal loss in [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]] and [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
  • USMLE Tip: Contrast apoptosis with necrosis. Necrosis is uncontrolled cell death due to injury, causing cell swelling, membrane rupture, and inflammation. Apoptosis is clean, programmed, and non-inflammatory.
content.takeAway: Apoptosis is the cell's intrinsic suicide program, executed by caspases, which neatly packages the cell for disposal without triggering an inflammatory response; its dysregulation is a central theme in both cancer (too little apoptosis) and neurodegeneration (too much apoptosis).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A{Cellular Stress} --> B(Intrinsic Pathway); B --> C(Mitochondria); C --Cytochrome c--> D; E{Death Ligands} --> F(Extrinsic Pathway); F --> D(Caspase Activation); D --> G(Execution Phase); G --> H(Apoptotic Body Formation);

content.definition: Apraclonidine is an α2-adrenergic agonist used topically in ophthalmology to lower intraocular pressure (IOP), primarily for the short-term treatment of [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: As a selective α2-agonist, it acts on presynaptic α2 receptors in the ciliary body to decrease aqueous humor synthesis. It also has some minor effect on increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Clinical Use: Used to lower IOP in patients with [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]]. It is particularly useful for preventing post-surgical IOP spikes. Its use is often limited to the short term due to tachyphylaxis (diminishing response).
  • Adverse Effects: Ocular side effects include blurry vision, ocular hyperemia (redness), foreign body sensation, and ocular allergic reactions. Systemic side effects are rare but can include dry mouth and fatigue.
  • Comparison: Similar to [[brimonidine]], another α2-agonist used for glaucoma, but apraclonidine has a higher rate of tachyphylaxis and allergic reactions.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that α2-agonists (like apraclonidine and clonidine) work by reducing sympathetic outflow. In the eye, this translates to decreased production of aqueous humor.
content.takeAway: Apraclonidine lowers intraocular pressure by acting as a 'brake' on aqueous humor production, stimulating α2-receptors in the ciliary body to reduce fluid synthesis, making it a useful agent for short-term management of glaucoma.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Apraclonidine] --> B(Stimulates α2 Receptors in Ciliary Body); B --> C(↓ Norepinephrine Release); C --> D(↓ Aqueous Humor Synthesis); D --> E(↓ Intraocular Pressure);

content.definition: Gait apraxia is a high-level gait disorder characterized by the inability to properly coordinate the motor sequences for walking, despite having normal motor, sensory, and cerebellar function. It is often described as a "magnetic gait," where the feet appear stuck to the floor.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Patients have difficulty initiating walking. The gait is wide-based, shuffling, and slow, with the feet barely leaving the ground. Turning is particularly difficult and requires multiple small steps.
  • Pathophysiology: It is considered a disorder of the frontal lobes or their connections, disrupting the cortical control of locomotion.
  • Classic Association: Gait apraxia is one of the three cardinal signs of [[7c59030e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)]].
  • NPH Triad: The classic triad is "Wobbly, Wacky, and Wet":
    1. Wobbly: Gait apraxia.
    2. Wacky: Cognitive dysfunction/dementia.
    3. Wet: Urinary incontinence.
  • USMLE Tip: The description of a 'magnetic' or 'feet stuck to the floor' gait in an elderly patient, especially when combined with cognitive changes and urinary incontinence, is a classic vignette for [[7c59030e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus]].
content.takeAway: Gait apraxia is a 'brain' problem, not a 'leg' problem; it represents a failure of the frontal lobe's motor programming for walking, famously manifesting as the 'magnetic' gait of [[7c59030e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus]].

content.definition: The Aqueous Humor Pathway describes the continuous production, circulation, and drainage of aqueous humor, the clear fluid that fills the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. The balance between production and drainage determines the intraocular pressure (IOP).
content.atAGlance:
• Production: Aqueous humor is produced by the nonpigmented epithelium of the ciliary body. This process is decreased by β-blockers, α2-agonists, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
  • Circulation: Fluid flows from the posterior chamber, through the pupil, into the anterior chamber.
  • Drainage Pathways:
    1. Trabecular Outflow (~90%): Fluid drains through the trabecular meshwork, into the Canal of Schlemm, and then into the episcleral vasculature. This pathway is enhanced by muscarinic agonists (e.g., pilocarpine).
    2. Uveoscleral Outflow (~10%): Fluid drains through the ciliary muscle and into the uveal and scleral tissues. This pathway is enhanced by prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost).
  • Clinical Relevance: Imbalance in this pathway leads to [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]]. [[5ea7b741|Open-angle glaucoma]] involves increased resistance in the trabecular meshwork, while [[9c80344d|angle-closure glaucoma]] involves physical obstruction of the angle.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand how different glaucoma medications target this pathway. Prostaglandins increase uveoscleral outflow, while β-blockers and acetazolamide decrease production.
content.takeAway: The Aqueous Humor Pathway is a dynamic circulatory system within the eye's anterior segment, where a delicate equilibrium between ciliary body production and dual-route (trabecular and uveoscleral) drainage is essential for maintaining normal intraocular pressure.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ciliary Body Epithelium] --Produces--> B(Aqueous Humor); B --> C(Posterior Chamber); C --> D(Anterior Chamber); D --> E{Drainage}; E --> F[Trabecular Outflow (90%)]; F --> G[Canal of Schlemm]; E --> H[Uveoscleral Outflow (10%)];

content.definition: Arachnoid granulations (or arachnoid villi) are microscopic protrusions of the [[46e279b9|arachnoid mater]] through the dura mater into the superior sagittal sinus and other [[21f1c955|dural venous sinuses]], functioning as one-way valves for the drainage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the subarachnoid space into the venous circulation.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: The primary site for CSF reabsorption into the bloodstream.
  • Mechanism: CSF flows from the subarachnoid space into the venous sinus down a pressure gradient. The structure acts as a one-way valve, preventing venous blood from entering the subarachnoid space.
  • Location: Most numerous along the superior sagittal sinus.
  • Pathology: Impaired function or obstruction of arachnoid granulations (e.g., from scarring after meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage) can lead to [[aa4115c7|communicating hydrocephalus]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that CSF is produced by the choroid plexus and reabsorbed by the arachnoid granulations. A problem with reabsorption (communicating hydrocephalus) is distinct from a blockage of flow within the ventricles (non-communicating hydrocephalus).
content.takeAway: Arachnoid granulations are the critical drainage ports for cerebrospinal fluid, acting as sophisticated one-way valves that allow CSF to exit the subarachnoid space and return to the venous system, thereby maintaining intracranial pressure homeostasis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choroid Plexus] --Produces--> B(CSF); B --> C(Ventricular System); C --> D(Subarachnoid Space); D --> E(Arachnoid Granulations); E --Reabsorption--> F[Dural Venous Sinuses];

content.definition: The Arachnoid Mater is the middle layer of the three meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord. It is a delicate, avascular membrane located between the outer [[5bbe3597|dura mater]] and the inner [[pia_mater|pia mater]].
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Composed of a web-like network of collagen and elastic fibers, from which it gets its name (from Greek 'arachne' for spider).
  • Embryologic Origin: Derived from the [[14c6f2a7|neural crest]].
  • Subarachnoid Space: The space between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater is the subarachnoid space, which contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and major cerebral blood vessels.
  • Arachnoid Granulations: Protrusions of the arachnoid mater through the dura into the superior sagittal sinus, responsible for CSF reabsorption.
  • Clinical Relevance: Rupture of an artery in the subarachnoid space (e.g., from a berry aneurysm) causes a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]]. A [[e98ea0ba|meningioma]], a common benign brain tumor, arises from arachnoid cap cells.
content.takeAway: The Arachnoid Mater forms a crucial boundary, creating the subarachnoid space that houses the CSF and cerebral vasculature, and its specialized granulations are essential for CSF drainage.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Skull] --> B[Dura Mater]; B --> C(Arachnoid Mater); C --> D[Subarachnoid Space - CSF]; D --> E[Pia Mater]; E --> F[Brain];

content.definition: The Area Postrema is a highly vascularized structure in the medulla oblongata, located on the floor of the fourth ventricle, that functions as the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) for vomiting. It is one of the circumventricular organs, meaning it lacks a complete [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata at the caudal end of the fourth ventricle.
  • Function: Detects emetogenic toxins in the blood and CSF and sends signals to the [[74b651ab|vomiting center]] (nucleus tractus solitarius) to induce emesis (vomiting).
  • Blood-Brain Barrier: Its fenestrated capillaries allow it to directly sample the chemical composition of the blood.
  • Receptors: Rich in various receptors, including dopamine D2, serotonin 5-HT3, and neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors.
  • Clinical Relevance: This is the site of action for many antiemetic drugs. For example, [[ondansetron]] is a 5-HT3 antagonist, and [[metoclopramide]] is a D2 antagonist. It is also the area stimulated by toxins during chemotherapy, leading to chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
content.takeAway: The Area Postrema serves as the brain's chemical surveillance system for the blood; its lack of a blood-brain barrier allows it to detect toxins and trigger the protective reflex of vomiting, making it a key target for antiemetic medications.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Emetogenic Toxins in Blood] --> B(Area Postrema/CTZ); B --> C(Vomiting Center - NTS); C --> D(Vomiting Reflex);

content.definition: The Argyll Robertson Pupil is a specific type of pupillary abnormality characterized by bilateral small pupils that constrict when the patient focuses on a near object (accommodation reflex) but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light reflex). This phenomenon is known as light-near dissociation.
content.atAGlance:
• Classic Mnemonic: Often called the "prostitute's pupil" because it "accommodates but does not react."
  • Pathophysiology: The lesion is thought to be in the pretectal nucleus in the superior colliculus of the midbrain, which interrupts the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex pathway before it reaches the Edinger-Westphal nuclei bilaterally. The pathway for accommodation, which is more complex and involves the cerebral cortex, is spared.
  • Classic Association: It is a highly specific sign of late-stage, or tertiary, neurosyphilis, particularly [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]].
  • Other Causes: While classic for syphilis, it can also be seen in other conditions causing midbrain lesions, such as diabetes mellitus or Parinaud syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with ataxia, a positive Romberg sign, and pupils that accommodate but don't react to light is a classic presentation of [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] due to neurosyphilis.
content.takeAway: The Argyll Robertson Pupil is a pathognomonic sign of neurosyphilis, representing a selective lesion in the midbrain that disconnects the pupillary light reflex pathway while preserving the separate, cortically-driven accommodation pathway, resulting in the classic light-near dissociation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Light] --> B(Optic Nerve); B --> C(Pretectal Nucleus); C --x Lesion; C --x D(Edinger-Westphal Nucleus); E[Near Object] --> F(Visual Cortex); F --> G(Accommodation Pathway); G --> D; D --> H(Pupillary Constriction);

content.definition: Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, primarily used at low doses for its antiplatelet effects in the prevention of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Irreversibly acetylates and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. Its antiplatelet effect is due to inhibition of COX-1 in platelets, which blocks the synthesis of Thromboxane A2 (TXA2), a potent promoter of platelet aggregation.
  • Clinical Use (Neurology): Used for secondary prevention of [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] and [[623ba776|transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)]]. It is a cornerstone of antiplatelet therapy.
  • Adverse Effects: GI distress (gastritis, ulcers), bleeding, tinnitus (a sign of toxicity), and Reye syndrome in children with viral illness.
  • Reye Syndrome: A rare but severe condition of acute encephalopathy and fatty liver failure in children given aspirin for a viral infection (e.g., influenza, varicella). Aspirin is contraindicated in children for this reason (except in Kawasaki disease).
  • USMLE Tip: The irreversibility of aspirin's effect on platelets is key. Since platelets lack a nucleus, they cannot synthesize new COX enzyme, so the antiplatelet effect lasts for the life of the platelet (~7-10 days).
content.takeAway: Aspirin's primary role in stroke prevention stems from its unique ability to irreversibly inhibit platelet COX-1, effectively silencing thromboxane A2 production for the platelet's entire lifespan and thus reducing the risk of thrombotic occlusion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Aspirin] --Irreversibly Inhibits--> B(Platelet COX-1); B --x C(Arachidonic Acid -> Thromboxane A2); C --x D(Platelet Aggregation); D --x E(Thrombus Formation);

content.definition: Asterixis is a type of negative myoclonus characterized by a brief, flapping tremor of the hands, typically elicited by having the patient extend their arms and dorsiflex their wrists. It is a classic sign of metabolic encephalopathy.
content.atAGlance:
• Elicitation: The patient holds their arms out with wrists extended ('stop traffic' pose). The 'flap' is a sudden, brief loss of postural tone, causing the hands to drop, followed by a rapid, jerky return to the original position.
  • Pathophysiology: It is not a true tremor but a failure of the brain to maintain a sustained posture, thought to be due to abnormal function of the diencephalic motor centers that regulate posture and tone.
  • Classic Association: Most commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy due to liver failure, where high ammonia levels are neurotoxic.
  • Other Causes: Can also be seen in other metabolic encephalopathies, including uremia (renal failure), CO2 narcosis (hypercapnia), and drug intoxication. It is also a feature of [[wilson_disease|Wilson disease]].
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a history of cirrhosis who presents with confusion and a 'flapping tremor' of the hands has hepatic encephalopathy. The tremor is asterixis.
content.takeAway: Asterixis is a 'negative' movement disorder—a brief lapse in muscle tone rather than an active contraction—that serves as a crucial physical exam finding for metabolic encephalopathies, most classically hepatic encephalopathy from hyperammonemia.

content.definition: Astigmatism is a common refractive error of the eye where vision is blurred or distorted at all distances. It occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular, non-spherical curvature, causing light rays to focus at multiple points rather than a single point on the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The cornea, which should be shaped like a sphere, is instead shaped more like a football (toric). This causes light entering the eye to have different focal points in different planes (e.g., vertical vs. horizontal).
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision, eye strain, and headaches.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosed during a standard eye exam using a phoropter and keratometer.
  • Correction: Corrected with eyeglasses or contact lenses that have a cylindrical lens to compensate for the irregular curvature. It can also be corrected with refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from other refractive errors: [[myopia|myopia]] (nearsightedness) and [[hyperopia|hyperopia]] (farsightedness) are caused by the length of the eyeball relative to its focusing power, while astigmatism is caused by an irregularly shaped cornea or lens.
content.takeAway: Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an asymmetrically shaped cornea or lens, which acts like a warped mirror, scattering light to multiple focal points and resulting in blurred vision that requires a cylindrical lens for correction.

content.definition: Astrocytes are the most abundant type of glial cell in the central nervous system. These star-shaped cells perform a wide variety of essential supportive and homeostatic functions for neurons, and are the origin of the most common primary brain tumor in adults, [[b6bbd0bc|glioblastoma]].
content.atAGlance:
• Functions: Physical support for neurons, repair (gliosis/scar formation), component of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]] (via foot processes), removal of excess neurotransmitters (especially glutamate), and maintenance of the ionic environment.
  • Histological Marker: They are identified by their expression of Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP), an intermediate filament protein.
  • Reactive Gliosis: In response to CNS injury (e.g., stroke, trauma), astrocytes proliferate and hypertrophy to form a glial scar, which walls off the damaged area but can also impede axonal regeneration.
  • Tumor Origin: Astrocytes are the cell of origin for astrocytomas, including the highly malignant [[b6bbd0bc|glioblastoma]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember GFAP as the key marker for astrocytes and astrocytic tumors. The formation of a glial scar by astrocytes is the CNS equivalent of fibrosis in other tissues.
content.takeAway: Astrocytes are the indispensable 'housekeepers' of the CNS, providing structural, metabolic, and homeostatic support to neurons, forming the blood-brain barrier, and orchestrating the glial scar response to injury, but they can also give rise to the most aggressive brain tumors.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Astrocyte]; A --> B(Physical Support); A --> C(Blood-Brain Barrier); A --> D(Neurotransmitter Uptake); A --> E(Ion Buffering); A --> F(Repair/Gliosis); A --Neoplastic Transformation--> G(Astrocytoma/Glioblastoma);

content.definition: Ataxia is a neurological sign consisting of a lack of voluntary coordination of muscle movements, leading to a clumsy, unsteady gait and impaired balance. It can be caused by damage to the cerebellum, the vestibular system, or sensory pathways.
content.atAGlance:
• Cerebellar Ataxia: Caused by damage to the cerebellum.
    - Truncal Ataxia: Affects the midline, causing an unsteady, wide-based ('drunken sailor') gait. Associated with lesions of the cerebellar vermis.
    - Limb Ataxia: Affects the extremities, causing dysmetria (overshooting/undershooting targets) and intention tremor. Associated with lesions of the cerebellar hemispheres.
  • Sensory Ataxia: Caused by loss of proprioception, typically from damage to the [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]] of the spinal cord or peripheral nerves. Patients have a positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]] (worsening of balance with eyes closed) and a stomping gait. Seen in [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] and [[6f5bea90|subacute combined degeneration]].
  • Vestibular Ataxia: Caused by dysfunction of the vestibular system. Associated with vertigo, nystagmus, and nausea.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiating the type of ataxia is key. A positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]] points to a sensory (dorsal column) cause, not a cerebellar cause. Patients with cerebellar ataxia are unsteady with their eyes open or closed.
content.takeAway: Ataxia is a sign of discoordination that can be localized by its characteristics: truncal and limb incoordination points to the cerebellum, a positive Romberg sign points to sensory loss in the dorsal columns, and associated vertigo points to the vestibular system.

content.definition: Athetosis is a type of involuntary movement disorder characterized by slow, writhing, snake-like movements, particularly affecting the distal extremities (fingers and hands). It is a symptom of damage to the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]].
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Slow, twisting, and writhing movements that are continuous and non-rhythmic. It is often described as being 'snake-like.'
  • Lesion Location: Caused by lesions in the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]], particularly the striatum (caudate and putamen).
  • Classic Association: Athetosis is a characteristic feature of [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]], where it often co-occurs with chorea (termed choreoathetosis).
  • Other Causes: Can also be seen in conditions like cerebral palsy.
  • USMLE Tip: When you see a description of slow, writhing, 'snake-like' movements of the fingers in a patient with other signs of a basal ganglia disorder (like chorea or dementia), think of athetosis, especially in the context of [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].
content.takeAway: Athetosis is a specific and visually distinct sign of basal ganglia dysfunction, representing a failure of motor control that manifests as slow, ceaseless, writhing movements, most classically seen in [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].

content.definition: Atonic seizures, also known as "drop attacks" or "drop seizures," are a type of generalized seizure characterized by a sudden loss of muscle tone, causing the individual to collapse to the ground. The loss of consciousness is typically very brief.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: A sudden, complete loss of postural muscle tone lasting 1-2 seconds. This can cause the head to drop, the jaw to slacken, or the entire body to fall limply to the floor.
  • Risk of Injury: There is a high risk of head and facial injuries from the sudden falls. Patients may need to wear protective helmets.
  • Associated Syndromes: While they can occur in various epilepsy syndromes, atonic seizures are a hallmark feature of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of childhood epilepsy.
  • EEG Findings: The EEG may show brief, generalized spike-and-wave discharges followed by diffuse slow waves.
  • USMLE Tip: A vignette describing a child with developmental delay who has multiple seizure types, including sudden falls leading to injury, is highly suggestive of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, with atonic seizures being a key component.
content.takeAway: Atonic seizures are dramatic 'drop attacks' caused by a sudden, global loss of muscle tone, posing a significant risk of injury and often signaling a severe underlying epilepsy syndrome like Lennox-Gastaut.

content.definition: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia to induce skeletal muscle relaxation and paralysis, facilitating endotracheal intubation and surgical procedures.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] from binding and causing muscle contraction.
  • Metabolism: Undergoes Hoffmann elimination, a spontaneous, non-enzymatic degradation at physiological pH and temperature. This makes its metabolism independent of liver or kidney function.
  • Clinical Use: Ideal for patients with renal or hepatic failure because its elimination does not depend on these organs.
  • Adverse Effects: Can cause histamine release, leading to hypotension, flushing, and bronchoconstriction. Its metabolite, laudanosine, can lower the seizure threshold, but this is rarely clinically significant.
  • Reversal: The neuromuscular blockade can be reversed by [[acetylcholinesterase_inhibitors|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., neostigmine), which increase the concentration of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft to outcompete the blocker.
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature of atracurium (and its stereoisomer, cisatracurium) is its Hoffmann elimination, making it the neuromuscular blocker of choice for patients with organ dysfunction.
content.takeAway: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker distinguished by its unique Hoffmann elimination pathway, a spontaneous chemical breakdown that makes it a safe and predictable choice for inducing paralysis in patients with kidney or liver disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Atracurium] --Competitively Antagonizes--> B(Nicotinic ACh Receptors); B --x C(ACh Binding); C --x D(Muscle Contraction); A --Hoffmann Elimination--> E(Inactive Metabolites);

content.definition: Atrophy is a cellular adaptation characterized by a decrease in the size of a cell, organ, or tissue after it has reached its normal mature size. It results from a decrease in cell substance and can be either physiologic or pathologic.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Atrophy occurs via a decrease in protein synthesis and an increase in protein degradation. The main pathway for protein degradation is the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. It can also involve autophagy, where the cell digests its own components.
  • Causes: Common causes include disuse, denervation, loss of endocrine stimulation, inadequate nutrition, and ischemia.
  • Neurologic Relevance (Denervation Atrophy): When a muscle loses its nerve supply (denervation), it undergoes rapid and profound atrophy. This is a key sign of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion.
  • UMN vs. LMN Lesions: Significant muscle atrophy is a hallmark of LMN lesions (e.g., polio, [[4ed629f9|ALS]], peripheral nerve injury). In contrast, upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions cause only mild disuse atrophy.
  • USMLE Tip: In a clinical vignette, the presence of marked muscle wasting (atrophy) and fasciculations strongly points towards an LMN component of a disease process.
content.takeAway: Atrophy is a reduction in cell size and substance, most often driven by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. In neurology, denervation atrophy is a critical sign that localizes a lesion to the lower motor neuron, distinguishing it from upper motor neuron pathology.

content.definition: Auditory anatomy and physiology describes the structures and mechanisms by which sound waves are collected, transmitted, transduced into neural signals, and processed by the brain to produce the sensation of hearing.
content.atAGlance:
• Outer Ear: The pinna and external auditory canal collect sound waves and funnel them to the tympanic membrane (eardrum).
  • Middle Ear: An air-filled cavity containing the ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes). The ossicles amplify the vibrations from the tympanic membrane and transmit them to the oval window of the inner ear.
  • Inner Ear: The [[001c359f|cochlea]], a fluid-filled, snail-shaped structure, contains the organ of Corti. Vibrations from the stapes create pressure waves in the cochlear fluid.
  • Transduction: These pressure waves cause the basilar membrane to vibrate at specific locations depending on the frequency (tonotopy). High frequencies vibrate the base, low frequencies vibrate the apex. This vibration bends the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti, opening ion channels and generating a neural signal.
  • Neural Pathway: The signal travels from the hair cells via the cochlear nerve (part of CN VIII) to the cochlear nuclei in the brainstem, then through a complex pathway (superior olive, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus) to the [[d24b6af6|auditory cortex]] in the temporal lobe.
content.takeAway: The auditory system is a remarkable transducer, converting mechanical energy (sound waves) into mechanical vibration (ossicles), then into hydraulic waves (cochlear fluid), and finally into electrical signals (hair cells) that the brain interprets as sound.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Sound Waves] --> B(Outer Ear); B --> C(Tympanic Membrane); C --> D(Middle Ear Ossicles); D --> E(Oval Window); E --> F(Cochlear Fluid); F --> G(Basilar Membrane Vibration); G --> H(Hair Cell Transduction); H --> I(CN VIII); I --> J(Brain);

content.definition: The Auditory Cortex is the region of the cerebral cortex responsible for processing auditory information. It is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe and includes the primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42) and surrounding auditory association areas.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe.
  • Function: The primary auditory cortex is responsible for the perception of basic sound characteristics like pitch and volume. The surrounding association areas, including [[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]] in the dominant hemisphere, are involved in the interpretation and comprehension of complex sounds, particularly speech.
  • Thalamic Relay: It receives its primary input from the medial geniculate nucleus (MGN) of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]]. Mnemonic: Medial = Music (hearing).
  • Tonotopic Organization: The auditory cortex is organized tonotopically, meaning that different frequencies of sound are processed in different, specific areas of the cortex, mirroring the organization of the [[001c359f|cochlea]].
  • USMLE Tip: A lesion in the primary auditory cortex does not typically cause complete deafness in one ear, as auditory information from each ear is processed bilaterally in the brain. However, a lesion in [[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]] (an auditory association cortex) will cause receptive aphasia.
content.takeAway: The Auditory Cortex is the final destination for sound processing in the brain, receiving signals from the medial geniculate nucleus and interpreting them, with specialized areas like Wernicke's area in the dominant hemisphere being crucial for language comprehension.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cochlea] --> B(CN VIII); B --> C(Brainstem Nuclei); C --> D(Medial Geniculate Nucleus); D --> E(Auditory Cortex);

content.definition: The Autonomic Nervous System (ANS) is the division of the peripheral nervous system that controls involuntary bodily functions, such as heart rate, digestion, respiratory rate, and pupillary response. It is subdivided into the sympathetic, parasympathetic, and enteric systems.
content.atAGlance:
• Sympathetic Division: Mediates the "fight or flight" response. Preganglionic neurons are short and release [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] onto nicotinic receptors in the paravertebral ganglia. Postganglionic neurons are long and primarily release norepinephrine onto adrenergic receptors.
  • Parasympathetic Division: Mediates the "rest and digest" response. Preganglionic neurons are long and release [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] onto nicotinic receptors in ganglia near or within target organs. Postganglionic neurons are short and release [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] onto muscarinic receptors.
  • CNS Control: The ANS is regulated by higher centers in the CNS, including the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] and the [[73ace357|limbic system]], which modulate autonomic outflow in response to emotional and environmental stimuli.
  • Clinical Relevance: Autonomic dysregulation is a feature of many neurological disorders, including [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré syndrome]] (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy), which can cause life-threatening cardiac irregularities and blood pressure instability.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the neurotransmitter/receptor pairings: All preganglionic neurons use ACh (nicotinic). Parasympathetic postganglionic neurons use ACh (muscarinic). Most sympathetic postganglionic neurons use norepinephrine (adrenergic), with the key exception being sweat glands (ACh, muscarinic).
content.takeAway: The Autonomic Nervous System maintains homeostasis through a balance of its sympathetic ('gas pedal') and parasympathetic ('brake pedal') divisions, utilizing a two-neuron chain with distinct neurotransmitters and receptor targets to exert involuntary control over virtually every organ system.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CNS] --> B(Preganglionic Neuron); B --ACh--> C(Autonomic Ganglion); C --NE/ACh--> D(Target Organ);

content.definition: Axonal injury refers to damage to the axons of neurons, which can occur from trauma, ischemia, or neurodegenerative processes. The neuronal response to injury and the potential for regeneration depend on whether the injury is in the central or peripheral nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Wallerian Degeneration: The process of degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury. The axon disintegrates and its myelin sheath breaks down, cleared by Schwann cells (PNS) or microglia (CNS).
  • Axonal Reaction (Central Chromatolysis): Changes occurring in the neuronal cell body proximal to the injury. The cell body swells, the nucleus is displaced to the periphery, and Nissl bodies disperse. This reflects an increase in protein synthesis for repair.
  • Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI): A severe form of traumatic brain injury caused by shearing forces from rapid acceleration/deceleration. It involves widespread damage to axons in the white matter tracts. MRI shows multiple punctate hemorrhages. Often results in coma or persistent vegetative state.
  • Regeneration: Axonal regeneration is limited in the CNS due to inhibitory factors from oligodendrocytes and glial scar formation by astrocytes. Regeneration is more successful in the PNS, guided by the remaining Schwann cells and endoneurial tube.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the key difference in response to injury: Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the cut, while axonal reaction (chromatolysis) occurs in the proximal cell body.
content.takeAway: Axonal injury triggers a cascade of degenerative and regenerative processes, with the outcome largely determined by the location; peripheral nerves have a significant capacity for regeneration guided by Schwann cells, whereas central nervous system axons are largely unable to regenerate due to an inhibitory environment.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Axon Injury] --> B(Proximal Segment); B --> C(Axonal Reaction/Chromatolysis); A --> D(Distal Segment); D --> E(Wallerian Degeneration);

content.definition: The Babinski reflex (or sign) is the dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes in response to stroking the plantar surface of the foot. While a normal primitive reflex in infants, its presence in an adult is a pathognomonic sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Technique: The sole of the foot is stroked with a blunt object from the heel along the lateral aspect to the ball of the foot.
  • Normal Response (Adult): Plantar flexion (downward curling) of the toes.
  • Abnormal Response (Babinski Sign): Extension (dorsiflexion) of the great toe and fanning of the other toes.
  • Pathophysiology: The sign indicates damage to the corticospinal tract, which normally suppresses this primitive reflex after infancy.
  • Clinical Significance: A positive Babinski sign is a key physical exam finding that helps differentiate UMN lesions from LMN lesions. It is a sign of upper motor neuron damage.
  • USMLE Tip: In an adult, a positive Babinski sign is always abnormal. It points to a lesion anywhere along the corticospinal tract, from the motor cortex down to the spinal cord.
content.takeAway: The Babinski sign is a clinical indicator of corticospinal tract dysfunction, representing the re-emergence of a primitive reflex that is normally suppressed by mature upper motor neurons; its presence in an adult is a definitive sign of a UMN lesion.

content.definition: Baclofen is a centrally acting skeletal muscle relaxant (antispasmodic) that functions as a GABAB receptor agonist, primarily used to treat muscle spasticity.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as an agonist at GABAB receptors in the spinal cord. This activation leads to hyperpolarization of motor neurons by increasing K+ conductance, which reduces the release of excitatory neurotransmitters.
  • Clinical Use: Treatment of spasticity associated with [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], spinal cord injuries, and [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]]. It is not typically used for acute muscle spasms from injury.
  • Administration: Can be administered orally or intrathecally (directly into the CSF) via a pump for severe spasticity.
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, drowsiness, dizziness, and muscle weakness. Abrupt withdrawal of intrathecal baclofen can be life-threatening, causing high fever, rebound spasticity, and seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that baclofen acts on the 'back' (spinal cord) at GABAB receptors. Differentiate its use for chronic spasticity from drugs like cyclobenzaprine used for acute muscle spasms.
content.takeAway: Baclofen effectively reduces chronic muscle spasticity by mimicking GABA's inhibitory effects at GABAB receptors specifically within the spinal cord, thereby dampening the hyperactive reflexes that cause stiffness and spasms.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Baclofen] --> B(Activates GABA-B Receptors in Spinal Cord); B --> C(↑ K+ Conductance); C --> D(Hyperpolarization of Motor Neurons); D --> E(↓ Spasticity);

content.definition: Barbiturates (e.g., phenobarbital, pentobarbital, thiopental) are a class of sedative-hypnotic drugs that act as central nervous system depressants by enhancing the effects of the neurotransmitter GABA.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Bind to the GABAA receptor at a different site than GABA or benzodiazepines. They increase the duration of chloride channel opening. Mnemonic: Barbidurates increase the duration.
  • Clinical Use: Formerly used for anxiety and insomnia but now largely replaced by benzodiazepines due to a worse safety profile. Current uses include:
    - Anticonvulsant: [[phenobarbital]] for seizures.
    - Anesthesia: Thiopental for induction of anesthesia.
  • Adverse Effects: Significant CNS and respiratory depression, which can be fatal in overdose and is potentiated by alcohol. High potential for dependence and abuse. Induces cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to numerous drug interactions.
  • Contraindication: Absolutely contraindicated in patients with porphyria, as they induce δ-ALA synthase.
  • USMLE Tip: The key difference from benzodiazepines is the mechanism (duration vs. frequency) and the lack of a ceiling effect on CNS depression, making overdose much more dangerous. There is no specific antidote for barbiturate overdose; treatment is supportive.
content.takeAway: Barbiturates are potent CNS depressants that enhance GABAergic inhibition by prolonging the opening of chloride channels, but their narrow therapeutic index and high risk of fatal respiratory depression have relegated them to niche uses like seizure control and anesthesia induction.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Barbiturate] --> B(Binds to GABA-A Receptor); B --> C(↑ Duration of Cl- Channel Opening); C --> D(↑ Cl- Influx); D --> E(Hyperpolarization of Neuron); E --> F(CNS Depression);

content.definition: The Basal Ganglia are a group of subcortical nuclei in the forebrain that are crucial for motor control, particularly in selecting and initiating voluntary movements, while suppressing unwanted movements. They also play a role in procedural learning, habit formation, and emotion.
content.atAGlance:
• Components: The main components are the Striatum (caudate nucleus + putamen), Globus Pallidus (internal and external segments), Subthalamic Nucleus, and Substantia Nigra (pars compacta and pars reticulata).
  • Function: The basal ganglia modulate motor output from the cortex via feedback loops. They do not directly connect to the spinal cord.
  • Direct Pathway: Facilitates movement. Cortical activation stimulates the striatum, which inhibits the globus pallidus internus (GPi), thereby disinhibiting the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]] and allowing it to excite the motor cortex.
  • Indirect Pathway: Inhibits movement. This more complex loop ultimately results in stimulation of the GPi, which increases inhibition of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]], thus suppressing cortical activity.
  • Pathology: Lesions in the basal ganglia lead to movement disorders.
    - [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta leads to bradykinesia and tremor (hypokinetic).
    - [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]: Degeneration of the striatum leads to chorea (hyperkinetic).
    - Hemiballismus: Lesion of the subthalamic nucleus leads to wild, flinging movements.
content.takeAway: The Basal Ganglia function as a sophisticated 'gatekeeper' for motor commands, using a balance between a 'go' (direct) pathway and a 'no-go' (indirect) pathway to fine-tune voluntary movement; disruption of this balance is the fundamental cause of movement disorders like Parkinson's and Huntington's disease.
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[Cortex] --> B(Striatum); B --|Direct Pathway (Go)|--> C(↓ GPi/SNr Inhibition); C --> D(↑ Thalamic Excitation); D --> A; B --|Indirect Pathway (No-Go)|--> E(↑ GPi/SNr Inhibition); E --> F(↓ Thalamic Excitation); F --> A;

content.definition: The Basal Nucleus of Meynert is a group of neurons located in the substantia innominata of the basal forebrain. It is the primary source of cholinergic ([[6a005559|acetylcholine]]) innervation to the entire cerebral cortex, playing a vital role in cognitive functions like memory and attention.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Basal forebrain, part of the substantia innominata.
  • Neurotransmitter: Synthesizes and releases [[6a005559|acetylcholine (ACh)]].
  • Projections: Provides widespread cholinergic projections to the neocortex and hippocampus.
  • Function: Modulates cortical excitability, arousal, attention, and is critical for learning and memory formation.
  • Clinical Relevance: There is significant degeneration and loss of cholinergic neurons in the Basal Nucleus of Meynert in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]. This loss of cortical ACh is a major contributor to the cognitive and memory deficits seen in the disease.
  • USMLE Tip: The degeneration of the Basal Nucleus of Meynert and the resulting cholinergic deficit is a key pathophysiological feature of [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and is the rationale for using [[acetylcholinesterase_inhibitors|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., [[47d0372e|donepezil]]) as a symptomatic treatment.
content.takeAway: The Basal Nucleus of Meynert is the brain's main cholinergic hub for the cortex; its profound degeneration in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] leads to a cortical acetylcholine deficit that underlies the hallmark cognitive decline of the disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Basal Nucleus of Meynert] --ACh Projections--> B(Cerebral Cortex & Hippocampus); B --> C(Arousal, Memory, Attention); A --x Degeneration in Alzheimer's;

content.definition: The Basal Plate is the ventral part of the neural tube in the developing embryo, which differentiates into motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem under the influence of the signaling molecule Sonic Hedgehog (SHH).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Ventral (anterior) region of the developing spinal cord and brainstem.
  • Function: Gives rise to motor components of the central nervous system, including the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves.
  • Inducing Signal: Development is induced by Sonic Hedgehog (SHH), a signaling molecule secreted by the underlying notochord.
  • Counterpart: The dorsal counterpart is the [[43be7a6e|Alar Plate]], which develops into sensory neurons under the influence of Bone Morphogenetic Proteins (BMPs).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the simple orientation: Basal = Motor = Ventral, and Alar = Sensory = Dorsal. This fundamental organization persists into the adult CNS.
content.takeAway: The Basal Plate is the embryonic blueprint for the motor output of the CNS, established by Sonic Hedgehog signaling from the notochord, which sets up the ventral-motor organization of the neural tube that is conserved throughout the nervous system.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Neural Tube] --> B(Alar Plate - Dorsal); A --> C(Basal Plate - Ventral); D[Ectoderm] --BMPs--> B; B --> E[Sensory Neurons]; F[Notochord] --SHH--> C; C --> G[Motor Neurons];

content.definition: In the central nervous system, the basement membrane is a thin, specialized layer of the extracellular matrix that surrounds cerebral capillaries and, along with astrocyte foot processes and endothelial tight junctions, forms a critical component of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
content.atAGlance:
• Composition: Primarily composed of Type IV collagen, laminin, and proteoglycans.
  • Function: Provides structural support to the capillary endothelium and acts as a selective filter, regulating the passage of molecules from the blood into the brain parenchyma.
  • Role in Blood-Brain Barrier: The basement membrane, together with endothelial [[tight_junctions|tight junctions]] and astrocyte end-feet, creates the highly restrictive [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
  • Pathology: Thickening of the basement membrane is a feature of chronic hyperglycemia in diabetes, contributing to microvascular complications like [[73b00ab0|diabetic retinopathy]]. In [[goodpasture_syndrome|Goodpasture syndrome]], autoantibodies target Type IV collagen in the basement membranes of the kidneys and lungs.
  • USMLE Tip: The three key components of the blood-brain barrier are: 1) Tight junctions between non-fenestrated endothelial cells, 2) The basement membrane, and 3) Astrocyte foot processes.
content.takeAway: The basement membrane of CNS capillaries is a crucial structural and functional element of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]], acting as both scaffolding and a selective filter to maintain the tightly controlled environment of the brain.

content.definition: The Basilar Artery is a critical artery at the base of the brain, formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries. It ascends along the anterior surface of the pons and is a key component of the posterior circulation, supplying the brainstem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes.
content.atAGlance:
• Formation: Formed by the confluence of the left and right vertebral arteries at the pontomedullary junction.
  • Branches: Gives rise to the [[3c075343|anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)]], superior cerebellar artery (SCA), and numerous small pontine arteries. It terminates by bifurcating into the two [[b6a2cc31|posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs)]].
  • Territory Supplied: Brainstem (pons, midbrain), cerebellum, and via its terminal branches (PCAs), the occipital and inferior temporal lobes.
  • Stroke Syndromes:
    - Basilar Artery Occlusion: Can be catastrophic, leading to "locked-in syndrome" if the ventral pons is infarcted bilaterally. This causes quadriplegia and mutism, with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements.
    - Top of the Basilar Syndrome: Embolic occlusion of the distal basilar artery affects the midbrain, thalamus, and temporal/occipital lobes, causing visual and behavioral disturbances with minimal motor deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: A stroke causing quadriplegia but sparing consciousness and vertical eye movements is pathognomonic for basilar artery occlusion leading to locked-in syndrome.
content.takeAway: The Basilar Artery is the central trunk of the posterior circulation; its occlusion can lead to devastating brainstem strokes, most notably the 'locked-in syndrome,' which severs the brain's motor output while leaving consciousness intact.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Vertebral Arteries] --> B(Basilar Artery); B --> C(Pontine Arteries); B --> D(AICA); B --> E(SCA); B --> F(PCAs);

content.definition: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia characterized by the loss of normal muscle atonia during REM sleep, leading to the physical enactment of vivid, often violent or action-filled dreams.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Failure of the brainstem mechanisms (particularly in the pons) that normally induce muscle paralysis during REM sleep.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients may shout, punch, kick, or jump out of bed during sleep, corresponding to the content of their dreams. This can result in injury to the patient or their bed partner.
  • Classic Association: RBD is a very strong predictor of future neurodegenerative disease, particularly α-synucleinopathies.
  • Associated Diseases: A majority of patients with idiopathic RBD will eventually develop [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]], or multiple system atrophy, often years or decades after the onset of RBD.
  • USMLE Tip: An older male patient who reports acting out violent dreams and has injured his spouse during sleep should raise immediate suspicion for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder, which should be considered a prodromal sign of Parkinson disease or Lewy body dementia.
content.takeAway: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder is more than just a sleep disturbance; it is a critical early warning sign of an underlying α-synucleinopathy, where the failure to paralyze muscles during dreaming precedes the onset of motor and cognitive symptoms of diseases like Parkinson's by many years.

content.definition: Behavior modulation refers to the complex neural processes by which the brain regulates and controls behavior, integrating emotional, cognitive, and homeostatic inputs to produce appropriate responses. This function is primarily orchestrated by the [[73ace357|limbic system]] and its connections with the prefrontal cortex and [[89e86633|hypothalamus]].
content.atAGlance:
• Limbic System's Role: The [[73ace357|limbic system]] (including the [[d220fc3f|amygdala]], [[a0590674|hippocampus]], and cingulate gyrus) is central to emotion, memory, and motivation, which are the core drivers of behavior.
  • Amygdala: Processes fear, aggression, and reward. Lesions can lead to placidity or disinhibited behavior (e.g., [[kluver_bucy_syndrome|Klüver-Bucy syndrome]]).
  • Hypothalamus: Integrates autonomic and endocrine responses with behavior, governing fundamental drives like hunger, thirst, and sexual behavior (the 'Four Fs': Feeding, Fleeing, Fighting, and sexual Functioning).
  • Prefrontal Cortex: Provides top-down executive control, inhibiting impulsive behaviors and guiding actions based on goals and social context. Lesions can cause disinhibition and impaired judgment.
  • USMLE Tip: The mnemonic for limbic system functions, the '5 F's' (Feeding, Fleeing, Fighting, Feeling, and Sex), highlights its role in modulating fundamental behaviors.
content.takeAway: Behavior modulation is a dynamic interplay between the primitive drives of the [[73ace357|limbic system]] and [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] and the executive oversight of the prefrontal cortex, with the final behavioral output reflecting the balance of these competing influences.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Limbic System - Emotion/Drives] --> C{Behavioral Output}; B[Prefrontal Cortex - Executive Control] --> C;

content.definition: Benzocaine is an ester-type local anesthetic used topically to numb surfaces such as the skin, mouth, and throat. It works by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels in nerve membranes, thereby preventing the propagation of action potentials.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels, preventing nerve depolarization.
  • Class: Ester local anesthetic. Patients with allergies to esters (e.g., procaine) may also react to benzocaine.
  • Clinical Use: Commonly found in over-the-counter products for teething pain, sore throats (sprays), and sunburn relief. Used in medical settings as a topical anesthetic for procedures like endoscopy.
  • Adverse Effect: A well-known cause of acquired methemoglobinemia, especially in infants and young children.
  • Methemoglobinemia: Benzocaine oxidizes the iron in hemoglobin from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state. Methemoglobin cannot bind oxygen, leading to functional anemia and cyanosis that does not improve with supplemental oxygen. Blood appears 'chocolate brown'. Treated with methylene blue.
  • USMLE Tip: A vignette describing a patient who develops cyanosis and shortness of breath shortly after an endoscopic procedure (where a topical anesthetic spray was used) should immediately raise suspicion for benzocaine-induced methemoglobinemia.
content.takeAway: Benzocaine is a widely used topical anesthetic that carries the rare but life-threatening risk of inducing methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin's iron is oxidized, rendering it unable to transport oxygen and causing a characteristic 'chocolate brown' blood appearance and cyanosis.

content.definition: Benzodiazepines are a class of psychoactive drugs that act as positive allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor, resulting in sedative, hypnotic, anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, and muscle relaxant properties.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Bind to an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor, increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening in response to GABA. Mnemonic: Frenzodiazepines increase frequency.
  • Clinical Uses: Anxiety disorders, panic attacks, status epilepticus (lorazepam, diazepam), alcohol withdrawal, insomnia, and procedural sedation/anesthesia (midazolam).
  • Pharmacokinetics: Classified by duration of action. Short-acting (e.g., [[083094db|alprazolam]], midazolam) have higher abuse potential. Long-acting (e.g., diazepam, chlordiazepoxide) are preferred for alcohol withdrawal. Those not metabolized by the liver (Oxazepam, Temazepam, Lorazepam - 'Outside The Liver') are safer in patients with hepatic dysfunction.
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, dependence, tolerance, withdrawal symptoms. Additive CNS depression with other depressants like alcohol and barbiturates.
  • Antidote: Overdose can be treated with flumazenil, a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABAA receptor.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[52564aea|barbiturates]], which increase the duration of channel opening and have a higher risk of fatal respiratory depression.
content.takeAway: Benzodiazepines are versatile CNS depressants that enhance GABA's inhibitory effects by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening, but their use is tempered by the significant risks of dependence and additive depression with other substances.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Benzodiazepine] --> B(Binds to GABA-A Receptor); B --> C(↑ Frequency of Cl- Channel Opening); C --> D(↑ Cl- Influx); D --> E(Hyperpolarization of Neuron); E --> F(CNS Depression/Anxiolysis);

content.definition: Benztropine is a centrally acting antimuscarinic (anticholinergic) drug used primarily to treat the symptoms of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and to manage extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) caused by antipsychotic medications.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at central muscarinic receptors, helping to restore the dopaminergic-cholinergic balance in the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] that is disrupted in Parkinson's disease.
  • Clinical Use (Parkinson's): Primarily effective for treating tremor and rigidity. It has little effect on bradykinesia. Mnemonic: 'Tri to Park my Mercedes-Benz' (Trihexyphenidyl and Benztropine for Parkinson's).
  • Clinical Use (EPS): Effective for treating acute dystonia and drug-induced parkinsonism caused by dopamine antagonists (antipsychotics).
  • Adverse Effects: Classic anticholinergic side effects: dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, urinary retention, tachycardia, and confusion/delirium, especially in the elderly.
  • USMLE Tip: Benztropine is the go-to drug for treating a patient who develops an acute dystonic reaction (e.g., torticollis, oculogyric crisis) after starting an antipsychotic like haloperidol.
content.takeAway: Benztropine combats the motor symptoms of Parkinson's and antipsychotic side effects by blocking central acetylcholine activity, thereby counteracting the relative cholinergic overactivity that results from dopamine deficiency or blockade in the basal ganglia.

content.definition: A Berry Aneurysm, also known as a saccular aneurysm, is a thin-walled, sac-like outpouching of a cerebral artery, typically located at arterial branch points within the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]]. Its rupture is the most common cause of non-traumatic [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Most commonly found at the junction of the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery (AComA)]] with the anterior cerebral artery. The second most common site is the junction of the posterior communicating artery (PComA) with the internal carotid artery.
  • Pathophysiology: Believed to form due to a congenital weakness in the vessel wall (lack of tunica media) at arterial bifurcations, which is exacerbated over time by hemodynamic stress from hypertension.
  • Associated Conditions: Increased incidence in patients with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD), Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and Marfan syndrome.
  • Clinical Presentation: Usually asymptomatic until rupture. Rupture causes a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]], presenting with a sudden, explosive "worst headache of my life."
  • USMLE Tip: A PComA aneurysm can compress the ipsilateral [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]], causing a painful third nerve palsy with a dilated, nonreactive pupil ('blown pupil'). This is a neurosurgical emergency.
content.takeAway: Berry aneurysms are silent vascular time bombs located at the branch points of the Circle of Willis; their rupture leads to a devastating subarachnoid hemorrhage, classically presenting as a 'thunderclap headache'.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Arterial Bifurcation in Circle of Willis] --> B(Congenital Wall Weakness); B --Hypertension--> C(Berry Aneurysm Formation); C --> D{Rupture}; D --> E[Subarachnoid Hemorrhage];

content.definition: Betaxolol is a β1-selective adrenergic antagonist (beta-blocker) used primarily in ophthalmology as eye drops to treat [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]] and ocular hypertension. It is also available in oral form for the treatment of systemic hypertension.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action (Glaucoma): When applied topically to the eye, it blocks β-adrenergic receptors on the ciliary epithelium, leading to a decrease in aqueous humor production and thus lowering intraocular pressure.
  • Selectivity: As a β1-selective blocker, it has less of an effect on β2 receptors in the lungs compared to non-selective beta-blockers like timolol.
  • Clinical Use: Used to treat [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]]. Its β1-selectivity makes it a safer option for patients with asthma or COPD compared to non-selective beta-blockers.
  • Adverse Effects: Ocular effects can include stinging and burning. Although it is β1-selective, systemic absorption can still occur and may cause bradycardia, hypotension, and fatigue. Caution is still advised in patients with respiratory conditions.
  • USMLE Tip: For a glaucoma patient with a history of asthma, a β1-selective blocker like betaxolol is a more appropriate choice than a non-selective one like timolol to minimize the risk of bronchoconstriction.
content.takeAway: Betaxolol lowers intraocular pressure in glaucoma by reducing aqueous humor production, and its key feature is its β1-selectivity, which offers a safer profile for patients with underlying pulmonary disease compared to non-selective beta-blockers.

content.definition: The Biceps reflex is a deep tendon reflex that causes flexion of the elbow when the biceps brachii tendon is tapped. It is used to test the integrity of the C5 and C6 spinal nerve roots and the musculocutaneous nerve.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: Primarily tests the C5 nerve root, with a contribution from C6. Mnemonic: C5, 6, pick up sticks.
  • Pathway: Tapping the biceps tendon stretches the muscle spindle in the biceps muscle. The afferent signal travels via the musculocutaneous nerve to the C5/C6 spinal cord segments. It synapses with a motor neuron, and the efferent signal returns via the musculocutaneous nerve to cause contraction of the biceps muscle and elbow flexion.
  • Diminished/Absent Reflex: Suggests a lower motor neuron lesion, such as a herniated disc compressing the C5 root or a peripheral neuropathy affecting the musculocutaneous nerve.
  • Exaggerated Reflex (Hyperreflexia): Suggests an upper motor neuron lesion, such as a stroke or spinal cord injury above the C5 level.
  • USMLE Tip: The biceps reflex, along with sensation over the lateral arm and deltoid/biceps strength, is a key part of the C5 neurological exam.
content.takeAway: The Biceps reflex is a fundamental component of the neurological exam, providing a quick and reliable assessment of the C5 and C6 nerve roots and the integrity of the reflex arc through the cervical spinal cord.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Tap Biceps Tendon] --> B(Stretch Biceps Muscle); B --> C(Afferent Signal via Musculocutaneous N.); C --> D[C5/C6 Spinal Cord]; D --> E(Efferent Signal via Musculocutaneous N.); E --> F(Biceps Contraction/Elbow Flexion);

content.definition: Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin analog used topically as an eye drop to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]] or ocular hypertension.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: It is a synthetic prostamide analog that mimics the action of prostaglandins (specifically PGF2α). It lowers IOP by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor through the secondary, or uveoscleral pathway.
  • Clinical Use: A first-line agent for the treatment of [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]] due to its high efficacy and once-daily dosing.
  • Adverse Effects: The most common side effects are ocular hyperemia (redness), stinging, and a notable cosmetic side effect of increased eyelash growth (length and darkness). A permanent side effect can be darkening of the iris color (browning).
  • Comparison: Other prostaglandin analogs include latanoprost and travoprost, all sharing a similar mechanism and side effect profile.
  • USMLE Tip: The unique side effect of eyelash growth has been exploited for cosmetic use (Latisse). Remember that prostaglandin analogs work by increasing outflow, whereas beta-blockers decrease production of aqueous humor.
content.takeAway: Bimatoprost is a highly effective first-line glaucoma medication that lowers eye pressure by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, with the well-known and cosmetically exploited side effect of promoting eyelash growth.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Bimatoprost] --> B(Acts on Prostaglandin Receptors); B --> C(↑ Uveoscleral Outflow); C --> D(↓ Intraocular Pressure);

content.definition: Bitemporal hemianopia is a specific type of partial blindness characterized by the loss of vision in the outer (temporal) halves of the visual fields of both eyes. It is classically caused by a lesion compressing the central part of the optic chiasm.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Loss of the temporal (lateral) visual fields in both eyes, often described as "tunnel vision."
  • Pathophysiology: The optic chiasm is where the nasal retinal fibers from each eye decussate (cross over). These nasal fibers are responsible for perceiving the temporal visual fields. A midline lesion at the chiasm selectively damages these crossing fibers.
  • Classic Cause: The most common cause is a [[5f3188bd|pituitary adenoma]] growing upward from the sella turcica and compressing the chiasm from below.
  • Other Causes: Other suprasellar masses like a [[7048db1e|craniopharyngioma]] or an aneurysm of the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery]] can also cause this defect.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient presenting with "tunnel vision" or complaining of bumping into things on either side, especially if accompanied by endocrine symptoms (e.g., galactorrhea, acromegaly), is a classic vignette for a [[5f3188bd|pituitary adenoma]] causing bitemporal hemianopia.
content.takeAway: Bitemporal hemianopia is the quintessential sign of optic chiasm compression, resulting from the selective damage to the crossing nasal retinal fibers and creating a characteristic 'tunnel vision' that points directly to a midline suprasellar pathology like a pituitary adenoma.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lesion at Optic Chiasm] --Compresses--> B(Crossing Nasal Retinal Fibers); B --> C(Loss of Temporal Visual Fields); C --> D(Bitemporal Hemianopia);

content.definition: Blepharitis is a common inflammatory condition of the eyelids, typically involving the part of the eyelid where the eyelashes grow. It is characterized by inflammation, irritation, itching, and crusting of the eyelid margins.
content.atAGlance:
• Anterior Blepharitis: Affects the outside front of the eyelid, where the eyelashes are attached. Often caused by bacteria (Staphylococcus) or seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Posterior Blepharitis: Affects the inner eyelid (the moist part that makes contact with the eye). Caused by dysfunction of the meibomian glands (Meibomian Gland Dysfunction - MGD). Associated with skin conditions like rosacea.
  • Symptoms: Red, swollen, or itchy eyelids; gritty or burning sensation in the eyes; crusty debris at the base of the eyelashes upon waking; flaking of skin around the eyes.
  • Complications: Can lead to [[hordeolum|hordeola (styes)]], [[193c24ec|chalazia]], dry eyes, or chronic conjunctivitis.
  • Treatment: The cornerstone of treatment is eyelid hygiene, including warm compresses and gentle scrubbing of the eyelid margins. Topical antibiotics or steroids may be used in some cases.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a patient complaining of chronic eye irritation with crusting on the eyelashes, especially in the morning. This is a classic description of blepharitis.
content.takeAway: Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the eyelid margins, akin to dandruff of the eyelashes, which is managed primarily through diligent eyelid hygiene to control symptoms and prevent complications like styes and chalazia.

content.definition: The Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) is a highly selective semipermeable border of endothelial cells that prevents solutes in the circulating blood from non-selectively crossing into the extracellular fluid of the central nervous system where neurons reside.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Components:
    1. [[5206aa83|Tight junctions]] between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells.
    2. A thick [[c335e16d|Basement Membrane]].
    3. Astrocyte foot processes that surround the capillary.
