• Etiology: Caused by a mass or pressure increase in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellar tumor, hemorrhage, or edema). It can also be iatrogenically caused by performing a lumbar puncture in the setting of high intracranial pressure.
  • Pathophysiology: The herniating tonsils directly compress the medulla oblongata.
  • Clinical Presentation: This is a rapidly fatal event. Compression of the medullary cardiorespiratory centers leads to bradycardia, respiratory arrest, and death. Patients may also present with headache, neck stiffness, and loss of consciousness.
  • Associated Malformation: This type of herniation is the defining feature of [[b96a6a07|Chiari I and II malformations]], although in those congenital conditions, the process is chronic rather than acute.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic scenario is a patient with signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, papilledema) who undergoes a lumbar puncture and then rapidly deteriorates with respiratory arrest. This highlights the danger of LP in the setting of unevaluated increased ICP.
content.takeAway: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation is the most lethal form of brain herniation, as the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum directly compresses the vital cardiorespiratory centers in the medulla, leading to swift respiratory and cardiac arrest.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Posterior Fossa Pressure] --> B(Cerebellar Tonsils Displace Downward); B --> C(Through Foramen Magnum); C --Compresses--> D(Medulla Oblongata); D --> E(Cardiorespiratory Arrest);

content.definition: Lesions of the cerebellar vermis, the midline portion of the cerebellum, result in a specific set of motor deficits related to the control of the trunk and axial musculature, as well as eye movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Anatomical Correlation: The vermis is centrally located and primarily controls the central body (trunk).
  • Hallmark Sign: Truncal ataxia. This manifests as an unsteady, wide-based gait often described as a "drunken sailor" gait. Patients have difficulty sitting or standing upright without swaying or falling.
  • Ocular Signs: Nystagmus and other impairments of eye movement control are common due to the vermis's connections with the vestibular nuclei.
  • Speech: Dysarthria (slurred, uncoordinated speech) can also occur.
  • Etiology: In adults, degeneration of the vermis is classically associated with chronic alcohol overuse. In children, a [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] is a common cause of a vermal lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate vermal lesions from cerebellar hemisphere lesions. Vermis lesion = truncal ataxia (midline problems). Hemisphere lesion = limb ataxia, intention tremor (lateral problems).
content.takeAway: A lesion of the cerebellar vermis selectively impairs control of the body's midline, leading to a profound truncal ataxia that makes stable standing and walking difficult, a presentation classically linked to chronic alcoholism in adults or medulloblastoma in children.

content.definition: The Cerebellum (Latin for "little brain") is a major feature of the hindbrain located posterior to the pons and medulla. It plays a crucial role in modulating motor commands to control balance, coordination, and precision of voluntary movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Modulates movement; aids in coordination, balance, and motor learning. It does not initiate movement but fine-tunes it.
  • Anatomical Divisions:
    - Vermis (midline): Controls axial and proximal limb musculature (truncal stability).
    - Hemispheres (lateral): Control distal limb musculature (limb coordination).
    - Flocculonodular Lobe: Involved in balance and eye movements via connections with the vestibular system.
  • Input/Output: Receives proprioceptive input from the spinal cord (ipsilateral) and motor plan input from the contralateral cortex. It sends output to the contralateral cortex via the thalamus to modulate movement. Each cerebellar hemisphere controls the ipsilateral side of the body.
  • Lesions: Cerebellar lesions cause ipsilateral deficits. Vermal lesions cause truncal ataxia. Hemispheric lesions cause limb ataxia, dysmetria, and intention tremor.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that cerebellar signs are ipsilateral to the lesion. A patient who falls to the left has a left-sided cerebellar lesion.
content.takeAway: The Cerebellum acts as the brain's master coordinator, comparing the intended movement from the cortex with the actual movement from proprioceptive feedback, and issuing corrective signals to ensure smooth, balanced, and accurate motor activity.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cortex] --Motor Plan--> B(Cerebellum); C[Spinal Cord] --Proprioception--> B; B --Corrective Signals--> A;

content.definition: The Cerebral Aqueduct (also known as the Aqueduct of Sylvius) is a narrow channel within the midbrain that connects the third ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle in the hindbrain, allowing for the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Traverses the midbrain.
  • Function: Serves as a conduit for CSF flow from the third to the fourth ventricle.
  • Clinical Significance: Due to its narrow diameter, the cerebral aqueduct is a common site for obstruction, leading to non-communicating hydrocephalus.
  • Causes of Stenosis:
    - Congenital: Can be congenitally narrow (aqueductal stenosis), sometimes as an X-linked condition.
    - Acquired: Can be compressed by tumors (e.g., pinealoma, brainstem glioma) or blocked by inflammation/hemorrhage.
  • Presentation of Obstruction: In infants, presents with an enlarging head circumference. In adults, presents with signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, papilledema, vomiting).
  • USMLE Tip: A CT or MRI showing enlarged lateral and third ventricles with a normal-sized fourth ventricle is the classic imaging finding for aqueductal stenosis.
content.takeAway: The Cerebral Aqueduct is a critical but vulnerable bottleneck in the CSF pathway; its obstruction leads to a backup of CSF and non-communicating hydrocephalus, effectively damming the flow between the third and fourth ventricles.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lateral Ventricles] --> B(Third Ventricle); B --> C(Cerebral Aqueduct); C --Obstruction--> D(Non-communicating Hydrocephalus); C --> E(Fourth Ventricle);

content.definition: The Cerebral Arteries are the network of blood vessels that supply oxygenated blood to the brain. They are broadly divided into the anterior circulation (derived from the internal carotid arteries) and the posterior circulation (derived from the vertebral arteries), which are connected by the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]].
content.atAGlance:
• Anterior Circulation: Includes the [[830c856c|Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)]] and the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Posterior Circulation: Includes the vertebral arteries, the [[e7a90cd9|basilar artery]], and the [[b6a2cc31|Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)]].
  • Cortical Distribution: Each major artery supplies a distinct territory of the cerebral cortex:
    - ACA: Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes (supplying the leg/foot area of the motor/sensory homunculus).
    - MCA: Lateral surface of the hemispheres (supplying the face/arm/hand area and language centers).
    - PCA: Occipital lobe and inferior surface of the temporal lobe (supplying the visual cortex).
  • Watershed Zones: Areas at the border between two major arterial territories (e.g., ACA-MCA) are vulnerable to ischemia during systemic hypoperfusion, leading to watershed infarcts.
  • USMLE Tip: Knowing the cortical distribution of the ACA, MCA, and PCA is essential for localizing stroke lesions from clinical symptoms.
content.takeAway: The brain's arterial supply is precisely organized, with the cerebral arteries each irrigating specific functional territories; this anatomical consistency allows clinicians to predict the location of a stroke based on the patient's neurological deficits.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Circle of Willis] --> B(Anterior Cerebral Artery); A --> C(Middle Cerebral Artery); A --> D(Posterior Cerebral Artery);

content.definition: The Cerebral Cortex is the outermost layer of the cerebrum, composed of gray matter (neuronal cell bodies). It is responsible for higher-order brain functions, including consciousness, thought, language, memory, and sensation.
content.atAGlance:
• Lobes: Divided into four main lobes: Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, and Occipital.
  • Functional Regions: Contains specialized areas for processing different types of information:
    - Frontal Lobe: Motor control (primary motor cortex), executive function (prefrontal cortex), speech production ([[a3bbace2|Broca's area]]).
    - Parietal Lobe: Somatosensation (primary somatosensory cortex), spatial awareness.
    - Temporal Lobe: Audition ([[d24b6af6|auditory cortex]]), language comprehension ([[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]]), memory ([[a0590674|hippocampus]]).
    - Occipital Lobe: Vision (primary visual cortex).
  • Arterial Distribution: Supplied by the [[e51a7691|cerebral arteries]]: [[830c856c|ACA]] (medial), [[143bb23d|MCA]] (lateral), [[b6a2cc31|PCA]] (posterior/inferior).
  • Clinical Syndromes: Lesions produce specific deficits, e.g., [[6bc9a567|aphasia]] (dominant hemisphere), hemineglect (non-dominant parietal lobe), [[ff289b3a|visual field defects]].
  • USMLE Tip: The homunculus is a key concept, mapping motor and sensory functions of the body onto the precentral and postcentral gyri, respectively.
content.takeAway: The Cerebral Cortex is the seat of higher cognition, with its intricately folded surface housing specialized regions for every aspect of conscious experience, from moving a finger to understanding language.

content.definition: Cerebral edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the intracellular or extracellular spaces of the brain, leading to an increase in brain volume and intracranial pressure (ICP).
content.atAGlance:
• Vasogenic Edema: The most common type. Caused by the breakdown of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]], allowing plasma proteins and fluid to leak into the extracellular space. Occurs with tumors, inflammation, and late-stage [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]].
  • Cytotoxic Edema: Involves swelling of the brain cells themselves (intracellular edema) due to failure of the Na+/K+ pump, leading to an influx of Na+ and water. Occurs early in [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] and other toxic/metabolic insults.
  • Clinical Consequences: Increased ICP can cause headache, vomiting, altered consciousness, and can lead to life-threatening [[8c0728b7|brain herniation]].
  • Treatment: Management aims to reduce ICP. This includes head elevation, osmotic therapy (mannitol, hypertonic saline), and therapeutic hyperventilation.
  • Therapeutic Hyperventilation: Intentionally lowering PaCO2 causes cerebral vasoconstriction, which reduces cerebral blood flow and thereby decreases ICP. This is a temporary measure.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the two main types: Vasogenic = leaky vessels (extracellular fluid), Cytotoxic = sick cells (intracellular fluid).
content.takeAway: Cerebral edema is a dangerous swelling of the brain that can be either vasogenic (leaky vessels) or cytotoxic (swollen cells), both of which increase intracranial pressure and risk herniation; management strategies like hyperventilation work by manipulating cerebral blood flow to reduce brain volume.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brain Insult] --> B{Types of Edema}; B --> C[Vasogenic]; C --> D(↑ BBB Permeability); D --> E(Extracellular Fluid); B --> F[Cytotoxic]; F --> G(Na+/K+ Pump Failure); G --> H(Intracellular Fluid); E & H --> I(↑ Intracranial Pressure);

content.definition: Cerebral Palsy (CP) is a non-progressive disorder of movement, muscle tone, or posture caused by damage to the immature, developing brain, most often before birth. It is the most common motor disability in childhood.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: A static (non-progressive) brain lesion that occurs prenatally, perinatally, or in early infancy. Major risk factors include prematurity and low birth weight. Other causes include intrauterine infections, birth asphyxia, and neonatal stroke.
  • Clinical Presentation: The primary feature is impaired motor function. The type of motor impairment depends on the location of the brain injury:
    - Spastic CP (most common): UMN lesion signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia).
    - Dyskinetic CP: Basal ganglia damage (athetosis, chorea).
    - Ataxic CP: Cerebellar damage (ataxia, incoordination).
  • Associated Conditions: Patients often have associated comorbidities, including intellectual disability, seizures, and sensory impairments (vision, hearing).
  • Treatment: Management is multidisciplinary and supportive, aimed at maximizing function. Treatments for spasticity include physical therapy, oral medications ([[1ddc3f08|baclofen]], tizanidine), and [[84b10400|botulinum toxin]] injections.
  • USMLE Tip: Cerebral palsy is a non-progressive motor disorder. If a child's motor symptoms are worsening over time, another diagnosis should be considered. Prematurity is the single most important risk factor.
content.takeAway: Cerebral Palsy is a permanent but non-progressive motor disorder resulting from an early-life brain injury, manifesting as a spectrum of movement and posture problems, with spasticity being the most common presentation.

content.definition: Cerebral perfusion refers to the blood flow to the brain tissue. It is tightly autoregulated to ensure a constant supply of oxygen and glucose, and is primarily driven by the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) and influenced by chemical factors, most notably PaCO2.
content.atAGlance:
• Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP): The net pressure gradient driving blood flow to the brain. It is calculated as: CPP = Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) - Intracranial Pressure (ICP). A normal CPP is >60 mmHg.
  • Autoregulation: Cerebral blood flow (CBF) is kept relatively constant over a wide range of MAP (approx. 60-140 mmHg). Outside this range, CBF becomes pressure-dependent.
  • Chemical Regulation:
    - PaCO2: The most potent regulator of CBF. Hypercapnia (↑ PaCO2) causes vasodilation and ↑ CBF. Hypocapnia (↓ PaCO2) causes vasoconstriction and ↓ CBF.
    - PaO2: Has little effect unless severe hypoxia (PaO2 < 50 mmHg) occurs, which causes marked vasodilation and ↑ CBF.
  • Clinical Application: In patients with increased ICP, therapeutic hyperventilation is used to induce hypocapnia, causing vasoconstriction and a temporary reduction in ICP.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the direct relationship between PaCO2 and cerebral blood flow. This is the physiological basis for using hyperventilation to manage acute cerebral edema.
content.takeAway: Cerebral perfusion is a tightly controlled process where the brain maintains its own blood flow despite fluctuations in systemic pressure, with carbon dioxide levels acting as the most powerful local controller of cerebral vessel diameter.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[MAP] --> B(CPP); C[ICP] --> B; B --> D(Cerebral Blood Flow); E[PaCO2] --Potent Regulator--> D;

content.definition: Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives blood flow to the brain. It is a critical parameter in the management of patients with brain injury, as inadequate CPP can lead to cerebral ischemia.
content.atAGlance:
• Formula: CPP = Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) - Intracranial Pressure (ICP).
  • Normal Value: A normal CPP is typically maintained between 60 and 80 mmHg. A CPP below 50-60 mmHg can result in cerebral ischemia.
  • Relationship with CBF: Cerebral blood flow (CBF) is directly proportional to CPP and inversely proportional to cerebral vascular resistance (CVR). (CBF = CPP / CVR).
  • Clinical Management: In patients with elevated ICP (e.g., from trauma, hemorrhage, or [[aa00bdef|cerebral edema]]), management focuses on both lowering ICP (e.g., mannitol, hyperventilation) and maintaining an adequate MAP (e.g., with vasopressors) to ensure sufficient CPP.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the formula. If a patient's MAP drops or their ICP rises, their CPP will decrease, putting them at risk for brain ischemia. If CPP = 0, there is no cerebral perfusion, which is consistent with [[1777e176|brain death]].
content.takeAway: Cerebral Perfusion Pressure is the critical driving force for brain blood flow, representing the balance between the systemic pressure pushing blood in (MAP) and the intracranial pressure pushing back (ICP); maintaining this pressure is paramount in neurocritical care.

content.definition: Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) is a clear, colorless body fluid found in the brain and spinal cord. It is produced by the choroid plexus, circulates through the ventricular system and subarachnoid space, and is eventually reabsorbed into the venous circulation, providing buoyancy, protection, and chemical stability for the CNS.
content.atAGlance:
• Production: Produced by the choroid plexus within the ventricles at a rate of about 20 mL/hr.
  • Circulation Pathway: Lateral ventricles → foramen of Monro → third ventricle → [[8a30e721|cerebral aqueduct]] → fourth ventricle → foramina of Luschka & Magendie → subarachnoid space.
  • Reabsorption: Reabsorbed into the venous circulation via the [[b7b67074|arachnoid granulations]], which project into the superior sagittal sinus.
  • Normal Composition: Clear, colorless, with very few cells (<5 lymphocytes/mm3), low protein (<45 mg/dL), and glucose that is approximately 2/3 of the serum glucose level.
  • Diagnostic Use: CSF analysis via lumbar puncture is crucial for diagnosing meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], and other CNS disorders. For example, [[a0f3ce4c|albuminocytologic dissociation]] is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the characteristic CSF findings for different types of meningitis: Bacterial (↑ PMNs, ↓ glucose, ↑ protein), Viral (↑ lymphocytes, normal glucose), Fungal/TB (↑ lymphocytes, ↓ glucose).
content.takeAway: Cerebrospinal Fluid is the brain's life-support system, providing a protective cushion and a stable chemical environment through a continuous cycle of production by the choroid plexus, circulation through the ventricles, and reabsorption by the arachnoid granulations.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choroid Plexus] --Production--> B(CSF in Ventricles); B --Circulation--> C(Subarachnoid Space); C --Reabsorption--> D(Arachnoid Granulations); D --> E[Venous Sinuses];

content.definition: A chalazion is a common, benign, inflammatory lump in the eyelid caused by a blocked meibomian gland. It is a granulomatous reaction to the lipids that leak from the obstructed gland.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Obstruction of a meibomian gland (a modified sebaceous gland in the tarsal plate) leads to leakage of lipid contents into the surrounding tissue, inciting a granulomatous inflammatory response.
  • Clinical Presentation: A firm, rubbery, painless nodule within the eyelid. It is typically slow-growing and not located on the eyelid margin itself.
  • Differentiation from Hordeolum (Stye): A [[hordeolum]] is an acute, painful, pyogenic (usually staphylococcal) infection of an eyelid gland, presenting as a tender red bump on the eyelid margin. A chalazion is a non-infectious, painless, granulomatous inflammation located within the eyelid.
  • Treatment: Most resolve spontaneously with conservative treatment, including warm compresses and gentle massage to help liquefy the trapped lipids and promote drainage. Persistent or large lesions may require incision and curettage or a glucocorticoid injection.
  • USMLE Tip: The key distinguishing feature from a stye is that a chalazion is painless and granulomatous, whereas a hordeolum is painful and infectious.
content.takeAway: A chalazion is a sterile, granulomatous 'lump' resulting from a blocked oil gland in the eyelid, presenting as a painless nodule that is fundamentally an inflammatory reaction, not an infection like a hordeolum.

content.definition: A Charcot joint, also known as neuropathic arthropathy, is a condition characterized by progressive destruction and deformity of a joint, resulting from a loss of protective sensation (proprioception and pain).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The loss of pain and position sense leads to recurrent, unrecognized microtrauma to the joint. This triggers a cycle of inflammation, bone resorption, and remodeling, ultimately leading to severe joint destruction, instability, and deformity.
  • Common Causes: Any condition that causes peripheral neuropathy can lead to a Charcot joint. The most common cause is diabetes mellitus (affecting the foot and ankle). Other classic causes include [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] (tertiary syphilis, affecting the knee) and [[syringomyelia]] (affecting the shoulder).
  • Clinical Presentation: The affected joint is typically swollen, warm, and erythematous, but is often surprisingly painless or has less pain than expected given the degree of destruction.
  • Radiology: X-rays show classic findings of severe degenerative changes, bone fragmentation, subluxation, and dislocation.
  • USMLE Tip: When a question describes a severely deformed, swollen, but relatively painless joint, think of Charcot joint. The next step is to identify the underlying cause of the neuropathy (e.g., diabetes, syphilis).
content.takeAway: A Charcot joint is the devastating consequence of a joint that cannot feel pain; without the protective feedback of sensation, repeated trauma leads to a vicious cycle of inflammation and bone destruction, resulting in a grossly deformed and unstable joint.

content.definition: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are minute aneurysms of the small, penetrating (lenticulostriate) arteries in the brain that are strongly associated with chronic hypertension. Their rupture is a major cause of hypertensive [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhage]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Chronic hypertension leads to hyaline arteriosclerosis, which weakens the walls of small penetrating arteries, causing them to form small outpouchings (microaneurysms).
  • Location: Most commonly affect the lenticulostriate arteries that supply the deep brain structures. Therefore, hemorrhages typically occur in the basal ganglia (putamen), thalamus, pons, and cerebellum.
  • Clinical Consequence: Rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm leads to a spontaneous, hypertensive [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhage]].
  • Differentiation: These are distinct from [[a9f6d703|saccular (berry) aneurysms]], which are larger, occur in the Circle of Willis, and cause subarachnoid hemorrhage. Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are too small to be seen on angiography.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a long history of poorly controlled hypertension who presents with a sudden focal neurological deficit and a CT scan showing a deep brain hemorrhage (e.g., in the basal ganglia) has likely ruptured a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm.
content.takeAway: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are the vascular consequence of chronic hypertension on the brain's smallest arteries; these tiny, fragile aneurysms are prone to rupture, causing devastating deep intracerebral hemorrhages.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chronic Hypertension] --> B(Hyaline Arteriosclerosis); B --> C(Weakening of Lenticulostriate Arteries); C --> D(Charcot-Bouchard Microaneurysm); D --Rupture--> E(Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage);

content.definition: Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease, also known as hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN), is a group of inherited disorders of the peripheral nervous system characterized by progressive weakness and sensory loss, predominantly affecting the distal extremities.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: The most common inherited neuropathy. It has multiple genetic forms, with the most common type, CMT1A, being an autosomal dominant condition caused by a duplication of the PMP22 gene.
  • Pathophysiology: The genetic defects lead to abnormal myelin sheath (demyelinating types like CMT1) or direct axonal damage (axonal types like CMT2). Demyelinating types show 'onion bulb' formations on nerve biopsy due to repeated demyelination and remyelination.
  • Clinical Presentation: Insidious onset, typically in adolescence or early adulthood. Presents with distal muscle weakness and atrophy, starting in the legs. This leads to foot drop, a steppage gait, and characteristic foot deformities like pes cavus (high arches) and hammer toes.
  • Sensory Loss: There is often a 'glove and stocking' pattern of sensory loss, particularly affecting vibration and proprioception.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic presentation is a young patient with progressive distal leg weakness, foot drop, high-arched feet (pes cavus), and sensory loss. The family history is often positive. Mnemonic: Can't Move Toes for CMT.
content.takeAway: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a genetic neuropathy that slowly 'whittles away' the peripheral nerves, starting from the feet and hands and moving proximally, leading to the classic clinical picture of distal muscle atrophy (stork legs), foot drop, and high-arched feet.

content.definition: The Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ) is a specific area in the brain, synonymous with the [[5dd343d3|area postrema]], that detects emetogenic substances in the blood and relays this information to the vomiting center to induce emesis.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Located in the [[5dd343d3|area postrema]] on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the medulla oblongata.
  • Blood-Brain Barrier: It is a circumventricular organ, meaning it lies outside the blood-brain barrier. This allows it to be directly exposed to and monitor chemicals and toxins circulating in the bloodstream.
  • Function: Acts as a chemosensor. When it detects emetic stimuli (e.g., chemotherapy drugs, toxins, opioids), it sends signals to the nucleus tractus solitarius (the vomiting center).
  • Receptors: The CTZ is rich in a variety of receptors, making it a key target for antiemetic drugs. Important receptors include dopamine D2, serotonin 5-HT3, and neurokinin-1 (NK-1).
  • USMLE Tip: Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting is largely mediated by the stimulation of 5-HT3 receptors in the CTZ. This is why 5-HT3 antagonists like [[ondansetron]] are so effective.
content.takeAway: The Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone is the brain's 'vomit surveillance center,' strategically located outside the blood-brain barrier to detect blood-borne toxins and trigger vomiting as a protective reflex, a mechanism exploited by many antiemetic drugs.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chemotherapy/Toxins in Blood] --> B(Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone); B --D2, 5-HT3, NK-1 Receptors--> C(Vomiting Center); C --> D(Emesis);

content.definition: Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea and Vomiting (CINV) is a common and distressing side effect of many cytotoxic cancer therapies. It is mediated by both central and peripheral pathways that stimulate the [[74b651ab|vomiting center]] in the brainstem.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology:
    - Acute CINV: Occurs within 24 hours. Primarily mediated by the release of serotonin (5-HT) from enterochromaffin cells in the GI tract, which stimulates vagal afferents and the [[93f70f8e|chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)]].
    - Delayed CINV: Occurs after 24 hours. Primarily mediated by substance P binding to neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors in the brain.
  • Treatment (Acute CINV): The mainstay of treatment is 5-HT3 receptor antagonists (e.g., [[ondansetron]]).
  • Treatment (Delayed CINV): The mainstay of treatment is NK-1 receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant).
  • Combination Therapy: High-emetogenic chemotherapy regimens are often treated prophylactically with a combination of a 5-HT3 antagonist, an NK-1 antagonist, and a corticosteroid (e.g., dexamethasone).
  • USMLE Tip: Know the two main pathways and their primary mediators: Acute CINV is driven by serotonin (target with ondansetron), while delayed CINV is driven by substance P (target with aprepitant).
content.takeAway: The management of Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea and Vomiting is a targeted pharmacological approach based on its biphasic pathophysiology; the acute phase is blocked by serotonin antagonists, while the delayed phase is prevented by substance P/NK-1 antagonists.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chemotherapy] --> B(GI Tract Damage); B --> C(Serotonin Release); C --> D(Vagal Afferents & CTZ); D --> E(Acute Vomiting); A --> F(CNS Effects); F --> G(Substance P Release); G --> H(NK-1 Receptors); H --> I(Delayed Vomiting);

content.definition: A cherry-red spot is a descriptive term for the fundoscopic finding of a small, circular reddish area at the fovea, surrounded by a pale retina. This sign is indicative of pathology in the retinal ganglion cell layer, which is absent at the fovea.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: The fovea appears red because its normal choroidal circulation is visible and contrasts sharply with the surrounding pale, edematous, or lipid-laden retina.
  • Ischemic Cause: The most common cause is [[3334840f|Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)]]. The inner retina becomes pale and edematous due to ischemia, making the underlying choroidal blood supply at the fovea stand out.
  • Metabolic Causes: It is also a classic finding in several lysosomal storage diseases where sphingolipids accumulate in the retinal ganglion cells, making the retina appear pale. These include:
    - Tay-Sachs disease (GM2 gangliosidosis)
    - Niemann-Pick disease (sphingomyelinase deficiency)
    - Metachromatic leukodystrophy and Sandhoff disease (less common).
  • USMLE Tip: When you see 'cherry-red spot,' your differential should immediately be CRAO vs. Tay-Sachs/Niemann-Pick. The clinical context (e.g., an elderly patient with sudden vision loss vs. an infant with neurodegeneration) will distinguish them.
content.takeAway: The cherry-red spot is a dramatic fundoscopic sign that highlights the normal foveal blood supply against a backdrop of a diseased retina, pointing to either acute, profound ischemia (CRAO) or lipid accumulation in the ganglion cells (lysosomal storage diseases).

content.definition: Chiari malformations are a group of structural defects in the cerebellum, characterized by the downward displacement of one or both cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This can lead to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow and brainstem compression.
content.atAGlance:
• Chiari I Malformation: Ectopia of the cerebellar tonsils (>5 mm below the foramen magnum). Usually a congenital condition but often asymptomatic until adolescence or adulthood. Presents with occipital headaches (often worse with Valsalva) and cerebellar symptoms. Strongly associated with [[d2b8e10c|syringomyelia]].
  • Chiari II Malformation (Arnold-Chiari): Downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, along with the medulla, through the foramen magnum. Presents in infancy. Almost universally associated with a lumbar myelomeningocele.
  • Pathophysiology: The herniated cerebellar tissue can obstruct CSF outflow from the fourth ventricle, causing non-communicating hydrocephalus.
  • Symptoms: Can include headache, neck pain, balance problems ([[9767fd6b|ataxia]]), and signs of brainstem compression (e.g., dysphagia, apnea).
  • USMLE Tip: Associate Chiari I with [[d2b8e10c|syringomyelia]] in an adult. Associate Chiari II with myelomeningocele and hydrocephalus in an infant.
content.takeAway: Chiari malformations represent a 'crowding' at the base of the skull where the cerebellum herniates through the foramen magnum, with Chiari I being a milder, later-onset form associated with syringomyelia, and Chiari II being a severe, infantile form associated with myelomeningocele and hydrocephalus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chiari Malformation] --> B(Downward Displacement of Cerebellum); B --> C(Through Foramen Magnum); C --> D(Obstruction of CSF Flow); D --> E(Hydrocephalus); C --> F(Brainstem Compression);

content.definition: Chickenpox (Varicella) is a highly contagious acute infectious disease caused by the primary infection with Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV), a member of the herpesvirus family. It is characterized by a generalized, pruritic, vesicular rash.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV), or Human Herpesvirus-3 (HHV-3).
  • Clinical Presentation: Prodrome of fever and malaise followed by a pruritic rash that begins on the trunk and face and spreads to the extremities. The rash is classically described as "lesions in different stages of healing" (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions all present simultaneously).
  • Complications: In children, the most common complication is a secondary bacterial skin infection (e.g., from S. aureus or S. pyogenes). In adults, the most common complication is pneumonia. Encephalitis is a rare but serious complication.
  • Latency and Reactivation: After the primary infection, VZV establishes latency in the dorsal root ganglia. Reactivation later in life causes Herpes Zoster (Shingles).
  • USMLE Tip: The description of a vesicular rash with lesions in various stages of development is pathognomonic for chickenpox. The 'chicken-wire' capillary pattern is a histological finding in oligodendroglioma, not related to chickenpox.
content.takeAway: Chickenpox is the primary manifestation of VZV infection, presenting as a classic 'dewdrop on a rose petal' rash with lesions in multiple stages of evolution, which resolves but leaves the virus dormant in the dorsal root ganglia, ready to reactivate as shingles years later.

content.definition: Childhood neurological disorders encompass a wide range of conditions affecting the developing brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves, from congenital malformations and genetic syndromes to acquired conditions like tumors and infections.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Brain Tumors: Most childhood brain tumors are infratentorial (located in the posterior fossa). The most common types, in order, are Pilocytic Astrocytoma, [[16d613bb|Medulloblastoma]], and [[14365ef4|Ependymoma]].
  • Leukocoria ("White Pupil"): An abnormal white reflection from the retina. In a child, this is a major red flag that must be investigated to rule out serious pathology, most notably [[63b964af|retinoblastoma]] and congenital [[85f03b02|cataracts]].
  • Neurocutaneous Syndromes: A group of genetic disorders affecting the skin and nervous system, often presenting in childhood (e.g., Neurofibromatosis, Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber).
  • Blindness: Common causes of blindness in children include retinopathy of prematurity, congenital cataracts, and retinoblastoma.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the location difference for brain tumors: Adults = Supratentorial, Children = Infratentorial. Leukocoria in a child is retinoblastoma until proven otherwise.
content.takeAway: The landscape of childhood neurological disorders is dominated by developmental and genetic conditions, with infratentorial brain tumors and congenital eye abnormalities like leukocoria being high-yield and clinically critical entities to recognize.

content.definition: Chlordiazepoxide (trade name Librium) is a long-acting benzodiazepine primarily used for the management of anxiety disorders and, most notably, for the treatment of acute alcohol withdrawal.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A positive allosteric modulator of the GABAA receptor. It increases the frequency of chloride channel opening in response to GABA, leading to enhanced CNS inhibition.
  • Pharmacokinetics: It is a long-acting benzodiazepine with active metabolites, which contributes to its smooth, tapering effect, making it ideal for withdrawal syndromes.
  • Clinical Use: The drug of choice for managing the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, including agitation, tremors, and preventing seizures and delirium tremens. Also used for anxiety disorders.
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, dizziness, confusion, dependence, and withdrawal. Its long half-life can lead to accumulation and excessive sedation, especially in the elderly or those with liver impairment.
  • USMLE Tip: For alcohol withdrawal, a long-acting benzodiazepine like chlordiazepoxide or diazepam is preferred to provide a stable level of CNS depression and prevent severe withdrawal symptoms.
content.takeAway: Chlordiazepoxide is the classic long-acting benzodiazepine used to safely manage alcohol withdrawal, providing a 'soft landing' by substituting for alcohol at the GABAA receptor and preventing the life-threatening hyperexcitability of delirium tremens.

content.definition: Chloroprocaine is a short-acting, ester-type local anesthetic used for regional anesthesia, particularly in obstetrics for epidural analgesia during labor and delivery.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels in nerve membranes, preventing the generation and conduction of nerve impulses.
  • Class: Ester local anesthetic. It is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterases.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a very rapid onset and a very short duration of action due to its rapid hydrolysis in the plasma.
  • Clinical Use: Its rapid onset and short duration make it ideal for epidural anesthesia in obstetrics, as it provides quick pain relief and its effects wear off quickly after delivery, minimizing systemic toxicity to both mother and neonate.
  • Adverse Effects: As an ester, it has a higher potential for allergic reactions (due to its metabolite, PABA) compared to amide anesthetics. Systemic toxicity is rare due to its rapid metabolism.
  • USMLE Tip: The key features of chloroprocaine are its ester linkage, rapid metabolism by plasma pseudocholinesterases, and its resulting fast-on, fast-off profile, making it a popular choice for labor epidurals.
content.takeAway: Chloroprocaine is an ester local anesthetic prized in obstetrics for its speed; its rapid breakdown in the plasma provides fast pain relief for labor with minimal risk of accumulation or toxicity to the baby.

content.definition: A cholesteatoma is a non-neoplastic, destructive and expanding growth consisting of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. Despite its name, it is not a tumor and does not contain cholesterol.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Most commonly acquired due to chronic eustachian tube dysfunction, which creates negative pressure in the middle ear and causes a retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane. This pocket fills with desquamated keratin debris, forming the cholesteatoma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Classically presents with painless, persistent, and often foul-smelling otorrhea (ear discharge). Progressive conductive hearing loss occurs as the mass erodes the ossicles.
  • Complications: The mass can produce lytic enzymes, leading to erosion of the ossicles, mastoid bone, and even extension into the cranium, causing complications like facial nerve palsy, vertigo, meningitis, or brain abscess.
  • Otoscopy: Examination may reveal a white, cheesy-looking mass behind an intact tympanic membrane or a perforation with keratin debris.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of chronic, painless, foul-smelling ear discharge and conductive hearing loss is highly suggestive of a cholesteatoma.
content.takeAway: A cholesteatoma is essentially 'skin in the wrong place,' a destructive collection of keratin debris in the middle ear that, through enzymatic erosion, can destroy the delicate structures of hearing and balance and even invade the brain.

content.definition: Cholinesterase inhibitors (or acetylcholinesterase inhibitors) are a class of drugs that prevent the breakdown of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] by the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE), thereby increasing the concentration and duration of action of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Inhibit AChE, leading to increased levels of ACh at both muscarinic and nicotinic synapses.
  • Clinical Uses:
    - [[77ae6148|Alzheimer Disease]]: Centrally acting agents ([[47d0372e|donepezil]], rivastigmine, galantamine) are used to improve cognitive symptoms by boosting cortical cholinergic function.
    - Myasthenia Gravis: Peripherally acting agents (neostigmine, pyridostigmine) increase ACh at the neuromuscular junction to improve muscle strength.
    - Reversal of Neuromuscular Blockade: Neostigmine is used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers after surgery.
    - Anticholinergic Toxicity: Physostigmine, a centrally acting inhibitor, is the antidote for severe anticholinergic overdose.
  • Toxicity (Cholinergic Crisis): Overdose or exposure to irreversible inhibitors (organophosphates) causes a cholinergic crisis. Mnemonic DUMBBELSS: Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis, Lacrimation, Salivation, Sweating.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate between centrally acting (physostigmine, donepezil) and peripherally acting (neostigmine, pyridostigmine) agents based on their ability to cross the blood-brain barrier.
content.takeAway: Cholinesterase inhibitors amplify cholinergic signaling throughout the body by preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine, a mechanism that is therapeutically harnessed to treat conditions of cholinergic deficit like Alzheimer's disease and myasthenia gravis, but which can become toxic in overdose, leading to a cholinergic crisis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Acetylcholine] --AChE--> B(Choline + Acetate); C[Cholinesterase Inhibitor] --x B;

content.definition: Cholinomimetic agents are drugs that mimic the effects of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]]. They can be classified as direct-acting agonists, which bind directly to cholinergic receptors, or indirect-acting agents ([[0835ea01|cholinesterase inhibitors]]), which increase the synaptic concentration of acetylcholine.
content.atAGlance:
• Direct-Acting Agonists:
    - Bethanechol: Muscarinic agonist used for non-obstructive urinary retention and postoperative ileus.
    - Pilocarpine: Muscarinic agonist used for [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]] and to treat xerostomia (dry mouth) in Sjögren syndrome.
    - [[c1ad76f4|Carbachol]]: Muscarinic and nicotinic agonist used for [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]].
  • Indirect-Acting Agents (Cholinesterase Inhibitors): See [[0835ea01|Cholinesterase Inhibitors]] card.
  • Effects: Produce effects similar to parasympathetic stimulation (rest and digest). Mnemonic DUMBBELSS (Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis, Lacrimation, Salivation, Sweating).
  • Glaucoma Therapy: Cholinomimetics like pilocarpine and [[c1ad76f4|carbachol]] are used in [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]] to increase aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork by contracting the ciliary muscle.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the difference between direct agonists (which bind to the receptor) and indirect agonists (which inhibit the breakdown of the natural ligand). Both result in increased cholinergic stimulation.
content.takeAway: Cholinomimetic agents amplify the 'rest and digest' signals of the parasympathetic nervous system, either by directly stimulating cholinergic receptors or by preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine, with therapeutic applications ranging from glaucoma to urinary retention.

content.definition: Chorea (from Greek for "dance") is an involuntary movement disorder characterized by brief, abrupt, irregular, and unpredictable movements that flow from one body part to another. It is a hallmark sign of [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] dysfunction.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Movements are non-rhythmic, jerky, and purposeless, often described as 'dance-like.' They can affect the face, limbs, and trunk.
  • Pathophysiology: Classically associated with damage to the striatum (specifically the caudate nucleus) in the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]], leading to a loss of inhibition in the indirect pathway and excessive cortical stimulation.
  • Classic Cause: The most well-known cause of chorea is [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]], an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder.
  • Other Causes:
    - Sydenham Chorea: A post-infectious complication of Group A streptococcal infection (rheumatic fever).
    - Drug-induced: Can be a side effect of long-term levodopa therapy for Parkinson disease.
    - Other: Systemic lupus erythematosus, pregnancy (chorea gravidarum).
  • USMLE Tip: A young to middle-aged adult presenting with new-onset chorea, especially if accompanied by psychiatric changes or a family history, should be evaluated for [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]. In a child with a recent sore throat, consider Sydenham chorea.
content.takeAway: Chorea is a hyperkinetic movement disorder that manifests as a continuous, unpredictable 'dance' of the body, resulting from a loss of inhibitory control from the basal ganglia, most famously due to the degeneration of the caudate nucleus in Huntington disease.

content.definition: The Choroid is the vascular layer of the eye, situated between the retina and the sclera. It is part of the uvea and is responsible for providing oxygen and nourishment to the outer layers of the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: The posterior part of the uvea, lying between the retina (inner layer) and the sclera (outer layer).
  • Function: Its rich blood supply provides essential oxygen and nutrients to the outer retina, including the photoreceptors (rods and cones). It also contains pigment that absorbs excess light, preventing blurring of the image.
  • Bruch's Membrane: The innermost layer of the choroid, which forms a barrier between the choroidal capillaries and the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Pathology:
    - [[c63255c8|Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD)]]: In wet AMD, abnormal blood vessels grow from the choroid through Bruch's membrane (choroidal neovascularization), leading to hemorrhage and vision loss.
    - Choroiditis: Inflammation of the choroid, a form of posterior uveitis.
    - Choroidal Melanoma: The most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults.
  • USMLE Tip: The choroidal circulation is responsible for the 'red' appearance of the fovea in a [[651ed480|cherry-red spot]], as it remains visible through the thin fovea when the surrounding retina is pale from ischemia or lipid deposition.
content.takeAway: The Choroid is the vital, vascular support system for the photoreceptors of the retina; its integrity is crucial for vision, and its breakdown, as seen in wet macular degeneration, can lead to rapid and severe sight loss.

content.definition: The Choroid Plexus is a specialized, highly vascularized tissue found within the ventricles of the brain that is responsible for the production of most of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Found in all four ventricles (lateral, third, and fourth).
  • Structure: Consists of a network of capillaries surrounded by a layer of modified ependymal cells, which are joined by tight junctions to form the blood-CSF barrier.
  • Function: Actively secretes [[7109d8b6|cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)]] into the ventricles. This process involves the transport of ions (Na+, Cl-, HCO3-) into the ventricles, with water following osmotically.
  • Enzymes: The process is dependent on enzymes like carbonic anhydrase.
  • Pathology:
    - Overproduction of CSF: A rare cause of [[0bc2f200|hydrocephalus]] can be a choroid plexus papilloma (a benign tumor).
    - Choroid Plexus Cysts: Often seen on prenatal ultrasound; usually a benign, transient finding but can be a soft marker for chromosomal abnormalities like Trisomy 18.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the simple flow: Choroid plexus produces CSF, arachnoid granulations reabsorb CSF. A tumor of the choroid plexus (papilloma) can cause communicating hydrocephalus due to overproduction.
content.takeAway: The Choroid Plexus functions as the brain's 'CSF factory,' a specialized tissue within the ventricles that continuously produces the fluid essential for cushioning and nourishing the central nervous system.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choroid Plexus] --Produces--> B(Cerebrospinal Fluid);

content.definition: The Ciliary Ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion located in the posterior orbit. It serves as a relay station for parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction (miosis) and lens accommodation.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Contains postganglionic parasympathetic neuron cell bodies that innervate the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles of the eye.
  • Parasympathetic Root (Motor): Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers arise from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus and travel with the [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]] to synapse in the ciliary ganglion.
  • Postganglionic Fibers: Axons from the ciliary ganglion travel via the short ciliary nerves to the eye.
  • Innervation:
    - Sphincter Pupillae Muscle: Contraction causes miosis (pupil constriction).
    - Ciliary Muscle: Contraction causes [[81b5f5fe|accommodation]] (rounding of the lens for near vision).
  • Clinical Relevance: A lesion in the ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerves (e.g., Adie's tonic pupil) results in a dilated pupil that reacts poorly to light but may show a slow, tonic constriction to near vision (light-near dissociation).
  • USMLE Tip: This ganglion is the final parasympathetic outpost for the eye. Remember the pathway: Edinger-Westphal nucleus → CN III → Ciliary Ganglion → Short ciliary nerves → Pupillary constriction and accommodation.
content.takeAway: The Ciliary Ganglion is the crucial parasympathetic relay center for the eye, translating signals from the oculomotor nerve into the commands that constrict the pupil and focus the lens for near vision.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Edinger-Westphal Nucleus] --Preganglionic Fibers (CN III)--> B(Ciliary Ganglion); B --Postganglionic Fibers--> C(Sphincter Pupillae & Ciliary Muscle);

content.definition: The Ciliospinal Center of Budge is a group of preganglionic sympathetic neurons located in the intermediolateral cell column of the spinal cord at the C8-T2 levels. It is the origin of the second-order neuron in the oculosympathetic pathway, which controls pupillary dilation.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Intermediolateral nucleus of the spinal cord from C8 to T2.
  • Function: It is the origin of the preganglionic sympathetic fibers that innervate the head and neck, including the eye.
  • Oculosympathetic Pathway: This is the second neuron in the three-neuron pathway for pupillary dilation:
    1. First-order neuron: Descends from the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] to the Ciliospinal Center.
    2. Second-order neuron: Ascends from the Ciliospinal Center, through the sympathetic chain, to the superior cervical ganglion.
    3. Third-order neuron: Travels from the superior cervical ganglion to the pupillary dilator muscle.
  • Clinical Relevance: A lesion affecting the Ciliospinal Center (e.g., spinal cord trauma, syringomyelia) can disrupt the sympathetic supply to the eye, resulting in an ipsilateral [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]] (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember this center as the spinal cord 'launch point' for the sympathetic nerves to the eye. A lesion here is a cause of a 'preganglionic' or second-order neuron Horner syndrome.
content.takeAway: The Ciliospinal Center of Budge is the critical spinal cord relay station for the oculosympathetic pathway, launching the preganglionic fibers that ultimately control pupillary dilation; its disruption is a key cause of Horner syndrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] --> B(Ciliospinal Center of Budge C8-T2); B --> C(Superior Cervical Ganglion); C --> D(Pupillary Dilator Muscle);

content.definition: Cingulate herniation, also known as subfalcine herniation, is the most common type of brain herniation. It occurs when an expanding lesion in one cerebral hemisphere pushes the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri to the opposite side.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Caused by a unilateral supratentorial mass lesion (e.g., tumor, hematoma, large stroke) that creates a lateral pressure gradient.
  • Structure Herniated: The cingulate gyrus is displaced under the rigid dural fold of the falx cerebri.
  • Clinical Presentation: Often clinically silent initially, but can be a precursor to more dangerous herniation syndromes.
  • Vascular Complication: The primary complication is compression of the ipsilateral or contralateral [[830c856c|anterior cerebral artery (ACA)]] against the falx cerebri.
  • Consequence of ACA Compression: Can lead to an ischemic infarct in the ACA territory, resulting in contralateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss.
  • USMLE Tip: While often asymptomatic itself, subfalcine herniation is a sign of significant mass effect. Look for the potential complication of ACA compression causing contralateral leg weakness.
content.takeAway: Cingulate herniation is the sideways shift of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri, which, while often clinically subtle, can have significant consequences by compressing the anterior cerebral artery and causing a stroke in the contralateral leg's motor cortex.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Unilateral Mass Lesion] --> B(↑ Pressure); B --> C(Cingulate Gyrus Herniates under Falx Cerebri); C --Compresses--> D(Anterior Cerebral Artery); D --> E(Contralateral Leg Weakness);

content.definition: The Cingulate Gyrus is an arch-shaped cortical structure situated in the medial aspect of each cerebral hemisphere, directly superior to the corpus callosum. It is a key component of the [[73ace357|limbic system]].
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Medial aspect of the cerebral cortex, forming a 'collar' (Latin: cingulum) around the corpus callosum.
  • Function: Plays an integral role in processing emotions, learning, and memory. It links behavioral outcomes to motivation (e.g., a behavior resulting in a pleasant outcome is more likely to be repeated).
  • Connections: It is a central node in the Papez circuit, a major pathway of the [[73ace357|limbic system]] involved in memory and emotion.
  • Clinical Relevance: Dysfunction of the cingulate gyrus is implicated in various psychiatric disorders, including depression and anxiety. In neurology, it is the structure that herniates under the falx cerebri in a [[25dc347a|cingulate (subfalcine) herniation]].
  • USMLE Tip: Recognize the cingulate gyrus as a core component of the limbic system involved in emotion and memory, and as the specific structure displaced in subfalcine herniation.
content.takeAway: The Cingulate Gyrus serves as a critical interface between emotion, memory, and behavior within the limbic system, and its anatomical position makes it the primary structure involved in the most common type of brain herniation.

content.definition: Circadian rhythms are endogenous, near-24-hour cycles of physiological processes, including the sleep-wake cycle, hormone release, and body temperature. These rhythms are controlled by a central 'master clock' in the brain.
content.atAGlance:
• Master Clock: The central pacemaker for circadian rhythms is the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), located in the anterior [[89e86633|hypothalamus]].
  • Entrainment: The SCN is synchronized (entrained) to the 24-hour day primarily by light. Light information from the retina travels via the retinohypothalamic tract to the SCN.
  • Hormonal Output: The SCN controls the release of melatonin from the pineal gland. Light exposure inhibits melatonin release, while darkness stimulates it, promoting sleep.
  • Clinical Relevance: Disruption of circadian rhythms can lead to sleep disorders (e.g., jet lag, shift work disorder) and is implicated in mood disorders.
  • USMLE Tip: The suprachiasmatic nucleus is the key structure to associate with circadian rhythm control. Lesions of the SCN disrupt the sleep-wake cycle.
content.takeAway: The body's internal 24-hour clock, or circadian rhythm, is orchestrated by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus, which uses light cues from the environment to synchronize a wide array of physiological and behavioral cycles, most notably the sleep-wake cycle via its control of melatonin.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Light] --> B(Retina); B --> C(Suprachiasmatic Nucleus - SCN); C --Inhibits--> D(Pineal Gland); D --Melatonin--> E(Sleep-Wake Cycle);

content.definition: The Circle of Willis is a ring-like arterial anastomosis located at the base of the brain that connects the anterior (internal carotid) and posterior (vertebrobasilar) circulations. This collateral pathway is crucial for maintaining cerebral perfusion in the event of stenosis or occlusion of one of the major feeding arteries.
content.atAGlance:
• Components:
    - Anteriorly: [[bd802d22|Anterior communicating artery]] connecting the two [[830c856c|anterior cerebral arteries (ACAs)]].
    - Laterally: Internal carotid arteries giving rise to the [[143bb23d|middle cerebral arteries (MCAs)]] and ACAs.
    - Posteriorly: Posterior communicating arteries connecting the internal carotids to the [[b6a2cc31|posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs)]], which arise from the [[e7a90cd9|basilar artery]].
  • Function: Provides collateral circulation to the brain. However, the communicating arteries are often small or absent in many individuals, limiting their effectiveness.
  • Clinical Significance: It is the most common location for [[a9f6d703|saccular (berry) aneurysms]], which typically form at the branch points.
  • Common Aneurysm Sites: The junction of the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery]] with the ACA is the most frequent site, followed by the junction of the posterior communicating artery with the internal carotid.
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to identify all the components of the Circle of Willis and know that its branch points are weak spots prone to aneurysm formation.
content.takeAway: The Circle of Willis is the brain's critical vascular interchange, uniting the anterior and posterior circulations to provide redundant blood flow, but its arterial junctions are also the most common sites of life-threatening berry aneurysms.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Internal Carotid] --> B(MCA); A --> C(ACA); D[Vertebral Arteries] --> E(Basilar Artery); E --> F(PCA); G(AComA) --Connects--> C; H(PComA) --Connects--> A & F;

content.definition: Cisatracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent and a stereoisomer of [[52194edb|atracurium]]. It is used to provide skeletal muscle relaxation during surgery and mechanical ventilation.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Metabolism: Like [[52194edb|atracurium]], it undergoes Hoffmann elimination (spontaneous, non-enzymatic degradation at physiological pH and temperature), making its metabolism independent of liver or kidney function.
  • Clinical Advantage: It is preferred over [[52194edb|atracurium]] because it produces less histamine release, resulting in greater hemodynamic stability (less hypotension and tachycardia). It also produces less laudanosine, a potentially neurotoxic metabolite.
  • Clinical Use: A neuromuscular blocker of choice for patients with renal or hepatic failure and for prolonged infusions in the ICU.
  • Reversal: Blockade is reversed by [[0835ea01|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., neostigmine) combined with an antimuscarinic (e.g., glycopyrrolate).
  • USMLE Tip: Cisatracurium = Atracurium with less histamine release. Both are known for Hoffmann elimination, making them safe in organ failure.
content.takeAway: Cisatracurium is a refined version of atracurium that retains the key advantage of organ-independent Hoffmann elimination while minimizing the adverse effect of histamine release, making it a safer choice for neuromuscular blockade in critically ill patients.

content.definition: Clasp-knife spasticity (or clasp-knife rigidity) is a specific type of hypertonia characterized by an initial resistance to passive movement of a joint, which then suddenly gives way. It is a hallmark sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: When a clinician passively flexes or extends a patient's limb, there is a velocity-dependent increase in muscle tone causing initial resistance, followed by a sudden collapse of resistance, analogous to the closing of a pocketknife.
  • Pathophysiology: It is thought to result from an exaggerated stretch reflex due to the loss of descending inhibitory input from the corticospinal tract. The sudden release is mediated by Golgi tendon organs, which sense excessive force and trigger an inhibitory reflex.
  • Clinical Significance: It is a specific sign of spasticity, which is a component of the upper motor neuron syndrome.
  • Associated UMN Signs: Other UMN signs include weakness (paresis), hyperreflexia, and a positive [[8947da55|Babinski sign]].
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of clasp-knife spasticity on physical exam helps to localize a lesion to the UMN pathways (cortex, brainstem, or spinal cord), distinguishing it from the rigidity seen in basal ganglia disorders (like Parkinson's) or the flaccidity of LMN lesions.
content.takeAway: Clasp-knife spasticity is a dynamic form of hypertonia pathognomonic for an upper motor neuron lesion, where initial resistance to passive movement abruptly melts away, reflecting a dysfunctional and exaggerated stretch reflex no longer modulated by descending cortical pathways.

content.definition: Clinical reflexes are involuntary and nearly instantaneous movements in response to a stimulus, which are tested during a neurological examination to assess the integrity of the sensory and motor pathways of the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): Monosynaptic stretch reflexes.
    - [[87d19a70|Achilles reflex]]: S1, S2 ('buckle my shoe').
    - Patellar reflex: L2, L3, L4 ('kick the door').
    - [[f36cfe18|Biceps]] & [[ac55d026|Brachioradialis]] reflexes: C5, C6 ('pick up sticks').
    - Triceps reflex: C7, C8 ('lay them straight').
  • Superficial Reflexes: Polysynaptic.
    - [[ce2052d6|Anal wink reflex]]: S3, S4 ('winks galore').
    - Cremasteric reflex: L1, L2 ('testicles move').
  • Primitive Reflexes: Present in infants, disappear with age. Re-emergence in adults suggests frontal lobe damage. Includes Moro, rooting, sucking, palmar, and [[8947da55|Babinski]] reflexes.
  • Interpretation:
    - Hyporeflexia/Areflexia: Suggests a lower motor neuron lesion.
    - Hyperreflexia: Suggests an upper motor neuron lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: Memorizing the nerve roots for the major DTRs is essential for localizing spinal cord or nerve root lesions.
content.takeAway: Testing clinical reflexes provides a rapid and powerful window into the functional status of the nervous system, allowing clinicians to localize lesions to specific spinal cord levels and differentiate between upper and lower motor neuron pathologies based on whether the reflexes are exaggerated or diminished.

content.definition: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that irreversibly blocks the P2Y12 ADP receptor on platelet surfaces, preventing platelet activation and aggregation. It is used for the prevention of thrombotic events.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: It is a prodrug that is metabolized to its active form by cytochrome P450 enzymes (notably CYP2C19). The active metabolite irreversibly blocks the P2Y12 receptor, preventing ADP from inducing platelet aggregation.
  • Clinical Use: Used for the secondary prevention of atherothrombotic events (myocardial infarction, [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]]) in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), recent MI or stroke, or peripheral arterial disease. Often used in combination with aspirin (dual antiplatelet therapy) after coronary stenting.
  • Adverse Effects: Bleeding is the major side effect. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a rare but serious adverse effect.
  • Pharmacogenomics: The effectiveness of clopidogrel can be reduced in patients who are 'poor metabolizers' due to genetic polymorphisms in the CYP2C19 enzyme.
  • USMLE Tip: Clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticagrelor are all P2Y12 inhibitors. Clopidogrel and prasugrel are irreversible inhibitors and prodrugs, while ticagrelor is a reversible inhibitor and not a prodrug.
content.takeAway: Clopidogrel is a cornerstone antiplatelet therapy that works by permanently disabling the P2Y12 receptor, a key amplifier of platelet aggregation, but its efficacy is dependent on metabolic activation by the genetically variable CYP2C19 enzyme.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Clopidogrel - Prodrug] --CYP2C19--> B(Active Metabolite); B --Irreversibly Blocks--> C(P2Y12 Receptor on Platelet); C --x D(ADP-mediated Aggregation); D --x E(Thrombus Formation);

content.definition: Cluster headaches are a type of primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent, excruciatingly severe, unilateral periorbital or temporal pain, accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms. The attacks occur in cyclical patterns or 'clusters'.
content.atAGlance:
• Epidemiology: More common in males. Onset is typically in young adulthood. Strong association with smoking.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden onset of severe, unilateral, periorbital or temporal pain, often described as 'stabbing' or 'boring'. Attacks last 15-180 minutes and occur in clusters (e.g., multiple times a day for weeks), often at the same time each day.
  • Autonomic Symptoms: The pain is accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic signs, such as conjunctival injection, lacrimation, nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, sweating, and potentially a transient [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]] (ptosis, miosis).
  • Acute Treatment: The two mainstays of acute therapy are 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather mask and subcutaneous [[sumatriptan]].
  • Prophylaxis: Verapamil (a calcium channel blocker) is the first-line prophylactic agent.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of severe, unilateral, short-lasting periorbital pain with autonomic features (tearing, runny nose) in a male smoker is the classic vignette for a cluster headache.
content.takeAway: Cluster headaches are one of the most painful conditions known, presenting as rapid-fire attacks of unilateral, excruciating periorbital pain accompanied by a storm of autonomic symptoms, which are uniquely responsive to high-flow oxygen and triptans for acute relief.

content.definition: An oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy is a condition resulting from damage to the third cranial nerve, leading to impaired function of four of the six extraocular muscles, the levator palpebrae superioris, and the parasympathetic fibers that constrict the pupil.
content.atAGlance:
• Presentation: The affected eye assumes a "down and out" position due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus (CN VI) and superior oblique (CN IV) muscles.
  • Motor Signs: Inability to adduct, elevate, or depress the eye. A severe ptosis (eyelid droop) is also present due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris.
  • Pupillary Involvement (Rule of the Pupil):
    - Pupil-involving (dilated, nonreactive): Suggests a compressive lesion (e.g., posterior communicating artery aneurysm, uncal herniation) because the parasympathetic fibers run on the outside of the nerve and are compressed first.
    - Pupil-sparing: Suggests an ischemic lesion (e.g., diabetic mononeuropathy) which affects the core of the nerve while sparing the peripheral parasympathetic fibers.
  • USMLE Tip: A painful third nerve palsy with a 'blown pupil' is a neurosurgical emergency until a PComA aneurysm is ruled out.
content.takeAway: A complete CN III palsy is a dramatic finding of a 'down and out' eye with a droopy eyelid; the status of the pupil is the critical clue to the etiology, with a dilated pupil pointing to a compressive emergency and a spared pupil suggesting a less urgent ischemic cause.

709aa7c2.title: Cranial Nerves III, IV, and VI

content.definition: Cranial nerves III (Oculomotor), IV (Trochlear), and VI (Abducens) are the three motor nerves responsible for controlling all movements of the eye by innervating the six extraocular muscles.
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation Mnemonic: (SO4LR6)3
    - SO4: The Superior Oblique muscle is innervated by CN IV.
    - LR6: The Lateral Rectus muscle is innervated by CN VI.
    - 3: The remaining four muscles (Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Medial Rectus, Inferior Oblique) are innervated by CN III.
  • [[68c66997|CN III (Oculomotor)]]: Moves the eye up, down, and medially. Also lifts the eyelid and constricts the pupil.
  • [[bba6093a|CN IV (Trochlear)]]: Moves the eye down and in (intorsion).
  • [[dd11dde6|CN VI (Abducens)]]: Moves the eye laterally (abduction).
  • Combined Palsies: Lesions affecting the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]] or superior orbital fissure can damage all three nerves simultaneously, leading to total ophthalmoplegia.
  • USMLE Tip: Testing eye movements (the 'H' pattern) systematically assesses the function of all three nerves and their respective muscles.
content.takeAway: The coordinated dance of eye movement is orchestrated by cranial nerves III, IV, and VI, each with a specific muscular responsibility that can be remembered by the simple formula (SO4LR6)3.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Eye Movements]; A --> B(CN III - Oculomotor); A --> C(CN IV - Trochlear); A --> D(CN VI - Abducens); B --> E(SR, IR, MR, IO); C --> F(SO); D --> G(LR);

content.definition: A trochlear nerve (CN IV) palsy is a condition resulting from damage to the fourth cranial nerve, leading to weakness of the superior oblique muscle and causing vertical and torsional diplopia.
content.atAGlance:
• Function of Superior Oblique: The primary actions are intorsion (internal rotation) and depression of the eye, especially when the eye is adducted.
  • Presentation: The affected eye is elevated and extorted (hypertropia and excyclotorsion). Patients complain of vertical [[9914d433|diplopia]] that is worse when looking down and in (e.g., reading or walking down stairs).
  • Compensatory Head Tilt: Patients characteristically tilt their head away from the side of the lesion to fuse the two images and alleviate the diplopia. This maneuver uses the intact vestibular system to intort the affected eye.
  • Bielschowsky Head Tilt Test: A diagnostic test where tilting the head toward the side of the lesion worsens the vertical deviation.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with vertical diplopia who compensates by tilting their head to the opposite shoulder is the classic vignette for a CN IV palsy. Remember: 'Can't see the floor with CN IV.'
content.takeAway: A CN IV palsy paralyzes the superior oblique muscle, causing the eye to drift upward and outward, resulting in vertical diplopia that patients instinctively correct by tilting their head away from the affected side.

content.definition: An abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy is a condition resulting from damage to the sixth cranial nerve, leading to weakness of the lateral rectus muscle and an inability to abduct the eye.
content.atAGlance:
• Function of Lateral Rectus: Abducts the eye (moves it laterally, away from the nose).
  • Presentation: The affected eye is deviated medially at rest (esotropia). The patient complains of horizontal [[9914d433|diplopia]] that is worse on gaze toward the side of the lesion.
  • Etiology: Due to its long intracranial course, CN VI is highly vulnerable to stretching from increased intracranial pressure (e.g., [[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]], hydrocephalus), making it a 'false localizing sign.' Other causes include diabetic mononeuropathy, trauma, and lesions in the pons or [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]].
  • Schwannoma Association: A [[03ecb69e|schwannoma]] at the cerebellopontine angle can compress CN VI along with CNs VII and VIII.
  • USMLE Tip: An isolated CN VI palsy in a patient with headaches and papilledema should raise suspicion for increased intracranial pressure.
content.takeAway: A CN VI palsy paralyzes the lateral rectus muscle, causing the eye to turn inward and resulting in horizontal double vision that worsens when looking toward the affected side; its presence can be a nonspecific sign of elevated intracranial pressure.

content.definition: Cocaine is a potent central nervous system stimulant and local anesthetic derived from the coca plant. It exerts its primary effects by blocking the reuptake of monoamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin).
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action:
    1. Stimulant Effect: Blocks the reuptake transporters for dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin, increasing their concentration in the synaptic cleft and leading to sympathetic activation and euphoria.
    2. Local Anesthetic Effect: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels, preventing nerve impulse conduction.
  • Intoxication: Presents with sympathetic overdrive: mydriasis, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, agitation, and potentially psychosis. Can cause coronary vasospasm leading to myocardial infarction, and seizures.
  • Withdrawal: Characterized by a 'crash' with hypersomnolence, depression, malaise, and severe craving.
  • Cardiotoxicity: A major cause of morbidity and mortality. Can cause MI (vasospasm), life-threatening arrhythmias (Na+ channel blockade), and aortic dissection.
  • USMLE Tip: In a patient with chest pain and signs of sympathetic activation, suspect cocaine use. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in cocaine-induced chest pain as they can lead to unopposed α-adrenergic stimulation, worsening hypertension and coronary vasospasm. Treat with benzodiazepines.
content.takeAway: Cocaine is a dual-action drug, acting as a powerful CNS stimulant by blocking monoamine reuptake and as a local anesthetic by blocking sodium channels; its major danger lies in the profound sympathetic stimulation, which can precipitate life-threatening cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction and arrhythmias.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cocaine] --> B(Blocks Monoamine Reuptake); B --> C(↑ Dopamine, Norepinephrine, Serotonin); C --> D(Sympathetic Activation & Euphoria); A --> E(Blocks Na+ Channels); E --> F(Local Anesthesia);

content.definition: The Cochlea is the spiral-shaped, fluid-filled cavity of the inner ear that contains the organ of Corti, the sensory organ of hearing. It is responsible for transducing the mechanical vibrations of sound into nerve impulses.
content.atAGlance:
• Anatomy: A snail-shaped structure within the bony labyrinth of the inner ear. It is divided into three fluid-filled chambers: the scala vestibuli, scala media (cochlear duct), and scala tympani.
  • Organ of Corti: Located within the scala media, it sits on the basilar membrane and contains the sensory hair cells (inner and outer) that are the mechanoreceptors for hearing.
  • Tonotopic Organization: The basilar membrane is organized by frequency. High-frequency sounds cause vibrations near the base of the cochlea (near the oval window), while low-frequency sounds cause vibrations near the apex (near the helicotrema).
  • Pathology: Damage to the hair cells within the cochlea is the cause of sensorineural hearing loss. This can be due to excessive noise exposure, ototoxic drugs, or aging ([[presbycusis]]).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the tonotopic map: the base of the cochlea detects high-pitched sounds (treble), and the apex detects low-pitched sounds (bass). Age-related hearing loss ([[presbycusis]]) typically affects high frequencies first, indicating damage at the cochlear base.
content.takeAway: The Cochlea is the auditory portion of the inner ear, functioning like a biological microphone that converts sound vibrations into precisely coded neural signals through the tonotopic organization of its basilar membrane and the mechanotransduction of its hair cells.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Stapes vibration at Oval Window] --> B(Pressure waves in cochlear fluid); B --> C(Vibration of Basilar Membrane); C --> D(Bending of Hair Cell Stereocilia); D --> E(Transduction into Neural Signal); E --> F(Cochlear Nerve);

content.definition: Codeine is a naturally occurring opioid agonist used for its analgesic, antitussive (cough suppressant), and antidiarrheal properties. It is a prodrug that is metabolized into morphine for its primary analgesic effect.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A weak agonist at μ-opioid receptors. Its analgesic effect is primarily due to its conversion to morphine by the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP2D6.
  • Clinical Use: Used for mild to moderate pain and as a cough suppressant. Often formulated with acetaminophen (Tylenol #3).
  • Pharmacogenomics: The efficacy of codeine is highly dependent on an individual's CYP2D6 genotype. 'Poor metabolizers' will get little to no analgesic effect. 'Ultra-rapid metabolizers' can convert codeine to morphine very quickly, leading to a risk of morphine toxicity and respiratory depression even at standard doses.
  • Adverse Effects: Common opioid side effects including constipation, sedation, nausea, and potential for dependence.
  • USMLE Tip: The role of CYP2D6 in activating codeine is a high-yield pharmacogenomic concept. An 'ultra-rapid metabolizer' can essentially get an overdose of morphine from a standard dose of codeine.
content.takeAway: Codeine is a weak opioid prodrug whose analgesic power is unlocked by its metabolic conversion to morphine via the genetically variable CYP2D6 enzyme, making its effectiveness and safety profile unpredictable across different individuals.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Codeine (Prodrug)] --CYP2D6--> B(Morphine); B --> C(μ-Opioid Receptor Agonism); C --> D(Analgesia);

content.definition: Coma is a state of profound and prolonged unconsciousness in which a person cannot be awakened, fails to respond normally to painful stimuli, light, or sound, lacks a normal wake-sleep cycle, and does not initiate voluntary actions. It is a medical emergency.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Results from diffuse bilateral hemispheric dysfunction or a focal lesion in the brainstem affecting the reticular activating system (RAS), which is responsible for maintaining arousal and consciousness.
  • Causes: Can be structural (e.g., stroke, trauma, tumor, [[8c0728b7|herniation syndromes]]) or metabolic/toxic (e.g., hypoglycemia, drug overdose, hypoxia, hepatic encephalopathy).
  • Evaluation: Assessed using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), which scores eye, verbal, and motor responses. A GCS score of 8 or less is typically defined as coma.
  • Herniation Syndromes: Progressive brain herniation (e.g., uncal, central) is a common pathway leading to coma due to compression of the brainstem and RAS.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate coma from other states of altered consciousness. In a persistent vegetative state, the patient has sleep-wake cycles and brainstem reflexes but lacks cortical function. In locked-in syndrome, the patient is fully conscious but quadriplegic and unable to communicate except via eye movements.
content.takeAway: Coma represents a profound failure of the brain's arousal systems, either from widespread cortical damage or a direct hit to the brainstem's reticular activating system, resulting in a state of 'unarousable unresponsiveness'.

content.definition: Communicating hydrocephalus is a type of [[0bc2f200|hydrocephalus]] where there is no obstruction to the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricular system. Instead, the condition arises from impaired CSF reabsorption by the [[b7b67074|arachnoid granulations]].
content.atAGlance:
