• Pathophysiology: The problem lies outside the ventricles, in the subarachnoid space or arachnoid granulations. The 'communication' between the ventricles is open. The primary issue is decreased CSF reabsorption.
  • Causes: Often caused by scarring or inflammation of the arachnoid granulations, which can occur after meningitis or a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
  • Imaging: CT or MRI shows enlargement of all four ventricles symmetrically, as the entire system is under increased pressure.
  • Clinical Presentation: Presents with signs of increased intracranial pressure: headache, nausea, vomiting, papilledema, and potentially cognitive changes or gait disturbance.
  • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH): A specific subtype of chronic communicating hydrocephalus in the elderly where CSF pressure is only intermittently elevated. It presents with the classic triad of 'wobbly, wacky, and wet' (gait apraxia, dementia, urinary incontinence).
  • USMLE Tip: The key to identifying communicating hydrocephalus is that all ventricles are dilated, and there is often a history of meningitis or hemorrhage. This contrasts with non-communicating hydrocephalus, where only the ventricles upstream of a blockage are enlarged.
content.takeAway: Communicating hydrocephalus is a 'drainage problem' rather than a 'plumbing blockage,' where CSF flows freely through the ventricles but cannot be effectively reabsorbed into the venous system, leading to a global increase in CSF volume and pressure.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choroid Plexus] --Normal Production--> B(CSF); B --> C(Ventricular System - Open); C --> D(Subarachnoid Space); D --x E(Impaired Reabsorption at Arachnoid Granulations); E --x F[Venous Sinuses];

content.definition: Conduction aphasia is a relatively rare type of fluent aphasia characterized by a profound impairment of repetition, despite intact auditory comprehension and fluent, though sometimes paraphasic, speech. It is a classic disconnection syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the white matter tract that connects [[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]] (comprehension) to [[a3bbace2|Broca's area]] (production).
  • Clinical Presentation:
    - Fluency: Speech is fluent, but may contain phonemic paraphasias (e.g., saying 'papple' for 'apple').
    - Comprehension: Auditory comprehension is intact.
    - Repetition: The hallmark is a severe deficit in repetition. The patient cannot repeat phrases or sentences spoken to them.
  • Patient Awareness: Patients are aware of their errors and will often try to self-correct.
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature that distinguishes conduction aphasia from other fluent aphasias (like Wernicke's) is the combination of good comprehension with poor repetition. If a patient can understand you but can't repeat 'no ifs, ands, or buts,' think conduction aphasia.
content.takeAway: Conduction aphasia is a language disorder resulting from a 'broken telephone line' between the brain's comprehension and production centers; the patient understands what is said and can speak fluently, but cannot accurately relay the message from one area to the other, leading to a profound inability to repeat.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Auditory Input] --> B(Wernicke's Area - Intact Comprehension); B --x C(Arcuate Fasciculus - Lesion); C --x D(Broca's Area); D --> E(Impaired Repetition);

content.definition: Conductive hearing loss is a type of hearing impairment that occurs when there is a problem with the mechanical transmission of sound waves through the outer ear or middle ear to the cochlea of the inner ear.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by any obstruction or damage to the structures that conduct sound, including the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, or ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes).
  • Common Causes: Cerumen (earwax) impaction, otitis media (middle ear fluid), otitis externa, perforated tympanic membrane, otosclerosis (fixation of the stapes), and [[03ef3134|cholesteatoma]].
  • Tuning Fork Tests:
    - Rinne Test: Abnormal. Bone conduction (BC) is greater than or equal to air conduction (AC) in the affected ear, because the normal amplification provided by the middle ear is lost.
    - Weber Test: Sound lateralizes to the affected ear. This is because the conductive loss masks ambient room noise, making the bone-conducted sound seem louder on that side.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the tuning fork results: In conductive hearing loss, the Weber test lateralizes to the bad ear, and the Rinne test is abnormal (BC > AC).
content.takeAway: Conductive hearing loss is a 'plumbing problem' of the ear, where sound waves are physically blocked from reaching the inner ear; this is in contrast to sensorineural hearing loss, which is a 'wiring problem' of the cochlea or auditory nerve.

content.definition: The Confluence of the Sinuses (or torcular Herophili) is a large venous junction located at the internal occipital protuberance, where several major dural venous sinuses converge.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Found on the inner surface of the occipital bone.
  • Converging Sinuses: It is the meeting point for the superior sagittal sinus, the straight sinus, and the occipital sinus.
  • Drainage: From the confluence, blood typically drains laterally into the left and right transverse sinuses.
  • Function: Serves as a major collection point for venous blood from the superior and deep parts of the brain before it is routed towards the internal jugular veins.
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to trace the path of venous drainage from the superior sagittal sinus: Superior Sagittal Sinus → Confluence of Sinuses → Transverse Sinus → Sigmoid Sinus → Internal Jugular Vein.
content.takeAway: The Confluence of the Sinuses acts as a central roundabout for venous blood drainage in the posterior cranium, collecting blood from the superior and deep brain and directing it into the transverse sinuses to begin its exit from the skull.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Superior Sagittal Sinus] --> C(Confluence of the Sinuses); B[Straight Sinus] --> C; C --> D[Transverse Sinuses]; D --> E[Sigmoid Sinuses]; E --> F[Internal Jugular Vein];

content.definition: A conjugate horizontal gaze palsy is the inability to move both eyes in the same horizontal direction (either left or right). It results from a lesion in the brainstem centers that coordinate horizontal eye movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Structure: The Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation (PPRF), also known as the horizontal gaze center, is the primary structure responsible for initiating horizontal saccades. The PPRF is located in the pons.
  • Pathway: To look to the left, the left PPRF activates the left [[dd11dde6|abducens (CN VI) nucleus]]. The CN VI nucleus then does two things: 1) sends a signal to the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle to abduct the left eye, and 2) sends a signal via the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral [[68c66997|oculomotor (CN III) nucleus]] to activate the medial rectus muscle and adduct the right eye.
  • PPRF Lesion: A lesion of the PPRF results in an ipsilateral gaze palsy. The patient cannot look toward the side of the lesion. The eyes will often deviate away from the side of the lesion due to the unopposed action of the contralateral PPRF.
  • Frontal Eye Field (FEF) Lesion: A destructive lesion in the cortical FEF (in the frontal lobe) causes the eyes to deviate toward the side of the lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate brainstem from cortical gaze palsies: PPRF lesion = eyes look away from the lesion. FEF lesion = eyes look toward the lesion.
content.takeAway: A conjugate horizontal gaze palsy is a failure of the brainstem's command center for horizontal eye movements, the PPRF; a lesion here prevents the eyes from looking toward the side of the damage, causing them to deviate to the opposite side.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Left PPRF] --> B(Left CN VI Nucleus); B --> C(Left Lateral Rectus - Abduction); B --> D(Right MLF); D --> E(Right CN III Nucleus); E --> F(Right Medial Rectus - Adduction);

content.definition: Conjunctivitis, commonly known as "pink eye," is the inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin, transparent membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelids and covers the white part of the eye (sclera).
content.atAGlance:
• Viral Conjunctivitis: The most common cause overall. Usually caused by [[aaeda12d|adenovirus]]. Presents with a red eye, watery discharge, and a gritty sensation. Often starts in one eye and spreads to the other. Highly contagious.
  • Bacterial Conjunctivitis: Commonly caused by S. aureus, S. pneumoniae, and H. influenzae. Presents with a red eye and a thick, purulent (mucopurulent) discharge that often causes the eyelids to be stuck together in the morning.
  • Allergic Conjunctivitis: An IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to an allergen (e.g., pollen). Presents with bilateral intense itching (pruritus), redness, and watery discharge.
  • Neonatal Conjunctivitis: Occurs in the first month of life. Caused by N. gonorrhoeae (very purulent, occurs at 2-5 days) or C. trachomatis (serotypes D-K, watery/mucoid, occurs at 5-14 days). Prophylaxis with erythromycin ointment is standard.
  • USMLE Tip: The type of discharge is the key to differentiating the cause: Watery = Viral or Allergic (look for itching). Purulent = Bacterial.
content.takeAway: Conjunctivitis is inflammation of the eye's surface membrane, with the etiology—viral, bacterial, or allergic—being strongly suggested by the character of the discharge and the presence or absence of itching.

content.definition: The Consensual Light Reflex is the constriction of the pupil of one eye in response to light being shone into the other eye. It is a normal brainstem reflex that is tested along with the direct light reflex to assess the integrity of the pupillary light reflex pathway.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathway: Light shone into one eye (e.g., the right eye) sends an afferent signal via the right optic nerve (CN II). This signal travels to the pretectal nuclei in the midbrain. Each pretectal nucleus then sends signals to both the ipsilateral and contralateral Edinger-Westphal nuclei.
  • Efferent Limb: Both Edinger-Westphal nuclei then send efferent parasympathetic signals via their respective oculomotor nerves (CN III) to cause constriction of both pupils.
  • Direct vs. Consensual: The constriction of the pupil in the eye receiving the light is the direct reflex. The simultaneous constriction of the pupil in the opposite eye is the consensual reflex.
  • Clinical Significance: Testing both reflexes helps localize lesions. For example, in a right CN II lesion, shining light in the right eye will cause neither pupil to constrict, but shining light in the left eye will cause both to constrict. In a right CN III lesion, shining light in either eye will cause only the left pupil to constrict.
  • USMLE Tip: The bilateral projection from the pretectal nucleus to both Edinger-Westphal nuclei is the anatomical basis for the consensual light reflex.
content.takeAway: The Consensual Light Reflex demonstrates the bilateral nature of the pupillary light reflex pathway; the brain processes the light signal from one eye and sends a command to constrict both pupils, ensuring a symmetrical response to light.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Light in Right Eye] --> B(Right Optic Nerve); B --> C(Pretectal Nuclei); C --> D(Right E-W Nucleus); C --> E(Left E-W Nucleus); D --> F(Right CN III -> Right Pupil Constricts - Direct); E --> G(Left CN III -> Left Pupil Constricts - Consensual);

content.definition: Convergence-retraction nystagmus is a specific type of abnormal eye movement characterized by jerky, convergent and retractory movements of the eyes, particularly on attempted upgaze. It is a key sign of Parinaud syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: On attempted upward gaze, the eyes jerkily converge (move toward each other) and retract into the orbits.
  • Associated Syndrome: It is a component of Parinaud syndrome (also known as dorsal midbrain syndrome).
  • Parinaud Syndrome Triad:
    1. Upward Gaze Palsy: The primary deficit is an inability to look up.
    2. Pupillary Light-Near Dissociation: Pupils react poorly to light but constrict normally to accommodation ([[08cb577f|Argyll Robertson-like pupils]]).
    3. Convergence-Retraction Nystagmus.
  • Lesion Location: Caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain, specifically compressing the superior colliculus and pretectal area.
  • Common Causes: In children, the most common cause is a pinealoma (pineal gland tumor). Other causes include stroke of the midbrain, hydrocephalus, and multiple sclerosis.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient, often a child or young adult, who cannot look up and has abnormal pupillary responses and jerky eye movements on attempted upgaze has Parinaud syndrome, and a pineal tumor should be suspected.
content.takeAway: Convergence-retraction nystagmus is a pathognomonic sign of dorsal midbrain compression (Parinaud syndrome), where the attempt to look up is thwarted and instead results in a paradoxical, jerky pulling of the eyes inward and backward.

content.definition: Rosenthal fibers, sometimes described as 'corkscrew fibers,' are thick, elongated, eosinophilic (pink) protein aggregates found in the cytoplasm of astrocytes. They are a characteristic histological finding in certain slow-growing glial processes and tumors.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: On H&E stain, they appear as bright pink, irregular, corkscrew-shaped or rope-like inclusions within astrocytic processes.
  • Composition: Composed of aggregates of intermediate filament proteins, including glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), along with heat shock proteins.
  • Classic Association: They are the histological hallmark of a pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children.
  • Other Conditions: Can also be seen in areas of long-standing gliosis and in Alexander disease, a rare leukodystrophy.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of Rosenthal fibers in a biopsy of a pediatric cerebellar cystic tumor is diagnostic for pilocytic astrocytoma.
content.takeAway: Rosenthal fibers are distinctive eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped inclusions that are the microscopic signature of a pilocytic astrocytoma, representing aggregates of glial proteins within the tumor cells.

content.definition: The Cornea is the transparent, avascular, dome-shaped outer layer at the very front of the eye. It covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber and is the eye's primary refractive surface.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Its primary function is to refract (bend) light, accounting for about two-thirds of the eye's total optical power. It also serves a protective role.
  • Structure: Composed of five layers (Epithelium, Bowman's layer, Stroma, Descemet's membrane, Endothelium). It is avascular and receives nutrients from the aqueous humor and oxygen from the air.
  • Innervation: Richly innervated by sensory nerve fibers from the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1), making it extremely sensitive to touch.
  • Pathology:
    - [[18cff34e|Astigmatism]]: Caused by an irregular curvature of the cornea.
    - Keratitis: Inflammation of the cornea.
    - Corneal Abrasion: A scratch on the corneal surface.
    - Kayser-Fleischer rings: Copper deposits in Descemet's membrane, seen in Wilson disease.
  • USMLE Tip: The [[64663383|corneal reflex]] (blinking in response to touching the cornea) tests the afferent limb of CN V1 and the efferent limb of CN VII.
content.takeAway: The Cornea is the eye's powerful, transparent front window, responsible for the majority of light refraction, while its dense sensory innervation makes it exquisitely sensitive and provides a critical protective reflex.

content.definition: The Corneal Reflex is an involuntary blinking of the eyelids elicited by stimulation of the cornea (such as by touching it with a wisp of cotton), which serves to protect the eye from foreign bodies.
content.atAGlance:
• Purpose: Tests the integrity of a brainstem reflex arc involving cranial nerves V and VII.
  • Afferent Limb (Sensation): The stimulus is detected by nociceptors in the [[7d70ac32|cornea]], and the sensory signal is carried to the pons by the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1).
  • Efferent Limb (Motor): Motor output is sent from the pons via the facial nerve (CN VII) bilaterally to the orbicularis oculi muscles, causing both eyes to blink.
  • Interpretation:
    - No blink in either eye: Lesion in the ipsilateral CN V1 (afferent defect).
    - Only contralateral eye blinks: Lesion in the ipsilateral CN VII (efferent defect).
    - Only ipsilateral eye blinks: Lesion in the contralateral CN VII.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the pathway: Sensation in via CN V, blinking out via CN VII. A lesion in CN V1 will knock out the reflex on both sides when the affected eye is stimulated. A lesion in CN VII will only knock out the blink on the affected side, regardless of which eye is stimulated.
content.takeAway: The Corneal Reflex is a critical brainstem reflex that protects the eye, relying on the trigeminal nerve (CN V) to 'feel' the threat and the facial nerve (CN VII) to 'act' by closing the eyelids.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Touch Cornea] --> B(Afferent: CN V1); B --> C(Pons); C --> D(Efferent: Bilateral CN VII); D --> E(Bilateral Orbicularis Oculi Contraction); E --> F(Blinking);

content.definition: Coronary vasospasm is a transient, focal constriction of a coronary artery that can cause myocardial ischemia, leading to a type of angina known as vasospastic or Prinzmetal angina. It can also be a side effect of certain drugs.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Involves hyperreactivity of coronary artery smooth muscle, leading to intense vasoconstriction. The exact cause is unknown but may involve endothelial dysfunction.
  • Prinzmetal Angina: Characterized by angina that occurs at rest, often at night, and is not precipitated by exertion. EKG during an episode shows transient ST-segment elevation.
  • Drug-Induced Vasospasm: Several drugs can trigger coronary vasospasm.
    - [[3a4a8ad6|Cocaine]]: A potent vasoconstrictor that can cause vasospasm and myocardial infarction, even in patients with normal coronary arteries.
    - [[triptans|Triptans]] (e.g., sumatriptan): Used for migraines, they are 5-HT1B/1D agonists that can cause coronary vasoconstriction and are contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease.
  • Treatment: Acute attacks are treated with nitroglycerin. Long-term prevention involves calcium channel blockers and nitrates.
  • USMLE Tip: Cocaine-induced chest pain should be treated with benzodiazepines and nitrates. Beta-blockers are contraindicated as they can lead to unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation and worsen the vasospasm.
content.takeAway: Coronary vasospasm is a spastic constriction of a coronary artery that causes ischemic chest pain at rest (Prinzmetal angina) and can be a dangerous side effect of vasoconstrictive drugs like cocaine and triptans.

content.definition: Cortical signs are specific neurological deficits that indicate involvement of the [[a1b198f9|cerebral cortex]], as opposed to subcortical structures like the basal ganglia, thalamus, or brainstem. Their presence is crucial for localizing lesions, particularly strokes.
content.atAGlance:
• Definition: Neurological signs that point to dysfunction of higher-order processing in the cerebral cortex.
  • Key Cortical Signs:
    - [[6bc9a567|Aphasia]]: Language disturbance (Broca's, Wernicke's), indicating a lesion in the dominant hemisphere (usually left).
    - Hemineglect: Inattention to one side of space, indicating a lesion in the non-dominant parietal lobe (usually right).
    - [[ff289b3a|Visual Field Defects]]: Homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia.
    - Agnosia: Inability to recognize objects, faces, or places.
    - Apraxia: Inability to perform learned motor tasks.
  • Clinical Significance: The presence of cortical signs helps differentiate large territorial strokes (e.g., [[143bb23d|MCA stroke]]) from small, deep strokes (lacunar infarcts), which characteristically lack cortical signs and present as pure motor or pure sensory deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient presents with contralateral hemiparesis PLUS aphasia, the lesion is cortical (likely MCA). If the patient has contralateral hemiparesis with NO aphasia, neglect, or visual field cut, the lesion is likely subcortical (e.g., a lacunar stroke in the internal capsule).
content.takeAway: Cortical signs are the clinical fingerprints of cerebral cortex dysfunction, representing deficits in higher-order functions like language and spatial awareness, and their presence or absence is a key factor in distinguishing cortical from subcortical strokes.

content.definition: The Corticospinal Tract (also known as the pyramidal tract) is the major descending motor pathway in the central nervous system that controls voluntary, fine movements of the distal and limb muscles.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Arises from upper motor neurons (UMNs) in the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, and supplementary motor area.
  • Pathway: Descends through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, cerebral peduncle (midbrain), pons, and medullary pyramids.
  • Decussation: Approximately 85-90% of fibers decussate (cross over) at the pyramidal decussation in the caudal medulla to form the lateral corticospinal tract, which descends in the lateral funiculus of the spinal cord.
  • Synapse: The UMNs of the corticospinal tract synapse on lower motor neurons (LMNs) in the anterior horn of the spinal cord.
  • Lesions: Damage to the corticospinal tract results in upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski) on the contralateral side if the lesion is above the decussation, and on the ipsilateral side if below. This tract is damaged in [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: The decussation at the medulla is a critical anatomical point. It explains why a stroke in the left motor cortex causes right-sided weakness.
content.takeAway: The Corticospinal Tract is the primary 'command pathway' for voluntary movement, originating in the motor cortex and crossing in the medulla to control the contralateral side of the body; damage to this tract is the basis of upper motor neuron syndrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Motor Cortex - UMN] --> B(Internal Capsule); B --> C(Brainstem); C --> D(Pyramidal Decussation - Medulla); D --> E(Lateral Corticospinal Tract); E --> F(Synapse on LMN in Anterior Horn);

content.definition: The Corticospinal Tracts are the primary descending motor pathways that carry motor signals from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord, enabling voluntary movement. They are composed of the lateral and anterior corticospinal tracts.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Control of voluntary, discrete, skilled movements, especially of the distal limbs.
  • Lateral Corticospinal Tract: The larger of the two tracts, containing ~90% of the fibers. These fibers have decussated (crossed) in the medullary pyramids and control the contralateral limbs.
  • Anterior (Ventral) Corticospinal Tract: Contains the ~10% of fibers that did not cross in the medulla. These fibers descend ipsilaterally and most cross at the spinal cord level they innervate, primarily controlling axial and proximal (truncal) muscles bilaterally.
  • Degeneration: Degeneration of the corticospinal tracts is a key feature of [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]], contributing to the upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) seen in the disease. It is also affected in [[6f5bea90|Subacute Combined Degeneration]] (B12 deficiency).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the vast majority of voluntary motor control to the limbs is contralateral, mediated by the lateral corticospinal tract which crosses in the medulla.
content.takeAway: The Corticospinal Tracts are the brain's direct lines of command to the spinal cord for voluntary movement, with the massive lateral tract controlling the contralateral limbs and the smaller anterior tract managing the axial musculature.

content.definition: Cotton-wool spots are fluffy, white, superficial retinal lesions seen on fundoscopic examination. They represent microinfarcts in the retinal nerve fiber layer due to occlusion of precapillary arterioles.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Ischemia in the nerve fiber layer leads to a blockage of axoplasmic transport, causing the accumulation of axoplasmic debris in the nerve fiber axons, which appear as white spots.
  • Appearance: Fluffy, white, or grayish lesions with indistinct borders on the surface of the retina.
  • Associated Conditions: They are a non-specific sign of retinal ischemia and can be seen in various systemic diseases, most commonly:
    - [[73b00ab0|Diabetic retinopathy]]
    - [[549b012e|Hypertensive retinopathy]]
  • Other Causes: Also seen in central/branch retinal vein occlusion, HIV retinopathy (including from [[cytomegalovirus|CMV]]), and systemic lupus erythematosus.
  • USMLE Tip: While not specific, the presence of cotton-wool spots on a fundoscopic exam should prompt consideration of underlying systemic vascular disease, particularly diabetes and hypertension.
content.takeAway: Cotton-wool spots are the retinal equivalent of mini-strokes, appearing as fluffy white patches that signify focal ischemia in the nerve fiber layer, most often as a consequence of microvascular damage from diabetes or hypertension.

content.definition: The Cough Reflex is a protective reflex that forcibly expels irritants, foreign material, and excess secretions from the larynx, trachea, and bronchi. It involves a complex coordination of sensory input and motor output mediated by the brainstem.
content.atAGlance:
• Afferent Limb (Sensation): The sensation of irritation in the larynx and upper airway is carried primarily by the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is itself a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Central Processing: The afferent signals are sent to the medulla oblongata.
  • Efferent Limb (Motor): The medulla coordinates a motor response involving multiple nerves:
    - The vagus nerve (CN X) causes the glottis to close and the larynx/trachea to contract.
    - The phrenic and spinal motor nerves cause contraction of the diaphragm and abdominal/intercostal muscles to generate high intrathoracic pressure.
  • Mechanism: A deep inhalation is followed by forceful exhalation against a closed glottis, which then suddenly opens, producing an explosive outflow of air.
  • USMLE Tip: The cough reflex is a key brainstem reflex. Both the afferent and primary efferent limbs are mediated by the vagus nerve (CN X). Aspiration risk is high in patients with impaired cough reflex (e.g., after a stroke affecting the medulla).
content.takeAway: The Cough Reflex is a vital airway defense mechanism orchestrated by the medulla, with the vagus nerve playing the dual role of both sensing the irritation in the airway and executing the forceful expulsion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Irritant in Airway] --> B(Afferent: CN X); B --> C(Medulla); C --> D(Efferent: CN X, Phrenic N., Spinal N.); D --> E(Forceful Expiration);

content.definition: Cranial dysraphism refers to a group of neural tube defects that result from the failure of the rostral (cranial) neuropore to close properly during the fourth week of embryonic development. This category includes conditions like [[5bcc9894|anencephaly]] and encephalocele.
content.atAGlance:
• [[5bcc9894|Anencephaly]]: The most severe form. Failure of the rostral neuropore to close leads to the absence of the forebrain and calvarium. It is incompatible with life and is associated with polyhydramnios.
  • Encephalocele: A sac-like protrusion of the brain and meninges through a defect in the skull. The occipital region is the most common site.
  • Pathophysiology: A failure of neural tube fusion at the cranial end.
  • Risk Factors: Associated with maternal folate deficiency and certain medications (e.g., valproate).
  • Diagnosis: Detected prenatally by elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and ultrasound.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate cranial dysraphism (rostral neuropore defects like anencephaly) from spinal dysraphism (caudal neuropore defects like spina bifida).
content.takeAway: Cranial dysraphism represents a failure of the neural tube to close at the head end, leading to severe and often lethal congenital malformations of the brain and skull, such as anencephaly.

content.definition: Cranial nerve nuclei are clusters of neurons (gray matter) in the brainstem from which the cranial nerves (III-XII) emerge or terminate. They are the functional equivalent of the gray matter horns of the spinal cord.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Located in the tegmentum of the brainstem (midbrain, pons, medulla).
  • Organization: Organized into functional columns. As a general rule, motor nuclei are located medially in the brainstem, while sensory nuclei are located laterally. This reflects the embryological origin from the basal (motor) and alar (sensory) plates.
  • Midline Motor Nuclei (Rule of 4s): The nuclei of cranial nerves whose numbers are factors of 12 (III, IV, VI, XII) are located medially.
  • Lateral Nuclei: The nuclei of cranial nerves V, VII, VIII, IX, X, and XI are located more laterally.
  • Clinical Significance: Brainstem strokes often present with specific cranial nerve deficits that can be used to localize the lesion. Medial brainstem syndromes affect the midline motor nuclei, while lateral syndromes affect the lateral sensory and branchiomotor nuclei.
  • USMLE Tip: Knowing the medial vs. lateral organization of the cranial nerve nuclei is a high-yield concept for solving brainstem lesion problems.
content.takeAway: The cranial nerve nuclei are the command and control centers for the cranial nerves, systematically arranged within the brainstem with motor nuclei positioned medially and sensory nuclei laterally, providing a precise anatomical map for localizing brainstem lesions.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brainstem]; A --> B(Medial Column - Motor Nuclei); B --> C(CN III, IV, VI, XII); A --> D(Lateral Column - Sensory/Other Nuclei); D --> E(CN V, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI);

content.definition: The cranial nerves are a set of 12 paired nerves that emerge directly from the brain or brainstem. They are part of the peripheral nervous system (with the exception of CN II) and are responsible for the sensory and motor functions of the head and neck, as well as certain autonomic functions.
content.atAGlance:
• Numbering: Numbered I through XII in rostral to caudal order.
  • Function Types (Mnemonic): "Some Say Marry Money But My Brother Says Big Brains Matter Most" indicates whether each nerve is Sensory, Motor, or Both.
  • Brainstem Location: CN I and II emerge from the cerebrum. CN III and IV emerge from the midbrain. CN V, VI, VII, and VIII emerge from the pons. CN IX, X, XI, and XII emerge from the medulla.
  • Common Lesions: Palsies of the cranial nerves produce specific, predictable deficits (e.g., [[fdfd22ca|CN III palsy]] causes a 'down and out' eye; [[facial_nerve_palsy|CN VII palsy]] causes facial droop).
  • Reflexes: Many clinical reflexes, such as the [[64663383|corneal reflex]] (CN V, VII) and gag reflex (CN IX, X), are used to test the integrity of specific cranial nerves and their brainstem pathways.
  • Polyradiculopathy: Conditions like [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré syndrome]] can affect cranial nerves, causing symptoms like bilateral facial weakness.
content.takeAway: The cranial nerves are the specialized peripheral nerves of the head and neck, each with a unique function and anatomical course, making their clinical examination a powerful tool for localizing lesions within the brainstem and skull base.

content.definition: The anatomical relationships between the cranial nerves and arteries at the base of the brain are clinically significant, as vascular pathologies like aneurysms or strokes can cause specific cranial nerve palsies due to compression or ischemia.
content.atAGlance:
• CN III (Oculomotor): Passes between the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and the superior cerebellar artery (SCA). An aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery (PComA) is a classic cause of a compressive CN III palsy.
  • CN VI (Abducens): Has a long intracranial course and is closely related to the [[3c075343|anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)]] near the pons.
  • CN XII (Hypoglossal): Exits the medulla near the [[1430f5b4|anterior spinal artery (ASA)]] and vertebral artery. Occlusion of the ASA can cause Medial Medullary Syndrome, which includes an ipsilateral CN XII palsy.
  • Cavernous Sinus: A critical location where CNs III, IV, V1, V2, and VI are in close proximity to the internal carotid artery.
  • USMLE Tip: The relationship between the PComA and CN III is extremely high-yield. A painful third nerve palsy with a dilated pupil is a PComA aneurysm until proven otherwise.
content.takeAway: The close proximity of cranial nerves and arteries at the skull base creates 'danger zones' where vascular abnormalities can directly impact nerve function, with the PComA aneurysm compressing CN III being the most classic and clinically urgent example.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[PComA Aneurysm] --Compresses--> B(CN III); C[AICA Stroke] --Affects--> D(CN VI, VII, VIII); E[ASA Stroke] --Affects--> F(CN XII);

content.definition: The cranial nerve foramina are the openings in the base of the skull through which the cranial nerves, as well as major blood vessels, pass to exit the cranial cavity.
content.atAGlance:
• Anterior Cranial Fossa:
    - Cribriform Plate: CN I (Olfactory nerves).
  • Middle Cranial Fossa:
    - Optic Canal: CN II, Ophthalmic artery.
    - Superior Orbital Fissure: CN III, IV, V1, VI.
    - Foramen Rotundum: CN V2.
    - Foramen Ovale: CN V3.
    - Foramen Spinosum: Middle meningeal artery.
  • Posterior Cranial Fossa:
    - Internal Auditory Meatus: CN VII, VIII.
    - Jugular Foramen: CN IX, X, XI, Jugular vein.
    - Hypoglossal Canal: CN XII.
    - Foramen Magnum: Brainstem/Spinal cord, Vertebral arteries, Spinal root of CN XI.
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonics are very helpful here. For the Superior Orbital Fissure: "Live Frankly To See Absolutely No Insult" (Lacrimal n., Frontal n., Trochlear n., Superior division of CN III, Abducens n., Nasociliary n., Inferior division of CN III). For Foramina of V: "Standing Room Only" (Superior orbital fissure for V1, Rotundum for V2, Ovale for V3).
content.takeAway: Knowledge of the cranial nerve foramina is essential for clinical localization, as fractures or tumors at the skull base can produce specific patterns of cranial nerve deficits based on which foramina are involved.

content.definition: A craniopharyngioma is a rare, benign, slow-growing suprasellar tumor that arises from epithelial remnants of Rathke's pouch. Despite being benign, it can cause significant morbidity due to its location and compression of surrounding structures.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Arises from remnants of Rathke's pouch (oral ectoderm), the same embryonic structure that forms the [[76ba7f2e|anterior pituitary]].
  • Epidemiology: Has a bimodal age distribution, with peaks in childhood (5-14 years) and adulthood (50-74 years). It is the most common childhood supratentorial tumor.
  • Location: Suprasellar region, near the pituitary gland and optic chiasm.
  • Clinical Presentation: Due to compression:
    - Optic Chiasm: [[6c3a980e|Bitemporal hemianopia]].
    - Pituitary Stalk/Gland: Endocrine dysfunction, most commonly growth hormone deficiency (short stature in children) and diabetes insipidus.
    - Third Ventricle: Hydrocephalus and increased ICP.
  • Histology & Imaging: Often cystic and calcified. The cysts are filled with a thick, brownish-yellow fluid rich in cholesterol crystals, described as "machine oil." Histology shows nests of squamous epithelium and "wet keratin" (anucleate squamous cells).
  • USMLE Tip: A child with short stature, headaches, and bitemporal hemianopia, with a calcified suprasellar mass on imaging, is the classic vignette for a craniopharyngioma.
content.takeAway: A craniopharyngioma is a benign but problematic tumor arising from embryonic remnants of Rathke's pouch, which classically presents in a child with a triad of visual field defects, endocrine failure, and hydrocephalus, often with characteristic calcifications on imaging.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Rathke's Pouch Remnant] --> B(Craniopharyngioma); B --Compresses--> C(Optic Chiasm); C --> D(Bitemporal Hemianopia); B --Compresses--> E(Pituitary/Hypothalamus); E --> F(Endocrinopathy);

content.definition: The Cremasteric Reflex is a superficial reflex in males that is elicited by lightly stroking or pinching the superior and medial part of the thigh, resulting in a rapid elevation of the ipsilateral testicle due to contraction of the cremaster muscle.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: Tests the integrity of the L1 and L2 spinal nerve roots. Mnemonic: L1, 2, testicles move.
  • Afferent Limb (Sensation): The stimulus is sensed by the ilioinguinal nerve and the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve.
  • Efferent Limb (Motor): The motor response is carried by the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, which innervates the cremaster muscle.
  • Clinical Significance: The reflex is characteristically absent in cases of testicular torsion, making it a crucial diagnostic sign in the evaluation of acute scrotal pain. It is also absent in L1-L2 spinal cord injury or nerve damage.
  • USMLE Tip: An absent cremasteric reflex in a male with acute scrotal pain is highly suggestive of testicular torsion until proven otherwise and constitutes a urologic emergency.
content.takeAway: The Cremasteric Reflex is a key physical exam finding in evaluating acute scrotal pain; its presence argues against testicular torsion, while its absence is a major red flag for this surgical emergency.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Stroke Inner Thigh] --> B(Afferent: Ilioinguinal/Genitofemoral N.); B --> C(L1-L2 Spinal Cord); C --> D(Efferent: Genitofemoral N.); D --> E(Cremaster Muscle Contraction); E --> F(Testicle Elevation);

content.definition: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is a rare, fatal, and transmissible neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions. It is characterized by a rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by prions, which are misfolded proteins (PrPSc) that induce the misfolding of normal cellular prion proteins (PrPC). This leads to an exponential accumulation of abnormal protein aggregates that are resistant to proteases.
  • Forms:
    - Sporadic (sCJD): Most common form (~85%), occurs spontaneously.
    - Familial (fCJD): Due to an inherited mutation in the PRNP gene.
    - Iatrogenic (iCJD): Transmitted via contaminated neurosurgical instruments, corneal transplants, or human-derived growth hormone.
    - Variant (vCJD): Linked to consumption of beef from cattle with bovine spongiform encephalopathy ('mad cow disease').
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapidly progressive dementia over weeks to months, accompanied by ataxia and startle myoclonus (jerking movements in response to loud noises or touch).
  • Diagnostic Findings:
    - EEG: Periodic sharp wave complexes.
    - CSF: Presence of 14-3-3 protein.
    - MRI: High signal intensity in the caudate nucleus and putamen or cortex on DWI/FLAIR sequences.
    - Histology: Spongiform encephalopathy (vacuolation of the neuropil) without significant inflammation.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with dementia that progresses from mild confusion to profound incapacity in just a few months, especially with myoclonus, is the classic presentation of CJD.
content.takeAway: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is a prion-mediated neurodegenerative catastrophe, distinguished by its astonishingly rapid progression from cognitive decline to death, and marked pathologically by the brain turning into a 'sponge' due to widespread neuronal loss and vacuolation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[PrPSc Prion] --> B(Induces Misfolding of Normal PrPC); B --> C(Aggregation of PrPSc); C --> D(Spongiform Encephalopathy); D --> E(Rapidly Progressive Dementia & Myoclonus);

content.definition: The Cushing reflex (or Cushing's triad) is a physiological nervous system response to a rapid increase in intracranial pressure (ICP). It is a late and ominous sign of severe brain injury or herniation, indicating imminent brainstem failure.
content.atAGlance:
• The Triad:
    1. Hypertension: A significant increase in systemic blood pressure.
    2. Bradycardia: A paradoxical slowing of the heart rate.
    3. Irregular Respirations: Abnormal breathing patterns, such as Cheyne-Stokes respirations.
  • Pathophysiology:
    - Hypertension: As ICP rises, it begins to compress cerebral arteries, reducing [[3eca3f19|cerebral perfusion]]. The brain's vasomotor center responds by triggering a massive sympathetic surge to increase systemic blood pressure (MAP) in an attempt to restore cerebral blood flow (CPP = MAP - ICP).
    - Bradycardia: The resulting systemic hypertension is sensed by peripheral baroreceptors (in the carotid sinus and aortic arch), which then trigger a reflexive, vagally-mediated slowing of the heart rate.
  • Clinical Significance: The appearance of Cushing's triad is a sign of severely elevated ICP and impending brainstem herniation. It is a neurosurgical emergency.
  • USMLE Tip: Do not confuse Cushing's triad with Cushing's syndrome. The triad is an acute neurological sign, while the syndrome is a chronic endocrine disorder. The combination of rising blood pressure and falling heart rate in a patient with a head injury is a major red flag.
content.takeAway: The Cushing reflex is the brain's last-ditch effort to save itself from ischemia due to high intracranial pressure, where it dramatically raises systemic blood pressure to force blood into the compressed cranium, inadvertently triggering a baroreceptor-mediated reflex bradycardia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Intracranial Pressure] --> B(↓ Cerebral Perfusion Pressure); B --> C(Cerebral Ischemia); C --> D(Sympathetic Surge); D --> E(↑ Systemic Hypertension); E --> F(Baroreceptor Activation); F --> G(Reflex Bradycardia);

content.definition: Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally acting skeletal muscle relaxant used for the short-term treatment of muscle spasms associated with acute, painful musculoskeletal conditions.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it is thought to act at the brainstem level to reduce tonic somatic motor activity. It is structurally related to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) and shares many of their properties.
  • Clinical Use: Used as an adjunct to rest and physical therapy for the relief of muscle spasms from acute musculoskeletal injuries (e.g., low back strain). It is not effective for spasticity of CNS origin (e.g., cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis).
  • Adverse Effects: Due to its structural similarity to TCAs, it has significant anticholinergic (dry mouth, urinary retention, confusion) and antihistaminic (sedation, drowsiness) side effects.
  • Contraindications: Should not be used with MAO inhibitors due to the risk of serotonin syndrome. Use with caution in the elderly due to its anticholinergic and sedative effects.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember cyclobenzaprine for acute muscle spasms. Differentiate its use from drugs like [[1ddc3f08|baclofen]] or tizanidine, which are used for chronic spasticity. Its TCA-like structure explains its side effect profile.
content.takeAway: Cyclobenzaprine is a short-term muscle relaxant for acute spasms that works centrally and carries a side effect profile very similar to tricyclic antidepressants, most notably sedation and anticholinergic effects.

content.definition: Cytotoxic edema is a type of [[aa00bdef|cerebral edema]] characterized by the swelling of brain cells, particularly neurons and glia, due to an intracellular accumulation of fluid. It is a key early event in cerebral ischemia.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The primary cause is a failure of the ATP-dependent Na+/K+ pump, typically due to ischemia and energy failure. The pump failure leads to an influx of Na+ and other ions into the cell, and water follows osmotically, causing the cell to swell.
  • Timing in Stroke: It is the first type of edema to appear after an [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]], developing within minutes to hours.
  • Contrast with Vasogenic Edema: Vasogenic edema involves leakage of fluid into the extracellular space due to a breakdown of the blood-brain barrier and occurs later in the course of a stroke.
  • Other Causes: Can also be caused by other metabolic insults like hypoxia, hypoglycemia, or certain toxins that disrupt cellular energy metabolism.
  • USMLE Tip: For a stroke timeline question, remember that cytotoxic edema (intracellular swelling) happens first, followed by vasogenic edema (extracellular fluid) hours to days later.
content.takeAway: Cytotoxic edema is the rapid, intracellular swelling of brain cells caused by energy failure and dysfunctional ion pumps, representing the initial and direct cellular response to ischemic injury.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ischemia/Hypoxia] --> B(↓ ATP); B --> C(Na+/K+ Pump Failure); C --> D(↑ Intracellular Na+); D --> E(Water Influx); E --> F(Cell Swelling - Cytotoxic Edema);

content.definition: Danazol is a synthetic steroid with weak androgenic, progestogenic, and glucocorticoid activity. It primarily acts as a weak androgen and is used to suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A synthetic androgen that acts as a partial agonist at androgen receptors. It suppresses the pituitary-ovarian axis by inhibiting the mid-cycle surge of FSH and LH, leading to decreased estrogen production and anovulation.
  • Clinical Use: Used to treat endometriosis, fibrocystic breast disease, and hereditary angioedema.
  • Adverse Effects: Due to its androgenic properties, it can cause weight gain, edema, acne, hirsutism, and masculinization. It is also hepatotoxic.
  • Neurologic Side Effect: Danazol is a known cause of [[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]] (pseudotumor cerebri).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember Danazol as a weak androgen used for gynecologic conditions like endometriosis. Be aware of its androgenic side effects and its association with pseudotumor cerebri.
content.takeAway: Danazol is a synthetic androgen that treats estrogen-dependent conditions like endometriosis by suppressing the pituitary-ovarian axis, but its clinical utility is limited by its masculinizing side effects and the risk of inducing idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

content.definition: Dandy-Walker malformation is a congenital brain malformation of the posterior fossa characterized by agenesis or hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, and enlargement of the posterior fossa.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A developmental anomaly of the cerebellum and the fourth ventricle. The key feature is the failure of the cerebellar vermis to develop.
  • Clinical Presentation: Often presents in infancy with signs of non-communicating hydrocephalus due to obstruction of CSF outflow from the fourth ventricle. This can cause a rapidly increasing head circumference, bulging fontanelles, and developmental delay.
  • Imaging: Brain imaging (ultrasound, CT, or MRI) shows a large posterior fossa, a cystically dilated fourth ventricle that communicates with the cisterna magna, and an absent or hypoplastic cerebellar vermis.
  • Associated Conditions: Can be associated with other CNS and systemic anomalies.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic imaging triad is: 1) Agenesis of the vermis, 2) Cystic dilation of the 4th ventricle, and 3) Enlarged posterior fossa. This leads to non-communicating hydrocephalus.
content.takeAway: Dandy-Walker malformation is a congenital defect defined by an absent cerebellar vermis, which allows the fourth ventricle to expand into a large posterior fossa cyst, commonly leading to hydrocephalus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Agenesis of Cerebellar Vermis] --> B(Cystic Dilation of 4th Ventricle); B --> C(Enlarged Posterior Fossa); B --> D(Obstruction of CSF Outflow); D --> E(Non-communicating Hydrocephalus);

content.definition: Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that is the primary treatment for malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts directly on skeletal muscle by binding to the ryanodine receptor (RyR1) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This blocks the release of Ca2+ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, thereby uncoupling excitation-contraction coupling.
  • Clinical Use:
    - [[malignant_hyperthermia|Malignant Hyperthermia (MH)]]: The definitive treatment for this life-threatening reaction to inhaled anesthetics and succinylcholine.
    - [[neuroleptic_malignant_syndrome|Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)]]: Used to treat the muscle rigidity and hyperthermia associated with this reaction to antipsychotic drugs.
  • Adverse Effects: Generalized muscle weakness, sedation, and potential for hepatotoxicity with long-term use.
  • USMLE Tip: Dantrolene is the life-saving antidote for both MH and NMS. Its unique mechanism of acting directly on the sarcoplasmic reticulum to block calcium release is key.
content.takeAway: Dantrolene is a crucial emergency drug that reverses the life-threatening hypermetabolic states of malignant hyperthermia and NMS by directly inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, effectively calming the over-contracting muscles.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dantrolene] --Inhibits--> B(Ryanodine Receptor RyR1); B --x C(Ca2+ Release from Sarcoplasmic Reticulum); C --x D(Muscle Contraction); D --> E(Treats MH & NMS);

content.definition: Daptomycin is a lipopeptide antibiotic with potent activity against gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It is not related to the visual finding of a 'dark curtain' vision loss.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Inserts its lipid tail into the bacterial cell membrane in a Ca2+-dependent manner, creating transmembrane channels that lead to ion leakage, depolarization, and rapid cell death.
  • Spectrum of Activity: Gram-positive organisms, including MRSA, vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), and S. epidermidis.
  • Clinical Use: Complicated skin and soft tissue infections, bacteremia, and right-sided endocarditis caused by susceptible gram-positive organisms.
  • Important Limitation: Cannot be used for pneumonia because it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant.
  • Adverse Effects: The most significant side effect is myopathy and rhabdomyolysis. Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels must be monitored.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember two key facts about daptomycin: 1) It's great for MRSA and VRE, but 2) It's useless in the lungs. The risk of myopathy is also high-yield.
content.takeAway: Daptomycin is a powerful weapon against resistant gram-positive bacteria, killing them by punching holes in their cell membranes, but its utility is nullified in the lungs by surfactant, and its use requires monitoring for muscle toxicity.

content.definition: Decerebrate posturing is a type of abnormal motor posturing characterized by rigid extension of the arms and legs, internal rotation of the arms, and plantar flexion of the feet. It is a sign of severe brain injury, specifically damage to the brainstem at or below the level of the red nucleus.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: Arms are adducted and extended, wrists pronated, fingers flexed; legs are stiffly extended with plantar flexion of the feet.
  • Pathophysiology: The lesion is located in the brainstem between the red nucleus (in the midbrain) and the vestibular nuclei (in the pons/medulla). This disrupts descending motor pathways from the cortex and red nucleus (which mediate flexion), leaving the extensor-promoting vestibulospinal tract unopposed.
  • Prognosis: Decerebrate posturing indicates more severe, caudal brainstem damage than decorticate posturing and thus carries a worse prognosis.
  • Comparison to Decorticate: In [[dcce4415|decorticate posturing]], the lesion is above the red nucleus, so the rubrospinal tract (flexor) is intact and dominates in the upper limbs.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that decerebrate posturing involves extension of the arms and is a sign of a more severe brainstem injury.
content.takeAway: Decerebrate posturing is an ominous sign of severe brainstem damage below the red nucleus, where the loss of flexor-driving pathways leaves the body in a state of rigid extension, driven by the unopposed vestibulospinal tract.

content.definition: Decorticate posturing is a type of abnormal motor posturing characterized by flexion of the arms, wrists, and fingers, with adduction of the upper extremities, while the lower extremities are extended. It is a sign of severe damage to the cerebral hemispheres, internal capsule, or thalamus, above the level of the midbrain.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: Arms are flexed or bent inward on the chest, hands are clenched into fists, and legs are held out straight. Mnemonic: The arms are flexed toward the 'cor' (core/heart).
  • Pathophysiology: The lesion is located above the red nucleus in the midbrain. This disrupts the corticospinal tract but leaves the rubrospinal tract (which originates from the red nucleus and facilitates flexion in the upper limbs) intact and unopposed. The vestibulospinal tract remains intact, causing extension in the lower limbs.
  • Prognosis: Indicates severe brain damage, but generally carries a better prognosis than [[528ae59c|decerebrate posturing]], which signifies a more caudal brainstem lesion.
  • Progression: A patient may initially present with decorticate posturing and then progress to decerebrate posturing as the injury descends, indicating a worsening condition.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to differentiating posturing types is the arm position. Decorticate = flexion (lesion above red nucleus). Decerebrate = extension (lesion below red nucleus).
content.takeAway: Decorticate posturing is a sign of severe supratentorial or diencephalic injury, where damage to the corticospinal tracts above the red nucleus results in a characteristic pattern of upper limb flexion (from the unopposed rubrospinal tract) and lower limb extension.

content.definition: Dementia is a syndrome characterized by a progressive decline in cognitive function, including memory, language, problem-solving, and other thinking abilities, that is severe enough to interfere with daily life. Consciousness is not affected.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Feature: A decline from a previous level of functioning that is not explained by delirium or major psychiatric disorder.
  • Most Common Types:
    1. [[77ae6148|Alzheimer Disease]]: Most common cause (~60-80%). Gradual onset, with memory impairment as the earliest and most prominent feature.
    2. [[99420dce|Vascular Dementia]]: Second most common. Caused by cerebrovascular disease. Typically has a stepwise decline in function with focal neurological deficits.
    3. [[db2f16e5|Lewy Body Dementia]]: Characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism.
  • Reversible Causes: It is crucial to rule out reversible causes of cognitive decline, such as hypothyroidism, vitamin B12 deficiency, neurosyphilis, depression (pseudodementia), and normal pressure hydrocephalus.
  • USMLE Tip: The specific pattern of deficits and associated symptoms helps differentiate the types of dementia. For example, early personality changes point to frontotemporal dementia, while visual hallucinations are characteristic of Lewy body dementia.
content.takeAway: Dementia is a broad clinical syndrome of acquired and progressive cognitive decline that impairs daily function; identifying the underlying cause, particularly distinguishing irreversible neurodegenerative types like Alzheimer's from potentially reversible conditions, is the primary diagnostic challenge.

content.definition: Demyelinating and dysmyelinating disorders are a group of neurological conditions characterized by damage to or defective formation of myelin, the protective sheath that surrounds nerve axons, leading to impaired nerve signal conduction.
content.atAGlance:
• Demyelination: The destruction of previously normal myelin. Can affect the CNS or PNS.
    - CNS Demyelination: [[45dd6d19|Multiple Sclerosis (MS)]] is the archetypal example, where oligodendrocytes are destroyed.
    - PNS Demyelination: [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome]] is the classic example, where Schwann cells are destroyed.
  • Dysmyelination: The formation of abnormal, defective myelin, typically due to genetic/metabolic defects. These are also known as leukodystrophies.
    - [[a078dbd0|Metachromatic Leukodystrophy]]: Arylsulfatase A deficiency.
    - [[246a82f3|Krabbe Disease]]: Galactocerebrosidase deficiency.
    - [[21d4b96a|Adrenoleukodystrophy]]: Defect in VLCFA transport into peroxisomes.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms vary widely depending on the location of the affected nerves but generally involve motor, sensory, and cognitive deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: The key distinction is demyelination (destruction of normal myelin, often autoimmune) versus dysmyelination (abnormal myelin formation, usually genetic/metabolic).
content.takeAway: Demyelinating and dysmyelinating disorders both disrupt the insulation of nerve fibers, but demyelination involves an attack on healthy myelin (like in MS), while dysmyelination involves a fundamental defect in myelin production from the start (like in leukodystrophies).

content.definition: The Dentate Nucleus is the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellar nuclei. It is a crucial relay station, receiving input from the cerebellar cortex and sending output from the cerebellum to modulate motor and cognitive functions.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Located deep within the lateral hemisphere of the [[bebe58d4|cerebellum]].
  • Function: Primarily involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements, especially of the distal extremities. It also contributes to cognitive functions.
  • Input: Receives inhibitory (GABAergic) input from Purkinje cells in the lateral cerebellar hemispheres.
  • Output: Sends excitatory (glutamatergic) projections via the superior cerebellar peduncle to the contralateral ventral lateral (VL) nucleus of the thalamus, which in turn projects to the motor cortex.
  • Lesion Effect: A lesion of the dentate nucleus results in ipsilateral limb ataxia, including dysmetria (inability to judge distance) and intention tremor.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic for the deep cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial: "Don't Eat Greasy Foods" (Dentate, Emboliform, Globose, Fastigial). The dentate is the largest and most lateral, corresponding to the lateral hemispheres' control of the limbs.
content.takeAway: The Dentate Nucleus is the primary output channel for the lateral cerebellum, responsible for translating the cerebellum's complex computations into corrective signals that are sent to the motor cortex via the thalamus to ensure smooth and accurate limb movements.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lateral Cerebellar Cortex] --Inhibitory--> B(Dentate Nucleus); B --Excitatory--> C(Contralateral Thalamus - VL); C --> D(Motor Cortex);

content.definition: Depolarizing neuromuscular blockers are a class of drugs that cause muscle paralysis by acting as agonists at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor of the neuromuscular junction, leading to persistent depolarization of the motor endplate.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Agent: Succinylcholine is the only depolarizing agent in clinical use.
  • Mechanism of Action (Phase I): Succinylcholine binds to the nicotinic ACh receptor and acts like acetylcholine, causing the muscle to depolarize. This initial depolarization leads to transient muscle twitching (fasciculations). However, succinylcholine is not metabolized by acetylcholinesterase, so it remains bound, keeping the membrane depolarized and rendering it unresponsive to further stimuli (flaccid paralysis).
  • Mechanism of Action (Phase II): With continued exposure, the receptor becomes desensitized, and the membrane repolarizes. However, the receptor is still unresponsive to acetylcholine, and the paralysis is maintained.
  • Clinical Use: Used for rapid sequence intubation due to its fast onset (30-60 seconds) and short duration of action (5-10 minutes).
  • Adverse Effects: Hyperkalemia (can be life-threatening in patients with burns, crush injuries, or neuromuscular disease), malignant hyperthermia, and increased intraocular/intragastric pressure.
  • USMLE Tip: The initial fasciculations are a key feature that distinguishes depolarizing blockers from non-depolarizing blockers. Remember the contraindication in burn/crush injury patients due to the risk of severe hyperkalemia.
content.takeAway: Succinylcholine, the sole depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, induces paralysis through a two-phase process of persistent depolarization followed by receptor desensitization, offering a uniquely rapid onset and offset ideal for emergency intubation but with significant risks like hyperkalemia and malignant hyperthermia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Succinylcholine] --> B(Binds Nicotinic ACh Receptor); B --> C(Phase I: Depolarization); C --> D(Fasciculations); D --> E(Flaccid Paralysis); B --Prolonged Exposure--> F(Phase II: Desensitization); F --> E;

content.definition: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a mood disorder characterized by a persistent feeling of sadness or a loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia), accompanied by other emotional and physical problems that significantly impair daily functioning.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurotransmitter Changes: The monoamine hypothesis suggests that depression is related to a deficiency in the brain of monoamine neurotransmitters, particularly serotonin (5-HT), norepinephrine (NE), and dopamine (DA).
  • Diagnosis (SIG E CAPS): Diagnosis requires ≥5 of the following symptoms for ≥2 weeks, including at least one of depressed mood or anhedonia:
    - Sleep disturbance
    - Interest loss (anhedonia)
    - Guilt or worthlessness
    - Energy loss
    - Concentration problems
    - Appetite/weight changes
    - Psychomotor retardation or agitation
    - Suicidal ideation
  • Treatment: First-line treatment is typically a combination of psychotherapy (e.g., CBT) and pharmacotherapy, most commonly with Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs).
  • USMLE Tip: The SIG E CAPS mnemonic is essential for recognizing MDD in a clinical vignette. Remember that most antidepressants work by increasing the levels of monoamine neurotransmitters in the synapse.
content.takeAway: Major Depressive Disorder is a debilitating mood disorder thought to stem from a functional deficit of monoamine neurotransmitters, leading to a persistent state of low mood and anhedonia that is treated by therapies aimed at restoring this neurochemical balance.

content.definition: A dermatome is an area of skin that is mainly supplied by afferent nerve fibers from a single dorsal root of a spinal nerve. Dermatome landmarks are specific, clinically useful areas of the body whose sensory innervation corresponds to a known spinal nerve root.
content.atAGlance:
• C3, C4, C5: Supply the diaphragm ('C3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive'). Phrenic nerve irritation can cause referred pain to the shoulder (C4 dermatome).
  • T4: Level of the nipples ('T4 at the teat pore').
  • T7: Level of the xiphoid process.
  • T10: Level of the umbilicus ('T10 at the belly bu-ten'). Site of referred pain in early appendicitis.
  • L1: Inguinal ligament region.
  • L4: Includes the kneecaps ('Down on ALL 4's').
  • S2, S3, S4: Sensation of the perineum ('S2, 3, 4 keep the penis off the floor').
  • USMLE Tip: Knowing these key landmarks is essential for localizing spinal cord lesions. For example, sensory loss below the umbilicus suggests a lesion at or above the T10 spinal level.
content.takeAway: Dermatome landmarks provide a crucial roadmap for the neurological exam, allowing clinicians to trace sensory deficits on the skin back to a specific spinal nerve root, thereby localizing lesions within the spinal cord or peripheral nervous system.

content.definition: Desflurane is a volatile halogenated ether used as an inhaled general anesthetic for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanism is unknown, but it is thought to enhance the activity of inhibitory neurotransmitter receptors (like GABAA and glycine receptors) and inhibit excitatory receptors (like NMDA receptors).
  • Pharmacokinetics: It has a very low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.42). This low solubility in blood leads to a very rapid onset of anesthesia and a very rapid recovery upon discontinuation.
  • Potency: It has a high MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration) of about 6%, meaning it is less potent than other volatile anesthetics like isoflurane.
  • Adverse Effects: Causes respiratory depression and myocardial depression (leading to hypotension). It is a pungent airway irritant, which can cause coughing, breath-holding, and laryngospasm, making it unsuitable for inhalation induction. It can also trigger malignant hyperthermia.
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature of desflurane is its extremely low blood solubility, which translates to the fastest induction and emergence of all the volatile anesthetics.
content.takeAway: Desflurane is the 'speedster' of inhaled anesthetics, offering exceptionally rapid onset and recovery due to its very low solubility in blood, though its pungency limits its use for inhalation induction.

content.definition: Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder characterized by chronic hyperglycemia, which leads to numerous long-term complications, including significant damage to the central and peripheral nervous systems.
content.atAGlance:
• Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy: The most common complication. Typically a distal, symmetric, 'glove and stocking' polyneuropathy affecting sensory and motor nerves. Caused by ischemic damage to nerves from microvascular disease and direct toxic effects of hyperglycemia (e.g., sorbitol accumulation).
  • Autonomic Neuropathy: Can affect any part of the autonomic nervous system, leading to gastroparesis, orthostatic hypotension, and erectile dysfunction.
  • Mononeuropathies: Can cause isolated cranial nerve palsies, most commonly affecting [[68c66997|CN III]] (often pupil-sparing) and [[dd11dde6|CN VI]].
  • Stroke Risk: Diabetes is a major risk factor for atherosclerotic disease, significantly increasing the risk of both ischemic and lacunar strokes.
  • Restless Legs Syndrome: Diabetes is a common secondary cause of [[919caff2|restless legs syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: A 'glove and stocking' sensory loss in a patient with a history of diabetes is classic for diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A diabetic patient with a 'down and out' eye but a normal, reactive pupil has an ischemic CN III palsy.
content.takeAway: Chronic hyperglycemia in diabetes mellitus is toxic to the nervous system, causing a wide spectrum of neurological complications from a slow, creeping 'glove and stocking' peripheral neuropathy to acute cranial nerve palsies and an increased risk of stroke.

content.definition: Diabetic retinopathy is a microvascular complication of [[5bc4bd07|diabetes mellitus]] and a leading cause of blindness in working-age adults. It is caused by chronic hyperglycemia-induced damage to the small blood vessels of the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Nonproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR): The earlier stage. Characterized by damaged capillaries leaking fluid and lipids into the retina. Fundoscopic findings include microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, hard exudates (lipid deposits), and [[2b254051|cotton-wool spots]] (nerve fiber layer infarcts). Vision loss in this stage is primarily due to macular edema.
  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): The more advanced and severe stage. Chronic retinal ischemia stimulates the production of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), leading to neovascularization (growth of new, abnormal blood vessels) on the retina or optic disc.
  • Complications of PDR: These fragile new vessels can bleed, causing vitreous hemorrhage. They can also lead to tractional retinal detachment.
  • Pathophysiology: Chronic hyperglycemia leads to the formation of advanced glycation end products and activation of the polyol pathway (glucose → sorbitol), causing osmotic damage and oxidative stress to pericytes and endothelial cells.
  • USMLE Tip: The key distinction is the presence (proliferative) or absence (nonproliferative) of neovascularization. Macular edema can cause vision loss in NPDR, while vitreous hemorrhage and retinal detachment are the major threats in PDR.
content.takeAway: Diabetic retinopathy progresses from a state of leaky, damaged vessels (nonproliferative) to a state of ischemic-driven, dangerous new vessel growth (proliferative), with both stages threatening vision through macular edema, hemorrhage, or retinal detachment.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chronic Hyperglycemia] --> B(Microvascular Damage); B --> C(Nonproliferative Retinopathy); C --> D(Hemorrhages, Exudates, Macular Edema); C --> E(Retinal Ischemia); E --> F(↑ VEGF); F --> G(Proliferative Retinopathy - Neovascularization);

content.definition: Diarrhea is the condition of having at least three loose, liquid, or watery bowel movements each day. It is a common symptom of gastrointestinal distress and can be classified as osmotic, secretory, inflammatory, or motility-related.
content.atAGlance:
• Osmotic Diarrhea: Caused by the presence of non-absorbable solutes in the intestine, which draw water into the lumen (e.g., lactose intolerance, magnesium-containing antacids). Stops with fasting.
  • Secretory Diarrhea: Caused by stimulation of ion and water secretion by the intestinal epithelium (e.g., cholera toxin, VIPoma). Persists with fasting.
  • Inflammatory Diarrhea: Caused by inflammation and damage to the mucosal lining, leading to loss of protein-rich fluid and blood (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, invasive bacterial infections like Shigella, Campylobacter).
  • Motility-Related Diarrhea: Caused by abnormally rapid intestinal transit time, which reduces water absorption (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome).
  • Pharmacologic Treatment: [[67a856bf|Opioids]] and their derivatives (e.g., loperamide, diphenoxylate) are effective antidiarrheal agents because they bind to μ-opioid receptors in the gut, which inhibits acetylcholine release and decreases peristalsis, increasing transit time and water absorption.
  • USMLE Tip: Loperamide is an over-the-counter opioid agonist that does not cross the blood-brain barrier, so it treats diarrhea without causing CNS effects. Diphenoxylate can have CNS effects at high doses and is co-formulated with atropine to discourage abuse.
content.takeAway: Diarrhea is a symptom with diverse mechanisms, and its treatment with opioids like loperamide is based on their ability to slow gut motility by acting on μ-receptors in the myenteric plexus, effectively 'braking' the overactive peristalsis.

content.definition: Diazepam (trade name Valium) is a long-acting benzodiazepine with prominent sedative, anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, and muscle relaxant properties.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A positive allosteric modulator of the GABAA receptor. It increases the frequency of chloride channel opening in response to GABA, leading to enhanced CNS inhibition.
  • Pharmacokinetics: It is a long-acting benzodiazepine with a rapid onset of action and active metabolites (including oxazepam and temazepam), which contributes to its prolonged effect.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Anxiety: For short-term management of severe anxiety.
    - Seizures: A first-line agent for treating status epilepticus.
    - Alcohol Withdrawal: Used to manage symptoms and prevent seizures and delirium tremens.
    - Muscle Spasms: Used as a skeletal muscle relaxant.
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal. Additive CNS depression with other depressants like alcohol. Its long half-life makes it less suitable for the elderly due to the risk of accumulation and falls.
  • USMLE Tip: Diazepam and lorazepam are the go-to drugs for terminating status epilepticus. Diazepam's long half-life makes it a good choice for managing alcohol withdrawal.
content.takeAway: Diazepam is a fast-acting, long-duration benzodiazepine that is a workhorse for acute CNS hyperexcitability, effectively terminating seizures in status epilepticus and calming the storm of alcohol withdrawal by robustly enhancing GABAergic inhibition.

content.definition: The Diencephalon is a major division of the forebrain (prosencephalon) situated between the telencephalon and the midbrain. It develops from the posterior part of the embryonic forebrain and gives rise to several critical brain structures.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryonic Origin: Arises from the prosencephalon (forebrain) vesicle.
  • Adult Derivatives: The diencephalon develops into four main components:
    1. [[afc0a64b|Thalamus]]: The major relay station for sensory information (except smell) to the cerebral cortex.
    2. [[89e86633|Hypothalamus]]: The primary regulator of the autonomic nervous system and endocrine system.
    3. Epithalamus: Includes the pineal gland (melatonin secretion) and habenula.
    4. Subthalamus: Includes the subthalamic nucleus, a key part of the basal ganglia motor circuit.
  • Associated Cavity: The cavity of the diencephalon becomes the third ventricle.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the thalamus and hypothalamus are the major derivatives of the diencephalon. The retina also develops as an out-pouching of the diencephalon.
content.takeAway: The Diencephalon is the embryonic precursor to the brain's central processing hub, forming the thalamus (the sensory gateway), the hypothalamus (the homeostatic command center), and other vital subcortical structures surrounding the third ventricle.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Prosencephalon - Forebrain] --> B(Telencephalon); A --> C(Diencephalon); C --> D(Thalamus); C --> E(Hypothalamus); C --> F(Epithalamus); C --> G(Subthalamus);

content.definition: Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) is a severe form of traumatic brain injury characterized by widespread shearing of axons in the white matter tracts of the brain. It is caused by sudden, forceful acceleration-deceleration or rotational forces, typically from a motor vehicle accident.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The brain moves at a different rate than the skull during rapid acceleration/deceleration, creating shearing forces that stretch and damage long axons in the white matter. This disrupts axonal transport and leads to delayed axonal swelling and disconnection.
  • Clinical Presentation: The severity of DAI correlates with the degree of coma. Patients often lose consciousness immediately at the time of impact and remain in a prolonged coma or persistent vegetative state.
  • Imaging: A standard CT scan may be normal or show only small petechial hemorrhages. MRI (especially diffusion-weighted imaging) is more sensitive and classically shows multiple, small, ovoid lesions (punctate hemorrhages or non-hemorrhagic lesions) at the gray-white matter junction and in the corpus callosum and brainstem.
  • Prognosis: Generally poor, with high rates of mortality and severe long-term disability.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who is in a coma immediately following a high-speed car accident but has a relatively normal initial head CT should raise high suspicion for diffuse axonal injury.
content.takeAway: Diffuse Axonal Injury is a devastating brain injury caused by the shearing of countless axons during high-impact trauma, leading to widespread disconnection of neural circuits and often resulting in immediate and profound coma.

content.definition: Dihydroergotamine (DHE) is an ergot alkaloid medication used for the acute treatment of [[c8833bae|migraine]] and [[21760f80|cluster headaches]]. It has complex effects on serotonin, dopamine, and adrenergic receptors.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a non-selective agonist at 5-HT1D and 5-HT1B receptors, similar to [[triptans|triptans]]. This leads to cranial vasoconstriction and inhibition of neuropeptide release in the trigeminal system. It also interacts with other serotonin, dopamine, and adrenergic receptors.
  • Clinical Use: Used for the acute (abortive) treatment of moderate to severe [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]] that are unresponsive to other therapies. It is available in injectable and nasal spray formulations.
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea and vomiting are very common. As a potent vasoconstrictor, it can cause peripheral ischemia, hypertension, and coronary vasospasm.
  • Contraindications: Absolutely contraindicated in patients with coronary, cerebral, or peripheral vascular disease, and in pregnancy. Should not be used within 24 hours of a triptan.
  • USMLE Tip: DHE is a powerful but 'dirtier' alternative to triptans for acute migraine, with a broader receptor profile and a higher risk of vasoconstrictive side effects.
content.takeAway: Dihydroergotamine is a potent, multi-receptor ergot alkaloid used to abort severe migraines, but its powerful vasoconstrictive properties necessitate careful patient selection to avoid serious cardiovascular and ischemic complications.

content.definition: Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is structurally related to meperidine and acts on the gastrointestinal tract to decrease motility.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Binds to μ-opioid receptors in the myenteric plexus of the gut. This inhibits the release of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]], leading to decreased peristalsis and increased intestinal transit time, which allows for more water and electrolyte absorption.
  • Clinical Use: Used for the management of [[f76181a6|diarrhea]].
  • Formulation: It is co-formulated with a subtherapeutic amount of atropine (trade name Lomotil). The atropine is added to discourage abuse, as high doses of diphenoxylate can cause CNS effects (euphoria, sedation), but the accompanying atropine would cause unpleasant anticholinergic side effects.
  • Adverse Effects: At therapeutic doses, side effects are mainly constipation and bloating. At high doses, it can cause CNS depression and opioid dependence.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from loperamide, another opioid antidiarrheal. Loperamide does not cross the blood-brain barrier and has a very low abuse potential, whereas diphenoxylate does and is therefore combined with atropine.
content.takeAway: Diphenoxylate is an effective opioid antidiarrheal that slows gut motility, but its potential for CNS effects at high doses necessitates its combination with atropine to serve as an abuse deterrent.

content.definition: Diplopia, or double vision, is the perception of two images of a single object. It is most often caused by a misalignment of the eyes (strabismus) due to problems with the extraocular muscles or the cranial nerves that innervate them.
content.atAGlance:
