• Binocular Diplopia: The most common type. It is present only when both eyes are open and resolves when one eye is covered. This indicates a misalignment problem.
  • Monocular Diplopia: Double vision that persists when one eye is covered. This is an optical problem within the eye itself, such as [[18cff34e|astigmatism]] or [[85f03b02|cataracts]].
  • Causes of Binocular Diplopia:
    - Cranial Nerve Palsies: Palsies of CN III, IV, or VI cause weakness of specific extraocular muscles.
    - Neuromuscular Junction Disease: Myasthenia gravis often presents with fluctuating diplopia and ptosis.
    - Orbital Disease: A mass or inflammation in the orbit (e.g., thyroid eye disease, orbital blowout fracture) can restrict eye movement.
  • Brainstem/Cerebellar Syndromes: Lesions in the brainstem (e.g., [[58c684bd|internuclear ophthalmoplegia]]) or cerebellum can disrupt the coordination of eye movements, causing diplopia.
  • USMLE Tip: The direction of the diplopia (horizontal, vertical, or torsional) and the gaze in which it is worst can help localize the specific muscle or nerve that is affected. For example, horizontal diplopia worse on lateral gaze suggests a [[dd11dde6|CN VI palsy]].
content.takeAway: Diplopia that disappears when one eye is closed is a sign of ocular misalignment, pointing to a neurological or mechanical problem with the eye muscles or their controlling nerves, and requires a careful examination of eye movements to pinpoint the cause.

content.definition: The Direct Pathway is a neural circuit within the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] that facilitates the initiation of voluntary movements. It acts to disinhibit the thalamus, thereby allowing the thalamus to excite the motor cortex.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: To facilitate or 'release' desired movements. It acts as the 'go' signal.
  • Pathway:
    1. The cortex excites the striatum (using glutamate).
    2. The striatum sends inhibitory (GABAergic) signals directly to the globus pallidus internus (GPi) and substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr).
    3. This inhibits the GPi/SNr.
    4. The GPi/SNr normally tonically inhibit the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]]. By inhibiting the inhibitors, the direct pathway disinhibits the thalamus.
    5. The disinhibited thalamus is now free to send excitatory signals to the motor cortex, facilitating movement.
  • Dopamine's Role: [[90adc821|Dopamine]] from the substantia nigra pars compacta stimulates the direct pathway by acting on D1 receptors in the striatum.
  • Pathology: In [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], the loss of dopamine leads to reduced stimulation of the direct pathway, contributing to bradykinesia (difficulty initiating movement).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the direct pathway's net effect is to Dis-inhibit the thalamus to get Desired movements. Dopamine on D1 receptors stimulates the Direct pathway.
content.takeAway: The Direct Pathway of the basal ganglia is a 'go' signal for movement, working through a clever process of 'disinhibition' where it inhibits the brain's natural motor brake (the GPi/SNr), thereby releasing the thalamus to excite the motor cortex and initiate movement.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cortex] --(+)--> B(Striatum); C(SNc) --Dopamine (D1)--> B; B --(-)--> D(GPi/SNr); D --(-)--> E(Thalamus); E --(+)--> A;

content.definition: The Direct Light Reflex is the constriction of the pupil in the eye into which a bright light is shone. It is a component of the pupillary light reflex, which also includes the [[19016061|consensual light reflex]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathway:
    - Afferent Limb: Light is detected by the retina, and the signal is transmitted via the optic nerve (CN II) to the pretectal nucleus in the midbrain.
    - Efferent Limb: The pretectal nucleus projects to the ipsilateral Edinger-Westphal nucleus, which sends preganglionic parasympathetic fibers via the oculomotor nerve (CN III) to the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibers then cause the sphincter pupillae muscle to contract.
  • Purpose: To protect the retina from excessive light by reducing the amount of light entering the eye.
  • Clinical Testing: Assessed by shining a light into one eye and observing the constriction of that same pupil.
  • Lesion Effects:
    - A lesion in the ipsilateral optic nerve (afferent) will abolish both the direct and consensual reflexes when light is shone in the affected eye.
    - A lesion in the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (efferent) will abolish the direct reflex in that eye, but the consensual reflex in the other eye will be intact.
  • USMLE Tip: The direct and consensual reflexes together help to precisely localize lesions in the pupillary light reflex arc.
content.takeAway: The Direct Light Reflex is the ipsilateral component of the pupillary light reflex, where the eye that 'sees' the light is the same eye that constricts, a fundamental brainstem reflex testing the integrity of both CN II and CN III on that side.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Light in Right Eye] --> B(Right Optic Nerve - CN II); B --> C(Pretectal Nucleus); C --> D(Right E-W Nucleus); D --> E(Right Oculomotor Nerve - CN III); E --> F(Right Pupil Constricts);

content.definition: In the context of neurology and ophthalmology, diuretics are used to reduce fluid volume and pressure within the enclosed spaces of the cranium and the eye. The primary agents used are osmotic diuretics and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
content.atAGlance:
• Osmotic Diuretics (e.g., Mannitol): Used to reduce acutely elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) from [[aa00bdef|cerebral edema]]. Mannitol is administered IV and acts by creating an osmotic gradient, drawing water out of the brain parenchyma and into the vasculature. It is also used in acute [[9c80344d|angle-closure glaucoma]].
  • Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors (e.g., [[1df262e8|Acetazolamide]]): Used to treat [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]] and [[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]] (pseudotumor cerebri). They work by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the ciliary body and choroid plexus, which decreases the production of aqueous humor and cerebrospinal fluid, respectively.
  • Loop Diuretics (e.g., Furosemide): Can also decrease CSF production and may be used as an adjunct in managing elevated ICP, but are less potent for this indication than mannitol.
  • USMLE Tip: Mannitol is for acute, emergency reduction of ICP. Acetazolamide is for chronic management of conditions like glaucoma and pseudotumor cerebri by reducing fluid production.
content.takeAway: In neuro-ophthalmology, diuretics are employed not for their renal effects, but for their ability to either osmotically pull fluid out of the brain (mannitol) or to decrease the production of CSF and aqueous humor at their source (acetazolamide).

content.definition: Dizziness is a non-specific term used by patients to describe a variety of sensations, including vertigo, lightheadedness, and disequilibrium. A key task for a clinician is to differentiate these distinct sensations to determine the underlying cause.
content.atAGlance:
• [[5603962d|Vertigo]]: A false sensation of movement, either of the self or the environment, often described as 'spinning.' It indicates a problem with the vestibular system (either peripheral or central).
  • Lightheadedness (Presyncope): A feeling of being about to faint or lose consciousness. It is typically caused by decreased cerebral perfusion (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, arrhythmia).
  • Disequilibrium: A sense of imbalance or unsteadiness that occurs primarily when standing or walking. It can be caused by cerebellar disorders, sensory deficits (e.g., peripheral neuropathy), or musculoskeletal problems.
  • Diagnostic Approach: The first step is to clarify what the patient means by 'dizzy.' Asking "Does it feel like the room is spinning, or like you are about to pass out?" can help differentiate [[5603962d|vertigo]] from presyncope.
  • USMLE Tip: In a board question, 'dizziness' is often used to mean [[5603962d|vertigo]]. Look for associated symptoms like nystagmus, nausea, or hearing changes to confirm a vestibular cause.
content.takeAway: Dizziness is an imprecise umbrella term; the clinician's first job is to translate it into a more specific category—vertigo (spinning), presyncope (fainting), or disequilibrium (imbalance)—as each points to a different set of underlying pathologies.

content.definition: Donepezil is a centrally acting, reversible [[0835ea01|cholinesterase inhibitor]] used for the symptomatic treatment of mild to moderate [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Reversibly inhibits acetylcholinesterase (AChE) in the central nervous system. This reduces the breakdown of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]], thereby increasing its concentration in the synaptic cleft and enhancing cholinergic neurotransmission.
  • Rationale for Use: [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] is associated with a significant loss of cholinergic neurons originating in the [[361438f2|basal nucleus of Meynert]], leading to a cortical cholinergic deficit. Donepezil aims to partially compensate for this loss.
  • Clinical Use: Provides modest, symptomatic improvement in cognitive function in some patients with mild to moderate [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]. It does not slow or reverse the underlying disease progression.
  • Adverse Effects: Primarily cholinergic side effects, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and bradycardia.
  • Other Agents: Rivastigmine and galantamine are other cholinesterase inhibitors used for Alzheimer's disease.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil are a mainstay of symptomatic therapy for Alzheimer's, based on the cholinergic hypothesis of the disease.
content.takeAway: Donepezil offers symptomatic relief in Alzheimer's disease by boosting the dwindling levels of acetylcholine in the brain, acting as a temporary patch for the cholinergic deficit but not as a cure for the underlying neurodegeneration.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Alzheimer's Disease] --> B(↓ ACh in CNS); C[Donepezil] --Inhibits--> D(AChE); D --x E(ACh Breakdown); E --> F(↑ ACh levels); F --> G(Symptomatic Improvement);

content.definition: Dopamine (DA) is a catecholamine neurotransmitter that plays a central role in several key brain functions, including motor control, motivation, reward, and executive function. Dysregulation of dopaminergic pathways is implicated in numerous neurological and psychiatric disorders.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Synthesized from the amino acid Tyrosine. Tyrosine → L-DOPA → Dopamine.
  • Major Pathways & Functions:
    - Nigrostriatal: From substantia nigra to striatum. Crucial for motor control. Degeneration causes [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
    - Mesolimbic: From ventral tegmental area (VTA) to nucleus accumbens. The 'reward' pathway; involved in addiction. Hyperactivity is linked to the positive symptoms of schizophrenia.
    - Mesocortical: From VTA to prefrontal cortex. Involved in executive function. Hypoactivity is linked to the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
    - Tuberoinfundibular: From hypothalamus to pituitary. Tonically inhibits prolactin release.
  • Pathology:
    - ↓ Dopamine: [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], [[9a0f5ba6|Depression]].
    - ↑ Dopamine: Schizophrenia (positive symptoms), Huntington disease.
  • USMLE Tip: Antipsychotic drugs primarily work by blocking D2 receptors. Blocking the tuberoinfundibular pathway leads to hyperprolactinemia. Blocking the nigrostriatal pathway causes extrapyramidal side effects.
content.takeAway: Dopamine is a multifaceted neurotransmitter whose function is defined by its pathway: it drives movement in the nigrostriatal path, reward in the mesolimbic path, cognition in the mesocortical path, and hormonal control in the tuberoinfundibular path, making its dysregulation a source of diverse pathologies from Parkinson's to psychosis.

content.definition: Dopamine agonists are a class of drugs that bind to and activate dopamine receptors, mimicking the effects of endogenous dopamine. They are used in the treatment of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and hyperprolactinemia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Directly stimulate dopamine receptors (primarily D2) in the brain.
  • Classes:
    - Ergot derivatives: [[d24a5ff0|Bromocriptine]]. Less commonly used due to side effects like pulmonary fibrosis.
    - Non-ergot derivatives: Pramipexole, Ropinirole. These are preferred for Parkinson disease.
  • Use in Parkinson Disease: Used as monotherapy in younger patients to delay the need for levodopa, or as an adjunct to levodopa in older patients to reduce motor fluctuations.
  • Use in Hyperprolactinemia: [[ca6ee143|Cabergoline]] and [[d24a5ff0|bromocriptine]] are used to treat prolactinomas and other causes of hyperprolactinemia by stimulating D2 receptors on pituitary lactotrophs, which inhibits prolactin release.
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea, postural hypotension, sedation ('sleep attacks'), and hallucinations. A notable side effect is impulse control disorders (e.g., pathological gambling, compulsive shopping).
  • USMLE Tip: For Parkinson's, non-ergot agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole) are preferred over ergot agonists. For prolactinomas, [[ca6ee143|cabergoline]] is preferred over [[d24a5ff0|bromocriptine]].
content.takeAway: Dopamine agonists provide a direct substitute for the missing dopamine in Parkinson's disease and mimic dopamine's natural inhibitory effect on prolactin, but their use can be complicated by significant CNS side effects, including impulse control disorders.

content.definition: Dopamine D2 receptors are a subtype of G protein-coupled receptors that bind the neurotransmitter [[90adc821|dopamine]]. They are primarily inhibitory (linked to Gi proteins) and are a major target for antipsychotic drugs and treatments for Parkinson disease.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: As Gi-coupled receptors, their activation leads to the inhibition of adenylyl cyclase, which decreases intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP).
  • Location & Function:
    - Nigrostriatal Pathway: Modulate motor control. Blockade by antipsychotics causes extrapyramidal symptoms.
    - Mesolimbic Pathway: Mediate reward and psychosis. Blockade is the primary mechanism of action for antipsychotic drugs.
    - Tuberoinfundibular Pathway: Inhibit prolactin release from the pituitary. Blockade leads to hyperprolactinemia.
    - [[93f70f8e|Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ)]]: D2 receptors in the CTZ mediate nausea and vomiting. D2 antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) are used as antiemetics.
  • USMLE Tip: The therapeutic effect of typical antipsychotics correlates strongly with their affinity for D2 receptors. Side effects like hyperprolactinemia and extrapyramidal symptoms are also a direct result of D2 blockade in different dopaminergic pathways.
content.takeAway: Dopamine D2 receptors are the principal targets for antipsychotic medications; their blockade in the mesolimbic pathway reduces psychosis, but off-target blockade in the nigrostriatal and tuberoinfundibular pathways leads to significant motor and endocrine side effects.

content.definition: The dopaminergic pathways are four major neuronal circuits in the brain that synthesize and release the neurotransmitter [[90adc821|dopamine]]. Their dysregulation is central to several major neurological and psychiatric disorders, and they are the primary targets for therapies for [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and schizophrenia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mesolimbic Pathway: Projects from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to the nucleus accumbens. It is the primary 'reward' pathway. Hyperactivity is associated with the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions).
  • Mesocortical Pathway: Projects from the VTA to the prefrontal cortex. It is involved in cognition and executive function. Hypoactivity is associated with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., apathy, flat affect).
  • Nigrostriatal Pathway: Projects from the substantia nigra pars compacta to the striatum. It is a key part of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] motor loop. Degeneration of this pathway causes [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]. Blockade by antipsychotics causes extrapyramidal side effects.
  • Tuberoinfundibular Pathway: Projects from the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland. It tonically inhibits prolactin secretion. Blockade by antipsychotics leads to hyperprolactinemia.
  • USMLE Tip: Understanding these four pathways is essential for understanding the therapeutic effects and side effects of antipsychotic drugs.
content.takeAway: The brain's four major dopaminergic pathways have distinct roles: the nigrostriatal for movement, the mesolimbic for reward, the mesocortical for cognition, and the tuberoinfundibular for hormonal control. This functional segregation explains why a single drug class, like antipsychotics, can have such diverse therapeutic and adverse effects.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dopaminergic Pathways]; A --> B(Mesolimbic - Reward/Positive Sx); A --> C(Mesocortical - Cognition/Negative Sx); A --> D(Nigrostriatal - Motor); A --> E(Tuberoinfundibular - Prolactin);

content.definition: The Dorsal Columns (also known as the posterior columns or the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway) are ascending sensory tracts in the spinal cord that transmit information about fine touch, vibration, and conscious proprioception from the body to the brainstem.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Transmits discriminative sensory modalities: fine touch, vibration, pressure, and conscious proprioception.
  • Components: Composed of two fasciculi: the fasciculus gracilis (medial, carries information from the lower body, T6 and below) and the fasciculus cuneatus (lateral, carries information from the upper body, T6 and above).
  • Pathway: First-order neurons from peripheral receptors enter the spinal cord and ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns. They synapse in the nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus in the medulla. Second-order neurons then decussate as the internal arcuate fibers and ascend as the [[f19bc454|medial lemniscus]] to the VPL nucleus of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]].
  • Lesions: Damage to the dorsal columns causes ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception below the level of the lesion. This results in sensory [[9767fd6b|ataxia]] and a positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]].
  • Associated Pathologies: The dorsal columns are classically damaged in [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] (tertiary syphilis) and [[6f5bea90|subacute combined degeneration]] (vitamin B12 deficiency).
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature of this pathway is that it ascends ipsilaterally in the spinal cord and crosses in the medulla. This is the opposite of the spinothalamic tract, which crosses at the spinal cord level.
content.takeAway: The Dorsal Columns are the spinal cord's high-fidelity pathway for discriminative touch and proprioception, uniquely ascending ipsilaterally before crossing in the medulla, a crucial anatomical fact for localizing spinal cord lesions like [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard syndrome]].
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Receptor] --> B(1st Order Neuron); B --> C(Ascends Ipsilaterally in Dorsal Column); C --> D(Synapse in Medulla); D --Decussation--> E(2nd Order Neuron - Medial Lemniscus); E --> F(Synapse in Thalamus); F --> G(3rd Order Neuron); G --> H(Somatosensory Cortex);

content.definition: A dorsal midbrain lesion causes Parinaud syndrome (also known as dorsal midbrain syndrome), a constellation of neuro-ophthalmologic signs resulting from compression of the superior colliculus and pretectal area.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by a mass in the pineal region (pinealoma) in children, or by a stroke or hydrocephalus in adults.
  • Classic Triad:
    1. Upward Gaze Palsy: The most prominent feature is a limitation of vertical gaze, especially upward gaze.
    2. Pupillary Light-Near Dissociation: Pupils react poorly or not at all to light but constrict normally during accommodation (convergence). These are sometimes called pseudo-[[08cb577f|Argyll Robertson pupils]].
    3. [[3db2e75e|Convergence-Retraction Nystagmus]]: On attempted upgaze, the eyes jerkily converge and retract into the orbits.
  • Other Signs: Eyelid retraction (Collier's sign) may also be present.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of an inability to look up, pupils that accommodate but don't react, and convergence-retraction nystagmus is pathognomonic for Parinaud syndrome and should point to a lesion in the dorsal midbrain, often a pineal tumor.
content.takeAway: A dorsal midbrain lesion disrupts the centers for vertical gaze and pupillary light reflex, producing the unique Parinaud syndrome, where the patient cannot look up and the pupils paradoxically fail to react to light but still constrict for near vision.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lesion in Dorsal Midbrain (e.g., Pinealoma)] --Compresses--> B(Superior Colliculus & Pretectal Area); B --> C(Parinaud Syndrome); C --> D(Upward Gaze Palsy); C --> E(Light-Near Dissociation); C --> F(Convergence-Retraction Nystagmus);

2f9dde44.title: Dorsal Motor Nucleus of the Vagus

content.definition: The Dorsal Motor Nucleus of the Vagus is a cranial nerve nucleus for the [[vagus_nerve|vagus nerve (CN X)]] located in the medulla oblongata. It is the primary source of preganglionic parasympathetic fibers for the thoracic and abdominal viscera.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Medulla oblongata, lateral to the hypoglossal nucleus and beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Function: Provides preganglionic parasympathetic innervation to the viscera of the thorax and abdomen, down to the splenic flexure of the colon.
  • Targets: Innervates intramural ganglia in the heart (slowing heart rate), lungs (bronchoconstriction), and GI tract (increasing motility and secretion).
  • Clinical Relevance: Lesions affecting the dorsal motor nucleus can lead to autonomic dysfunction, such as gastroparesis or arrhythmias.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember this nucleus as the main parasympathetic 'command center' of the vagus nerve for controlling the internal organs of the chest and abdomen.
content.takeAway: The Dorsal Motor Nucleus of the Vagus is the origin of the extensive parasympathetic outflow of the vagus nerve, responsible for the 'rest and digest' functions of the heart, lungs, and majority of the gastrointestinal tract.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dorsal Motor Nucleus of Vagus] --Preganglionic Parasympathetic Fibers (CN X)--> B(Thoracic & Abdominal Viscera);

content.definition: The Dorsal Optic Radiation is the superior bundle of nerve fibers that projects from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe. It carries visual information from the superior half of the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathway: Originates in the LGN, travels superiorly through the parietal lobe, and terminates in the superior portion of the primary visual cortex (cuneus gyrus), above the calcarine sulcus.
  • Visual Field Information: It carries information from the superior retina, which corresponds to the inferior visual field.
  • Lesion Effect: A lesion of the dorsal optic radiation causes a contralateral inferior quadrantanopia (a 'pie in the floor' visual field defect).
  • Counterpart: The [[ventral_optic_radiation|ventral optic radiation (Meyer's loop)]] travels through the temporal lobe and carries information from the inferior retina (superior visual field).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic PITS: Parietal lesion = Inferior field defect, Temporal lesion = Superior field defect. A lesion in the parietal lobe affecting the dorsal optic radiation causes a 'pie on the floor' defect.
content.takeAway: The Dorsal Optic Radiation is the superior visual pathway that takes a direct, superior route through the parietal lobe to carry information about the inferior visual world from the thalamus to the visual cortex.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Superior Retina] --> B(LGN); B --> C(Dorsal Optic Radiation); C --> D(Through Parietal Lobe); D --> E(Primary Visual Cortex); F[Lesion in Dorsal Radiation] --> G(Contralateral Inferior Quadrantanopia);

content.definition: Double Y male, or XYY syndrome, is a sex chromosome aneuploidy in which a male has an extra Y chromosome, resulting in a 47,XYY karyotype. It is caused by a paternal meiotic II nondisjunction event.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: 47,XYY karyotype, resulting from nondisjunction of the Y chromosome during meiosis II in the father.
  • Phenotype: Most individuals are phenotypically normal and are often undiagnosed. They typically have normal intelligence and are fertile.
  • Clinical Features: Associated with tall stature, severe acne, and an increased risk of learning disabilities and autism spectrum disorder.
  • Historical Misconception: Was once incorrectly linked to aggressive and criminal behavior (the 'supermale' myth), but this has been largely debunked.
  • 'Down-and-out' eye: This term describes a [[fdfd22ca|CN III palsy]] and is not related to XYY syndrome. The index entry is likely a processing error.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic presentation is a very tall male with learning difficulties or behavioral problems. Remember that it results from a paternal meiotic II error.
content.takeAway: XYY syndrome is a common and often asymptomatic sex chromosome aneuploidy, primarily characterized by tall stature, with most of the historical associations with aggression being unfounded.

content.definition: Dream enactment is the cardinal feature of [[91fcdbc5|REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)]], where individuals physically act out their dreams, often in a violent or dramatic manner, due to a failure of the normal muscle atonia that accompanies REM sleep.
content.atAGlance:
• Associated Disorder: The defining symptom of [[91fcdbc5|REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)]].
  • Mechanism: Loss of the physiological muscle paralysis (atonia) that normally occurs during REM sleep.
  • Behaviors: Can range from simple limb twitching to complex and vigorous actions like punching, kicking, yelling, or jumping out of bed, which can cause injury to the patient or their bed partner.
  • Clinical Significance: The presence of dream enactment is a powerful predictor of future neurodegenerative disease, particularly α-synucleinopathies like [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]].
  • USMLE Tip: An older patient, especially male, who reports a history of 'fighting in his sleep' or has injured his spouse while dreaming, is a classic presentation for RBD and should be considered at high risk for developing Parkinson's or Lewy body dementia.
content.takeAway: Dream enactment is a dramatic and potentially dangerous manifestation of REM sleep without atonia, serving as a critical prodromal marker for underlying α-synuclein neurodegenerative disorders.

content.definition: DRESS syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms) is a severe, potentially life-threatening, idiosyncratic drug hypersensitivity reaction characterized by a triad of fever, rash, and internal organ involvement.
content.atAGlance:
• Timeline: Typically has a long latency period, with symptoms appearing 2 to 8 weeks after starting the offending drug.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    - Rash: Widespread morbilliform rash that can progress to exfoliative dermatitis.
    - Fever: High fever is common.
    - Systemic Symptoms: Lymphadenopathy and involvement of internal organs, most commonly the liver (hepatitis), kidneys (interstitial nephritis), and lungs (pneumonitis).
  • Laboratory Findings: Hallmark findings are eosinophilia and atypical lymphocytosis.
  • Causative Drugs: Classically associated with anticonvulsants (e.g., [[eddd2bc5|carbamazepine]], [[5aea213f|phenytoin]], [[08d19a8f|lamotrigine]]), allopurinol, sulfonamides, and certain antibiotics like minocycline and vancomycin.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who started a new anticonvulsant or allopurinol several weeks ago and now presents with fever, a widespread rash, facial edema, and elevated liver enzymes with eosinophilia is the classic vignette for DRESS syndrome.
content.takeAway: DRESS syndrome is a delayed and severe drug reaction where the immune system goes into overdrive, causing not just a rash but also systemic inflammation with eosinophilia and potentially fatal internal organ damage, often triggered by anticonvulsants or allopurinol.

content.definition: Drooling (sialorrhea) is the unintentional flow of saliva outside the mouth. While normal in infants, it can be a sign of neurological disease in older children and adults, often due to impaired swallowing (dysphagia) rather than excessive saliva production.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurological Causes: Common in conditions with oropharyngeal muscle weakness or incoordination, such as [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], [[4ed629f9|amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)]], and [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]]. It results from an inability to effectively manage and swallow normal amounts of saliva.
  • Infectious Causes: Can be a sign of acute infections that cause painful swallowing or airway obstruction, such as epiglottitis or peritonsillar abscess.
  • Treatment: Management focuses on the underlying cause. For neurological conditions, anticholinergic (antimuscarinic) drugs like glycopyrrolate or scopolamine can be used to reduce saliva production.
  • Drop Metastases: This term refers to the spread of CNS tumors (classically [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]]) via the CSF to the spinal cord, and is unrelated to drooling.
  • Drop Seizures: This term refers to [[ed7a236f|atonic seizures]] and is unrelated to drooling.
  • USMLE Tip: In a patient with a known neurodegenerative disorder, the onset of drooling is a significant sign of progressive bulbar dysfunction and worsening dysphagia, indicating an increased risk of aspiration.
content.takeAway: In a neurological context, drooling is typically not a problem of making too much saliva, but rather a problem of not being able to swallow it, serving as a visible sign of underlying bulbar muscle weakness and dysphagia.

content.definition: Drug safety is a branch of pharmacology focused on identifying, evaluating, and preventing adverse drug reactions (ADRs). A key quantitative measure of a drug's safety is its therapeutic index.
content.atAGlance:
• Therapeutic Index (TI): The ratio of the dose of a drug that causes toxicity to the dose that produces the desired therapeutic effect. It is calculated as TD50/ED50 (median toxic dose / median effective dose).
  • Interpretation: A high therapeutic index indicates a wide margin between the effective dose and the toxic dose, suggesting a safer drug (e.g., penicillin). A low therapeutic index indicates a narrow margin of safety, meaning the effective and toxic doses are close, requiring careful monitoring (e.g., warfarin, digoxin, lithium).
  • Therapeutic Window: The range of drug dosages that can treat disease effectively without having toxic effects.
  • 'Drunken Sailor' Gait: This term describes a wide-based, unsteady gait known as truncal ataxia, which is a classic sign of a [[6e31977d|cerebellar vermis lesion]]. It is not directly a concept of drug safety, but can be a sign of drug toxicity (e.g., from phenytoin or alcohol).
  • USMLE Tip: Drugs with a low therapeutic index are high-yield for exam questions. Be prepared to identify them and know that they require therapeutic drug monitoring.
content.takeAway: The therapeutic index is a critical measure of drug safety, quantifying the 'wiggle room' a clinician has between a dose that helps and a dose that harms; drugs with a narrow therapeutic window require vigilant monitoring to prevent toxicity.

content.definition: Drusen are small, yellow or white extracellular deposits that accumulate between Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). They are a hallmark finding of dry (atrophic) age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: Appear as distinct, yellowish spots on fundoscopic examination, typically concentrated in the macula.
  • Pathophysiology: Composed of lipids, proteins, and cellular debris. Their accumulation is thought to impair the function of the RPE, leading to chronic oxidative stress, inflammation, and eventual atrophy of the RPE and overlying photoreceptors.
  • Clinical Significance: The number and size of drusen are key indicators of the risk and severity of [[c63255c8|age-related macular degeneration]]. 'Hard' drusen are small and distinct, carrying a lower risk. 'Soft' drusen are larger, have indistinct borders, and are associated with a higher risk of progression to advanced AMD (either geographic atrophy or wet AMD).
  • Associated Disease: The defining feature of dry AMD.
  • USMLE Tip: Yellowish deposits in the macula of an elderly patient complaining of gradual central vision loss is a classic description of drusen in dry AMD.
content.takeAway: Drusen are the characteristic 'waste products' that build up under the retina in dry age-related macular degeneration, serving as a key biomarker for the disease and contributing to the slow, progressive loss of central vision.

content.definition: The Dura Mater (Latin for "tough mother") is the thick, outermost layer of the three meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord. It provides a durable, protective covering for the central nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Composed of dense, fibrous connective tissue. In the cranium, it consists of two layers: an outer periosteal layer that adheres to the skull, and an inner meningeal layer.
  • Dural Reflections: The inner meningeal layer folds inward to form septa that divide the cranial cavity into compartments, such as the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli.
  • Dural Venous Sinuses: The two dural layers separate in certain locations to form the [[21f1c955|dural venous sinuses]] (e.g., superior sagittal sinus), which are channels for venous blood drainage.
  • Innervation: The dura is richly innervated by sensory nerves (primarily CN V), which is why dural stretching or irritation can cause headaches.
  • Clinical Relevance:
    - [[a61683ae|Epidural Hematoma]]: Bleeding between the dura and the skull.
    - [[8aaeb0d8|Subdural Hematoma]]: Bleeding between the dura and the arachnoid mater.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the spaces relative to the dura: Epidural is 'above' the dura, Subdural is 'below' the dura.
content.takeAway: The Dura Mater is the tough, protective outer shield of the CNS, which not only provides a physical barrier but also forms the critical venous drainage channels (dural sinuses) and the partitions that compartmentalize the brain.

content.definition: The Dural Venous Sinuses are large venous channels located between the periosteal and meningeal layers of the [[5bbe3597|dura mater]]. They are the primary system for venous drainage of the brain and also receive cerebrospinal fluid from the [[b7b67074|arachnoid granulations]].
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Unlike typical veins, they are valveless channels lined by endothelium.
  • Major Sinuses: Superior sagittal sinus, inferior sagittal sinus, straight sinus, [[6e281699|confluence of the sinuses]], transverse sinuses, sigmoid sinuses, and [[c260efc8|cavernous sinuses]].
  • Drainage Pathway: Most venous blood and CSF ultimately drain via the sigmoid sinuses into the internal jugular veins at the jugular foramen.
  • Clinical Significance:
    - Dural Venous Sinus Thrombosis: A clot within a sinus, which can increase intracranial pressure and lead to venous infarction. Associated with hypercoagulable states.
    - [[c260efc8|Cavernous Sinus]]: A clinically important sinus due to the numerous cranial nerves that pass through it.
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to trace the main venous drainage path: Superior Sagittal Sinus → Confluence → Transverse Sinus → Sigmoid Sinus → Internal Jugular Vein.
content.takeAway: The Dural Venous Sinuses are the brain's unique, low-pressure venous drainage system, ingeniously housed within the tough dural layers, responsible for collecting both deoxygenated blood and spent cerebrospinal fluid for return to the systemic circulation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cerebral Veins] --> B(Dural Venous Sinuses); C[Arachnoid Granulations] --> B; B --> D(Internal Jugular Vein);

content.definition: Duret hemorrhages are small, linear hemorrhages in the midline of the pons and midbrain that are a secondary complication of downward [[bad81d37|central transtentorial brain herniation]]. They are typically a terminal event.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by the stretching and tearing of small, perforating branches of the [[e7a90cd9|basilar artery]] as the brainstem is forced downward and compressed during herniation.
  • Associated Condition: A classic finding in patients who have died from severe, acute increases in intracranial pressure leading to [[bad81d37|central transtentorial herniation]].
  • Location: Midline and paramedian areas of the pons and midbrain.
  • Clinical Significance: They are not the primary cause of the patient's condition but rather a consequence of it. Their presence indicates severe, irreversible brainstem damage and is an ominous prognostic sign.
  • USMLE Tip: Duret hemorrhages are a specific pathological finding associated with the final stages of central herniation. They are a consequence, not a cause, of the primary brain injury.
content.takeAway: Duret hemorrhages are the fatal vascular footprints of downward brainstem herniation, caused by the mechanical shearing of pontine and midbrain arteries as the brainstem is crushed, signifying an irreversible terminal event.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Central Transtentorial Herniation] --> B(Downward Brainstem Displacement); B --> C(Stretching/Tearing of Perforating Arteries); C --> D(Duret Hemorrhages);

content.definition: Dysarthria is a motor speech disorder resulting from impaired movement of the muscles used for speech production, including the lips, tongue, vocal folds, and diaphragm. It is a problem with articulation, not language formulation.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by weakness, paralysis, or incoordination of the speech musculature due to a neurological injury.
  • Clinical Presentation: Speech may be slurred, slow, quiet, or strained. The content and grammar of language are intact, but the clarity of speech is poor.
  • Differentiation from Aphasia: This is a critical distinction. [[6bc9a567|Aphasia]] is a language disorder (difficulty finding words, forming sentences, or comprehending). Dysarthria is a speech disorder (difficulty articulating words). A patient with dysarthria can write normally, while a patient with aphasia often cannot.
  • Causes: Can result from various brain lesions, including [[c5da3c57|stroke]] (especially brainstem or cerebellar), [[4ed629f9|amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)]], [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], and [[7a680d3d|osmotic demyelination syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient's speech is slurred but they can write a coherent sentence, the problem is dysarthria (a motor issue), not aphasia (a language issue).
content.takeAway: Dysarthria is a mechanical problem of speech articulation due to muscle weakness or incoordination, where the 'message' is correct but the 'delivery' is flawed, distinguishing it fundamentally from aphasia, which is a problem with the message itself.

content.definition: Dyskinesias are a category of movement disorders characterized by involuntary, erratic, writhing movements of the face, arms, legs, or trunk. They are often a side effect of long-term levodopa treatment in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Involuntary, non-rhythmic, often complex movements that can appear dance-like ([[0fa0d8ee|chorea]]), writhing ([[19272e70|athetosis]]), or a combination (choreoathetosis).
  • Levodopa-Induced Dyskinesia (LID): A common complication of long-term [[541cd176|carbidopa/levodopa]] therapy for [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]. The movements typically occur when dopamine levels are at their peak ('peak-dose dyskinesia').
  • Tardive Dyskinesia: A type of dyskinesia that appears after long-term use of dopamine-receptor blocking agents (antipsychotics). Characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, often of the face (e.g., grimacing, lip smacking, tongue protrusion).
  • Other Types: Other dyskinesias include [[b564ac97|asterixis]], [[73999a73|dystonia]], and [[myoclonus]].
  • USMLE Tip: Dyskinesia in a Parkinson's patient is most likely a side effect of their levodopa therapy. Tardive dyskinesia is a feared long-term side effect of antipsychotics.
content.takeAway: Dyskinesias are involuntary 'overflow' movements resulting from a dysregulated [[ed462927|basal ganglia]], often iatrogenically caused by medications that alter the brain's delicate dopamine balance, such as levodopa or antipsychotics.

content.definition: Dysmetria is a lack of coordination of movement typified by the undershoot or overshoot of intended position with the hand, arm, leg, or eye. It is a type of [[9767fd6b|ataxia]] and is a classic sign of a cerebellar lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: An inability to judge distance or scale.
    - Hypermetria: Overshooting the target.
    - Hypometria: Undershooting the target.
  • Clinical Testing: Assessed with the finger-to-nose test or the heel-to-shin test. A patient with dysmetria will miss the target.
  • Lesion Location: A key sign of a lesion in the [[bebe58d4|cerebellar hemisphere]] or its connections (e.g., the [[c819d97b|dentate nucleus]]). The deficit is ipsilateral to the lesion.
  • Associated Signs: Often occurs with an intention tremor, where the limb oscillates as it approaches the target.
  • Causes: Can be caused by [[c5da3c57|stroke]] (e.g., AICA or PICA stroke), [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], or tumors affecting the cerebellum. It is also a feature of [[350f1c8b|central vertigo]].
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who consistently overshoots or undershoots when trying to touch the examiner's finger has dysmetria, which points to an ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere lesion.
content.takeAway: Dysmetria is the clinical manifestation of the cerebellum's failure to properly calibrate movement, resulting in an inability to accurately 'measure' the distance to a target and leading to the characteristic over- or undershooting of voluntary actions.

content.definition: Dysphagia is the medical term for difficulty swallowing. It can be caused by mechanical obstruction (oropharyngeal or esophageal) or by neuromuscular dysfunction.
content.atAGlance:
• Oropharyngeal Dysphagia: Difficulty initiating a swallow, often accompanied by coughing, choking, or nasal regurgitation. This points to a neuromuscular problem.
  • Esophageal Dysphagia: Sensation of food getting stuck in the esophagus after a swallow has been initiated.
  • Neurological Causes: Dysphagia is a common symptom of neurological disorders that affect the muscles of swallowing or their neural control. This includes:
    - [[c5da3c57|Stroke]]: Particularly brainstem strokes affecting the medulla (e.g., Lateral Medullary Syndrome from a PICA stroke, which damages the nucleus ambiguus [CN IX, X]).
    - Motor Neuron Disease: A key feature of [[901f3180|bulbar palsy]] in [[4ed629f9|ALS]].
    - Myasthenia Gravis: Fluctuating weakness of bulbar muscles.
    - [[7a680d3d|Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome]]: Can cause dysphagia due to pontine damage.
  • USMLE Tip: Dysphagia accompanied by hoarseness and a diminished gag reflex is a classic sign of a lesion in the nucleus ambiguus, pointing to a lateral medullary stroke.
content.takeAway: In a neurological context, dysphagia is a critical 'red flag' for brainstem dysfunction, particularly involving the lower cranial nerves (IX, X) that orchestrate the complex motor sequence of swallowing.

content.definition: Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by sustained or intermittent muscle contractions causing abnormal, often repetitive, movements, postures, or both. The movements are typically patterned and twisting, and may be tremulous.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Involuntary muscle contractions that force body parts into abnormal, sometimes painful, positions. Can be focal (affecting one body part, e.g., torticollis), segmental, or generalized.
  • Acute Dystonic Reaction: A common extrapyramidal side effect of typical antipsychotics (especially high-potency ones like haloperidol) and antiemetics like metoclopramide. Occurs hours to days after starting the drug.
  • Presentation of Acute Dystonia: Can manifest as torticollis (neck twisting), oculogyric crisis (eyes forced upward), or opisthotonus (arching of the back).
  • Treatment of Acute Dystonia: This is a frightening but reversible condition. Treat with centrally acting anticholinergic drugs (e.g., [[383f6fbe|benztropine]]) or diphenhydramine.
  • Other Causes: Can be a feature of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] or other neurodegenerative disorders. Can also be inherited (primary dystonia).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who recently started an antipsychotic and develops a sudden, painful neck twist has an acute dystonic reaction. The treatment is [[383f6fbe|benztropine]] or diphenhydramine.
content.takeAway: Dystonia is a disorder of sustained muscle contraction leading to abnormal postures, which can occur as a frightening acute side effect of dopamine-blocking drugs and is promptly reversible with anticholinergic medication.

content.definition: Echothiophate is a long-acting, irreversible organophosphate cholinesterase inhibitor used topically in ophthalmology for the treatment of glaucoma.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Irreversibly inhibits acetylcholinesterase (AChE) by forming a stable covalent bond with the enzyme. This leads to a buildup of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] at cholinergic synapses in the eye.
  • Ocular Effects: The increased ACh causes contraction of the ciliary muscle (increasing trabecular outflow of aqueous humor) and the sphincter pupillae muscle (causing miosis). Both effects contribute to a reduction in intraocular pressure.
  • Clinical Use: Used for [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]], particularly when other agents are ineffective. Its use is limited due to its side effect profile and the availability of safer alternatives.
  • Adverse Effects: Ocular side effects include blurred vision, brow ache, and potential for cataracts with long-term use. Systemic absorption can occur, potentially leading to systemic cholinergic effects (e.g., bradycardia, bronchospasm), although this is rare with topical use.
  • USMLE Tip: Echothiophate is a classic example of an irreversible cholinesterase inhibitor (an organophosphate) used therapeutically. Its mechanism is the same as that of organophosphate pesticides.
content.takeAway: Echothiophate is a potent, irreversible cholinesterase inhibitor that provides long-lasting reduction of intraocular pressure in glaucoma by amplifying the effects of acetylcholine, but its use is restricted due to the potential for significant side effects.

content.definition: Ectopia lentis is the displacement or malposition of the eye's crystalline lens from its normal location. While it can be caused by trauma, its presence can be a key sign of an underlying systemic connective tissue disorder.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by weakness or disruption of the zonular fibers that hold the lens in place.
  • Marfan Syndrome: A classic cause. Due to a defect in fibrillin-1, the zonular fibers are weak. The lens typically dislocates upward and outward (superotemporally).
  • Homocystinuria: An autosomal recessive disorder of methionine metabolism. Defective cystathionine synthase leads to weak zonular fibers. The lens typically dislocates downward and inward (inferonasally).
  • Differentiation Mnemonic: Marfan looks up at the fan on the ceiling (upward dislocation). In homocystinuria, you look down to pick up your dropped 'homies' (downward dislocation).
  • Other Causes: Trauma is the most common overall cause. Other rare genetic causes include Weill-Marchesani syndrome and sulfite oxidase deficiency.
  • USMLE Tip: The direction of lens dislocation is a key feature used to distinguish Marfan syndrome from homocystinuria in a clinical vignette.
content.takeAway: Ectopia lentis is a significant clinical sign that points beyond the eye, with the direction of lens displacement—upward in Marfan syndrome, downward in homocystinuria—serving as a classic differentiator between these two systemic connective tissue disorders.

content.definition: Edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the interstitial tissue spaces or body cavities. It can be localized or generalized and results from an imbalance in the Starling forces that govern fluid exchange across capillaries.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by one or more of the following:
    - ↑ Hydrostatic pressure: (e.g., heart failure, venous obstruction)
    - ↓ Oncotic pressure: (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, liver failure, malnutrition)
    - ↑ Capillary permeability: (e.g., inflammation, burns, sepsis)
    - Lymphatic obstruction: (e.g., lymphedema)
  • Cerebral Edema: A specific and life-threatening type of edema within the brain. It is classified as:
    - [[8e51aa24|Cytotoxic Edema]]: Intracellular swelling due to cellular injury (e.g., early stroke).
    - Vasogenic Edema: Extracellular fluid accumulation due to a disrupted blood-brain barrier (e.g., tumor, late stroke).
  • USMLE Tip: In the context of neurology, edema is most often referring to [[aa00bdef|cerebral edema]], a critical condition that increases intracranial pressure.
content.takeAway: Edema is the clinical manifestation of 'leaky' or over-pressurized capillaries, with the specific cause determining whether the fluid accumulation is due to too much pressure pushing out, not enough protein pulling in, or a damaged vessel wall.

content.definition: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is the parasympathetic preganglionic nucleus that innervates the eye. It is located in the midbrain and its axons travel with the [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]] to control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Rostral midbrain, dorsal to the main oculomotor nucleus.
  • Function: Provides preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the eye.
  • Pathway: Axons from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus travel in CN III to the orbit, where they synapse in the [[6d7a091d|ciliary ganglion]]. Postganglionic fibers then travel via the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles.
  • Reflexes: It is the efferent motor nucleus for both the pupillary light reflex and the [[81b5f5fe|accommodation reflex]].
  • Clinical Relevance: A lesion compressing CN III (e.g., PComA aneurysm) often affects these superficial parasympathetic fibers first, leading to a fixed, dilated pupil.
  • USMLE Tip: This nucleus is the starting point for the parasympathetic control of the pupil and lens. Its bilateral activation by the pretectal nuclei is the basis for the consensual light reflex.
content.takeAway: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is the parasympathetic command center for the eye, sending signals via the oculomotor nerve to constrict the pupil and focus the lens, making it a critical component of the light and accommodation reflexes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Edinger-Westphal Nucleus] --Preganglionic Fibers (CN III)--> B(Ciliary Ganglion); B --Postganglionic Fibers--> C(Sphincter Pupillae & Ciliary Muscle);

content.definition: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a group of inherited connective tissue disorders caused by defects in the synthesis or structure of collagen. It is characterized by joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Most types are caused by mutations in genes encoding for collagen (e.g., COL5A1, COL5A2 in the classical type) or enzymes involved in collagen processing. The vascular type (the most severe) is due to a defect in Type III collagen (COL3A1 gene).
  • Clinical Presentation: Varies by type, but common features include joint hypermobility ('double-jointed'), easy bruising, abnormal scar formation (atrophic, 'cigarette paper' scars), and soft, velvety, hyperextensible skin.
  • Vascular Type (vEDS): The most life-threatening form. Associated with fragility of large blood vessels and hollow organs, leading to a high risk of arterial dissection or rupture (e.g., aortic dissection), and organ rupture (e.g., colon, gravid uterus).
  • Neurological Complication: The vascular fragility in some types of EDS increases the risk of intracranial [[a9f6d703|berry aneurysms]] and subsequent [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with joint hypermobility, stretchy skin, and a family history of sudden death should raise suspicion for the vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
content.takeAway: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a genetic defect in the body's 'glue' (collagen), leading to fragile, stretchy tissues that manifest as hypermobile joints and skin, with the dangerous vascular type predisposing to catastrophic arterial and organ rupture.

content.definition: An embolic stroke is a type of [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] that occurs when a clot or other debris (an embolus) forms elsewhere in the body, travels through the bloodstream, and lodges in a cerebral artery, obstructing blood flow.
content.atAGlance:
• Onset: Typically has a sudden, maximal-at-onset presentation of neurological deficits, as the vessel is abruptly occluded.
  • Common Sources of Emboli:
    1. Cardiogenic (most common): Thrombus formation in the heart, most frequently due to atrial fibrillation. Other cardiac sources include mural thrombus after MI, valvular disease (e.g., endocarditis), and patent foramen ovale (paradoxical embolus).
    2. Artery-to-Artery: An embolus from a proximal atherosclerotic plaque, typically in the carotid artery or aortic arch.
  • Vascular Territory: Often lodges at arterial bifurcations. The [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]] is the most common destination for emboli from the internal carotid circulation. Emboli can cause infarcts in multiple vascular territories.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a history of atrial fibrillation who suddenly develops aphasia and right-sided weakness has likely had an embolic stroke to the left MCA.
content.takeAway: An embolic stroke is a 'stroke from a distance,' where a clot, most often from the heart in atrial fibrillation, travels to and abruptly blocks a cerebral artery, causing a sudden onset of neurological deficits.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Atrial Fibrillation/Carotid Plaque] --> B(Thrombus Formation); B --> C(Embolus Travels to Brain); C --> D(Occludes Cerebral Artery); D --> E(Ischemic Stroke);

content.definition: The Emboliform Nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei, located medial to the dentate nucleus and lateral to the globose nucleus. Along with the globose nucleus, it forms the interposed nucleus.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Deep within the white matter of the [[bebe58d4|cerebellum]], part of the interposed nuclei.
  • Function: The interposed nuclei (emboliform + globose) are involved in coordinating agonist-antagonist muscle pairs during voluntary movements of the distal limbs. They receive input from the intermediate zone of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Output: Projects to the contralateral red nucleus, contributing to the rubrospinal tract.
  • Mnemonic: The deep cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial are "Don't Eat Greasy Foods" (Dentate, Emboliform, Globose, Fastigial).
  • USMLE Tip: While less commonly tested than the dentate (limb ataxia) or fastigial (truncal ataxia) nuclei, remember that the interposed nuclei (emboliform and globose) are involved in modulating limb movements.
content.takeAway: The Emboliform Nucleus, as part of the interposed nuclei, acts as a cerebellar relay station that helps fine-tune the execution of voluntary movements in the distal limbs by modulating activity in the red nucleus.

content.definition: Neuroembryology is the study of the development of the nervous system in the embryo. It begins with the process of neurulation, where the neural plate folds to form the neural tube, the precursor to the entire central nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurulation: The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate, which then folds to create the neural tube. This process occurs in the 3rd and 4th weeks of gestation.
  • Neural Tube Derivatives: The neural tube gives rise to the CNS (brain and spinal cord), including neurons, oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, and ependymal cells.
  • Neural Crest Derivatives: Neural crest cells migrate away from the neural tube to form the PNS (e.g., Schwann cells, dorsal root ganglia, autonomic ganglia) and many non-neural structures.
  • Brain Vesicles: The rostral neural tube develops into three primary vesicles (prosencephalon, mesencephalon, rhombencephalon), which then differentiate into five secondary vesicles that form the adult brain structures.
  • Clinical Relevance: Errors in neuroembryology lead to congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects ([[5bcc9894|anencephaly]], spina bifida) and [[b96a6a07|posterior fossa malformations]].
  • USMLE Tip: Folate deficiency is a major risk factor for neural tube defects. Supplementation before and during early pregnancy is crucial for prevention.
content.takeAway: Neuroembryology traces the intricate transformation of a simple ectodermal sheet into the complex architecture of the brain and spinal cord, a process highly vulnerable to disruption in early pregnancy, leading to severe congenital malformations.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ectoderm] --Notochord Induction--> B(Neural Plate); B --> C(Neural Tube); C --> D(Brain & Spinal Cord); B --> E(Neural Crest); E --> F(PNS & Other Structures);

content.definition: In neuroscience, emotion refers to complex psychophysiological experiences involving subjective feeling, physiological response, and behavioral expression. The processing and regulation of emotion are primarily functions of the [[73ace357|limbic system]].
content.atAGlance:
• Key Neural Structures: The [[73ace357|limbic system]] is the main circuit for emotion. Key components include:
    - [[d220fc3f|Amygdala]]: Central to processing fear, anger, and pleasure. It attaches emotional significance to memories.
    - [[89e86633|Hypothalamus]]: Mediates the physiological expression of emotion through its control of the autonomic nervous system and endocrine system (e.g., fight-or-flight response).
    - [[22e49c50|Cingulate Gyrus]]: Involved in emotional learning and the link between emotion, memory, and behavior.
    - Prefrontal Cortex: Provides top-down regulation of emotion, inhibiting impulsive emotional responses.
  • Papez Circuit: A historical model of the emotional circuit involving the hippocampus, mammillary bodies, anterior thalamic nucleus, and cingulate gyrus.
  • USMLE Tip: The [[d220fc3f|amygdala]] is the most important structure to associate with the generation of fear and emotional learning. Bilateral lesions lead to Klüver-Bucy syndrome, characterized by a loss of fear.
content.takeAway: Emotion is a product of the brain's [[73ace357|limbic system]], where the [[d220fc3f|amygdala]] acts as the primary processor of emotional stimuli, and the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] translates these feelings into physiological responses, all under the watchful, regulatory eye of the prefrontal cortex.

content.definition: Encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, more commonly known as Sturge-Weber syndrome, is a rare, congenital neurocutaneous disorder characterized by a facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and an associated vascular malformation of the brain and eye.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Caused by a somatic mosaic mutation in the GNAQ gene. It is not inherited.
  • Classic Triad:
    1. Facial Port-Wine Stain: A capillary malformation in the distribution of the ophthalmic (V1) and sometimes maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve.
    2. Leptomeningeal Angioma: An abnormal collection of blood vessels on the surface of the brain, typically ipsilateral to the facial lesion. This can lead to seizures (most common neurological symptom), intellectual disability, and focal neurological deficits.
    3. Glaucoma: Increased intraocular pressure, often ipsilateral to the facial lesion.
  • Imaging: Skull X-rays or CT scans may show characteristic 'tram-track' calcifications, which represent calcification of the cortex underlying the leptomeningeal angioma.
  • USMLE Tip: A child with a port-wine stain on their face, seizures, and intellectual disability is the classic presentation of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
content.takeAway: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a congenital vascular disorder that 'stains' the face with a port-wine birthmark and the underlying brain with a leptomeningeal angioma, leading to a triad of dermatological, neurological (seizures), and ophthalmological (glaucoma) problems.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Somatic GNAQ Mutation] --> B(Vascular Malformation); B --> C(Facial Port-Wine Stain); B --> D(Leptomeningeal Angioma); D --> E(Seizures); B --> F(Ocular Involvement); F --> G(Glaucoma);

content.definition: Endolymphatic hydrops is the distention of the endolymphatic system of the inner ear, caused by an excess volume of endolymph fluid. It is the underlying pathological finding in Ménière disease.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to involve either overproduction or impaired reabsorption of endolymph, leading to increased pressure within the membranous labyrinth.
  • Associated Disease: This is the pathophysiological basis for [[menieres_disease|Ménière disease]].
  • Clinical Manifestations: The increased pressure damages the vestibular and cochlear hair cells, leading to the classic triad of Ménière disease:
    1. Episodic [[5603962d|Vertigo]]: Attacks of spinning dizziness that last for minutes to hours.
    2. Sensorineural Hearing Loss: Typically fluctuating and affecting low frequencies initially.
    3. Tinnitus: Ringing or roaring sound in the affected ear.
  • USMLE Tip: Endolymphatic hydrops = Ménière disease. Remember the triad of vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.
content.takeAway: Endolymphatic hydrops is essentially 'glaucoma of the inner ear,' where excessive endolymph fluid pressure damages the delicate sensory structures for hearing and balance, causing the debilitating episodic attacks of vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss that define Ménière disease.

content.definition: The Endoneurium is the delicate layer of connective tissue that surrounds each individual myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fiber (axon) within a peripheral nerve fascicle.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Composed of reticular fibers, fibroblasts, and capillaries. It is the innermost of the three connective tissue sheaths of a peripheral nerve.
  • Function: Provides a supportive and nutritive microenvironment for the axon and its associated Schwann cell.
  • Blood-Nerve Barrier: The capillaries within the endoneurium have tight junctions, forming part of the [[03ba9967|blood-nerve barrier]].
  • Pathology: The endoneurium is the primary site of inflammation in [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré syndrome]] (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy), where inflammatory cells infiltrate this space and attack the myelin sheath.
  • Nerve Layers (from inside out): Axon → Myelin → Endoneurium → Perineurium (surrounds fascicle) → Epineurium (surrounds entire nerve).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the inflammation in Guillain-Barré syndrome occurs in the endoneurium, targeting Schwann cells and myelin.
content.takeAway: The Endoneurium is the intimate connective tissue wrapping around a single nerve fiber, providing essential support and forming the inner sanctum of the peripheral nerve, which becomes a battleground in inflammatory neuropathies like Guillain-Barré syndrome.

content.definition: Entacapone is a peripherally acting, reversible inhibitor of catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT). It is used as an adjunctive therapy with [[541cd176|levodopa/carbidopa]] for the treatment of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Inhibits COMT in the peripheral tissues. COMT is one of the enzymes that metabolizes levodopa. By blocking this peripheral breakdown, entacapone increases the plasma half-life of levodopa and increases the amount of levodopa available to cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • Clinical Use: Used in combination with [[541cd176|levodopa/carbidopa]] to treat patients with Parkinson disease who are experiencing motor fluctuations ('wearing-off' phenomenon). It helps to prolong the 'on' time.
  • Site of Action: It acts only in the periphery and does not cross the blood-brain barrier. This contrasts with tolcapone, another COMT inhibitor, which acts both peripherally and centrally.
  • Adverse Effects: Can potentiate the dopaminergic side effects of levodopa (e.g., dyskinesias, nausea, confusion). It can also cause a harmless orange discoloration of the urine.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that entacapone is a 'levodopa extender.' It doesn't have any effect on its own but works by preventing the peripheral breakdown of levodopa, thereby boosting its effectiveness.
content.takeAway: Entacapone serves as a 'bodyguard' for levodopa in the periphery, inhibiting the COMT enzyme to prevent levodopa's breakdown before it can reach the brain, thus extending its therapeutic effect in Parkinson's disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Levodopa] --Peripheral COMT--> B(3-O-methyldopa - Inactive); C[Entacapone] --x B; A --> D(Crosses BBB); D --> E(Dopamine in CNS);

content.definition: The Entorhinal Cortex is an area of the brain located in the medial temporal lobe that functions as a major hub in a widespread network for memory, navigation, and the perception of time. It is the main interface between the [[a0590674|hippocampus]] and the neocortex.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Medial temporal lobe, adjacent to the [[a0590674|hippocampus]].
  • Function: Serves as the primary gateway for information entering and leaving the [[a0590674|hippocampus]]. It is crucial for the formation of long-term episodic and spatial memories.
  • Connections: It receives highly processed sensory information from all cortical association areas and funnels it into the [[a0590674|hippocampus]] for memory consolidation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The entorhinal cortex is one of the first areas of the brain to be affected in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]. The formation of neurofibrillary tangles in this region is a very early pathological sign, contributing to the initial memory deficits of the disease.
  • USMLE Tip: The degeneration of the entorhinal cortex is a key early event in the progression of [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], effectively cutting off the hippocampus from its cortical inputs and leading to profound anterograde amnesia.
content.takeAway: The Entorhinal Cortex acts as the main 'entrance and exit ramp' for the hippocampus, and its early destruction in Alzheimer's disease is a critical event that isolates the memory-forming hippocampus from the rest of the brain.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Neocortex] <--> B(Entorhinal Cortex); B <--> C(Hippocampus);

content.definition: Ependymal cells are a type of glial cell that form the epithelial lining of the ventricles in the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. They are involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Simple cuboidal or columnar epithelial cells. Their apical surfaces are covered with cilia (which help circulate CSF) and microvilli (which help with CSF absorption).
  • Choroid Plexus: Ependymal cells are modified in certain locations to form the [[ae65e9c7|choroid plexus]], the specialized tissue responsible for producing the majority of the [[7109d8b6|CSF]].
  • Blood-CSF Barrier: The ependymal cells of the choroid plexus are joined by tight junctions, forming the blood-CSF barrier.
  • Tumor Origin: These cells can give rise to [[14365ef4|ependymomas]], a type of brain tumor. In children, ependymomas most commonly arise in the fourth ventricle.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that ependymal cells line the ventricles and produce CSF. A tumor of these cells, an ependymoma, can therefore obstruct CSF flow and cause non-communicating hydrocephalus, especially when located in the fourth ventricle.
content.takeAway: Ependymal cells are the specialized epithelial lining of the brain's ventricular system, with the crucial dual roles of forming a barrier and, in the choroid plexus, actively producing the cerebrospinal fluid that bathes the CNS.

content.definition: An ependymoma is a primary CNS tumor that arises from [[3a777d5f|ependymal cells]], the glial cells that line the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord.
content.atAGlance:
• Epidemiology: Most common in children, where it is the third most common posterior fossa tumor (after pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma).
  • Location: In children, they most commonly arise in the fourth ventricle. In adults, they are more common in the spinal cord.
  • Clinical Presentation: Tumors in the fourth ventricle often obstruct CSF flow, leading to non-communicating hydrocephalus and signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting, papilledema).
  • Histology: The characteristic histological finding is the perivascular pseudorosette, where tumor cells are arranged in a circular pattern around a central blood vessel, with a clear zone in between. Rod-shaped blepharoplasts (basal ciliary bodies) may be seen near the nucleus.
  • Prognosis: Variable, but generally poor for infratentorial tumors in children.
  • USMLE Tip: A child with hydrocephalus and a tumor located within the fourth ventricle showing perivascular pseudorosettes on histology is the classic presentation of an ependymoma.
content.takeAway: An ependymoma is a tumor of the ventricular lining cells that most characteristically occurs in the fourth ventricle of children, where it acts as a 'plug in the drain,' causing obstructive hydrocephalus, and is identified microscopically by its unique perivascular pseudorosettes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ependymal Cells] --Neoplastic Transformation--> B(Ependymoma); B --Location in 4th Ventricle--> C(Obstruction of CSF Flow); C --> D(Non-communicating Hydrocephalus);

content.definition: An epidural hematoma (EDH) is a collection of blood that forms between the inner surface of the skull and the outer layer of the dura mater. It is a neurosurgical emergency, typically caused by trauma.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by a fracture of the temporal bone, which lacerates the middle meningeal artery.
  • Pathophysiology: Arterial bleeding leads to rapid accumulation of blood in the epidural space, which strips the dura away from the skull.
  • Clinical Presentation: The classic presentation is a patient who suffers head trauma with a brief loss of consciousness, followed by a "lucid interval" where they seem fine, and then a rapid neurological deterioration (headache, vomiting, seizure, coma) as the hematoma expands and increases intracranial pressure.
  • Imaging: A non-contrast head CT shows a hyperdense, biconvex (lentiform) blood collection. The hematoma does not cross suture lines, where the dura is tightly adherent to the skull.
  • USMLE Tip: Lucid interval + temporal bone fracture + lentiform bleed on CT = Epidural hematoma. This is a classic trauma vignette.
content.takeAway: An epidural hematoma is a high-pressure arterial bleed, typically from the middle meningeal artery after a temporal bone fracture, that creates a rapidly expanding, lens-shaped clot which can be fatal if not evacuated promptly; the deceptive 'lucid interval' is a classic but not universal feature.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Temporal Bone Fracture] --> B(Laceration of Middle Meningeal Artery); B --> C(Arterial Bleeding into Epidural Space); C --> D(Biconvex Hematoma); D --> E(↑ ICP & Herniation);

content.definition: The epidural space is a potential or actual space located between the dura mater and the overlying bone (skull in the cranium, vertebrae in the spinal canal).
content.atAGlance:
• Cranial Epidural Space: A potential space between the skull and the periosteal layer of the [[5bbe3597|dura mater]]. It becomes a real space only pathologically, when blood accumulates in it to form an [[a61683ae|epidural hematoma]].
  • Spinal Epidural Space: A real space between the vertebrae and the dural sheath. It contains fat, connective tissue, and a network of veins (the internal vertebral venous plexus).
  • Clinical Significance (Spinal): The spinal epidural space is the target for epidural anesthesia and analgesia, where local anesthetics are injected to block the spinal nerve roots. It is also the site of spinal epidural abscesses and hematomas.
  • Clinical Significance (Cranial): The site of [[a61683ae|epidural hematomas]], typically from rupture of the middle meningeal artery.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the difference between the cranial (potential) and spinal (real) epidural spaces. An epidural anesthetic is placed in the real space in the spine, not the potential space in the head.
content.takeAway: The epidural space is an anatomically distinct area outside the dura mater, which is a potential space in the cranium that can fill with blood in an epidural hematoma, and a real, fat-filled space in the spine that is utilized for regional anesthesia.

content.definition: Epilepsy is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by a predisposition to generate recurrent, unprovoked [[64c08e92|seizures]]. A seizure is a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
content.atAGlance:
• Definition: Requires at least two unprovoked seizures occurring more than 24 hours apart, or one unprovoked seizure with a high probability of further seizures.
  • Seizure Types: Seizures are broadly classified as focal (originating in one hemisphere) or generalized (originating in both hemispheres simultaneously).
    - Focal Seizures: Can be aware or have impaired awareness.
    - Generalized Seizures: Include [[a0c128f4|absence]], tonic-clonic, myoclonic, and [[ed7a236f|atonic]] seizures.
  • Etiology: Can be genetic, structural (e.g., from a prior stroke, tumor, or trauma), infectious, metabolic, or immune-mediated. In many cases, the cause is unknown.
  • Treatment: Managed with [[f91a0cfa|anticonvulsant]] (antiepileptic) drugs. The choice of drug depends on the seizure type.
  • USMLE Tip: It is crucial to distinguish epilepsy from a single provoked seizure (e.g., febrile seizure, alcohol withdrawal seizure), which does not necessarily require long-term anticonvulsant therapy.
content.takeAway: Epilepsy is a disorder of brain hyperexcitability, defined by the tendency for recurrent, unprovoked seizures, and its management requires accurate classification of the seizure type to guide the selection of appropriate anticonvulsant therapy.

content.definition: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a catecholamine hormone and neurotransmitter that is central to the 'fight or flight' response. It is produced by the adrenal medulla and acts on both α- and β-adrenergic receptors throughout the body.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Synthesized in the adrenal medulla from norepinephrine.
  • Receptor Activity: Acts on α1, α2, β1, and β2 receptors. The effect depends on the dose and the receptor density in the target tissue.
    - Low Dose: β-effects predominate (β1: ↑ heart rate/contractility; β2: vasodilation, bronchodilation) → ↑ systolic BP, ↓ diastolic BP, ↑ pulse pressure.
    - High Dose: α1-effects predominate (vasoconstriction) → ↑ systolic and diastolic BP.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Anaphylaxis: Drug of choice. Causes vasoconstriction (α1), bronchodilation (β2), and ↑ cardiac output (β1).
    - Cardiac Arrest: Used in ACLS protocols.
    - [[3ce6c035|Glaucoma]]: Topical epinephrine (α1 agonist) decreases aqueous humor synthesis via vasoconstriction and increases outflow.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the dose-dependent effects of epinephrine. At low doses, it acts like isoproterenol (β-agonist), while at high doses, it acts more like norepinephrine (α-agonist).
content.takeAway: Epinephrine is the ultimate 'fight or flight' hormone, exerting widespread, dose-dependent effects on the cardiovascular and respiratory systems by activating all subtypes of adrenergic receptors, making it the life-saving drug of choice for anaphylaxis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Epinephrine]; A --Low Dose--> B(β > α effects); B --> C(↑ HR, ↑ Contractility, Vasodilation); A --High Dose--> D(α > β effects); D --> E(Potent Vasoconstriction);

content.definition: The Epineurium is the dense, irregular connective tissue sheath that forms the outermost layer of a peripheral nerve. It bundles together multiple nerve fascicles and provides structural support and protection to the entire nerve trunk.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: The thickest of the three connective tissue layers of a peripheral nerve. It is continuous with the dura mater at the spinal nerve roots.
  • Function: Provides mechanical protection to the nerve, cushions it from external pressure, and contains the vasa nervorum (the blood supply to the nerve).
  • Nerve Layers (from outside in): Epineurium (surrounds entire nerve) → Perineurium (surrounds a fascicle of axons) → [[8039c888|Endoneurium]] (surrounds an individual axon).
  • Clinical Relevance: During nerve repair surgery (neurorrhaphy), the epineurium is the layer that is typically sutured together to re-approximate the severed nerve ends.
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to identify the three connective tissue layers of a peripheral nerve and their respective locations.
content.takeAway: The Epineurium is the tough, outer 'jacket' of a peripheral nerve, bundling all the fascicles together and providing the primary structural integrity and blood supply for the nerve trunk.

content.definition: Esotropia is a form of strabismus (eye misalignment) in which one or both eyes turn inward, toward the nose. It is the most common type of strabismus in infants and children.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: An inward deviation of the eye.
  • Causes in Children:
    - Congenital/Infantile Esotropia: Appears in the first few months of life.
    - Accommodative Esotropia: The most common type in children over 6 months. It is caused by uncorrected hyperopia (farsightedness). The effort to focus on near objects (accommodate) triggers an excessive convergence reflex, causing the eyes to cross.
  • Causes in Adults: A new onset of esotropia in an adult is often due to a [[01c1b782|cranial nerve VI (abducens) palsy]], which paralyzes the lateral rectus muscle and allows the medial rectus to pull the eye inward unopposed.
  • Complication: If left untreated in children, esotropia can lead to [[a4a401c7|amblyopia]] ('lazy eye') in the deviating eye.
  • USMLE Tip: An adult who suddenly develops horizontal diplopia and an inward-turning eye likely has a CN VI palsy. A child with intermittent eye crossing, especially when looking at near objects, may have accommodative esotropia.
