content.takeAway: Esotropia is an inward turning of the eye that, in children, is often a refractive problem linked to the accommodation-convergence reflex, while in adults, it is more commonly a neurological sign of a sixth nerve palsy.

content.definition: Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder, characterized by a postural and action tremor, most often affecting the hands and arms. It is typically bilateral and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: A high-frequency tremor that is absent at rest, emerges when the arms are held in a posture (e.g., outstretched), and worsens with goal-directed movements (action tremor), such as writing or drinking from a cup.
  • Affected Areas: Most commonly affects the hands, but can also involve the head (titubation), voice, and legs.
  • Key Feature: The tremor characteristically improves with small amounts of alcohol.
  • Differentiation from Parkinson's: This is a critical distinction. Essential tremor is an action tremor that improves with alcohol. The tremor of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] is a resting tremor that improves with movement.
  • Treatment: First-line treatments are propranolol (a non-selective beta-blocker) and primidone (an anticonvulsant).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who complains of shaky hands that make it difficult to write or eat, but notes that a glass of wine helps, is the classic presentation of essential tremor.
content.takeAway: Essential tremor is an action tremor, not a resting tremor, that is famously and diagnostically relieved by alcohol and managed pharmacologically with propranolol or primidone.

content.definition: Eszopiclone (trade name Lunesta) is a non-benzodiazepine hypnotic agent, commonly referred to as a 'Z-drug,' used for the treatment of insomnia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a positive allosteric modulator at the benzodiazepine (BZ1) subtype of the GABAA receptor. This enhances the effect of GABA, leading to increased chloride conductance and CNS depression (sedation).
  • Class: Non-benzodiazepine hypnotic ('Z-drug'), along with zolpidem and zaleplon.
  • Clinical Use: Approved for the long-term treatment of insomnia, helping with both sleep onset and sleep maintenance.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a longer half-life compared to zolpidem and zaleplon.
  • Adverse Effects: Anterograde amnesia, hallucinations, and complex sleep-related behaviors (e.g., sleepwalking, sleep-driving). A common side effect is an unpleasant or metallic taste. Risk of dependence and withdrawal is lower than with benzodiazepines but still present.
  • Antidote: The effects can be reversed by flumazenil, the same antidote used for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the 'Z-drugs' (Zolpidem, Zaleplon, esZopiclone) as a separate class from benzodiazepines, but know that they act on the same receptor complex and their overdose is treated with the same antidote (flumazenil).
content.takeAway: Eszopiclone is a 'Z-drug' hypnotic that induces sleep by selectively enhancing GABAergic inhibition at the BZ1 receptor, offering an alternative to benzodiazepines for insomnia but still carrying risks of complex sleep behaviors and dependence.

content.definition: Ethosuximide is a narrow-spectrum anticonvulsant medication that is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated [[a0c128f4|absence seizures]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons. This disrupts the oscillatory rhythm between the thalamus and the cortex that is responsible for generating the characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges of absence seizures.
  • Clinical Use: First-line and specific therapy for [[a0c128f4|absence seizures]] ('petit mal'). It is not effective for other seizure types.
  • Adverse Effects: Common side effects can be remembered with the mnemonic EFGHIJ: Ethosuximide causes Fatigue, GI distress (nausea, vomiting), Headache, Itching (and urticaria), and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.
  • Comparison: [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]] is also effective for absence seizures and is used if the patient also has tonic-clonic seizures. Carbamazepine and phenytoin can worsen absence seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: The unique mechanism of blocking thalamic T-type calcium channels makes ethosuximide the specific drug of choice for absence seizures.
content.takeAway: Ethosuximide is the targeted therapy for absence seizures, working by selectively blocking the T-type calcium channels in the thalamus that generate the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike-and-wave rhythm of this specific seizure type.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ethosuximide] --Blocks--> B(Thalamic T-type Ca2+ Channels); B --x C(3 Hz Spike-and-Wave Discharges); C --x D(Absence Seizure);

content.definition: Etomidate is an intravenous general anesthetic used for the induction of anesthesia, particularly in patients who are hemodynamically unstable. It provides sedation and hypnosis but lacks analgesic properties.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Potentiates the GABAA receptor, enhancing the inhibitory effects of GABA on the central nervous system.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a rapid onset and short duration of action, making it ideal for induction.
  • Key Advantage: It is hemodynamically neutral, causing minimal changes in blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This makes it the induction agent of choice for patients with cardiovascular instability (e.g., trauma, sepsis, cardiac disease).
  • Clinical Use: Primarily used for the induction of general anesthesia and for rapid sequence intubation.
  • Adverse Effects: The most significant side effect is adrenocortical suppression. It reversibly inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, an enzyme critical for cortisol and aldosterone synthesis. This effect can last for several hours after a single bolus dose. Also associated with postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember etomidate for its cardiovascular stability ('hemodynamically neutral') and its unique side effect of adrenal suppression.
content.takeAway: Etomidate is a valuable anesthetic induction agent prized for its minimal impact on hemodynamics, making it safe for critically ill patients, but its utility is tempered by a transient but significant suppression of adrenal steroid synthesis.

content.definition: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo is an apparent increase in the size of the cerebral ventricles and subarachnoid spaces on neuroimaging that is not due to increased cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, but rather to a loss of brain parenchyma (atrophy).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: This is not a true hydrocephalus. The enlargement of the CSF spaces is a passive process that occurs to fill the void left by the loss of brain tissue. Intracranial pressure (ICP) is normal.
  • Causes: Seen in conditions associated with significant cortical atrophy, such as:
    - [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]
    - Frontotemporal dementia (Pick disease)
    - [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]
    - HIV-associated dementia
  • Imaging: CT or MRI shows enlarged ventricles and prominent cortical sulci, indicating diffuse brain atrophy.
  • Differentiation: It is crucial to differentiate from [[7c59030e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)]]. In NPH, the ventricles are disproportionately enlarged compared to the sulci, and patients present with the clinical triad of gait apraxia, dementia, and urinary incontinence. NPH is potentially treatable with CSF shunting, whereas hydrocephalus ex vacuo is not.
  • USMLE Tip: If a brain scan shows large ventricles but also very wide sulci, think hydrocephalus ex vacuo (atrophy). If the ventricles are large but the sulci are relatively normal, think true hydrocephalus (like NPH).
content.takeAway: Hydrocephalus ex vacuo is a misnomer; it is not a problem of excess fluid but of brain tissue loss, where the ventricles passively expand to fill the space created by cortical atrophy, a hallmark of advanced neurodegenerative diseases.

content.definition: Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca's aphasia, is a language disorder characterized by difficulty in producing fluent, grammatical speech, while comprehension remains relatively intact. It is caused by a lesion in [[a3bbace2|Broca's area]].
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere.
  • Vascular Supply: Supplied by the superior division of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Clinical Presentation: Speech is nonfluent, telegraphic, and effortful. Patients use short phrases and omit functional words (e.g., "Walk dog"). Repetition is impaired.
  • Comprehension: Auditory and reading comprehension are relatively preserved, although complex grammar may be difficult.
  • Patient Awareness: Patients are typically aware of their deficits and become very frustrated by their inability to communicate effectively.
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: Broca's is Broken Boca (mouth). Look for a patient with a right hemiparesis (especially face and arm) who can follow commands but struggles to speak in complete sentences.
content.takeAway: Broca's aphasia is a disorder of language production, not comprehension, resulting from damage to the brain's motor-speech planning center. The resulting speech is broken and effortful, leaving the patient frustratingly aware of their inability to express their intact thoughts.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lesion in Broca's Area] --> B(Impaired Speech Production); B --> C(Nonfluent, Telegraphic Speech); A --Spares--> D(Wernicke's Area); D --> E(Intact Comprehension);

content.definition: Neonatal extracranial injuries are a group of head injuries that occur in newborns during the process of birth, involving bleeding or swelling in the layers of the scalp superficial to the cranium. They are typically caused by mechanical forces during delivery.
content.atAGlance:
• [[a5ec55b5|Caput Succedaneum]]: Edematous swelling of the scalp soft tissue. It is soft, pits on pressure, and crosses suture lines. Present at birth and resolves in days.
  • [[a1721d6f|Cephalohematoma]]: A subperiosteal hemorrhage. It is firm, does not cross suture lines, and may take weeks to resolve. Can cause neonatal jaundice.
  • Subgaleal Hemorrhage: Bleeding into the potential space between the periosteum and the galea aponeurosis. This is a dangerous, diffuse swelling that can cross suture lines and lead to significant blood loss and hypovolemic shock.
  • Etiology: Often associated with prolonged labor, forceps delivery, or vacuum-assisted delivery.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to differentiating caput succedaneum and cephalohematoma is their relationship to the suture lines. Caput crosses, cephalohematoma does not.
content.takeAway: Neonatal extracranial injuries are a spectrum of birth-related scalp swellings, with the benign, superficial caput succedaneum and the deeper, suture-bound cephalohematoma being the most common and distinguished by their location and ability to cross suture lines.

content.definition: Eye movements are the voluntary or involuntary movements of the eyes, controlled by the six extraocular muscles, which are innervated by cranial nerves III, IV, and VI. These movements allow for fixation, tracking, and scanning of the visual environment.
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation: Mnemonic (SO4LR6)3. CN IV ([[bba6093a|Trochlear]]) innervates the Superior Oblique. CN VI ([[dd11dde6|Abducens]]) innervates the Lateral Rectus. CN III ([[68c66997|Oculomotor]]) innervates the rest.
  • Conjugate Gaze: Coordinated movement of both eyes in the same direction. Horizontal gaze is controlled by the [[paramedian_pontine_reticular_formation|PPRF]] in the pons. Vertical gaze is controlled by centers in the midbrain.
  • Disorders:
    - [[eab31845|Cranial Nerve Palsies]]: Weakness of one or more extraocular muscles, leading to [[9914d433|diplopia]] and strabismus.
    - [[58c684bd|Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO)]]: A disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze from a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).
    - [[c5da3c57|Stroke]]: Can cause gaze palsies depending on the location (e.g., frontal eye field lesion vs. PPRF lesion).
  • USMLE Tip: A systematic examination of the six cardinal positions of gaze is essential to test the function of all extraocular muscles and their innervating cranial nerves.
content.takeAway: The precise and coordinated control of eye movements is a complex neurological function orchestrated by three cranial nerves and integrated by brainstem centers, making the analysis of eye movement disorders a powerful tool for localizing neurological lesions.

content.definition: Eyelid disorders encompass a range of inflammatory, infectious, and structural conditions affecting the eyelids, which can cause discomfort, cosmetic concerns, and in some cases, affect vision.
content.atAGlance:
• [[8056ce48|Blepharitis]]: Chronic inflammation of the eyelid margins, causing redness, crusting, and irritation.
  • [[hordeolum|Hordeolum (Stye)]]: An acute, painful, pyogenic infection of an eyelid gland (e.g., gland of Zeis or Moll), typically caused by S. aureus. Presents as a tender red bump on the eyelid margin.
  • [[193c24ec|Chalazion]]: A granulomatous inflammation due to a blocked meibomian gland. Presents as a firm, rubbery, painless nodule within the eyelid.
  • [[xanthelasma|Xanthelasma]]: Yellowish plaques of lipid-laden macrophages on the medial eyelids, often associated with hyperlipidemia.
  • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid. Can be caused by [[fdfd22ca|CN III palsy]], [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]], or myasthenia gravis.
  • Cellulitis: Preseptal cellulitis is an infection anterior to the orbital septum. Orbital cellulitis is a more serious infection posterior to the septum, causing pain with eye movements and proptosis.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to differentiating a hordeolum from a chalazion is pain: Hordeolum = Hurt (painful infection). Chalazion = Chill (painless inflammation).
content.takeAway: Eyelid disorders range from common inflammatory conditions like blepharitis to infectious styes and granulomatous chalazia, with the distinction between painful (infectious) and painless (inflammatory/obstructive) lesions being a key diagnostic principle.

content.definition: The eye is the organ of vision, a complex structure that transduces light energy into neural signals. Its anatomy is organized to focus light onto the retina, and its physiology involves the intricate processes of photoreception and neural processing.
content.atAGlance:
• Normal Anatomy: Comprises three layers (sclera/cornea, uvea, retina) and three chambers (anterior, posterior, vitreous). Light enters through the [[7d70ac32|cornea]], passes through the pupil and [[lens]], and is focused on the retina.
  • Aqueous Humor Pathway: Fluid produced by the ciliary body flows from the posterior to the anterior chamber and drains via the trabecular meshwork. Disruption of this pathway causes [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]].
  • Lens Disorders: The lens focuses light onto the retina. [[85f03b02|Cataracts]] (opacification) and [[25e91fde|ectopia lentis]] (dislocation) are common pathologies. Loss of accommodation with age is [[presbyopia]].
  • Eye Misalignment: [[cdcda821|Strabismus]] is the misalignment of the eyes, which can lead to [[a4a401c7|amblyopia]] (lazy eye) in children if not corrected.
  • USMLE Tip: A thorough understanding of the eye's anatomy is crucial for interpreting physical exam findings and localizing pathology, from the anterior segment (glaucoma, cataracts) to the posterior segment (retinal disorders).
content.takeAway: The eye functions as a biological camera, with the cornea and lens acting as the focusing system, the iris as the aperture, and the retina as the light-sensitive film, all working in concert to capture and transmit visual information to the brain.

content.definition: The Facial Nerve (CN VII) is a mixed cranial nerve that carries motor fibers to the muscles of facial expression, parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal and salivary glands, and special sensory fibers for taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
content.atAGlance:
• Functions (Mnemonic - Facial): Facial expression, Afferent taste (anterior 2/3), Crying (lacrimation), Innervation of stapedius, Afferent from ear, Licking (salivation).
  • Motor Function: Innervates the muscles of facial expression. A lesion causes facial droop.
  • UMN vs. LMN Lesion:
    - UMN Lesion (e.g., stroke): Causes contralateral lower facial droop, with sparing of the forehead (due to bilateral cortical innervation).
    - LMN Lesion (e.g., Bell's palsy): Causes paralysis of the entire ipsilateral half of the face (forehead included).
  • Other Lesion Signs: Depending on the location of the lesion along the nerve's path, a CN VII palsy can also cause hyperacusis (paralysis of stapedius), loss of taste, and decreased salivation/lacrimation.
  • Bell's Palsy: The most common cause of an idiopathic, unilateral LMN facial nerve palsy, thought to be due to HSV-1 reactivation.
  • USMLE Tip: The ability to wrinkle the forehead is the key to distinguishing a central (UMN) from a peripheral (LMN) facial nerve lesion. If the forehead is spared, the lesion is central.
content.takeAway: The Facial Nerve is the nerve of facial expression, and its paralysis creates a clinically distinct pattern: a lower motor neuron lesion paralyzes the entire half of the face, while an upper motor neuron lesion spares the forehead due to bilateral cortical input.

content.definition: Factor V Leiden is a specific gene mutation that results in a hypercoagulable state. It is the most common inherited thrombophilia in Caucasians.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: An autosomal dominant point mutation in the Factor V gene, resulting in an arginine-to-glutamine substitution (R506Q).
  • Pathophysiology: The mutation renders Factor Va resistant to cleavage and inactivation by Activated Protein C (APC). This leads to increased activity of Factor Va, resulting in excess thrombin generation and a prothrombotic state.
  • Clinical Presentation: Increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). It is a common cause of recurrent VTE in young patients.
  • Neurological Complication: Can be a cause of dural venous sinus thrombosis, an uncommon type of stroke.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosed with a functional assay (APC resistance test) or genetic testing for the specific mutation.
  • USMLE Tip: Suspect Factor V Leiden in a young patient with a history of recurrent DVTs or a DVT in an unusual location (like a cerebral vein), especially with a positive family history. The key mechanism is resistance to inactivation by Protein C.
content.takeAway: Factor V Leiden is a genetic thrombophilia where a mutated Factor V becomes resistant to its natural 'off switch' (Activated Protein C), leading to unchecked thrombin generation and a lifelong increased risk for venous blood clots.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Protein C] --x B(Factor V Leiden); B --> C(↑ Factor Va activity); C --> D(↑ Thrombin Generation); D --> E(Hypercoagulable State); E --> F(Venous Thromboembolism);

content.definition: Farsightedness, or hyperopia, is a refractive error where parallel light rays from a distant object are focused behind the retina when the eye is in a state of rest. This causes near objects to appear blurry, while distant objects may be clear.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Occurs when the eyeball is too short or the refractive power of the cornea and lens is too weak.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty focusing on near objects, leading to blurry vision, eye strain, and headaches, especially with reading. Young people can often compensate for mild hyperopia by accommodating.
  • Correction: Corrected with a convex (converging) lens, which increases the refractive power and moves the focal point forward onto the retina.
  • Comparison to Myopia: In [[myopia]] (nearsightedness), the eye is too long, and light focuses in front of the retina. It is corrected with a concave lens.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember: Hyperopia = farsighted = eye too short = focus behind retina = correct with convex (+) lens.
content.takeAway: Farsightedness (hyperopia) is a refractive error where the eye's focusing power is insufficient for its length, causing light to focus behind the retina and making near vision blurry; it is corrected by adding focusing power with a convex lens.

content.definition: Fasciculations are small, involuntary muscle twitches or contractions that are visible under the skin. They are caused by the spontaneous depolarization of a lower motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates (a motor unit).
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Fine, rapid, flickering or twitching movements of a muscle, which do not produce joint movement.
  • Clinical Significance: Fasciculations are a classic sign of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion. They represent a sign of denervation and neuronal hyperexcitability.
  • Associated LMN Signs: They are often seen in conjunction with other LMN signs, such as muscle [[0c2b4642|atrophy]], flaccid weakness, and hyporeflexia.
  • Classic Disease Association: A hallmark finding in [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]], where they occur alongside upper motor neuron signs. Also seen in spinal muscular atrophy and polio.
  • Benign Fasciculations: Can also occur in healthy individuals (benign fasciculation syndrome), often in the calf or eyelid, and are not associated with weakness or atrophy.
  • USMLE Tip: In a clinical vignette, the presence of fasciculations is a strong clue pointing towards an LMN pathology. When combined with UMN signs, it is highly suggestive of ALS.
content.takeAway: Fasciculations are the visible twitches of dying motor units, serving as a key physical exam finding that signals a lower motor neuron lesion and, when seen with upper motor neuron signs, points strongly to a diagnosis of ALS.

content.definition: The Fastigial Nucleus is the most medial of the deep cerebellar nuclei. It is primarily involved in the control of axial and vestibular functions, including balance and gait.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Located deep within the white matter of the cerebellar vermis (the midline portion of the cerebellum).
  • Function: Receives input from the vermis and flocculonodular lobe. It is involved in controlling axial and proximal limb muscles for balance and posture, as well as coordinating eye movements with the vestibular system.
  • Output: Projects to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation in the brainstem.
  • Lesion Effect: A lesion of the fastigial nucleus results in truncal ataxia, characterized by an unsteady, wide-based gait and difficulty maintaining an upright posture.
  • Mnemonic: The deep cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial are "Don't Eat Greasy Foods" (Dentate, Emboliform, Globose, Fastigial). The fastigial nucleus is the most medial, corresponding to the midline vermis's control of the trunk.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a 'drunken sailor' gait who sways and falls when trying to stand still likely has a lesion in the cerebellar midline (vermis or fastigial nucleus).
content.takeAway: The Fastigial Nucleus is the deep cerebellar nucleus responsible for midline stability; it processes information from the vermis to fine-tune balance and posture, and a lesion here leads to a characteristic truncal ataxia.

content.definition: A febrile seizure is a convulsion in a child that is caused by a spike in body temperature (fever), often from an infection. They occur in the absence of any underlying intracranial infection or metabolic disturbance.
content.atAGlance:
• Epidemiology: The most common seizure disorder in childhood, affecting 2-5% of children between the ages of 6 months and 5 years.
  • Simple Febrile Seizure (most common):
    - Type: Generalized tonic-clonic.
    - Duration: Lasts less than 15 minutes.
    - Frequency: Occurs only once in a 24-hour period.
  • Complex Febrile Seizure: Has one or more of the following features: focal onset, duration longer than 15 minutes, or more than one seizure in 24 hours.
  • Prognosis: Simple febrile seizures are benign and have an excellent prognosis. They do not cause brain damage or increase the risk of developing epilepsy significantly.
  • Management: The primary goal is to identify and treat the underlying cause of the fever. Antipyretics (acetaminophen, ibuprofen) can be used for comfort but do not prevent future febrile seizures. Long-term anticonvulsant therapy is not indicated for simple febrile seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: A key point is to reassure parents about the benign nature of simple febrile seizures. The main task is to rule out more serious causes of the fever and seizure, such as meningitis.
content.takeAway: Febrile seizures are common, age-dependent, and typically benign convulsions triggered by fever in young children; the vast majority are simple, self-limited, and do not lead to long-term neurological problems or epilepsy.

content.definition: In the central nervous system, fenestrated capillaries are a specialized type of capillary that, unlike the vast majority of CNS capillaries, possess pores (fenestrae) in their endothelial lining. This feature allows for the relatively free passage of fluids and small solutes, and is characteristic of the circumventricular organs.
content.atAGlance:
• CNS Capillaries (General): Most capillaries in the brain are continuous and have [[5206aa83|tight junctions]], forming the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
  • Fenestrated Capillaries: These are an exception to the rule. Their pores allow them to 'sample' the chemical composition of the blood.
  • Location: Found exclusively in the circumventricular organs (CVOs), which are structures that lack a [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
  • Examples of CVOs:
    - [[5dd343d3|Area Postrema]]: The chemoreceptor trigger zone for vomiting.
    - Posterior Pituitary: Allows for the release of ADH and oxytocin into the bloodstream.
    - Median Eminence of the Hypothalamus: Allows for the release of hypothalamic hormones into the portal system.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of fenestrated capillaries is the anatomical basis for why circumventricular organs lack a blood-brain barrier and can interact directly with the systemic circulation.
content.takeAway: Fenestrated capillaries are the 'leaky' vessels of the brain, strategically located in the circumventricular organs to create windows in the blood-brain barrier, allowing these specialized regions to monitor and interact with the chemical messengers of the blood.

content.definition: Fentanyl is a potent, synthetic opioid analgesic that acts as a strong agonist at μ-opioid receptors. It is used for severe pain and as an adjunct in anesthesia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Strong agonist at μ-opioid receptors, leading to profound analgesia and sedation.
  • Potency: It is approximately 50 to 100 times more potent than morphine.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Highly lipid-soluble, allowing for rapid onset and short duration of action when given IV. This property also allows for transdermal and transmucosal administration.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Anesthesia: Used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, often in combination with other agents.
    - Pain Management: Used for severe acute pain (IV) and chronic pain (transdermal patch).
  • Adverse Effects: Like other opioids, it can cause respiratory depression, sedation, constipation, and miosis. Due to its high potency, the risk of fatal respiratory depression in overdose is very high.
  • USMLE Tip: Fentanyl's high potency and rapid onset make it a powerful tool in anesthesia and pain management, but also make it extremely dangerous in the context of illicit drug use. Overdose is treated with naloxone.
content.takeAway: Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid of exceptional potency, providing rapid and powerful analgesia, but its narrow therapeutic window and profound respiratory depressant effects make it one of the most dangerous opioids when used illicitly.

content.definition: Fever (pyrexia) is an elevation of body temperature that exceeds the normal daily variation, occurring in conjunction with an increase in the hypothalamic set point. It is a common, coordinated response to infection or inflammation.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Exogenous pyrogens (e.g., bacterial LPS) induce immune cells to release endogenous pyrogens (cytokines like IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α). These cytokines increase the synthesis of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) in the hypothalamus. PGE2 then acts on the anterior hypothalamus to raise the thermoregulatory set point.
  • Mechanism of Heat Production: The body responds to the new, higher set point by initiating heat-generating mechanisms, such as shivering and peripheral vasoconstriction, until the blood temperature matches the new set point.
  • Management: Antipyretics like NSAIDs and acetaminophen work by inhibiting COX enzymes, thereby decreasing PGE2 synthesis and lowering the hypothalamic set point back toward normal.
  • Fever vs. Heat Stroke: This is a critical distinction. In fever, the hypothalamic set point is elevated. In [[heat_stroke|heat stroke]], the set point is normal, but the body's heat-dissipating mechanisms are overwhelmed. Therefore, antipyretics are ineffective for heat stroke.
  • USMLE Tip: The central mediator of fever is PGE2 acting on the hypothalamus. This is the target of antipyretic drugs.
content.takeAway: Fever is not a failure of thermoregulation but a deliberate resetting of the body's thermostat by the hypothalamus, orchestrated by PGE2 in response to inflammation, a process that is pharmacologically reversed by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Infection/Inflammation] --> B(Cytokine Release); B --> C(↑ PGE2 in Hypothalamus); C --> D(↑ Hypothalamic Set Point); D --> E(Heat Conservation/Production); E --> F(Fever);

content.definition: Finger agnosia is a specific neurological deficit characterized by the inability to name, identify, or recognize one's own or another person's fingers. It is a component of Gerstmann syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Finger agnosia is a key localizing sign for a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus of the parietal lobe.
  • Associated Syndrome: It is one of the four classic components of [[38f3ed1f|Gerstmann syndrome]].
  • Gerstmann Syndrome Tetrad: The full syndrome includes Finger Agnosia, [[13d6bca7|Agraphia]] (inability to write), [[8558c64b|Acalculia]] (inability to perform calculations), and Left-Right Disorientation.
  • Vascular Territory: These symptoms often result from a stroke in the territory of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]] that supplies the dominant parietal lobe.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of finger agnosia with any of the other elements of the Gerstmann tetrad is a strong indicator of a lesion in the dominant (usually left) parietal lobe.
content.takeAway: Finger agnosia is a bizarre and highly specific neurological sign that, along with its partners in Gerstmann syndrome, points directly to a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus, a critical association area for language, calculation, and body schema.

content.definition: Flaccid paralysis is a clinical manifestation of neurological disease characterized by extreme weakness of muscles and loss of muscle tone. It is the hallmark sign of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Results from damage to the LMNs in the anterior horn of the spinal cord or the peripheral nerves, which disrupts the final common pathway for muscle contraction. The muscle is deprived of all input.
  • Associated LMN Signs: Flaccid paralysis is accompanied by other LMN signs:
    - Hypotonia: Decreased muscle tone.
    - Hyporeflexia/Areflexia: Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes.
    - [[5198afd0|Fasciculations]]: Involuntary muscle twitches.
    - Severe Muscle [[0c2b4642|Atrophy]]: Pronounced muscle wasting.
  • Causes: [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré syndrome]], poliomyelitis, spinal muscular atrophy, [[4ed629f9|ALS]] (as part of the mixed UMN/LMN picture), and peripheral nerve trauma.
  • Botulism: A classic cause of descending flaccid paralysis due to inhibition of acetylcholine release by [[84b10400|botulinum toxin]].
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from spastic paralysis, which is caused by UMN lesions and is characterized by hypertonia and hyperreflexia.
content.takeAway: Flaccid paralysis is the clinical sign of a 'disconnected' muscle, resulting from a lower motor neuron lesion that severs the final neural command line, leading to a limp, wasted, and areflexic state.

content.definition: Focal aware seizures, formerly known as simple partial seizures, are seizures that originate within a localized network in one cerebral hemisphere and occur without any impairment of consciousness or awareness.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Feature: Consciousness and awareness are fully preserved throughout the event. The patient can recall the event afterward.
  • Symptoms: The manifestations depend on the location of the seizure focus in the brain.
    - Motor: Jerking movements (clonus) of a single limb or one side of the face (e.g., Jacksonian march).
    - Sensory: Paresthesias (tingling) or other sensory phenomena.
    - Autonomic: Epigastric rising sensation, sweating, piloerection.
    - Psychic: Déjà vu, fear, or other emotional experiences.
  • Aura: A focal aware seizure can serve as an 'aura' or warning before a more significant seizure, such as a focal impaired awareness seizure or a secondary generalized tonic-clonic seizure.
  • USMLE Tip: The defining characteristic is the preservation of consciousness. If a patient describes a seizure event in detail (e.g., 'my right hand started shaking, but I was fully awake'), it is a focal aware seizure.
content.takeAway: Focal aware seizures are localized electrical storms in the brain that produce motor, sensory, or emotional symptoms without affecting consciousness, often serving as a prelude or 'aura' to a larger seizure.

content.definition: Focal impaired awareness seizures, formerly known as complex partial seizures, are seizures that originate within a localized network in one cerebral hemisphere and are characterized by an alteration or loss of consciousness or awareness.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Feature: Impairment of consciousness. The patient may appear awake but is unresponsive or responds inappropriately. There is typically amnesia for the event.
  • Origin: Most commonly originate in the temporal lobe.
  • Automatisms: Often accompanied by stereotyped, purposeless movements called automatisms, such as lip smacking, chewing, or fumbling with clothing.
  • Aura: May be preceded by an aura (a focal aware seizure), such as an epigastric rising sensation, fear, or an olfactory hallucination.
  • Postictal State: Followed by a period of confusion, drowsiness, or other neurological deficits (e.g., Todd's paralysis).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who stares blankly, is unresponsive, and performs repetitive, automatic behaviors like lip smacking is the classic presentation of a focal impaired awareness seizure, most likely of temporal lobe origin.
content.takeAway: Focal impaired awareness seizures are temporal lobe-originating seizures that temporarily disconnect a person's consciousness, leaving them in a dream-like state where they may perform automatic behaviors (automatisms) for which they have no memory.

content.definition: Focal seizures (formerly partial seizures) are seizures that originate within a localized network in one cerebral hemisphere. Their clinical manifestations depend on the specific area of the cortex involved.
content.atAGlance:
• Types: Classified based on the level of consciousness during the event:
    - [[b8ce0d03|Focal Aware Seizure]]: Consciousness is fully maintained.
    - [[00be40b6|Focal Impaired Awareness Seizure]]: Consciousness is altered or lost.
  • Secondary Generalization: A focal seizure can spread to involve both hemispheres, evolving into a bilateral tonic-clonic seizure.
  • Etiology: Often caused by a structural brain lesion, such as a tumor, scar tissue from a previous stroke or trauma, or a developmental malformation.
  • Treatment: Typically treated with narrow-spectrum anticonvulsants like [[eddd2bc5|carbamazepine]] or [[5aea213f|phenytoin]], although broad-spectrum agents are also effective.
  • USMLE Tip: The initial symptoms of a seizure (the aura) can help localize its origin. For example, an olfactory hallucination (e.g., smelling burning rubber) points to a temporal lobe onset.
content.takeAway: Focal seizures are the result of an electrical fire starting in one specific part of the brain, with the resulting symptoms providing a direct clue to the location of the seizure's origin.

content.definition: The Foramen of Magendie, or median aperture, is a single opening in the midline of the roof of the fourth ventricle. It is one of the three apertures that allow cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to exit the ventricular system and enter the subarachnoid space.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Midline of the posterior roof of the fourth ventricle.
  • Function: Allows CSF to flow from the fourth ventricle into the cisterna magna, a large CSF cistern in the subarachnoid space located posterior to the medulla and inferior to the cerebellum.
  • Paired Foramina: It works in conjunction with the two lateral [[098c1e45|foramina of Luschka]].
  • Clinical Significance: Obstruction of the foramina of Magendie and Luschka (e.g., by a tumor, inflammation, or congenital malformation like [[b96a6a07|Chiari malformation]]) blocks CSF outflow from the ventricles, causing non-communicating hydrocephalus.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the three exits from the fourth ventricle: two lateral foramina of Luschka and one median foramen of Magendie.
content.takeAway: The Foramen of Magendie is the central drain of the fourth ventricle, allowing CSF to escape into the subarachnoid space; its blockage leads to a dangerous backup of fluid and hydrocephalus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Fourth Ventricle] --> B(Foramen of Magendie); B --> C(Subarachnoid Space/Cisterna Magna);

content.definition: The Interventricular Foramen, also known as the foramen of Monro, are two short conduits that connect the paired lateral ventricles with the third ventricle at the midline of the brain, allowing for the passage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Situated at the junction of the anterior and body portions of the lateral ventricles, connecting them to the anterior part of the third ventricle.
  • Function: Allows CSF produced in the lateral ventricles to flow into the third ventricle.
  • Clinical Significance: Obstruction of one or both foramina can lead to non-communicating hydrocephalus. A common cause of obstruction is a colloid cyst of the third ventricle, which can act as a ball-valve, causing intermittent obstruction and positional headaches.
  • Imaging: Blockage of a foramen of Monro will lead to enlargement of the ipsilateral lateral ventricle, while the third and fourth ventricles remain normal in size.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with positional headaches that are relieved by lying down, who has an enlarged lateral ventricle on imaging, should be evaluated for a colloid cyst obstructing the foramen of Monro.
content.takeAway: The Foramen of Monro is the crucial channel that allows CSF to drain from each lateral ventricle into the third ventricle; its blockage, often by a colloid cyst, leads to a buildup of pressure in the affected lateral ventricle.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lateral Ventricles] --Foramen of Monro--> B(Third Ventricle);

content.definition: The Foramina of Luschka, or lateral apertures, are two openings on the lateral aspects of the fourth ventricle. They are part of the three apertures that allow cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to exit the ventricular system and enter the subarachnoid space.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Paired openings located on the lateral recesses of the fourth ventricle.
  • Function: Allow CSF to flow from the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space, specifically into the cerebellopontine angle cistern.
  • Paired with: Works in conjunction with the single, midline [[0569a9e3|foramen of Magendie]].
  • Clinical Significance: Obstruction of the foramina of Luschka and Magendie (e.g., by a tumor, inflammation, or congenital malformation like [[96ec2121|Dandy-Walker malformation]]) blocks CSF outflow from the ventricles, causing non-communicating hydrocephalus.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the three exits from the fourth ventricle: two Lateral foramina of Luschka and one median foramen of Magendie.
content.takeAway: The Foramina of Luschka are the paired lateral drains of the fourth ventricle, essential for allowing CSF to escape into the subarachnoid space; their blockage results in a dangerous buildup of fluid and pressure within the entire ventricular system.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Fourth Ventricle] --> B(Foramina of Luschka); B --> C(Subarachnoid Space/Cerebellopontine Angle);

content.definition: Frataxin is a mitochondrial protein that is essential for the synthesis of iron-sulfur clusters and for regulating mitochondrial iron homeostasis. A deficiency of frataxin is the underlying cause of [[39bc1763|Friedreich ataxia]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Plays a critical role in mitochondrial iron metabolism and the assembly of iron-sulfur cluster-containing proteins, which are essential for the electron transport chain and other enzymatic reactions.
  • Genetic Basis: The gene for frataxin (FXN) is located on chromosome 9. In [[39bc1763|Friedreich ataxia]], there is an expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in an intron of this gene.
  • Pathophysiology: The GAA repeat expansion leads to reduced transcription of the FXN gene, resulting in a deficiency of the frataxin protein. This leads to mitochondrial iron overload, oxidative stress, and impaired mitochondrial function, particularly in high-energy-demand tissues.
  • Affected Tissues: The deficiency of frataxin particularly affects neurons (especially in the cerebellum, dorsal root ganglia, and corticospinal tracts), cardiomyocytes, and pancreatic β-cells.
  • USMLE Tip: Frataxin deficiency → Mitochondrial dysfunction → [[39bc1763|Friedreich ataxia]]. Remember the GAA repeat and the key systems affected: nervous system (ataxia), heart (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy), and pancreas (diabetes).
content.takeAway: Frataxin is a vital mitochondrial protein for iron management; its deficiency, caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion, leads to mitochondrial iron overload and oxidative damage, culminating in the multisystem neurodegenerative disorder, Friedreich ataxia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[GAA Repeat Expansion in FXN Gene] --> B(↓ Frataxin Protein); B --> C(Mitochondrial Iron Overload & Oxidative Stress); C --> D(Cell Death in Neurons, Cardiomyocytes, Pancreatic β-cells); D --> E(Friedreich Ataxia);

content.definition: Free nerve endings are unencapsulated, branching terminations of sensory nerve fibers found throughout the body, particularly in the skin, cornea, and pulp of teeth. They are the most common type of nerve ending and are responsible for detecting pain (nociception) and temperature (thermoception).
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Simple, unencapsulated dendritic endings of sensory neurons.
  • Function: Mediate the sensations of pain and temperature. They are also involved in crude touch.
  • Fiber Types: The signals are transmitted by two main types of nerve fibers:
    - Aδ fibers: Thinly myelinated, fast-conducting fibers that transmit sharp, well-localized 'fast' pain and cold sensation.
    - C fibers: Unmyelinated, slow-conducting fibers that transmit dull, aching, poorly-localized 'slow' pain and warmth sensation.
  • Location: Abundant in the epidermis and cornea, but also found in most other body tissues.
  • USMLE Tip: Associate free nerve endings with the primary sensations of pain and temperature, and remember the two different fiber types (fast Aδ and slow C) that carry these signals.
content.takeAway: Free nerve endings are the body's primary detectors for noxious and thermal stimuli, acting as simple but crucial sensors that alert the nervous system to potential or actual tissue damage through the sensations of pain and temperature.

content.definition: The term "fried egg" cells is a classic histological description for the appearance of cells in an oligodendroglioma. These cells have a round, central nucleus (the 'yolk') surrounded by a clear halo of cytoplasm (the 'egg white').
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: Round cells with a dark, central nucleus and a clear cytoplasmic halo. This appearance is an artifact of tissue processing.
  • Associated Tumor: The pathognomonic histological feature of an oligodendroglioma, a primary CNS tumor derived from [[a24f9747|oligodendrocytes]].
  • Other Features of Oligodendroglioma: These tumors often have a delicate network of branching capillaries, described as a 'chicken-wire' pattern, and are frequently calcified.
  • Other 'Fried Egg' Appearances: The term is also used to describe other cells in pathology, such as koilocytes in HPV infection and the cells of a seminoma. In the context of neuropathology, it refers to oligodendroglioma.
  • USMLE Tip: A brain tumor biopsy showing 'fried egg' cells and a 'chicken-wire' capillary pattern is diagnostic for an oligodendroglioma.
content.takeAway: The 'fried egg' appearance is the memorable histological signature of an oligodendroglioma, created by a processing artifact that leaves the tumor cells with a clear cytoplasm surrounding a central nucleus, resembling a sunny-side-up egg.

content.definition: Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive gait and limb ataxia, dysarthria, and loss of proprioception and vibration sense. It is the most common hereditary ataxia.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Caused by an expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in an intron of the FXN gene on chromosome 9. This leads to reduced expression of the mitochondrial protein [[fc5e9480|frataxin]].
  • Pathophysiology: Frataxin deficiency causes mitochondrial iron overload and oxidative stress, leading to degeneration of multiple spinal cord tracts (dorsal columns, corticospinal, spinocerebellar), dorsal root ganglia, and the cerebellum.
  • Neurological Manifestations: Progressive gait and limb [[9767fd6b|ataxia]], dysarthria, loss of deep tendon reflexes (due to dorsal root ganglia degeneration), and an extensor plantar response (Babinski sign, due to corticospinal tract damage).
  • Systemic Manifestations:
    - Cardiac: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of death.
    - Endocrine: Diabetes mellitus.
    - Skeletal: Kyphoscoliosis and foot deformities (pes cavus, hammer toes).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic for Friedreich Ataxia: Frataxin is deficient, Ataxic (GAA), Autosomal recessive. The combination of neurological symptoms (ataxia, loss of reflexes) with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and skeletal deformities is classic.
content.takeAway: Friedreich ataxia is a multisystem disorder caused by a GAA repeat expansion leading to frataxin deficiency and mitochondrial dysfunction, which manifests as a devastating combination of progressive neurodegeneration (ataxia), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and diabetes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[GAA Repeat Expansion] --> B(↓ Frataxin); B --> C(Mitochondrial Dysfunction); C --> D(Spinal Cord & Cerebellar Degeneration); D --> E(Ataxia); C --> F(Cardiomyocyte Damage); F --> G(Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy); C --> H(Pancreatic β-cell Damage); H --> I(Diabetes Mellitus);

content.definition: The Frontal Eye Fields (FEF) are a region of the prefrontal cortex (Brodmann area 8) responsible for planning and initiating voluntary, saccadic eye movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Located in the middle frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe.
  • Function: Controls voluntary, conjugate eye movements to the contralateral side. For example, the left FEF drives the eyes to the right.
  • Pathway: The FEF projects to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), the brainstem's horizontal gaze center.
  • Lesion Effects:
    - Destructive Lesion (e.g., stroke): Causes a temporary gaze deviation toward the side of the lesion. This is because the contralateral, intact FEF is unopposed and drives the eyes toward the damaged side.
    - Irritative Lesion (e.g., seizure): Causes the eyes to deviate away from the side of the lesion, as the hyperactive FEF drives the eyes to the contralateral side.
  • USMLE Tip: The direction of eye deviation is a key localizing sign. Remember: FEF lesion = eyes look toward the 'bad' side. PPRF lesion = eyes look away from the 'bad' side.
content.takeAway: The Frontal Eye Fields are the cortical command center for voluntary eye movements, with each hemisphere driving the eyes to the opposite side; a destructive lesion here results in the unopposed action of the healthy hemisphere, causing the eyes to 'look at the lesion'.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Left FEF] --Activates--> B(Right PPRF); B --> C(Gaze to the Right); D[Right FEF] --Activates--> E(Left PPRF); E --> F(Gaze to the Left);

content.definition: The Frontal Lobe is the largest of the four major lobes of the cerebral cortex in the brain of mammals, located at the front of each cerebral hemisphere. It is responsible for higher-level executive functions, motor control, and speech production.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Motor Cortex (Precentral Gyrus): Controls voluntary movements of the contralateral side of the body. Organized somatotopically (motor homunculus).
  • Premotor Cortex & Supplementary Motor Area: Involved in planning and sequencing movements.
  • [[5ddbdcd3|Frontal Eye Fields (FEF)]]: Control voluntary eye movements.
  • [[a3bbace2|Broca's Area]]: Located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, responsible for speech production.
  • Prefrontal Cortex: The large anterior portion of the frontal lobe responsible for executive functions: planning, decision-making, working memory, personality expression, and moderating social behavior.
  • Lesion Effects: Damage to the frontal lobe can cause contralateral paralysis ([[830c856c|ACA stroke]] -> leg; [[143bb23d|MCA stroke]] -> arm/face), expressive aphasia (Broca's), and profound changes in personality and social conduct (frontal lobe syndrome).
  • USMLE Tip: Frontal lobe lesions are classically associated with personality changes, disinhibition, and deficits in executive function.
content.takeAway: The Frontal Lobe is the brain's 'CEO,' orchestrating voluntary movement, producing language, and governing the complex executive functions that define personality and guide goal-directed behavior.

content.definition: Frontal lobe syndrome refers to a clinical syndrome resulting from damage to the prefrontal cortex of the [[0405ada3|frontal lobe]], leading to profound changes in personality, social behavior, and executive function.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by lesions affecting the prefrontal cortex, such as traumatic brain injury (e.g., Phineas Gage), tumors, stroke, or neurodegenerative diseases like [[5fff42cd|frontotemporal dementia]].
  • Key Features: The specific symptoms depend on the area of the prefrontal cortex affected:
    - Disinhibition: Damage to the orbitofrontal cortex leads to impulsive, socially inappropriate behavior, poor judgment, and emotional lability.
    - Apathy: Damage to the medial frontal cortex can cause abulia (lack of motivation) or akinetic mutism.
    - Executive Dysfunction: Damage to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex impairs planning, problem-solving, working memory, and concentration.
  • Primitive Reflexes: Lesions can lead to the re-emergence of primitive reflexes (e.g., grasp, rooting) due to loss of cortical inhibition.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a dramatic personality change, becoming impulsive and socially inappropriate after a head injury, is a classic presentation of frontal lobe syndrome.
content.takeAway: Frontal lobe syndrome is the clinical manifestation of damage to the brain's 'CEO,' the prefrontal cortex, resulting in a loss of executive control and a breakdown of the personality and social filters that govern appropriate behavior.

content.definition: Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD), formerly known as Pick disease, is a group of neurodegenerative disorders characterized by the progressive atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes. It is a common cause of early-onset dementia (before age 65).
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Variants:
    - Behavioral Variant (bvFTD): The most common form. Presents with early and prominent changes in personality, social conduct, and behavior (e.g., apathy, disinhibition, compulsive behaviors). This is a classic [[4c1bee62|frontal lobe syndrome]].
    - Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA): Presents with a progressive decline in language abilities.
  • Histopathology: Characterized by the presence of intracellular inclusions. In some cases, these are hyperphosphorylated tau proteins forming round aggregates known as Pick bodies. In other cases, the inclusions are ubiquitinated TDP-43 protein.
  • Imaging: MRI or CT shows focal atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes.
  • Differentiation from Alzheimer's: FTD is distinguished from [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] by the early prominence of behavioral or language deficits, with relative sparing of memory and visuospatial skills in the initial stages.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient in their 50s or 60s with a dramatic change in personality (e.g., becoming socially inappropriate or apathetic) but with preserved memory is the classic vignette for behavioral variant FTD.
content.takeAway: Frontotemporal Dementia is a neurodegenerative disease that selectively attacks the frontal and temporal lobes, leading to a devastating loss of personality, social grace, and language, while initially sparing the memory functions typically lost in Alzheimer's disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Frontal & Temporal Lobe Atrophy] --> B{FTD Variants}; B --> C(Behavioral Variant - Personality Change); B --> D(Primary Progressive Aphasia - Language Loss);

content.definition: A funduscopic examination (or ophthalmoscopy) is a routine part of a physical exam that involves visualizing the fundus of the eye, which includes the retina, optic disc, macula, and retinal vessels. It provides a direct, non-invasive view of the central nervous system's vasculature and parenchyma.
content.atAGlance:
• Purpose: Used to detect and evaluate a wide range of ocular and systemic diseases.
  • Key Structures Visualized: Optic disc, retinal arteries and veins, macula, and fovea.
  • Findings in Glaucoma: In [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]], the exam may reveal optic disc cupping, which is an enlargement of the cup-to-disc ratio due to the loss of optic nerve fibers.
  • Findings in Retinal Disorders: Can identify numerous pathologies, including:
    - [[73b00ab0|Diabetic retinopathy]]: Microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, neovascularization.
    - [[549b012e|Hypertensive retinopathy]]: AV nicking, cotton-wool spots, hemorrhages.
    - [[c63255c8|Macular degeneration]]: [[3f8bff66|Drusen]] (dry) or hemorrhage (wet).
    - [[3334840f|CRAO]]: Cherry-red spot.
    - [[b69e35b5|CRVO]]: 'Blood and thunder' appearance.
  • Papilledema: Swelling of the optic disc with blurred margins, a sign of increased intracranial pressure.
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to recognize the classic funduscopic findings of common systemic diseases like diabetes and hypertension, as well as ophthalmologic emergencies like CRAO and papilledema.
content.takeAway: The funduscopic examination is a powerful diagnostic tool, offering a unique 'window' into the health of both the eye and the body's microvasculature, revealing signs of diseases ranging from glaucoma and diabetes to life-threatening increased intracranial pressure.

content.definition: Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the mature central nervous system. Its principal role is to reduce neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Synthesized from glutamate by the enzyme glutamate decarboxylase, which requires vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) as a cofactor.
  • Receptors:
    - GABAA: An ionotropic receptor (ligand-gated Cl- channel). Binding of GABA causes an influx of Cl-, leading to hyperpolarization of the neuron.
    - GABAB: A metabotropic receptor (G protein-coupled). Activation opens K+ channels and closes Ca2+ channels, also leading to hyperpolarization.
  • Pharmacology: The GABAA receptor is a major target for many CNS depressant drugs, including [[14464617|benzodiazepines]], [[52564aea|barbiturates]], and alcohol. [[1ddc3f08|Baclofen]] is a GABAB agonist used to treat spasticity in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]].
  • Pathology: A deficiency of GABA is implicated in [[d1c786e9|anxiety disorders]] and [[64c08e92|epilepsy]]. A profound loss of GABAergic neurons in the striatum is the hallmark of [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that GABA is the main 'brake' of the CNS. Drugs that enhance GABA's effect are depressants, while a loss of GABAergic neurons leads to hyperkinetic disorders like Huntington's.
content.takeAway: GABA is the brain's universal inhibitory signal, acting primarily through GABAA receptors to open chloride channels and quiet neuronal firing, a mechanism that is therapeutically enhanced by anxiolytics and sedatives.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Glutamate] --Glutamate Decarboxylase (B6)--> B(GABA); B --> C(Binds to GABA Receptors); C --> D(↑ Cl- influx or ↑ K+ efflux); D --> E(Hyperpolarization); E --> F(Inhibition of Neuron);

content.definition: The GABAA receptor is an ionotropic receptor and ligand-gated chloride channel that is the primary target for the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA. Its action is allosterically modulated by several classes of drugs, including benzodiazepines and barbiturates.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: A pentameric transmembrane protein that forms a central chloride (Cl-) ion channel.
  • GABA Action: When GABA binds to the receptor, the channel opens, allowing Cl- to flow into the neuron, causing hyperpolarization and making it less likely to fire an action potential.
  • [[14464617|Benzodiazepine]] Action: Bind to an allosteric site on the receptor and increase the frequency of channel opening in the presence of GABA.
  • [[52564aea|Barbiturate]] Action: Bind to a different allosteric site and increase the duration of channel opening in the presence of GABA. At high concentrations, barbiturates can directly open the channel even without GABA.
  • Mnemonic: Frenzodiazepines increase frequency. Barbidurates increase duration.
  • USMLE Tip: The different mechanisms of action explain the different safety profiles. Benzodiazepines have a ceiling effect on CNS depression because they require GABA to be present. Barbiturates do not, making their overdose much more likely to be fatal.
content.takeAway: The GABAA receptor's inhibitory action is fine-tuned by allosteric modulators: benzodiazepines make the chloride channel open more often, while barbiturates make it stay open longer, with both leading to enhanced CNS depression.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[GABA] --> B(Binds to GABA-A Receptor); B --> C(Cl- Channel Opens); D[Benzodiazepines] --Increase Frequency--> C; E[Barbiturates] --Increase Duration--> C;

content.definition: Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant medication that is structurally related to the neurotransmitter GABA. Despite its name, it does not act on GABA receptors but is primarily used for the treatment of neuropathic pain and as an adjunctive therapy for focal seizures.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: The primary mechanism is believed to be the inhibition of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels, specifically by binding to the α2δ-1 subunit. This reduces the release of excitatory neurotransmitters like glutamate.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Neuropathic Pain: First-line agent for various types of neuropathic pain, including diabetic neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia.
    - Seizures: Used as an adjunctive therapy for [[953ad620|focal seizures]].
    - Other: Also used for [[919caff2|restless legs syndrome]] and fibromyalgia.
  • Class: It is a gabapentinoid, along with pregabalin, which shares a similar mechanism and clinical use.
  • Adverse Effects: The most common side effects are sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • USMLE Tip: Do not be fooled by the name; gabapentin does not work on GABA receptors. Its main use is for neuropathic pain, not as a primary anticonvulsant.
content.takeAway: Gabapentin is a widely prescribed medication for neuropathic pain that works by inhibiting calcium channels to dampen the release of excitatory neurotransmitters, despite its name misleadingly suggesting a direct interaction with the GABA system.

content.definition: Gabapentinoids are a class of drugs that includes [[57eb8e27|gabapentin]] and pregabalin. They are structurally related to GABA but exert their effects by binding to voltage-gated calcium channels, not GABA receptors.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Bind to the α2δ-1 subunit of presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels in the CNS. This binding reduces the influx of calcium into the presynaptic terminal, which in turn decreases the release of excitatory neurotransmitters such as glutamate, norepinephrine, and substance P.
  • Agents: [[57eb8e27|Gabapentin]] and Pregabalin.
  • Clinical Use: Primarily used for neuropathic pain (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, postherpetic neuralgia), fibromyalgia, and as adjunctive therapy for [[953ad620|focal seizures]].
  • Adverse Effects: The most common dose-dependent side effects are sedation, dizziness, and ataxia. Peripheral edema can also occur.
  • USMLE Tip: The key mechanism is the inhibition of presynaptic calcium channels, leading to reduced neurotransmitter release. This is a distinct mechanism from most other anticonvulsants.
content.takeAway: Gabapentinoids are a class of drugs that calm hyperexcitable neurons by 'turning down the volume' on neurotransmitter release, achieved by blocking presynaptic calcium channels, making them effective for both neuropathic pain and seizures.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Gabapentinoid] --> B(Binds to α2δ-1 subunit of Ca2+ channel); B --> C(↓ Ca2+ Influx); C --> D(↓ Release of Excitatory Neurotransmitters); D --> E(Analgesia & Anticonvulsant Effect);

content.definition: The Gag Reflex is a protective reflex involving a bilateral contraction of the pharyngeal muscles, elicited by touching the posterior pharynx, tonsils, or base of the tongue. It serves to prevent foreign objects from entering the throat.
content.atAGlance:
• Purpose: Tests the integrity of a brainstem reflex arc involving cranial nerves IX and X.
  • Afferent Limb (Sensation): The touch sensation from the posterior pharynx is carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
  • Efferent Limb (Motor): The motor response (elevation of the palate, contraction of the pharyngeal muscles) is carried out by the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Clinical Significance: An absent or diminished gag reflex indicates a lesion in either CN IX, CN X, or the medulla oblongata. It is a sign of bulbar dysfunction.
  • Associated Conditions: A diminished gag reflex is seen in [[901f3180|bulbar palsy]] and brainstem strokes like the lateral medullary syndrome (which affects the nucleus ambiguus, the motor nucleus for CN IX and X).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the simple pathway: Sensation 'in' via CN IX, motor action 'out' via CN X.
content.takeAway: The Gag Reflex is a crucial brainstem reflex that relies on CN IX to sense a stimulus in the throat and CN X to execute the protective muscular contraction, making its absence a key indicator of lower cranial nerve or medullary pathology.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Touch Posterior Pharynx] --> B(Afferent: CN IX); B --> C(Medulla); C --> D(Efferent: CN X); D --> E(Pharyngeal Muscle Contraction);

content.definition: Gait disturbance is an abnormality in the manner of walking. The pattern of the gait abnormality can provide important clues to the location and nature of the underlying neurological or musculoskeletal pathology.
content.atAGlance:
• Ataxic Gait: Unsteady and wide-based, often described as 'drunken.' Caused by cerebellar dysfunction ([[39bc1763|Friedreich ataxia]], alcohol intoxication) or sensory ataxia ([[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]]).
  • Spastic Gait: Stiff, shuffling, with feet scraping the floor. Seen in UMN lesions (e.g., cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury).
  • Steppage Gait (Foot Drop): Inability to dorsiflex the foot, causing the patient to lift the leg high to avoid tripping. Caused by common peroneal nerve palsy or L5 radiculopathy.
  • Parkinsonian Gait: Shuffling with short steps (festinating), stooped posture, and difficulty initiating movement. Seen in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
  • [[eb32eb82|Gait Apraxia]] ('Magnetic Gait'): Feet appear 'stuck to the floor.' The patient has difficulty initiating steps despite normal motor power. A classic sign of [[7c59030e|normal pressure hydrocephalus]].
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to recognize the descriptions of different gait patterns and associate them with their classic underlying causes.
content.takeAway: Gait disturbance is a highly informative neurological sign, with the specific pattern of walking—be it ataxic, spastic, shuffling, or magnetic—offering a window into the location of the underlying pathology, from the peripheral nerves to the cerebellum and cerebral cortex.

content.definition: The Galant reflex, also known as the truncal incurvation reflex, is a primitive reflex found in newborns. It is elicited by stroking the skin along one side of the infant's spine, which causes the infant to laterally flex their lower body toward the stimulated side.
content.atAGlance:
• Elicitation: The infant is held in ventral suspension (face down). The examiner strokes the skin along one side of the spine from the shoulder to the hip.
  • Normal Response: The infant's trunk and hips curve toward the side of the stimulus.
  • Timeline: Present at birth and typically disappears by 4 to 6 months of age.
  • Clinical Significance: It is one of several primitive reflexes tested in the newborn neurological exam to assess brainstem and spinal cord integrity. An absent or asymmetric response may indicate a spinal cord lesion or other neurological injury.
  • USMLE Tip: The Galant reflex is a normal finding in a newborn. Its persistence beyond 6 months or its absence at birth can be a sign of CNS dysfunction.
content.takeAway: The Galant reflex is a primitive spinal reflex in newborns that demonstrates the integrity of the spinal cord arc, where a unilateral tactile stimulus triggers a corresponding lateral flexion of the trunk.

content.definition: Galantamine is a reversible [[0835ea01|cholinesterase inhibitor]] used for the symptomatic treatment of mild to moderate [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Reversibly inhibits acetylcholinesterase (AChE), increasing the concentration of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] in the brain. It also has a secondary action as a positive allosteric modulator of nicotinic receptors.
  • Rationale for Use: [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] is associated with a significant loss of cholinergic neurons, and galantamine aims to enhance the function of the remaining neurons.
  • Clinical Use: Provides modest, symptomatic improvement in cognitive function in some patients with mild to moderate [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]. It does not alter the course of the underlying disease.
  • Adverse Effects: Primarily cholinergic side effects, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and dizziness.
  • Other Agents: [[47d0372e|Donepezil]] and rivastigmine are other cholinesterase inhibitors used for Alzheimer's disease.
  • USMLE Tip: Along with donepezil and rivastigmine, galantamine is a first-line symptomatic treatment for Alzheimer's, based on the cholinergic hypothesis of the disease.
content.takeAway: Galantamine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that provides a modest cognitive boost in Alzheimer's disease by increasing acetylcholine levels, thereby supporting the function of the brain's dwindling cholinergic system.

content.definition: Upward gaze palsy (or vertical gaze palsy) is the inability to voluntarily move the eyes upward. It is the hallmark sign of Parinaud syndrome (dorsal midbrain syndrome).
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain, specifically compressing the superior colliculus and the vertical gaze center located there.
  • Associated Syndrome: The primary component of Parinaud syndrome.
  • Parinaud Syndrome Triad:
    1. Upward Gaze Palsy.
    2. Pupillary Light-Near Dissociation: Pupils react poorly to light but constrict to accommodation.
    3. [[3db2e75e|Convergence-Retraction Nystagmus]]: Jerky movements of the eyes on attempted upgaze.
  • Common Causes: In children, a pinealoma is the classic cause. In adults, causes include stroke of the midbrain or hydrocephalus causing pressure on the tectum.
  • USMLE Tip: The inability to look up, especially in a child or young adult, should immediately raise suspicion for a pineal region tumor causing Parinaud syndrome.
content.takeAway: Upward gaze palsy is a definitive localizing sign, pointing to a lesion in the dorsal midbrain that has disrupted the vertical gaze center, and is the most prominent feature of Parinaud syndrome.

content.definition: Generalized seizures are a type of seizure that originates at some point within, and rapidly engages, bilaterally distributed neural networks. Consciousness is typically impaired from the onset.
content.atAGlance:
• Types of Generalized Seizures:
    - Tonic-Clonic (Grand Mal): The most well-known type. Begins with a tonic phase (stiffening) followed by a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking). Associated with loss of consciousness and a postictal state.
    - [[a0c128f4|Absence (Petit Mal)]]: Brief episodes of staring and impaired awareness, with a 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG pattern.
    - Myoclonic: Sudden, brief, shock-like muscle jerks.
    - [[ed7a236f|Atonic ('Drop' Seizures)]]: Sudden loss of muscle tone, causing a fall.
    - Tonic: Sustained muscle stiffening.
  • Treatment: Require [[4dff096f|broad-spectrum anticonvulsants]] that are effective against multiple seizure types, such as [[valproic_acid|valproic acid]], [[08d19a8f|lamotrigine]], or [[2341f9c0|levetiracetam]].
  • Contraindicated Drugs: Narrow-spectrum agents like [[eddd2bc5|carbamazepine]] and [[5aea213f|phenytoin]] can worsen certain generalized seizures, particularly absence and myoclonic seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature of generalized seizures is the immediate involvement of both hemispheres, leading to an abrupt loss of consciousness at the start of the event.
content.takeAway: Generalized seizures represent a widespread electrical storm involving both cerebral hemispheres from the outset, leading to an immediate loss of consciousness and diverse motor manifestations, requiring treatment with broad-spectrum anticonvulsants.

content.definition: Geriatric patients experience a number of age-related physiological changes and have a different spectrum of neurological diseases compared to younger adults. These considerations are critical for diagnosis and management.
content.atAGlance:
• Common Neurological Conditions:
    - Stroke: Incidence increases dramatically with age. [[c5da3c57|Ischemic stroke]] is the most common cause of seizures in the elderly.
    - Dementia: [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and [[99420dce|vascular dementia]] are highly prevalent.
    - [[58c8ea03|Parkinson Disease]]: A neurodegenerative movement disorder of older age.
    - Hearing Loss: [[presbycusis|Presbycusis]] (age-related sensorineural hearing loss) is extremely common.
    - Vision Changes: [[85f03b02|Cataracts]], [[c63255c8|age-related macular degeneration]], and [[presbyopia]] (loss of accommodation) are nearly universal.
  • Aneurysm Risk: The risk of both [[a9f6d703|saccular aneurysm]] rupture and [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhage]] (from CAA or hypertension) increases with age.
  • USMLE Tip: When presented with an elderly patient with a new neurological symptom, the differential diagnosis is heavily weighted towards stroke, neurodegeneration, and malignancy. Also, be mindful of polypharmacy and altered drug metabolism in this population.
content.takeAway: The neurology of geriatric patients is dominated by the 'D's'—Degeneration (Alzheimer's, Parkinson's), Deprivation of blood flow (stroke), and Decreased sensory function (presbycusis, macular degeneration)—requiring a distinct diagnostic approach compared to younger populations.

content.definition: Gerstmann syndrome is a neurological disorder characterized by a specific tetrad of cognitive deficits, resulting from a lesion in the dominant (usually left) inferior parietal lobule, specifically the angular gyrus.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Dominant inferior parietal lobule (angular gyrus).
  • Classic Tetrad:
    1. [[13d6bca7|Agraphia]]: Inability to write.
    2. [[8558c64b|Acalculia]]: Inability to perform simple mathematical calculations.
    3. [[c88383fe|Finger Agnosia]]: Inability to identify or distinguish one's own fingers.
    4. Left-Right Disorientation: Inability to distinguish left from right.
  • Etiology: Most commonly caused by a [[c5da3c57|stroke]] in the territory of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]] that supplies the dominant parietal lobe.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of all four components of this tetrad is highly specific for a lesion in the dominant angular gyrus. If you see a patient who can't write, do math, or tell their fingers apart, think Gerstmann syndrome.
content.takeAway: Gerstmann syndrome is a unique cognitive syndrome where a single lesion in the dominant angular gyrus disrupts a cluster of seemingly unrelated higher-order functions—writing, calculation, finger identification, and left-right orientation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lesion in Dominant Angular Gyrus] --> B(Gerstmann Syndrome); B --> C(Agraphia); B --> D(Acalculia); B --> E(Finger Agnosia); B --> F(Left-Right Disorientation);

content.definition: Weakness, or paresis, is a reduction in the force exerted by one or more muscles. In neurology, the pattern of weakness and associated signs helps distinguish between an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion and a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) Weakness: Caused by a lesion in the corticospinal tract (e.g., stroke, spinal cord injury). It is characterized by spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia, increased tone, and a positive Babinski sign. Weakness is often more pronounced in extensors of the upper limb and flexors of the lower limb.
  • Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) Weakness: Caused by a lesion of the anterior horn cells, nerve roots, or peripheral nerves. It is characterized by flaccid paralysis, hyporeflexia, decreased tone, significant muscle atrophy, and fasciculations.
  • Spinal Cord Lesions: The pattern of weakness depends on the tracts involved. For example, an [[b48b54d7|anterior spinal artery occlusion]] causes bilateral LMN weakness at the level of the lesion and UMN weakness below it.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of both UMN and LMN signs in the same patient is the hallmark of [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]].
content.takeAway: The character of muscle weakness is a powerful localizing tool: spasticity and hyperreflexia point to an upper motor neuron lesion, while flaccidity, atrophy, and fasciculations indicate a lower motor neuron lesion.

content.definition: Weber syndrome, also known as medial midbrain syndrome, is a brainstem stroke syndrome caused by an infarct in the anterior midbrain, affecting the cerebral peduncle and the fibers of the oculomotor nerve (CN III).
content.atAGlance:
• Vascular Territory: Caused by occlusion of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA).
  • Structures Damaged:
    1. Cerebral Peduncle: Contains the descending corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts.
    2. Oculomotor Nerve (CN III) Fibers: Emerge from the midbrain between the cerebral peduncles.
  • Clinical Presentation: A classic crossed deficit:
    - Ipsilateral CN III palsy: The eye is deviated 'down and out,' with ptosis and a dilated pupil.
    - Contralateral Hemiplegia/Hemiparesis: Weakness of the arm and leg due to corticospinal tract damage.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of an ipsilateral CN III palsy and contralateral hemiplegia is pathognomonic for Weber syndrome and localizes the lesion to the anterior midbrain.
content.takeAway: Weber syndrome is a classic midbrain stroke syndrome that 'knocks out' the oculomotor nerve and the corticospinal tract on one side, resulting in the tell-tale combination of an ipsilateral 'down and out' eye and contralateral body paralysis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[PCA Branch Occlusion] --> B(Anterior Midbrain Infarct); B --> C(Ipsilateral CN III Palsy); B --> D(Contralateral Hemiplegia);

content.definition: Werdnig-Hoffmann disease, also known as Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Type 1, is the most severe form of SMA. It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the degeneration of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord, leading to progressive, symmetric muscle weakness and atrophy.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Autosomal recessive mutation or deletion in the SMN1 (Survival Motor Neuron 1) gene on chromosome 5.
  • Pathophysiology: The SMN protein is essential for the survival of lower motor neurons. Its deficiency leads to apoptosis of anterior horn cells.
  • Clinical Presentation: Onset is before 6 months of age. Presents as a "floppy baby" with profound, symmetric hypotonia and flaccid weakness, which is more pronounced proximally than distally. Tongue fasciculations are a characteristic finding.
  • Motor Milestones: Infants are never able to sit unsupported.
  • Prognosis: Without treatment, death from respiratory failure typically occurs before age 2.
  • Comparison to Polio: The pathology (destruction of anterior horn cells) is similar to poliomyelitis, but the cause is genetic, not infectious.
  • USMLE Tip: A 'floppy infant' with tongue fasciculations and absent deep tendon reflexes is the classic presentation for Werdnig-Hoffmann disease.
content.takeAway: Werdnig-Hoffmann disease (SMA Type 1) is a devastating genetic disorder that selectively destroys lower motor neurons, resulting in a 'floppy baby' with progressive paralysis that ultimately leads to respiratory failure in early childhood.

content.definition: Wernicke's aphasia, also known as receptive aphasia, is a language disorder characterized by fluent but meaningless speech and severely impaired language comprehension. It is caused by a lesion in Wernicke's area.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Superior temporal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere.
  • Vascular Supply: Supplied by the inferior division of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Clinical Presentation:
    - Fluency: Speech is fluent and grammatically correct but is nonsensical and contains paraphasic errors and neologisms (made-up words). This is often described as a "word salad."
