  • Type of Mutation: The mutation seen in [[1c42ff26|Sturge-Weber syndrome]] is a somatic mosaic mutation. This means it occurs after conception, is not inherited, and affects only a subset of the body's cells.
  • Associated Disorder: The primary neurological disorder associated with this mutation is [[1c42ff26|Sturge-Weber syndrome]] (encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis).
  • Pathophysiology in Sturge-Weber: The somatic mutation in neural crest derivatives is thought to cause the development of the characteristic vascular malformations (facial port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angioma).
  • USMLE Tip: Associate the somatic GNAQ mutation with Sturge-Weber syndrome. The fact that it's a somatic mutation explains why the disorder is not inherited and why its manifestations can be patchy or mosaic.
content.takeAway: A post-zygotic somatic GNAQ gene mutation is the underlying genetic event that gives rise to the vascular malformations of Sturge-Weber syndrome, explaining its sporadic occurrence and mosaic pattern of involvement.

content.definition: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is a tropic peptide hormone synthesized and released from GnRH neurons within the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]]. It is the primary driver of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, controlling reproduction.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Stimulates the [[76ba7f2e|anterior pituitary]] to secrete the gonadotropins: follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
  • Pulsatile Release: GnRH must be released in a pulsatile fashion to be effective. Continuous, non-pulsatile administration paradoxically leads to the downregulation of GnRH receptors on the pituitary, suppressing FSH and LH release.
  • Pharmacologic Use:
    - Pulsatile administration of GnRH analogs (e.g., gonadorelin) is used to treat infertility.
    - Continuous administration of GnRH analogs (e.g., leuprolide) is used to suppress gonadal function in conditions like prostate cancer, endometriosis, and precocious puberty.
  • Kallmann Syndrome: A genetic disorder characterized by the failure of GnRH-producing neurons to migrate to the hypothalamus, resulting in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia.
  • USMLE Tip: The distinction between pulsatile (stimulatory) and continuous (inhibitory) GnRH action is a critical and frequently tested concept.
content.takeAway: GnRH is the master regulator of the reproductive axis, whose unique requirement for pulsatile release allows for a pharmacological paradox: it can be used to either stimulate fertility (pulsatile) or induce a state of medical castration (continuous).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] --Pulsatile GnRH--> B(Anterior Pituitary); B --> C(FSH & LH Release); C --> D(Gonads);

content.definition: A tonic-clonic seizure, formerly known as a grand mal seizure, is a type of [[2e7554b7|generalized seizure]] that involves a loss of consciousness and violent muscle contractions. It is the most dramatic and widely recognized type of seizure.
content.atAGlance:
• Phases: Characterized by two distinct phases:
    1. Tonic Phase: A sudden stiffening of the body, arms, and legs, causing the person to fall. The patient may cry out as air is forced out of the lungs. Lasts 10-20 seconds.
    2. Clonic Phase: Rhythmic, convulsive jerking of the limbs. The patient may bite their tongue or have urinary/fecal incontinence.
  • Postictal State: Following the seizure, there is a period of confusion, drowsiness, headache, and muscle soreness that can last for hours.
  • Etiology: Can be primary (idiopathic generalized epilepsy) or secondary to a focal seizure that spreads to both hemispheres (focal to bilateral tonic-clonic).
  • Treatment: Acute management involves ensuring patient safety. Long-term prevention requires [[4dff096f|broad-spectrum anticonvulsants]] like [[valproic_acid|valproic acid]] or [[2341f9c0|levetiracetam]].
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of a postictal state is a key feature that helps distinguish a tonic-clonic seizure from syncope.
content.takeAway: A tonic-clonic seizure is a global cerebral electrical storm that manifests as a dramatic sequence of body stiffening (tonic phase) followed by rhythmic convulsions (clonic phase), culminating in a prolonged postictal state of confusion and exhaustion.

content.definition: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute, immune-mediated polyneuropathy characterized by rapidly progressive, symmetric muscle weakness and areflexia. The most common form is [[ed52e40b|acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP)]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: An autoimmune response, often triggered by a preceding infection, leads to demyelination and/or axonal damage of peripheral nerves. Molecular mimicry is the proposed mechanism.
  • Triggers: Classically associated with an antecedent gastrointestinal infection with Campylobacter jejuni. Also associated with other infections (CMV, EBV, Zika) and, rarely, vaccinations.
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapidly progressive, symmetric ascending paralysis, typically starting in the legs and moving up. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished or absent.
  • Complications: Life-threatening complications include respiratory failure from diaphragmatic weakness and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., cardiac arrhythmias, blood pressure instability).
  • Diagnosis: Lumbar puncture reveals the classic finding of [[a0f3ce4c|albuminocytologic dissociation]] in the CSF (high protein, normal cell count). Nerve conduction studies show evidence of demyelination.
  • Treatment: Management is supportive (especially respiratory support). Disease-modifying therapies include plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). Steroids are not effective.
  • USMLE Tip: 'Ascending paralysis' after a diarrheal illness + 'high protein, normal cells' in CSF = Guillain-Barré Syndrome.
content.takeAway: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an acute autoimmune assault on the peripheral nervous system, triggered by a recent infection, that causes a rapidly ascending paralysis which can threaten breathing and autonomic stability.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Antecedent Infection] --Molecular Mimicry--> B(Autoimmune Attack on Peripheral Nerves); B --> C(Demyelination of Schwann Cells); C --> D(Ascending Paralysis & Areflexia);

content.definition: The gustatory pathway is the neural pathway that transmits the sensation of taste from the taste buds on the tongue to the cerebral cortex for conscious perception.
content.atAGlance:
• Peripheral Receptors: Taste buds on the tongue detect the five basic tastes: sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami.
  • First-Order Neurons (Cranial Nerves):
    - [[dea9755f|Facial Nerve (CN VII)]] (via chorda tympani): Transmits taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    - [[97e2c817|Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX)]]: Transmits taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    - [[vagus_nerve|Vagus Nerve (CN X)]]: Transmits taste from the epiglottis and pharynx.
  • Brainstem Relay: All three cranial nerves project to the solitary nucleus (gustatory nucleus) in the medulla.
  • Thalamic Relay: Second-order neurons ascend from the solitary nucleus to the [[23ac314a|ventral posteromedial (VPM) nucleus]] of the thalamus.
  • Cortical Destination: Third-order neurons project from the VPM to the gustatory cortex, located in the insula and frontal operculum.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the cranial nerve innervation for taste: 7 for the front, 9 for the back. The central pathway is Solitary Nucleus → VPM of Thalamus → Cortex.
content.takeAway: The gustatory pathway is a three-neuron chain that carries taste information from the tongue via cranial nerves VII, IX, and X to the solitary nucleus, then relays through the VPM of the thalamus before reaching the cortex for the conscious perception of flavor.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Taste Buds] --> B{CN VII, IX, X}; B --> C(Solitary Nucleus - Medulla); C --> D(VPM Nucleus - Thalamus); D --> E(Gustatory Cortex);

content.definition: The Tuberoinfundibular Pathway is one of the four major dopaminergic pathways in the brain. It consists of dopamine-releasing neurons that project from the arcuate nucleus of the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] to the median eminence, where dopamine is released into the hypophyseal portal system to act on the anterior pituitary.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: The primary role of this pathway is the tonic inhibition of prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary lactotrophs.
  • Mechanism: [[90adc821|Dopamine]] released into the portal system binds to D2 receptors on lactotrophs, inhibiting the synthesis and release of prolactin.
  • Clinical Relevance (Pharmacology): This pathway is significantly affected by dopamine D2 receptor antagonists (i.e., most antipsychotic drugs).
  • Antipsychotic Side Effect: Blockade of D2 receptors in this pathway removes the normal inhibition of prolactin, leading to hyperprolactinemia. This can cause galactorrhea, gynecomastia, amenorrhea, and sexual dysfunction.
  • USMLE Tip: Hyperprolactinemia is a classic side effect of typical and some atypical antipsychotics. Remember that dopamine normally 'puts the brakes' on prolactin; blocking dopamine releases the brake.
content.takeAway: The Tuberoinfundibular Pathway is the neuroendocrine link through which the hypothalamus controls prolactin, with dopamine acting as the primary inhibitory signal; its blockade by antipsychotic drugs predictably leads to hyperprolactinemia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] --Dopamine--> B(Anterior Pituitary); B --Inhibits--> C(Prolactin Release);

content.definition: Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the growth of numerous benign hamartomas in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, heart, kidneys, and lungs.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Autosomal dominant inheritance with variable expressivity. Caused by a mutation in the tumor suppressor genes TSC1 (encoding hamartin) or TSC2 (encoding tuberin).
  • Pathophysiology: Hamartin and tuberin normally form a complex that inhibits mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin), a key regulator of cell growth and proliferation. Loss of function leads to unregulated cell growth and hamartoma formation.
  • Clinical Features (Mnemonic HAMARTOMAS):
    - Hamartomas in CNS and skin
    - Angiofibromas (facial)
    - Mitral regurgitation
    - Ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented macules)
    - Cardiac Rhabdomyoma (most common cardiac tumor in children)
    - Tuberous Sclerosis
    - Autosomal dOminant
    - Mental retardation (intellectual disability)
    - Renal Angiomyolipoma
    - Seizures (infantile spasms are common), Shagreen patches.
  • Neurological Manifestations: Cortical tubers and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs) are common brain hamartomas, leading to seizures and intellectual disability.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of skin findings (ash-leaf spots, angiofibromas) and neurological symptoms (seizures, developmental delay) in a child is classic for TSC. Cardiac rhabdomyoma in an infant is also highly suggestive.
content.takeAway: Tuberous Sclerosis is a genetic disorder of cellular growth control, caused by mutations in mTOR pathway inhibitors, which manifests as a widespread development of benign hamartomas, classically presenting with the triad of skin lesions, seizures, and intellectual disability.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[TSC1/TSC2 Mutation] --> B(Loss of Hamartin/Tuberin); B --x C(Inhibition of mTOR); C --> D(Unregulated Cell Growth); D --> E(Hamartoma Formation in Multiple Organs);

content.definition: Uncal transtentorial herniation is a subtype of downward brain herniation where the uncus, the innermost part of the temporal lobe, is forced medially and downward through the tentorial notch, compressing the adjacent midbrain.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by an expanding mass lesion in the middle cranial fossa, such as an [[a61683ae|epidural hematoma]], subdural hematoma, or temporal lobe tumor.
  • Early Signs (Ipsilateral CN III Compression): The herniating uncus first compresses the ipsilateral [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]]. This affects the superficial parasympathetic fibers, causing a fixed, dilated pupil ("blown pupil"). This is followed by paralysis of the extraocular muscles innervated by CN III, leading to a 'down and out' gaze.
  • Later Signs (Brainstem Compression):
    - Contralateral Cerebral Peduncle Compression: Leads to ipsilateral hemiparesis (a false localizing sign known as Kernohan's notch phenomenon).
    - Brainstem Compression: Can lead to altered consciousness, coma, and Duret hemorrhages.
  • PCA Compression: The ipsilateral posterior cerebral artery can also be compressed, leading to a contralateral homonymous hemianopia.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a head injury who develops a unilateral 'blown pupil' is the classic presentation of uncal herniation. This is a neurosurgical emergency.
content.takeAway: Uncal herniation is a life-threatening event where the temporal lobe is squeezed against the brainstem, classically heralded by a 'blown pupil' from oculomotor nerve compression, which can rapidly progress to coma and death if the underlying pressure is not relieved.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Expanding Temporal Lobe Mass] --> B(Uncus Herniates Medially); B --Compresses--> C(Ipsilateral CN III); C --> D(Ipsilateral Blown Pupil); B --Compresses--> E(Ipsilateral Cerebral Peduncle); E --> F(Contralateral Hemiparesis); B --Compresses--> G(Contralateral Cerebral Peduncle - Kernohan's Notch); G --> H(Ipsilateral Hemiparesis);

content.definition: The upper extremities receive their motor and sensory innervation primarily from the brachial plexus, which is formed by the ventral rami of the spinal nerves C5, C6, C7, C8, and T1.
content.atAGlance:
• Brachial Plexus: A complex network of nerves that gives rise to the major peripheral nerves of the upper limb (musculocutaneous, axillary, radial, median, and ulnar nerves).
  • Motor Homunculus: The motor and sensory control of the upper limb is represented on the lateral aspect of the precentral and postcentral gyri, respectively.
  • Vascular Supply (Cortex): The cortical areas for the arm and hand are supplied by the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Spinal Cord Tracts: Motor commands descend via the corticospinal tracts. Sensation ascends via the dorsal columns (proprioception/vibration) and spinothalamic tracts (pain/temperature).
  • Syringomyelia: A syrinx (fluid-filled cavity) in the cervical spinal cord classically damages the decussating spinothalamic fibers at the anterior white commissure, leading to a 'cape-like' bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the motor and sensory deficits associated with lesions of the brachial plexus and its terminal branches.
content.takeAway: The neurological control of the upper extremities is a complex system involving the brachial plexus for peripheral innervation and specific, well-defined areas of the cerebral cortex and spinal cord, making the pattern of deficits a reliable guide for lesion localization.

content.definition: An upper motor neuron (UMN) is a neuron whose cell body is located in the motor cortex of the brain and whose axon descends to synapse on a lower motor neuron (or an interneuron) in the brainstem or spinal cord. UMNs constitute the descending motor pathways, such as the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: UMNs initiate, control, and modulate voluntary movement. They provide both excitatory and inhibitory input to LMNs.
  • UMN Lesion: Damage to UMNs or their descending tracts.
  • UMN Lesion Signs: Result from a loss of descending inhibition on the spinal reflex arcs. Signs include:
    - Spastic Paralysis/Paresis: Increased muscle tone.
    - Hyperreflexia: Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes.
    - [[ca51f29a|Clasp-knife spasticity]].
    - Positive [[8947da55|Babinski sign]]: Upgoing toe.
    - Mild (Disuse) Atrophy: No significant muscle wasting.
  • Causes of UMN Lesions: [[c5da3c57|Stroke]], [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], traumatic brain or spinal cord injury, [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]], and [[4ed629f9|amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)]].
  • Facial Paralysis: A UMN lesion (e.g., stroke) causes contralateral lower facial weakness, sparing the forehead, due to bilateral UMN innervation of the upper face.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that UMN signs are 'hyper' (hyperreflexia, hypertonia) and the Babinski sign is 'up'. This contrasts with LMN signs, which are 'hypo' (hyporeflexia, hypotonia, atrophy).
content.takeAway: An upper motor neuron is the 'commander' of voluntary movement, originating in the brain; a lesion to it cuts off the regulatory descending control, leading to a 'released' and hyperactive state in the spinal reflexes, manifesting as spasticity and hyperreflexia.

content.definition: Uveitis is inflammation of the uvea, the middle, pigmented, vascular layer of the eye, which is composed of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.
content.atAGlance:
• Classification by Location:
    - Anterior Uveitis (Iritis/Iridocyclitis): Most common type. Inflammation of the iris and ciliary body. Presents with eye pain, redness (ciliary flush), photophobia, and blurred vision. Inflammatory cells may be seen in the anterior chamber (hypopyon).
    - Intermediate Uveitis: Inflammation of the vitreous.
    - Posterior Uveitis (Choroiditis/Retinitis): Inflammation of the choroid and/or retina. Often presents with floaters and painless vision loss.
  • Systemic Associations: Uveitis is strongly associated with systemic inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. Anterior uveitis is classically associated with HLA-B27-associated spondyloarthropathies (e.g., ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis). Other causes include sarcoidosis, inflammatory bowel disease, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
  • Infectious Causes: Can be caused by infections such as syphilis, tuberculosis, toxoplasmosis, and herpesviruses.
  • Complications: Can lead to [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]], [[85f03b02|cataracts]], and macular edema.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with low back pain and stiffness (ankylosing spondylitis) who develops a painful red eye has anterior uveitis.
content.takeAway: Uveitis is an intraocular inflammation that often serves as an ocular 'window' to systemic disease, with anterior uveitis being a classic manifestation of HLA-B27-associated spondyloarthropathies.

content.definition: The vagal nuclei are three main nuclei in the medulla oblongata that are associated with the [[vagus_nerve|vagus nerve (CN X)]], controlling its diverse motor, sensory, and parasympathetic functions.
content.atAGlance:
• [[2f9dde44|Dorsal Motor Nucleus]]: The primary source of parasympathetic preganglionic fibers of the vagus nerve. It innervates the viscera of the thorax and abdomen (heart, lungs, GI tract up to the splenic flexure).
  • Nucleus Ambiguus: A motor nucleus that provides branchial motor fibers to the muscles of the pharynx and larynx (via CN IX and X). It is essential for swallowing and phonation.
  • Nucleus Solitarius (Solitary Tract Nucleus): A sensory nucleus. It receives general visceral sensory information from the GI tract, baroreceptors, and chemoreceptors (via CN IX and X), as well as special sensory (taste) information from the epiglottis (via CN X).
  • Clinical Relevance: Lesions in the lateral medulla (e.g., [[1d7d392c|Wallenberg syndrome]]) can damage these nuclei, leading to dysphagia, hoarseness (nucleus ambiguus), and autonomic dysfunction.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the three functions and their corresponding nuclei: Parasympathetic (Dorsal Motor), Motor to pharynx/larynx (Ambiguus), and Sensory/Taste (Solitarius).
content.takeAway: The diverse functions of the vagus nerve are neatly segregated among its three medullary nuclei: the dorsal motor nucleus for parasympathetic outflow, the nucleus ambiguus for motor control of swallowing and speech, and the nucleus solitarius for visceral and taste sensation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Vagus Nerve - CN X]; A --> B(Dorsal Motor Nucleus - Parasympathetic); A --> C(Nucleus Ambiguus - Motor); A --> D(Nucleus Solitarius - Sensory);

content.definition: The Vagus Nerve (CN X) is a mixed cranial nerve with extensive motor, sensory, and parasympathetic functions. It is the longest cranial nerve, 'wandering' (Latin: vagus) from the brainstem to the abdomen.
content.atAGlance:
• Function Type: Both motor and sensory.
  • Motor Function: Innervates most muscles of the pharynx and larynx, responsible for swallowing and phonation (speech). A lesion causes a hoarse voice and dysphagia.
  • Parasympathetic Function: Provides preganglionic parasympathetic innervation to nearly all thoracic and abdominal viscera up to the splenic flexure, slowing the heart rate, causing bronchoconstriction, and increasing GI motility and secretion.
  • General Sensory Function: Sensation from the pharynx, larynx, and a small area around the external auditory meatus.
  • Visceral Sensory Function: Transmits sensory information (e.g., stretch, chemoreception) from the aortic arch baroreceptors and chemoreceptors, and from the thoracic and abdominal viscera.
  • Lesion Signs: A unilateral lesion causes uvula deviation away from the side of the lesion, a hoarse voice, dysphagia, and loss of the efferent limb of the [[5b6bd754|gag reflex]].
  • USMLE Tip: The vagus nerve is the workhorse of the parasympathetic nervous system. Remember its key motor functions in the pharynx/larynx and its role in the gag reflex (efferent limb).
content.takeAway: The Vagus Nerve is the primary conduit of the parasympathetic nervous system to the trunk, regulating vital organ functions, while also providing the motor control for speech and swallowing; its unilateral paralysis is clinically evident by the uvula pointing away from the weak side.

content.definition: Valproate (valproic acid) is a broad-spectrum anticonvulsant medication that is also used as a mood stabilizer and for migraine prophylaxis. It has multiple mechanisms of action.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action:
    1. Increases CNS levels of [[5aa5cb91|GABA]] by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
    2. Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels.
    3. Blocks T-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Seizures: A first-line agent for generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Also effective for [[a0c128f4|absence]] and myoclonic seizures.
    - Bipolar Disorder: Used as a mood stabilizer.
    - [[c8833bae|Migraine]] Prophylaxis.
  • Adverse Effects: GI distress, weight gain, tremor, and hair loss. The most serious side effects are hepatotoxicity (can be fatal, requires LFT monitoring) and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: It is a potent teratogen, highly associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida). It is contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • USMLE Tip: Valproate is a great broad-spectrum AED, but its use is limited by its significant side effect profile, especially hepatotoxicity and teratogenicity.
content.takeAway: Valproate is a powerful, multi-mechanism anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer, but its clinical utility is significantly constrained by its black box warnings for hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, and its high risk of causing neural tube defects in pregnancy.

content.definition: Vascular dementia is the second most common cause of dementia, resulting from cognitive decline due to cerebrovascular disease, typically involving multiple ischemic strokes or chronic ischemia.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by brain damage from cerebrovascular disease. This can be from multiple large-vessel strokes, a single strategic infarct in a critical area (e.g., thalamus), or, most commonly, multiple small, subcortical lacunar infarcts (multi-infarct dementia).
  • Risk Factors: The risk factors are the same as for stroke: hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.
  • Clinical Presentation: The hallmark is a stepwise decline in cognitive function, where the patient's condition deteriorates abruptly with each new ischemic event, followed by periods of stability.
  • Associated Signs: Unlike Alzheimer's, vascular dementia is often accompanied by focal neurological deficits corresponding to the locations of the infarcts (e.g., hemiparesis, visual field defects, dysarthria).
  • Imaging: MRI or CT of the brain shows evidence of multiple cortical and/or subcortical infarcts.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a history of hypertension and multiple strokes who presents with a stepwise decline in cognition and focal neurological signs has vascular dementia.
content.takeAway: Vascular dementia is a cognitive decline driven by cerebrovascular 'hits' to the brain, characterized by a stepwise deterioration that mirrors the occurrence of new ischemic events and is often accompanied by focal neurological signs.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypertension & other vascular risk factors] --> B(Cerebrovascular Disease); B --> C(Multiple Infarcts); C --> D(Stepwise Cognitive Decline); D --> E(Vascular Dementia);

content.definition: Central nervous system (CNS) vasculitis is inflammation of the blood vessel walls within the brain, spinal cord, and meninges. It can be a primary disorder confined to the CNS or a secondary manifestation of a systemic vasculitis.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary CNS Vasculitis: A rare disorder where vasculitis is restricted to the CNS without evidence of systemic involvement.
  • Secondary CNS Vasculitis: CNS involvement can occur in systemic vasculitides, such as polyarteritis nodosa, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
  • Pathophysiology: Inflammation of the vessel walls can lead to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysm formation, resulting in ischemic or hemorrhagic events.
  • Clinical Presentation: Highly variable. Can present with diffuse encephalopathy, headaches, seizures, or multifocal [[c5da3c57|ischemic strokes]] or [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhages]] occurring over time in different vascular territories.
  • Diagnosis: Can be challenging. Angiography may show characteristic 'beading' (alternating areas of stenosis and dilation). Brain biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • USMLE Tip: Consider CNS vasculitis in a patient, especially a younger one, who presents with multiple strokes in different vascular territories that are not explained by a cardioembolic source.
content.takeAway: CNS vasculitis is an inflammatory attack on the brain's blood vessels that can cause a wide array of neurological symptoms by producing multiple, scattered ischemic and hemorrhagic lesions over time.

content.definition: Vasogenic edema is the most common type of [[aa00bdef|cerebral edema]], characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the extracellular space of the brain. It is caused by a breakdown of the tight endothelial junctions that form the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Disruption of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]] allows plasma proteins and fluid to leak from the intravascular space into the interstitial space of the brain, particularly affecting the white matter.
  • Causes: Commonly seen in conditions that disrupt the BBB, such as brain tumors, abscesses, inflammation, trauma, and the later stages of [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]].
  • Imaging: On imaging (CT/MRI), vasogenic edema appears as white matter hypodensity (CT) or hyperintensity (T2/FLAIR MRI) that often follows the finger-like projections of the white matter tracts.
  • Contrast with Cytotoxic Edema: [[8e51aa24|Cytotoxic edema]] is intracellular swelling due to cellular energy failure and occurs early in ischemia. Vasogenic edema is extracellular and occurs later.
  • USMLE Tip: The ring-enhancing lesion of a [[b6bbd0bc|glioblastoma]] or abscess is often surrounded by extensive vasogenic edema, which contributes significantly to the mass effect.
content.takeAway: Vasogenic edema is the result of a 'leaky' blood-brain barrier, causing fluid to pour into the brain's extracellular space, a common and significant contributor to mass effect in brain tumors and late-stage strokes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Tumor/Inflammation/Late Stroke] --> B(Disruption of Blood-Brain Barrier); B --> C(Leakage of Plasma Fluid & Proteins); C --> D(Accumulation in Extracellular Space); D --> E(Vasogenic Edema);

content.definition: Vecuronium is an intermediate-acting, non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent of the aminosteroid class. It is used to provide skeletal muscle relaxation during surgery and mechanical ventilation.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] from binding and causing muscle contraction.
  • Class: Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, similar to rocuronium and pancuronium.
  • Metabolism: Primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted in bile and urine. Its duration of action can be prolonged in patients with hepatic or renal failure.
  • Adverse Effects: Unlike some other neuromuscular blockers (e.g., atracurium), it does not cause histamine release and is hemodynamically stable.
  • Reversal: The neuromuscular blockade can be reversed by [[0835ea01|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., neostigmine) combined with an antimuscarinic (e.g., glycopyrolate), or by sugammadex.
  • USMLE Tip: Vecuronium and rocuronium are workhorse non-depolarizing blockers in anesthesia. Remember that their effects are reversed by increasing the amount of acetylcholine at the synapse with an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
content.takeAway: Vecuronium is a standard non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that provides predictable paralysis for surgery by competitively blocking acetylcholine receptors, with the advantage of being hemodynamically stable.

content.definition: A persistent vegetative state (PVS) is a disorder of consciousness in which a patient with severe brain damage is in a state of partial arousal rather than true awareness. It is characterized by the return of sleep-wake cycles and autonomic functions, but a complete lack of cognitive function or awareness of the environment.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Results from severe, diffuse damage to the cerebral hemispheres (cortex and white matter), with relative preservation of the brainstem and diencephalon.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients appear to be awake (eyes are open and may track objects) but are not aware. They have intact sleep-wake cycles and can breathe spontaneously. They may have primitive reflexes (e.g., startle, grasp) but show no purposeful, voluntary behaviors or evidence of language comprehension.
  • Differentiation from Coma: In a [[d36eed18|coma]], the patient is unarousable and their eyes are closed. In PVS, the patient is arousable (has sleep-wake cycles) and their eyes are open.
  • Differentiation from Locked-in Syndrome: In locked-in syndrome, the patient is fully conscious and aware but is quadriplegic and cannot speak.
  • Prognosis: If the state persists for more than a few months, the chance of significant recovery is very low. The term 'persistent' is used after 1 month, and 'permanent' after 3 months (anoxic injury) or 12 months (traumatic injury).
  • USMLE Tip: The key to identifying PVS is the dissociation between arousal (awake, open eyes) and awareness (no cognitive function).
content.takeAway: A persistent vegetative state is a devastating outcome of severe brain injury where the 'wakefulness' centers of the brainstem are preserved, but the 'awareness' centers of the cortex are lost, leaving a patient who is 'awake but not aware'.

content.definition: Dural venous sinus thrombosis (DVST), or cerebral venous thrombosis, is the formation of a blood clot in the [[21f1c955|dural venous sinuses]], which are the primary drainage channels for the brain. This obstruction of venous outflow can lead to increased intracranial pressure and venous infarction.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Thrombosis of a sinus impedes venous drainage, leading to venous congestion and increased intracranial pressure. It can also cause back-pressure in cortical veins, leading to hemorrhagic venous infarcts.
  • Risk Factors: Associated with hypercoagulable states. These include inherited thrombophilias (e.g., [[514c69e0|Factor V Leiden]]), oral contraceptive use, pregnancy and the postpartum period, malignancy, and certain infections (e.g., mastoiditis, sinusitis).
  • Clinical Presentation: Highly variable. The most common symptom is a severe headache that can be acute or subacute. Other signs include seizures, focal neurological deficits (that may not conform to a single arterial territory), and signs of increased ICP (papilledema).
  • Diagnosis: The imaging modality of choice is an MRI with magnetic resonance venography (MRV), which can directly visualize the lack of flow or the thrombus within the sinus (e.g., the 'empty delta sign' in the superior sagittal sinus).
  • Treatment: The primary treatment is anticoagulation (e.g., with heparin), even in the presence of hemorrhagic infarction, to prevent thrombus propagation and promote recanalization.
  • USMLE Tip: Suspect DVST in a young patient, especially a woman who is pregnant, postpartum, or on OCPs, who presents with a severe headache and/or stroke-like symptoms.
content.takeAway: Dural venous sinus thrombosis is a 'stroke on the venous side,' where a clot in the brain's drainage system causes a pressure backup, leading to headaches, seizures, and potentially hemorrhagic infarcts, often in the setting of a hypercoagulable state.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypercoagulable State] --> B(Thrombus in Dural Sinus); B --> C(Obstruction of Venous Outflow); C --> D(↑ Intracranial Pressure); C --> E(Venous Infarction);

content.definition: A tonic-clonic seizure, formerly known as a grand mal seizure, is a type of [[2e7554b7|generalized seizure]] that involves a loss of consciousness and violent muscle contractions. It is the most dramatic and widely recognized type of seizure.
content.atAGlance:
• Phases: Characterized by two distinct phases:
    1. Tonic Phase: A sudden stiffening of the body, arms, and legs, causing the person to fall. The patient may cry out as air is forced out of the lungs. Lasts 10-20 seconds.
    2. Clonic Phase: Rhythmic, convulsive jerking of the limbs. The patient may bite their tongue or have urinary/fecal incontinence.
  • Postictal State: Following the seizure, there is a period of confusion, drowsiness, headache, and muscle soreness that can last for hours.
  • Etiology: Can be primary (idiopathic generalized epilepsy) or secondary to a focal seizure that spreads to both hemispheres (focal to bilateral tonic-clonic).
  • Treatment: Acute management involves ensuring patient safety. Long-term prevention requires [[4dff096f|broad-spectrum anticonvulsants]] like [[valproic_acid|valproic acid]] or [[2341f9c0|levetiracetam]].
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of a postictal state is a key feature that helps distinguish a tonic-clonic seizure from syncope.
content.takeAway: A tonic-clonic seizure is a global cerebral electrical storm that manifests as a dramatic sequence of body stiffening (tonic phase) followed by rhythmic convulsions (clonic phase), culminating in a prolonged postictal state of confusion and exhaustion.

content.definition: Topiramate is a broad-spectrum anticonvulsant medication with multiple mechanisms of action. It is used to treat various types of seizures and for the prophylaxis of migraine headaches.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Has several effects:
    1. Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels.
    2. Potentiates the inhibitory effect of GABA at GABAA receptors.
    3. Antagonizes glutamate receptors (AMPA/kainate).
    4. Weakly inhibits carbonic anhydrase.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Seizures: Used for [[953ad620|focal seizures]] and primary [[2e7554b7|generalized tonic-clonic seizures]].
    - [[c8833bae|Migraine]] Prophylaxis: A first-line agent for preventing migraine headaches.
  • Adverse Effects: The most common side effects are somnolence, dizziness, and cognitive slowing ('mental dulling' or 'word-finding difficulty'). It can also cause weight loss and paresthesias.
  • Serious Adverse Effects: Due to its carbonic anhydrase inhibition, it can cause metabolic acidosis and increases the risk of calcium phosphate kidney stones. It can also precipitate acute [[9c80344d|angle-closure glaucoma]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the unique side effect profile of topiramate: weight loss, cognitive slowing ('dope-a-max'), and kidney stones.
content.takeAway: Topiramate is a multi-target anticonvulsant that is also effective for migraine prevention, but its utility is often limited by cognitive side effects and the risk of metabolic acidosis and kidney stones stemming from its carbonic anhydrase activity.

content.definition: Touch sensation (tactition) is the perception of pressure or distortion of the skin. It is mediated by various mechanoreceptors and transmitted to the brain via two distinct ascending pathways.
content.atAGlance:
• Fine/Light Touch: The ability to discriminate fine details of texture and shape (stereognosis).
    - Receptors: Meissner's corpuscles (light touch, rapidly adapting), Merkel's discs (pressure, slowly adapting).
    - Pathway: Transmitted via the [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway]].
  • Crude/Deep Static Touch: A non-discriminative sense of being touched or pressure.
    - Receptors: Pacinian corpuscles (deep pressure/vibration), Ruffini corpuscles (stretch).
    - Pathway: Transmitted via the [[07eecef1|spinothalamic tract]] (anterior portion).
  • Clinical Significance: The dissociation of these pathways is clinically important. A lesion of the dorsal columns will impair fine touch and proprioception while leaving crude touch intact.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the two pathways for touch: Fine touch travels with proprioception and vibration in the dorsal columns. Crude touch travels with pain and temperature in the spinothalamic tract.
content.takeAway: The sensation of touch is not monolithic; it is divided into a high-fidelity 'fine touch' system that travels via the dorsal columns and a low-resolution 'crude touch' system that travels via the spinothalamic tract, a separation that allows for precise lesion localization.

content.definition: The TP53 gene is a critical tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 17. It encodes the protein p53, often called the "guardian of the genome," which plays a central role in regulating the cell cycle, initiating apoptosis, and preventing tumor formation.
content.atAGlance:
• Function of p53: In response to DNA damage, p53 is activated and can:
    1. Halt the cell cycle at the G1/S checkpoint to allow for DNA repair.
    2. Induce [[1a804e11|apoptosis]] if the DNA damage is irreparable.
  • Mechanism: p53 acts as a transcription factor, upregulating the expression of genes like CDKN1A (which encodes p21, a cell cycle inhibitor) and pro-apoptotic genes like BAX.
  • Li-Fraumeni Syndrome: A rare, autosomal dominant hereditary cancer syndrome caused by a germline mutation in one allele of the TP53 gene. It confers a very high lifetime risk of developing a wide range of malignancies, often at a young age (e.g., sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, adrenocortical carcinomas).
  • Somatic Mutations: Somatic mutations in TP53 are the most common genetic alterations found in human cancers, occurring in over 50% of all tumors.
  • tPA (Tissue Plasminogen Activator): A thrombolytic drug used for [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] treatment. It is not related to the TP53 gene. The index entry is likely a processing error.
  • USMLE Tip: Loss of p53 function is a key step in the development of most cancers. Remember its role as the 'guardian of the genome' that either pauses the cell cycle for repair or triggers cell suicide.
content.takeAway: The TP53 gene is the master regulator of cell cycle control and apoptosis; its inactivation removes the primary safeguard against genomic instability, paving the way for malignant transformation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[DNA Damage] --> B(↑ p53); B --> C(Cell Cycle Arrest - G1/S); B --> D(Apoptosis); E[TP53 Mutation] --x B; E --> F(Uncontrolled Cell Proliferation); F --> G(Cancer);

content.definition: Tramadol is a centrally acting synthetic analgesic with a dual mechanism of action. It is used for the management of moderate to moderately severe pain.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action:
    1. A very weak agonist at μ-opioid receptors.
    2. Inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, which modulates pain pathways in the spinal cord.
  • Clinical Use: Used for moderate pain when non-opioid analgesics are insufficient.
  • Adverse Effects: Similar to opioids, it can cause sedation, dizziness, nausea, and constipation. A major risk is that it lowers the seizure threshold and is contraindicated in patients with epilepsy or other seizure risk factors.
  • Serotonin Syndrome: Due to its effect on serotonin reuptake, it can cause serotonin syndrome when co-administered with other serotonergic drugs (e.g., SSRIs, MAOIs).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the dual mechanism of tramadol. Its opioid effect is weak, but its inhibition of serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake contributes significantly to its analgesia and also to its unique side effect profile (seizures, serotonin syndrome).
content.takeAway: Tramadol is a unique analgesic that combines weak opioid activity with the properties of an SNRI antidepressant, but this dual action carries the distinct risks of lowering the seizure threshold and precipitating serotonin syndrome.

content.definition: A Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) is a transient episode of neurological dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia, without acute infarction. It is often referred to as a "mini-stroke."
content.atAGlance:
• Definition: Traditionally defined as symptoms resolving within 24 hours. The modern, tissue-based definition is a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction without evidence of acute infarction on brain imaging (e.g., diffusion-weighted MRI).
  • Etiology: The causes are the same as for [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]]: thrombosis, embolism (cardiac or artery-to-artery), or stenosis.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden onset of focal neurological deficits that are temporary. A classic example is [[f0aac1c3|amaurosis fugax]] (transient monocular blindness).
  • Clinical Significance: A TIA is a major warning sign of an impending [[c5da3c57|stroke]]. The risk of stroke is highest in the first few days after a TIA.
  • Management: Patients with a TIA require urgent evaluation to determine the cause and initiate secondary prevention strategies. This includes brain imaging, carotid imaging, and cardiac evaluation. Treatment involves antiplatelet therapy (e.g., [[09db7b12|aspirin]], [[22372d48|clopidogrel]]), statins, and management of vascular risk factors.
  • USMLE Tip: Treat a TIA with the same urgency as a stroke. The goal is to prevent a future, permanent stroke.
content.takeAway: A Transient Ischemic Attack is a 'warning stroke' where neurological symptoms are temporary because blood flow is quickly restored, but it signals a high, imminent risk of a permanent stroke and necessitates immediate medical evaluation and preventive therapy.

content.definition: A tremor is an involuntary, rhythmic, oscillatory movement of a body part. It is classified based on its characteristics, particularly whether it occurs at rest or during action.
content.atAGlance:
• Resting Tremor: Occurs when the muscle is relaxed and supported against gravity. It is suppressed by voluntary movement. The classic example is the "pill-rolling" tremor of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], caused by a lesion in the substantia nigra.
  • Postural Tremor: Occurs when holding a position against gravity (e.g., holding arms outstretched). The most common type is [[40039e56|essential tremor]].
  • Intention (Action) Tremor: Occurs during a purposeful, goal-directed movement and worsens as the target is approached. It is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., lesion of the cerebellar hemisphere or [[c819d97b|dentate nucleus]]).
  • Asterixis: Not a true tremor, but a negative myoclonus ('flapping tremor') seen in metabolic encephalopathies.
  • USMLE Tip: The timing of the tremor is the key to the diagnosis: At rest? Think Parkinson's. With action/posture? Think essential tremor. As you approach a target? Think cerebellum.
content.takeAway: The clinical classification of tremor—whether it manifests at rest, with posture, or with intention—is a powerful diagnostic tool that points to distinct underlying pathologies in the basal ganglia, cerebellum, or other motor systems.

content.definition: Triazolam is a very short-acting benzodiazepine used for the short-term treatment of insomnia, particularly sleep-onset insomnia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A positive allosteric modulator of the GABAA receptor, increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening.
  • Pharmacokinetics: It has a very rapid onset and a very short half-life (2-3 hours). Mnemonic for short-acting benzodiazepines: ATOM (Alprazolam, Triazolam, Oxazepam, Midazolam).
  • Clinical Use: Primarily for sleep-onset insomnia. Its short duration minimizes next-day 'hangover' effects.
  • Adverse Effects: Higher risk of anterograde amnesia and rebound insomnia upon discontinuation compared to longer-acting agents. High abuse potential due to its rapid onset and short duration.
  • USMLE Tip: Triazolam is a good choice for a patient who has trouble falling asleep but not staying asleep. Its short half-life is its defining feature.
content.takeAway: Triazolam is a fast-on, fast-off benzodiazepine hypnotic, ideal for initiating sleep but with a higher risk of rebound insomnia and dependence due to its short duration of action.

content.definition: The Triceps reflex is a deep tendon reflex that causes extension of the elbow when the triceps brachii tendon is tapped. It is used to test the integrity of the C7 and C8 spinal nerve roots and the radial nerve.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: Primarily tests the C7 nerve root, with a contribution from C6 and C8. Mnemonic: C6, 7, 8, lay them straight.
  • Pathway: Tapping the triceps tendon stretches the muscle. The afferent signal travels via the radial nerve to the C7/C8 spinal cord segments, synapses, and an efferent signal returns via the radial nerve to cause contraction of the triceps muscle and elbow extension.
  • Diminished/Absent Reflex: Suggests a lower motor neuron lesion, such as a herniated disc compressing the C7 root or a peripheral neuropathy affecting the radial nerve.
  • Exaggerated Reflex (Hyperreflexia): Suggests an upper motor neuron lesion, such as a stroke or spinal cord injury above the C7 level.
  • USMLE Tip: The triceps reflex, along with sensation over the middle finger and strength of wrist flexion/finger extension, is a key part of the C7 neurological exam.
content.takeAway: The Triceps reflex is a standard part of the neurological exam that specifically assesses the C7 nerve root, providing a quick check on the integrity of the lower cervical spinal cord and the radial nerve.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Tap Triceps Tendon] --> B(Stretch Triceps Muscle); B --> C(Afferent Signal via Radial N.); C --> D[C7/C8 Spinal Cord]; D --> E(Efferent Signal via Radial N.); E --> F(Triceps Contraction/Elbow Extension);

content.definition: Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are a class of medications primarily used to treat depression, though their use has declined due to a significant side effect profile and the availability of safer alternatives. They are also used for neuropathic pain, migraine prophylaxis, and OCD.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Block the reuptake of norepinephrine (NE) and serotonin (5-HT).
  • Adverse Effects: Their side effects are due to blockade of multiple other receptors:
    - Anticholinergic (muscarinic): Dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, blurred vision, confusion.
    - Antihistaminic (H1): Sedation, weight gain.
    - Anti-adrenergic (α1): Orthostatic hypotension.
  • Overdose (Tri-C's): TCA overdose is life-threatening. Remember the Tri-C's: Convulsions, Coma, Cardiotoxicity. Cardiotoxicity (QRS widening, ventricular arrhythmias) is due to Na+ channel blockade and is the most common cause of death. Treat with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Neurologic Use: Tertiary amines like [[c6814506|amitriptyline]] are used for chronic neuropathic pain and migraine prophylaxis. Clomipramine is used for OCD. Some TCAs are used to treat pain in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]].
  • USMLE Tip: The wide range of receptor blockade explains the extensive side effect profile of TCAs. Cardiotoxicity in overdose is a critical, high-yield concept.
content.takeAway: Tricyclic antidepressants are 'dirty' drugs that, in addition to their therapeutic effect of blocking serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake, also block muscarinic, histaminic, and adrenergic receptors, leading to a broad and problematic side effect profile, especially life-threatening cardiotoxicity in overdose.

content.definition: The Trigeminal Nerve (CN V) is the largest cranial nerve and is a mixed nerve, containing both sensory and motor fibers. It is the principal sensory nerve for the face and provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.
content.atAGlance:
• Function Type: Both sensory and motor.
  • Three Divisions:
    1. Ophthalmic (V1): Sensory. Supplies the forehead, scalp, cornea, and upper eyelid.
    2. Maxillary (V2): Sensory. Supplies the midface, lower eyelid, upper lip, and upper teeth.
    3. Mandibular (V3): Both sensory and motor. Provides sensation to the lower face, lower lip, lower teeth, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (general sensation, not taste). Provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, pterygoids).
  • Reflexes: The afferent limb of the [[64663383|corneal reflex]] is carried by V1. The afferent and efferent limbs of the jaw jerk reflex are carried by V3.
  • Lesions: A lesion of CN V can cause facial numbness, weakness in chewing, and deviation of the jaw toward the side of the lesion upon opening.
  • Trigeminal Neuralgia: A condition characterized by recurrent, severe, lancinating pain in the distribution of one or more branches of CN V. Treated with [[eddd2bc5|carbamazepine]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember V3 is the only division with motor fibers ('M' for Mandibular and Motor).
content.takeAway: The Trigeminal Nerve is the great sensory nerve of the face, with its three divisions mapping out distinct facial territories, and it also provides the crucial motor power for chewing via its mandibular branch.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Trigeminal Nerve - CN V]; A --> B(V1 - Ophthalmic - Sensory); A --> C(V2 - Maxillary - Sensory); A --> D(V3 - Mandibular - Sensory & Motor); D --> E(Muscles of Mastication);

content.definition: Trihexyphenidyl is a centrally acting antimuscarinic (anticholinergic) drug used to treat the symptoms of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at central muscarinic receptors, helping to restore the dopaminergic-cholinergic balance in the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] that is disrupted in Parkinson's disease.
  • Clinical Use (Parkinson's): Primarily effective for treating tremor and rigidity. It has little effect on bradykinesia. Often used in younger patients where tremor is the predominant symptom. Mnemonic: 'Tri to Park my Mercedes-Benz' (Trihexyphenidyl and [[383f6fbe|Benztropine]] for Parkinson's).
  • Clinical Use (EPS): Can be used to treat drug-induced parkinsonism and dystonia.
  • Adverse Effects: Classic anticholinergic side effects: dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, urinary retention, tachycardia, and confusion/delirium, especially in the elderly.
  • USMLE Tip: Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are the two main anticholinergics used for Parkinson's. They are most useful for tremor in younger patients.
content.takeAway: Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic agent that helps manage Parkinson's disease by reducing the relative overactivity of acetylcholine in the dopamine-depleted basal ganglia, thereby improving tremor and rigidity.

content.definition: Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan) are a class of drugs that are serotonin 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists. They are a first-line therapy for the acute (abortive) treatment of moderate to severe [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action:
    1. Agonism at 5-HT1B receptors on cranial blood vessels causes vasoconstriction.
    2. Agonism at presynaptic 5-HT1D receptors on trigeminal nerve endings inhibits the release of vasoactive neuropeptides like CGRP.
  • Clinical Use: Acute treatment of [[c8833bae|migraines]] and [[21760f80|cluster headaches]]. They are not used for prophylaxis.
  • Adverse Effects: Tingling, paresthesias, dizziness, and a sensation of chest tightness or pressure ('triptan sensations').
  • Contraindications: Due to their vasoconstrictive effects, they are contraindicated in patients with a history of coronary artery disease, uncontrolled hypertension, or stroke. They should not be used with ergotamines or within 2 weeks of MAOI use.
  • USMLE Tip: Triptans are the go-to abortive therapy for migraines. Remember their 5-HT1B/1D agonist mechanism and their major contraindication in patients with cardiovascular disease due to the risk of [[dd3c9b1b|coronary vasospasm]].
content.takeAway: Triptans abort migraine attacks through a dual mechanism of constricting painfully dilated cranial vessels and inhibiting the release of inflammatory neuropeptides from the trigeminal nerve, but their vasoconstrictive nature makes them risky in patients with vascular disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Triptan] --> B(5-HT1B/1D Agonist); B --> C(Cranial Vasoconstriction); B --> D(↓ CGRP Release); C & D --> E(Migraine Relief);

content.definition: The Trochlear Nerve (CN IV) is a motor cranial nerve that provides innervation to a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique. It is unique among cranial nerves in that it is the only one to exit from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem and to decussate completely.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Innervates the contralateral superior oblique muscle. The primary actions of this muscle are intorsion (internal rotation) and depression of the eyeball, especially when the eye is adducted.
  • Pathway: Emerges from the dorsal midbrain, decussates, and then travels anteriorly to enter the orbit via the superior orbital fissure.
  • Palsy: A lesion of the CN IV nucleus or nerve causes a [[de532715|trochlear nerve palsy]]. Due to the decussation, a lesion of the nucleus affects the contralateral eye, while a lesion of the nerve after it has decussated affects the ipsilateral eye.
  • Palsy Presentation: The affected eye is hypertropic (elevated) and extorted. Patients present with vertical [[9914d433|diplopia]] that is worse when looking down and in (e.g., reading). They classically compensate by tilting their head away from the side of the palsied eye.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic (SO4LR6)3: Superior Oblique is innervated by CN IV. A patient with a head tilt and difficulty walking down stairs is a classic presentation for a CN IV palsy.
content.takeAway: The Trochlear Nerve is the unique, crossed nerve for the superior oblique muscle; its paralysis leads to a characteristic vertical diplopia and a compensatory head tilt away from the affected eye.

content.definition: Truncal ataxia is a type of [[9767fd6b|ataxia]] characterized by instability of the trunk, leading to a wide-based, unsteady gait and difficulty sitting or standing without support. It is a hallmark of midline cerebellar disease.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Caused by a lesion in the cerebellar vermis or the [[644b8e4d|fastigial nucleus]].
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients have a wide-based, lurching gait often described as a 'drunken sailor' gait. They may sway or fall when sitting or standing still, even with their eyes open.
  • Romberg Test: The Romberg test is typically negative, as the instability is present with both eyes open and closed (distinguishing it from sensory ataxia).
  • Causes:
    - In children, the most common cause is a [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] located in the vermis.
    - In adults, the most common cause is cerebellar degeneration secondary to chronic alcohol use disorder.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate truncal ataxia from limb ataxia. Truncal ataxia (midline lesion) affects gait and posture. Limb ataxia (hemispheric lesion) affects coordinated movements of the extremities, like the finger-to-nose test.
content.takeAway: Truncal ataxia is a profound instability of the body's core, resulting from damage to the cerebellar vermis, which manifests as a characteristic wide-based, staggering gait independent of visual input.

content.definition: The Temporal Lobe is one of the four major lobes of the cerebral cortex, located beneath the lateral fissure on both cerebral hemispheres. It is primarily involved in processing auditory information and is crucial for memory, emotion, and language comprehension.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Auditory Cortex: Located in the superior temporal gyrus, it is responsible for the perception of sound.
  • [[wernicke_area|Wernicke's Area]]: Located in the posterior superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, it is critical for the comprehension of spoken and written language.
  • Medial Temporal Lobe Structures: Contains key components of the limbic system:
    - [[a0590674|Hippocampus]]: Essential for the formation of new long-term memories.
    - [[d220fc3f|Amygdala]]: Central to processing emotions, particularly fear.
  • Visual Pathway: The inferior optic radiation, or [[6dcf9281|Meyer's loop]], passes through the temporal lobe.
  • Lesion Effects:
    - Dominant Lobe: [[2c4a6130|Wernicke's aphasia]].
    - Medial Lobe (bilateral): [[a62c0c9f|Anterograde amnesia]] (hippocampus), [[kluver_bucy_syndrome|Klüver-Bucy syndrome]] (amygdala).
    - Meyer's Loop: Contralateral superior quadrantanopia ('pie in the sky').
    - Temporal Lobe Epilepsy: The most common site for focal seizures, often presenting with auras (e.g., epigastric rising sensation, olfactory hallucinations).
content.takeAway: The Temporal Lobe is a multifaceted brain region that processes what we hear, allows us to understand language, forms new memories, and generates emotional responses, making it a hub for some of the most complex human cognitive functions.

content.definition: Tension-type headaches are the most common type of primary headache, characterized by a mild to moderate, bilateral, non-throbbing headache often described as a tight band around the head.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Bilateral, 'band-like' or pressing/tightening quality. The pain is typically mild to moderate in intensity and is not aggravated by routine physical activity.
  • Associated Symptoms: Unlike migraines, tension headaches are not associated with nausea or vomiting. Patients may have either photophobia (sensitivity to light) or phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), but not both.
  • Duration: Can last from 30 minutes to 7 days.
  • Treatment (Acute): Simple analgesics like NSAIDs or acetaminophen are usually effective.
  • Prophylaxis: For chronic tension-type headaches, [[c6814506|amitriptyline]] (a TCA) and behavioral therapy are common prophylactic strategies.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to differentiating a tension headache from a migraine is the absence of severe, debilitating features. Tension headaches are bilateral, non-pulsating, and lack significant associated symptoms like nausea.
content.takeAway: Tension-type headaches are the common, 'featureless' headache, defined more by what they lack (unilaterality, pulsating quality, nausea, severe disability) than what they have, presenting as a simple, bilateral pressure or tightness.

content.definition: Many anticonvulsant (antiepileptic) drugs are known teratogens, meaning they can cause birth defects if taken during pregnancy. This poses a significant management challenge for women with epilepsy of childbearing age.
content.atAGlance:
• General Risk: All anticonvulsants carry some risk, and the goal is to use the lowest effective dose of a single agent (monotherapy) if possible.
  • [[0d37e045|Valproate]]: Has the highest risk of teratogenicity. It is strongly associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida) due to its interference with folate metabolism. It can also cause other malformations and is associated with lower IQ in offspring.
  • [[eddd2bc5|Carbamazepine]]: Also associated with neural tube defects.
  • [[5aea213f|Phenytoin]]: Can cause Fetal Hydantoin Syndrome, characterized by craniofacial abnormalities (cleft lip/palate), hypoplastic nails and distal phalanges, and growth/intellectual disability.
  • Folate Supplementation: High-dose folic acid supplementation is recommended for all women of childbearing potential who are taking anticonvulsants to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
  • USMLE Tip: Valproate is the most notorious teratogen among the anticonvulsants, with a strong link to neural tube defects.
content.takeAway: The teratogenicity of anticonvulsants is a major clinical concern, with valproate carrying the highest risk, particularly for neural tube defects, necessitating careful counseling and high-dose folate supplementation for women with epilepsy who are planning a pregnancy.

content.definition: Tetracaine is a potent, long-acting, ester-type local anesthetic used for spinal anesthesia and topically for anesthesia of the eye, nose, or throat.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels in nerve membranes, preventing the generation and conduction of nerve impulses.
  • Class: Ester local anesthetic. It is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterases.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a slow onset but a long duration of action.
  • Clinical Use: Commonly used for spinal anesthesia due to its long duration. Also used in topical formulations for ophthalmology and ENT procedures.
  • Adverse Effects: As an ester, it has a higher potential for allergic reactions (due to its metabolite, PABA) compared to amide anesthetics. Systemic toxicity can cause CNS excitation and cardiovascular collapse.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the classification of local anesthetics: Esters (one 'i' in the name, e.g., tetracaine, cocaine) are metabolized in the plasma, while Amides (two 'i's, e.g., lidocaine) are metabolized in the liver.
content.takeAway: Tetracaine is a long-acting ester anesthetic whose prolonged nerve-blocking effect makes it well-suited for spinal anesthesia, but its ester structure carries a risk of allergic reactions.

content.definition: Tetracyclines (e.g., tetracycline, doxycycline, minocycline) are a class of broad-spectrum bacteriostatic antibiotics that inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Bind to the 30S ribosomal subunit and prevent the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A site.
  • Clinical Use: Effective against a wide range of bacteria, including atypical organisms (Mycoplasma, Chlamydia), spirochetes (Borrelia burgdorferi in Lyme disease), and rickettsial species. Also used for acne.
  • Adverse Effects: GI distress, photosensitivity, and discoloration of teeth and inhibition of bone growth in children. They are teratogenic and should be avoided in pregnancy.
  • Neurologic Side Effect: Tetracyclines, particularly minocycline, are a known cause of [[7c4e7c74|idiopathic intracranial hypertension]] (pseudotumor cerebri).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the major side effects: photosensitivity, teeth discoloration in kids, and teratogenicity. The association with pseudotumor cerebri is also a high-yield fact.
content.takeAway: Tetracyclines are broad-spectrum antibiotics that, in addition to their well-known side effects like photosensitivity and teeth staining, can also cause the neurological condition of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

content.definition: The Thalamus is a large, paired gray matter structure in the diencephalon, located superior to the brainstem. It serves as the primary relay and integration center for sensory information (except smell) on its way to the cerebral cortex, and also plays a crucial role in motor control, consciousness, sleep, and alertness.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: The major sensory relay station of the brain. All sensory input (except olfaction) synapses in the thalamus before being projected to the appropriate cortical area.
  • Key Nuclei and Functions:
    - [[2ae957b8|VPL]]: Relays sensation (pain, temp, proprioception, touch) from the body.
    - [[23ac314a|VPM]]: Relays sensation from the face (via trigeminal nerve) and taste.
    - LGN (Lateral Geniculate Nucleus): Relays visual information. Mnemonic: LGN for Light.
    - MGN (Medial Geniculate Nucleus): Relays auditory information. Mnemonic: MGN for Music.
    - VA/VL: Relays motor information from the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] and cerebellum to the motor cortex.
  • Limbic System Connection: The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is part of the Papez circuit, a component of the [[73ace357|limbic system]].
  • Lesions: A thalamic stroke can cause contralateral sensory loss of all modalities. It can also lead to [[714f15fc|central post-stroke pain syndrome]] (thalamic pain syndrome).
content.takeAway: The Thalamus acts as the brain's central switchboard, sorting and directing nearly all incoming sensory and motor signals to their appropriate cortical destinations, making it indispensable for perception, movement, and consciousness.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Sensory Input] --> B(Thalamus); B --> C(Cortex); D[Basal Ganglia/Cerebellum] --> B;

content.definition: A thrombotic stroke is a type of [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] that occurs when a thrombus (blood clot) forms on an atherosclerotic plaque within a cerebral artery, obstructing blood flow.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Atherosclerosis leads to the formation of plaques in cerebral arteries. Rupture of one of these plaques can trigger local thrombus formation, leading to arterial occlusion.
  • Onset: The onset of symptoms is often gradual or stuttering, developing over minutes to hours, as the thrombus grows to completely occlude the vessel. Patients may awaken from sleep with the deficit.
  • Location: Most commonly occurs at arterial branch points, such as the carotid bifurcation or the origin of the [[143bb23d|middle cerebral artery (MCA)]].
  • Risk Factors: The risk factors are those for atherosclerosis: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and smoking.
  • Differentiation from Embolic Stroke: [[6a805ecd|Embolic strokes]] typically have a sudden, maximal-at-onset presentation, whereas thrombotic strokes can have a more gradual onset.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with known risk factors for atherosclerosis who develops neurological deficits that progress over several hours is likely having a thrombotic stroke.
content.takeAway: A thrombotic stroke is a 'stroke from within,' where a clot forms directly on a pre-existing atherosclerotic plaque in a brain artery, gradually choking off blood flow and causing a stuttering or progressive onset of neurological symptoms.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Atherosclerotic Plaque] --Rupture--> B(Thrombus Formation); B --> C(Occlusion of Cerebral Artery); C --> D(Ischemic Stroke);

content.definition: Thrush, or oral candidiasis, is a fungal infection of the mucous membranes of the mouth caused by an overgrowth of Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Characterized by white, cottage cheese-like plaques on the tongue, buccal mucosa, and palate. These plaques can be scraped off, revealing an erythematous, sometimes bleeding, base.
  • Risk Factors: Occurs in states of immunosuppression or disruption of normal oral flora. Common risk factors include infancy, use of inhaled corticosteroids (without rinsing), antibiotic therapy, and immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV/AIDS).
  • Diagnosis: Usually clinical. Can be confirmed by a KOH preparation of a scraping, which will show pseudohyphae and budding yeasts.
  • Treatment: Topical antifungal agents like nystatin 'swish and swallow' or clotrimazole troches. Systemic fluconazole may be used for more severe or refractory cases.
  • 'Thunderclap Headache': This term describes the sudden, severe headache of a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]] and is not related to thrush. The index entry is likely a processing error.
  • USMLE Tip: The ability to scrape off the white plaques is a key feature that distinguishes thrush from oral hairy leukoplakia (seen in HIV, cannot be scraped off).
content.takeAway: Thrush is a superficial Candida infection of the mouth, presenting as white plaques that can be scraped off, and serves as a clinical indicator of either local or systemic immunosuppression.

content.definition: In the central nervous system, tight junctions (zonula occludens) are multiprotein junctional complexes that join the cerebral endothelial cells together, forming a continuous seal that is the primary structural component of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: They severely restrict paracellular (between-cell) diffusion of solutes from the blood into the brain. This forces most substances to pass through the endothelial cells themselves (transcellular route), allowing for highly selective transport.
  • Proteins: Composed of transmembrane proteins like claudins and occludins.
  • Blood-Brain Barrier: The tight junctions of the non-fenestrated CNS capillary endothelium are the most critical element in forming the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
  • Pathology: Disruption of tight junctions leads to a breakdown of the blood-brain barrier and the development of vasogenic edema. This can occur in response to inflammation, tumors, or ischemia.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of extensive tight junctions is the key feature that distinguishes CNS capillaries from the more permeable ('fenestrated' or 'discontinuous') capillaries found in other parts of the body.
content.takeAway: Tight junctions are the molecular 'mortar' that seals the gaps between cerebral endothelial cells, creating the formidable blood-brain barrier and forcing nearly all substances to undergo a highly regulated transcellular journey to enter the brain.

content.definition: Timolol is a non-selective β-adrenergic antagonist (beta-blocker) used topically as eye drops to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) in the treatment of [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks both β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors on the ciliary epithelium. This decreases the production of aqueous humor, thereby lowering IOP.
  • Class: Non-selective beta-blocker.
  • Clinical Use: A first-line agent for [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]].
  • Adverse Effects: Ocular side effects are minimal. Systemic absorption can occur, leading to bradycardia, hypotension, fatigue, and bronchoconstriction (due to β2 blockade).
  • Contraindications: Should be used with caution or avoided in patients with asthma, COPD, bradycardia, or severe heart failure.
  • USMLE Tip: Timolol is a classic first-line glaucoma drug. Its non-selective nature means you must consider the risk of bronchospasm in patients with reactive airway disease. In such patients, a β1-selective agent like [[43508d57|betaxolol]] would be a safer choice.
content.takeAway: Timolol is a highly effective topical beta-blocker for glaucoma that works by reducing aqueous humor production, but its non-selectivity requires caution due to the potential for systemic side effects, particularly bronchoconstriction in susceptible individuals.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Timolol] --> B(Blocks β-Receptors on Ciliary Epithelium); B --> C(↓ Aqueous Humor Production); C --> D(↓ Intraocular Pressure);

content.definition: Tizanidine is a centrally acting α2-adrenergic agonist that is used as a skeletal muscle relaxant (antispasmodic) to treat spasticity.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as an α2-agonist in the spinal cord. This enhances presynaptic inhibition of motor neurons, reducing the release of excitatory amino acids and thereby decreasing muscle spasticity.
  • Clinical Use: Management of spasticity associated with [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], spinal cord injury, and [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]].
  • Adverse Effects: Hypotension, sedation/somnolence, dry mouth, and dizziness. Hepatotoxicity is a rare but serious side effect, requiring monitoring of liver function tests.
  • Comparison to Clonidine: Tizanidine is structurally and mechanistically related to clonidine (an antihypertensive), but it has a greater effect on muscle spasticity with less of an effect on blood pressure.
  • USMLE Tip: Tizanidine is a muscle relaxant that works via the α2-agonist mechanism, similar to clonidine. Remember its use for chronic spasticity and its potential to cause hypotension.
content.takeAway: Tizanidine reduces muscle spasticity by acting as an α2-agonist in the spinal cord, which dampens the excitability of motor neurons, but its shared mechanism with clonidine means it also carries the risk of causing hypotension and sedation.

content.definition: Tobacco smoking is a major modifiable risk factor for a wide range of neurological diseases, primarily through its profound effects on the cardiovascular system and its direct neurotoxic and pro-inflammatory properties.
content.atAGlance:
• Stroke: Smoking is a potent risk factor for both [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] and [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]]. It promotes atherosclerosis, increases blood pressure, and induces a hypercoagulable state.
  • Cerebral Aneurysms: Smoking is a significant risk factor for the formation and rupture of [[a9f6d703|saccular (berry) aneurysms]].
  • Dementia: Smoking increases the risk of both [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and [[99420dce|vascular dementia]].
  • Multiple Sclerosis: Smoking is associated with an increased risk of developing [[45dd6d19|MS]] and with a more rapid disease progression.
  • USMLE Tip: In a patient with a stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage, smoking should be identified as a key modifiable risk factor.
content.takeAway: Tobacco smoking is a powerful neurotoxin and vasculotoxin, accelerating atherosclerosis and promoting thrombosis, thereby dramatically increasing the risk of devastating neurological events like stroke and aneurysm rupture.

content.definition: Tolcapone is a reversible inhibitor of catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) that is used as an adjunctive therapy with [[541cd176|levodopa/carbidopa]] for the treatment of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Inhibits COMT, the enzyme that metabolizes levodopa. Unlike [[eb2da2bc|entacapone]], tolcapone acts in both the periphery and the central nervous system because it can cross the blood-brain barrier. This dual action increases the bioavailability of levodopa to the brain and also prevents the breakdown of dopamine within the brain.
  • Clinical Use: Used with [[541cd176|levodopa/carbidopa]] to prolong the 'on' time and reduce 'off' time in patients with motor fluctuations.
  • Adverse Effects: Potentiates levodopa side effects (dyskinesias, nausea). The most significant adverse effect is hepatotoxicity, which can be fatal. Its use is limited due to this risk and requires regular monitoring of liver function tests.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the key difference between the COMT inhibitors: Tolcapone acts in Two places (CNS and periphery) and is toxic to the liver. Entacapone acts in the Endiphery (periphery) only.
content.takeAway: Tolcapone is a potent COMT inhibitor that works both centrally and peripherally to extend the action of levodopa, but its clinical use is severely restricted by the risk of life-threatening hepatotoxicity.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Levodopa] --Peripheral COMT--> B(3-O-methyldopa); C[Tolcapone] --x B; A --> D(Crosses BBB); D --> E[Dopamine in CNS]; E --Central COMT--> F(3-MT); C --x F;

content.definition: The tongue is a muscular organ in the mouth that is vital for gustation (taste), mastication (chewing), deglutition (swallowing), and articulation (speech). Its complex functions are controlled by multiple cranial nerves.
content.atAGlance:
• Motor Innervation: All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII), except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Sensory Innervation (Anterior 2/3):
    - General Sensation (touch, pain, temp): Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
    - Taste (Special Sensation): Chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • Sensory Innervation (Posterior 1/3):
    - General Sensation & Taste: Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
  • Swallowing: Coordinated movement of the tongue, primarily by CN XII, is essential for the oral phase of swallowing.
  • USMLE Tip: A lesion of CN XII will cause the tongue to deviate toward the side of the lesion upon protrusion ('lick your wounds'). Remember the different sensory nerves for the anterior vs. posterior tongue.
content.takeAway: The tongue is a neurologically complex organ, with its motor function dominated by CN XII, while its sensory and taste functions are neatly divided between CN V, VII, and IX for the anterior and posterior portions.

content.definition: A tonic seizure is a type of [[2e7554b7|generalized seizure]] characterized by a sudden, sustained increase in muscle tone, causing the body, arms, or legs to become stiff and rigid. Consciousness is typically impaired.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: The seizure consists of a sudden, forceful, sustained contraction of muscles. If standing, the person will fall stiffly ('like a tree falling'). The eyes may roll back, and breathing may be temporarily arrested. The event is usually brief, lasting from a few seconds to a minute.
  • Tonic-Clonic Seizure: A tonic seizure is the initial phase of a [[39f6b128|generalized tonic-clonic seizure]].
  • Associated Syndromes: Tonic seizures are a common feature of severe epilepsy syndromes, particularly Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • EEG Findings: The EEG typically shows a generalized, low-voltage fast activity or a flattening (desynchronization) of the background rhythm.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate a tonic seizure (sustained stiffening) from a clonic seizure (rhythmic jerking) and an atonic seizure (sudden loss of tone).
content.takeAway: A tonic seizure is a manifestation of a widespread neuronal discharge that locks the body's muscles into a state of rigid contraction, often seen as the initial 'stiffening' phase of a grand mal seizure or as a feature of severe epilepsy syndromes.

content.definition: The Superior Rectus is one of the six extraocular muscles responsible for moving the eye. Its primary action is elevation, but it also contributes to adduction and intorsion.
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation: It is innervated by the superior division of the oculomotor nerve (CN III).
  • Primary Action: Elevation (moving the eye upward).
