    - CN IX (Glossopharyngeal): Taste from posterior 1/3 of the tongue, and signals from carotid body chemoreceptors and carotid sinus baroreceptors.
    - CN X (Vagus): Taste from the epiglottis, and signals from aortic arch baroreceptors/chemoreceptors and visceral organs.
  • Role in Reflexes: It is the afferent hub for the baroreflex and chemoreflex, crucial for blood pressure and respiratory control. It also plays a role in the gag and cough reflexes.
  • Vomiting Center: The NTS receives input from the [[5dd343d3|area postrema]] (chemoreceptor trigger zone) and the GI tract (via the vagus nerve) to coordinate the vomiting reflex.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the NTS as the main visceral sensory nucleus for CNs VII, IX, and X, integrating taste, blood pressure, and gut sensation.
content.takeAway: The Nucleus Tractus Solitarius acts as the brainstem's central processing unit for all visceral sensation, integrating critical information about taste, blood pressure, and blood gases from three different cranial nerves to orchestrate vital autonomic reflexes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CN VII, IX, X] --Visceral Sensory Info--> B(Nucleus Tractus Solitarius); B --> C(Taste Pathway); B --> D(Autonomic Reflexes e.g., Baroreflex); B --> E(Vomiting Center);

content.definition: Nystagmus is a condition of involuntary, rhythmic eye movements, which can be horizontal, vertical, or rotary. It is a sign of dysfunction in the systems responsible for controlling eye position and movement, such as the vestibular system or the cerebellum.
content.atAGlance:
• Jerk Nystagmus: The most common form, characterized by a slow drift of the eyes in one direction (slow phase) followed by a rapid corrective jerk back in the opposite direction (fast phase). Nystagmus is named for the direction of the fast phase.
  • Peripheral vs. Central Vertigo: The characteristics of nystagmus help differentiate the cause of vertigo. Peripheral vertigo (inner ear) typically causes horizontal or torsional nystagmus that is suppressed by visual fixation. Central vertigo (brainstem/cerebellum) can cause purely vertical or purely torsional nystagmus that is not suppressed by fixation.
  • Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO): A lesion of the MLF causes nystagmus in the abducting eye during horizontal gaze.
  • Friedreich Ataxia: Nystagmus is a common finding in this neurodegenerative disease due to cerebellar involvement.
  • Retinoblastoma: Can present with nystagmus in an infant if the tumor affects central vision.
  • USMLE Tip: Purely vertical or purely torsional nystagmus is a major red flag for a central (brainstem or cerebellar) lesion.
content.takeAway: Nystagmus is a key objective sign of vestibular or cerebellar dysfunction, and a careful analysis of its direction, trajectory, and response to fixation can precisely localize the lesion to either the peripheral or central nervous system.

content.definition: Obstructive hydrocephalus, also known as non-communicating hydrocephalus, is the accumulation of excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to a physical blockage within the ventricular system, leading to ventricular dilation proximal to the obstruction and increased intracranial pressure.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A structural lesion blocks the flow of CSF from one part of the ventricular system to another or into the subarachnoid space. This leads to a buildup of CSF and pressure in the ventricles 'upstream' of the blockage.
  • Common Sites of Obstruction:
    - Cerebral Aqueduct (of Sylvius): The narrowest part of the ventricular system, connecting the 3rd and 4th ventricles. Aqueductal stenosis is a common cause in children.
    - Foramen of Monro: Can be blocked by a colloid cyst.
    - Fourth Ventricle Outlets: Can be compressed by posterior fossa tumors like a [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] or [[14365ef4|ependymoma]].
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, such as headache, nausea, vomiting, and [[4ae219da|papilledema]]. In infants, presents with an enlarging head circumference and bulging fontanelle.
  • USMLE Tip: A [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] in a child is a classic cause of obstructive hydrocephalus due to compression of the fourth ventricle.
content.takeAway: Obstructive hydrocephalus is a 'plumbing problem' within the brain's ventricular system, where a physical blockage leads to a dam-like effect, causing upstream ventricular dilation and a dangerous rise in intracranial pressure.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CSF Production in Lateral/Third Ventricles] --> B(Flow through Cerebral Aqueduct); B --Blockage (e.g., Tumor)--> C(Obstruction); B --> D(Fourth Ventricle); C --> E(Dilation of Lateral & Third Ventricles); E --> F(Increased ICP);

content.definition: The Occipital Lobe is the most posterior lobe of the cerebral cortex, primarily dedicated to the processing of visual information.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Visual Cortex (V1): Located in the calcarine sulcus, it receives visual input directly from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]]. It is responsible for initial processing of visual stimuli.
  • Visual Association Cortex: Surrounds the primary visual cortex and is involved in higher-order visual processing, such as interpreting color, form, and motion.
  • Blood Supply: Primarily supplied by the Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA). The occipital pole, which represents the macula (central vision), often has a dual blood supply from the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Lesion Effects: A unilateral lesion of the occipital lobe (e.g., from a PCA stroke) causes a contralateral homonymous hemianopia. Due to the dual blood supply, this often presents with macular sparing.
  • USMLE Tip: Any visual field defect that is homonymous (affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes) and respects the vertical midline points to a lesion posterior to the optic chiasm. If it involves macular sparing, the lesion is almost certainly in the occipital lobe.
content.takeAway: The Occipital Lobe functions as the brain's dedicated visual processing center; damage to this area results not in blindness of an eye, but in the loss of the contralateral visual field from both eyes.

content.definition: Ocular motility refers to the movement of the eyes, which is controlled by six extraocular muscles innervated by three cranial nerves (III, IV, and VI). These movements allow for fixation, tracking, and scanning of the visual environment.
content.atAGlance:
• Extraocular Muscles: Four rectus muscles (superior, inferior, medial, lateral) and two oblique muscles (superior, inferior).
  • Cranial Nerve Innervation: Mnemonic: LR6SO4R3 (Lateral Rectus by CN VI, Superior Oblique by CN IV, Rest by CN III).
  • Primary Actions:
    - Abduction: [[f7b5ee5d|Lateral Rectus]] (CN VI)
    - Adduction: Medial Rectus (CN III)
    - Elevation: Superior Rectus & Inferior Oblique (CN III)
    - Depression: Inferior Rectus (CN III) & Superior Oblique (CN IV)
  • Clinical Testing: Assessed by having the patient follow a target in the six cardinal positions of gaze (the 'H' pattern).
  • USMLE Tip: To isolate the vertical actions of the rectus muscles, have the patient look out (abduct). To isolate the vertical actions of the oblique muscles, have the patient look in (adduct).
content.takeAway: The precise and coordinated control of ocular motility by cranial nerves III, IV, and VI allows for the complex eye movements necessary for binocular vision; any weakness or paralysis (ophthalmoplegia) results in misalignment and diplopia.

content.definition: The Oculomotor Nerve (CN III) is a cranial nerve that controls most of the eye's movements, including constriction of the pupil and maintaining an open eyelid. It contains both somatic motor and visceral motor (parasympathetic) fibers.
content.atAGlance:
• Motor Function: Innervates the superior, medial, and inferior rectus muscles, the inferior oblique muscle, and the levator palpebrae superioris (eyelid elevation).
  • Parasympathetic Function: Carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibers innervate the sphincter pupillae (pupillary constriction) and the ciliary muscle ([[81b5f5fe|accommodation]]).
  • Palsy Presentation: A complete CN III palsy results in a "down and out" eye position (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique), severe [[6202e6af|ptosis]], and a fixed, dilated pupil ("blown pupil").
  • Pupil Sparing vs. Pupil Involving: A compressive lesion (e.g., PCom aneurysm, uncal herniation) typically affects the superficial parasympathetic fibers first, causing a blown pupil. An ischemic lesion (e.g., diabetic neuropathy) often affects the deeper motor fibers while sparing the pupil.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of a CN III palsy with a dilated, nonreactive pupil is a neurological emergency, highly suggestive of an aneurysm compressing the nerve.
content.takeAway: The Oculomotor Nerve is the primary motor nerve of the eye, and its dual somatic and parasympathetic functions mean that a complete palsy presents with a dramatic triad of a deviated eye, a drooping eyelid, and a dilated pupil, with the pupillary involvement being a key sign for differentiating compressive from ischemic causes.

content.definition: The Oculosympathetic Pathway is a three-neuron chain that provides sympathetic innervation to the eye and face, controlling pupillary dilation, eyelid elevation, and facial sweating.
content.atAGlance:
• First-Order Neuron (Central): Originates in the posterior [[89e86633|hypothalamus]], descends through the brainstem and synapses in the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8-T2) in the spinal cord.
  • Second-Order Neuron (Preganglionic): Exits the spinal cord at T1, travels up the sympathetic chain, and synapses in the superior cervical ganglion. This neuron passes over the apex of the lung.
  • Third-Order Neuron (Postganglionic): Ascends along the internal carotid artery, passes through the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]], and travels with the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V1) to innervate the dilator pupillae muscle, superior tarsal muscle, and facial sweat glands.
  • Clinical Significance: Disruption of this pathway at any point results in Horner Syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).
  • USMLE Tip: The location of the lesion along the three-neuron arc determines the pattern of anhidrosis. A lesion of the 1st or 2nd neuron causes anhidrosis of the entire ipsilateral face, while a lesion of the 3rd neuron (distal to the carotid bifurcation) spares sweating on the forehead.
content.takeAway: The long and circuitous route of the Oculosympathetic Pathway—from the hypothalamus down the spinal cord, up the neck, and back into the head—makes it vulnerable to a wide range of pathologies, from brainstem strokes to apical lung tumors, all of which can produce the same classic triad of Horner syndrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[1st Order: Hypothalamus] --> B(Ciliospinal Center C8-T2); B --> C[2nd Order: Superior Cervical Ganglion]; C --> D[3rd Order: Eye & Face];

content.definition: Olfaction is the sense of smell, a chemical sense mediated by olfactory receptor neurons in the nasal cavity that detect odorant molecules and transmit this information to the brain via the [[4487bc38|olfactory nerve (CN I)]].
content.atAGlance:
• Receptors: Olfactory receptor neurons are located in the olfactory epithelium in the superior part of the nasal cavity.
  • Pathway: Axons of these neurons form the olfactory nerve (CN I), which passes through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone to synapse in the olfactory bulb. From the bulb, olfactory tracts project directly to the primary olfactory cortex (piriform cortex) in the temporal lobe.
  • Unique Feature: Olfaction is the only sensory modality that does not have a primary relay in the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]] before projecting to the cortex.
  • Limbic System Connection: The olfactory cortex has strong connections to the [[73ace357|limbic system]], particularly the amygdala and hippocampus, which is why smells can evoke strong emotions and memories.
  • Clinical Significance: Loss of smell is called anosmia. It can be caused by trauma (shearing of olfactory nerve fibers at the cribriform plate), viral infections, or neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's.
content.takeAway: Olfaction is a unique and primitive sense that bypasses the thalamic relay common to all other senses, projecting directly to cortical areas intertwined with the [[73ace357|limbic system]], providing a direct and powerful link between smells, emotions, and memory.

content.definition: The Olfactory Nerve (CN I) is the first and shortest cranial nerve, a purely sensory nerve responsible for the sense of olfaction (smell).
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Special visceral afferent (SVA) fibers for smell.
  • Pathway: Composed of the axons of olfactory receptor neurons located in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity. These axons pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone to synapse on mitral cells in the olfactory bulb.
  • Central Projections: The olfactory tract then projects from the bulb to the primary olfactory cortex (piriform cortex) without relaying through the thalamus.
  • Lesion Effects: Damage to the olfactory nerve results in anosmia (loss of smell). This can be caused by head trauma (shearing forces at the cribriform plate), viral infections, or tumors at the base of the frontal lobe (e.g., olfactory groove meningioma).
  • USMLE Tip: Anosmia following a frontal head injury is a classic presentation of CN I damage due to shearing of its delicate fibers as they pass through the cribriform plate.
content.takeAway: The Olfactory Nerve is unique among cranial nerves as it is a direct extension of the telencephalon, consists of unmyelinated axons that regenerate, and its pathway is the only sensory system to bypass the thalamus, projecting directly to the cortex.

content.definition: Oligodendrocytes are a type of glial cell found in the central nervous system (CNS) whose primary function is to produce the myelin sheath that insulates neuronal axons, allowing for rapid saltatory conduction of action potentials.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Myelination of axons in the CNS (brain, spinal cord, and optic nerve). A single oligodendrocyte can myelinate multiple axons (up to ~30).
  • Appearance: Histologically, they have a "fried egg" appearance with a round nucleus and clear cytoplasm, especially prominent in [[c932ed4e|oligodendrogliomas]].
  • Embryonic Origin: Derived from neuroectoderm of the neural tube.
  • Pathology: They are the primary target of autoimmune attack in [[45dd6d19|Multiple Sclerosis]]. They are also damaged in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) by the JC virus and in various leukodystrophies.
  • Distinction from Schwann Cells: [[c65a8909|Schwann cells]] perform the same function (myelination) but in the peripheral nervous system (PNS). A key difference is that one Schwann cell myelinates only one segment of a single axon.
  • USMLE Tip: The destruction of oligodendrocytes is the central pathological event in [[45dd6d19|Multiple Sclerosis]].
content.takeAway: Oligodendrocytes are the myelin-producing cells of the CNS, with each cell extending multiple processes to ensheath numerous axons; this 'one-to-many' relationship contrasts with Schwann cells and explains the widespread, patchy nature of demyelination when these cells are destroyed in diseases like MS.

content.definition: An Oligodendroglioma is a relatively rare, slow-growing primary brain tumor derived from [[a24f9747|oligodendrocytes]]. It is most commonly found in the cerebral hemispheres of adults, particularly the frontal lobes.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Typically located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres, with a predilection for the frontal lobes.
  • Clinical Presentation: Often presents with seizures due to its cortical location. Other symptoms include headaches and focal neurologic deficits.
  • Imaging: On CT scans, these tumors are often calcified. On MRI, they appear as well-circumscribed masses.
  • Histology: Characterized by sheets of uniform cells with round nuclei, clear cytoplasm, and well-defined cell borders, creating a classic "fried egg" appearance. A delicate network of branching capillaries, often described as a "chicken-wire" pattern, is also characteristic.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of a calcified frontal lobe tumor in an adult presenting with seizures, and a "fried egg" appearance on histology, is pathognomonic for an oligodendroglioma.
content.takeAway: The Oligodendroglioma is defined by its classic histological appearance of "fried egg" cells and a "chicken-wire" vascular pattern, which reflects its origin from the myelin-producing cells of the CNS and often presents with seizures due to its typical frontal lobe location.

content.definition: Open-Angle Glaucoma is the most common type of [[3ce6c035|glaucoma]], a chronic, progressive optic neuropathy characterized by an open, normal-appearing anterior chamber angle and increased intraocular pressure (IOP) due to decreased aqueous humor outflow.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The primary defect is an increased resistance to aqueous humor drainage through the trabecular meshwork. The anterior chamber angle itself is open and not obstructed.
  • Clinical Presentation: Typically asymptomatic in the early stages, earning it the name "silent thief of sight." The first noticeable symptom is often a gradual loss of peripheral vision, which progresses to central vision loss and blindness if untreated.
  • Risk Factors: Increased age, African American ethnicity, family history, and diabetes mellitus.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosed based on elevated IOP, characteristic optic disc cupping on fundoscopy, and corresponding visual field defects on perimetry.
  • Treatment: The goal is to lower IOP. First-line agents are typically prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost) which increase uveoscleral outflow, or beta-blockers (e.g., timolol) which decrease aqueous humor production.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from angle-closure glaucoma: open-angle is chronic, painless, and involves peripheral vision loss, while acute angle-closure is sudden, painful, and presents with a red eye and blurry vision.
content.takeAway: Open-Angle Glaucoma is a chronic and insidious disease where the eye's drainage system (the trabecular meshwork) becomes clogged over time, leading to a slow, painless rise in pressure that gradually damages the optic nerve from the periphery inward.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Decreased Outflow through Trabecular Meshwork] --> B(Increased IOP); B --> C(Optic Nerve Damage); C --> D(Progressive Peripheral Vision Loss);

content.definition: A neuron action potential is a rapid, all-or-none electrical signal that propagates down an axon, caused by the sequential opening and closing of voltage-gated ion channels, which temporarily reverses the membrane potential and allows for long-distance communication in the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Resting Potential (~-70 mV): Maintained by the Na+/K+ pump and high resting permeability to K+ (K+ leak channels).
  • Depolarization: A stimulus reaching threshold potential (~-55 mV) triggers the rapid opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels, causing a massive influx of Na+ and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  • Repolarization: Voltage-gated Na+ channels inactivate, and voltage-gated K+ channels open, leading to an efflux of K+ that brings the membrane potential back down.
  • Hyperpolarization: K+ channels are slow to close, causing the membrane potential to briefly dip below the resting potential.
  • USMLE Tip: Many neurotoxins and drugs target these channels. [[tetrodotoxin|Tetrodotoxin]] (pufferfish) and [[lidocaine|local anesthetics]] block voltage-gated Na+ channels, preventing action potential propagation.
content.takeAway: The neuron action potential is fundamentally a precisely orchestrated sequence of ionic movements: a rapid influx of Na+ causes the rising phase (depolarization), and a subsequent efflux of K+ causes the falling phase (repolarization), enabling high-speed signal transmission.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A(Resting State) --Stimulus--> B(Threshold); B --Na+ Influx--> C(Depolarization); C --Na+ Inactivation & K+ Efflux--> D(Repolarization); D --Slow K+ Channel Closing--> E(Hyperpolarization); E --> A;

content.definition: Neurons are the fundamental, signal-transmitting cells of the nervous system, composed of a cell body (soma), dendrites that receive input, and an axon that sends output. They are permanent cells that do not typically divide in adults.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: The cell body contains the nucleus and Nissl substance (rough ER). Dendrites receive signals, and the axon transmits signals via [[832463e6|action potentials]].
  • Axonal Injury Response: When an axon is severed, the distal portion undergoes Wallerian degeneration. The cell body swells, the nucleus moves to the periphery, and Nissl substance disperses (central chromatolysis or axonal reaction).
  • Spinal Tracts: Neurons are organized into tracts in the spinal cord. First-order neurons bring sensory information from the periphery. Second-order neurons decussate and ascend to the thalamus. Third-order neurons project from the thalamus to the cortex. Motor pathways involve upper and lower motor neurons.
  • Markers: Neurons can be identified by immunohistochemical stains for neurofilament protein and synaptophysin.
  • USMLE Tip: The histological changes of axonal reaction (central chromatolysis) are a classic sign of a neuron attempting to repair itself after its axon has been damaged.
content.takeAway: Neurons are highly specialized for communication, with a complex structure that supports the generation and propagation of electrical signals over long distances. Their response to injury, particularly the process of central chromatolysis, reflects a robust but often incomplete attempt at regeneration.

content.definition: Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers that transmit signals across a synapse from one neuron to another target neuron, muscle cell, or gland cell. Their synthesis, release, and degradation are tightly regulated and are the targets of many psychoactive drugs.
content.atAGlance:
• Acetylcholine (ACh): Decreased in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]. Synthesized in the [[361438f2|basal nucleus of Meynert]].
  • Dopamine: Decreased in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]. Increased in schizophrenia. Synthesized in the ventral tegmentum and substantia nigra.
  • GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid): Main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Decreased in anxiety and [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]. Synthesized in the nucleus accumbens.
  • Norepinephrine: Increased in anxiety; decreased in depression. Synthesized in the locus coeruleus.
  • Serotonin (5-HT): Decreased in anxiety and depression. Synthesized in the raphe nuclei.
  • Glutamate: Main excitatory neurotransmitter. Implicated in excitotoxicity.
content.takeAway: The balance of key neurotransmitters in specific brain regions is critical for normal neurological function; imbalances are the core pathophysiology of many major neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as the dopamine deficit in Parkinson's and the acetylcholine deficit in Alzheimer's.

content.definition: A Nevus Flammeus, commonly known as a port-wine stain, is a congenital capillary vascular malformation characterized by a flat, pink-to-reddish-purple patch of skin. When it occurs in the trigeminal nerve distribution, it is a hallmark of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A congenital malformation of dermal capillaries, resulting in ectasia (dilation) of these vessels. It does not involute and grows in proportion with the child.
  • Clinical Presentation: A flat, erythematous patch present at birth.
  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome: A nevus flammeus in the ophthalmic (V1) and/or maxillary (V2) distribution of the trigeminal nerve is the key cutaneous finding of [[fd52a8b8|Sturge-Weber syndrome]].
  • Associated Findings in Sturge-Weber: The syndrome also includes an ipsilateral leptomeningeal angioma (leading to seizures and intellectual disability) and may involve episcleral hemangioma (leading to early-onset glaucoma).
  • USMLE Tip: A newborn with a port-wine stain following the V1/V2 dermatome must be evaluated for [[fd52a8b8|Sturge-Weber syndrome]], including an ophthalmologic exam for glaucoma and neuroimaging to look for leptomeningeal angiomas.
content.takeAway: A nevus flammeus is more than a birthmark when it appears on the face in a trigeminal distribution; it serves as a critical external clue to the potential presence of underlying vascular malformations in the brain and eye, as seen in [[fd52a8b8|Sturge-Weber syndrome]].

content.definition: The Nigrostriatal Pathway is a critical dopaminergic tract that projects from the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) to the striatum (caudate and putamen). It is a key component of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] motor loop, responsible for modulating the initiation of voluntary movement.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) in the midbrain.
  • Termination: Dorsal striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).
  • Neurotransmitter: [[90adc821|Dopamine]].
  • Function: Modulates motor activity by exciting the direct pathway (via D1 receptors) and inhibiting the indirect pathway (via D2 receptors), with a net effect of facilitating movement.
  • Pathology: Degeneration of this pathway is the primary cause of the motor symptoms in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]. The loss of dopamine leads to overactivity of the indirect pathway and underactivity of the direct pathway, resulting in bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor.
  • USMLE Tip: The destruction of the nigrostriatal pathway is the central event in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]. Antipsychotic drugs can block D2 receptors in this pathway, causing drug-induced parkinsonism (extrapyramidal side effects).
content.takeAway: The Nigrostriatal Pathway acts as the 'gas pedal' for the basal ganglia's motor circuit; its dopaminergic input facilitates movement, and its degeneration in Parkinson's disease effectively 'puts the brakes on,' leading to the characteristic poverty of motion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Substantia Nigra pars compacta] --Dopamine--> B(Striatum); B --> C(Modulation of Direct/Indirect Pathways); C --> D(Initiation of Movement);

content.definition: Nimodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker with a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels, used specifically to prevent cerebral vasospasm following a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks L-type calcium channels on smooth muscle cells, leading to vasodilation. It is more selective for cerebral arteries than other calcium channel blockers.
  • Clinical Use: Exclusively used to improve neurological outcomes by preventing or reducing the severity of cerebral vasospasm, a delayed complication that occurs 3-10 days after a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
  • Administration: Typically given orally or via nasogastric tube for 21 days following an aneurysmal SAH.
  • Adverse Effects: The most common side effect is hypotension. Others include headache, nausea, and bradycardia.
  • USMLE Tip: If a question describes a patient who had a subarachnoid hemorrhage and then develops new focal neurological deficits several days later, the cause is vasospasm. The prophylactic treatment for this complication is nimodipine.
content.takeAway: Nimodipine is a specialized calcium channel blocker whose primary role is not to treat hypertension but to prevent the devastating secondary ischemic strokes caused by vasospasm after a subarachnoid hemorrhage, thereby improving survival and functional outcomes.

content.definition: Noise-induced hearing loss is a type of sensorineural hearing loss caused by damage to the delicate hair cells in the [[2e814378|organ of Corti]] within the cochlea, resulting from exposure to loud sounds.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Loud noise causes mechanical damage and metabolic exhaustion of the stereociliated hair cells in the [[2e814378|organ of Corti]]. Damage is typically irreversible.
  • Frequency Pattern: The hearing loss characteristically begins at high frequencies, with a classic audiogram showing a "notch" or dip at 4000 Hz. This is because the basal part of the cochlea, which is responsible for high-frequency hearing, is most susceptible to damage.
  • Causes: Can be caused by a single, intense acoustic trauma (e.g., explosion) or, more commonly, by chronic exposure to loud noise (e.g., occupational, recreational music).
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients report difficulty hearing, especially in noisy environments, and may experience tinnitus.
  • USMLE Tip: An audiogram showing a bilateral, symmetric hearing loss with a characteristic notch at 4000 Hz is the classic finding for noise-induced hearing loss.
content.takeAway: Noise-induced hearing loss is a direct result of mechanical trauma to the hair cells of the inner ear, characteristically affecting high-frequency hearing first (especially at 4000 Hz) because the region of the cochlea responsible for these frequencies is most vulnerable to the damaging energy of loud sounds.

content.definition: Non-REM (NREM) sleep is one of the two main stages of sleep, comprising three distinct stages (N1, N2, N3) characterized by progressively slower brain waves and deeper relaxation. It is the period when the body repairs and regrows tissues, builds bone and muscle, and strengthens the immune system.
content.atAGlance:
• Stage N1 (Light Sleep): Transition between wakefulness and sleep. EEG shows low-voltage, mixed-frequency waves.
  • Stage N2 (Intermediate Sleep): The largest percentage of total sleep time. EEG is characterized by sleep spindles (bursts of rhythmic activity) and K-complexes (large, high-voltage slow waves). Bruxism (teeth grinding) occurs in this stage.
  • Stage N3 (Deep Sleep/Slow-Wave Sleep): The deepest stage of sleep. EEG shows low-frequency, high-amplitude delta waves. This is the stage where sleepwalking (somnambulism), night terrors, and bedwetting (enuresis) occur.
  • Physiology: Characterized by decreased heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate.
  • USMLE Tip: Associate specific EEG findings and parasomnias with their respective NREM stages: N2 with sleep spindles and K-complexes, and N3 with delta waves, sleepwalking, and night terrors.
content.takeAway: Non-REM sleep is a period of deep physiological rest and restoration, progressing through stages of increasing depth, with Stage N3 (slow-wave sleep) being the most restorative and the time when disorders of arousal like sleepwalking and night terrors manifest.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Awake] --> B(NREM Stage 1); B --> C(NREM Stage 2); C --> D(NREM Stage 3); D --> C; C --> E(REM Sleep);

content.definition: Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics, often called "Z-drugs," are a class of psychoactive drugs used for the treatment of insomnia. While structurally unrelated to benzodiazepines, they act on a specific subtype of the GABAA receptor to produce sedative effects.
content.atAGlance:
• Examples: Zolpidem, Zaleplon, esZopiclone.
  • Mechanism of Action: Act as selective agonists at the BZ1 (ω1) subtype of the GABAA receptor. This enhances the effect of GABA, leading to increased Cl- conductance and neuronal hyperpolarization, but with more specificity for sedation than benzodiazepines.
  • Clinical Use: Short-term treatment of insomnia.
  • Adverse Effects: Ataxia, headaches, confusion. Can cause anterograde amnesia and complex sleep-related behaviors (e.g., sleepwalking, sleep-driving).
  • Pharmacokinetics: Have a rapid onset and short duration of action. Effects are reversed by flumazenil, the same antidote used for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • USMLE Tip: Z-drugs are preferred over benzodiazepines for insomnia due to a lower risk of dependence and less disruption of sleep architecture. However, they are still controlled substances and carry risks. Remember that their effects are reversed by flumazenil.
content.takeAway: Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics are 'smarter' sleeping pills than benzodiazepines because they selectively target the sedative (BZ1) subtype of the GABAA receptor, inducing sleep with less anxiolytic, muscle relaxant, and anticonvulsant effects, and a lower risk of altering sleep stages.

content.definition: Non-communicating hydrocephalus, also known as obstructive hydrocephalus, is the accumulation of excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to a physical blockage within the ventricular system, leading to ventricular dilation proximal to the obstruction and increased intracranial pressure.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A structural lesion blocks the flow of CSF from one part of the ventricular system to another or into the subarachnoid space. This leads to a buildup of CSF and pressure in the ventricles 'upstream' of the blockage.
  • Common Sites of Obstruction:
    - Cerebral Aqueduct (of Sylvius): The narrowest part of the ventricular system, connecting the 3rd and 4th ventricles. Aqueductal stenosis is a common cause in children.
    - Foramen of Monro: Can be blocked by a colloid cyst.
    - Fourth Ventricle Outlets: Can be compressed by posterior fossa tumors like a [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] or [[14365ef4|ependymoma]].
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, such as headache, nausea, vomiting, and [[4ae219da|papilledema]]. In infants, presents with an enlarging head circumference and bulging fontanelle.
  • USMLE Tip: A [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] in a child is a classic cause of obstructive hydrocephalus due to compression of the fourth ventricle.
content.takeAway: Non-communicating hydrocephalus is a 'plumbing problem' within the brain's ventricular system, where a physical blockage leads to a dam-like effect, causing upstream ventricular dilation and a dangerous rise in intracranial pressure.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CSF Production in Lateral/Third Ventricles] --> B(Flow through Cerebral Aqueduct); B --Blockage (e.g., Tumor)--> C(Obstruction); B --> D(Fourth Ventricle); C --> E(Dilation of Lateral & Third Ventricles); E --> F(Increased ICP);

content.definition: Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs are a class of agents that cause skeletal muscle paralysis by acting as competitive antagonists at the nicotinic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
content.atAGlance:
• Examples: Rocuronium, vecuronium, atracurium, cisatracurium, [[243d4db1|pancuronium]]. Mnemonic: End in '-curonium' or '-curium'.
  • Mechanism of Action: Competitively bind to NM receptors on the motor endplate, preventing [[6a005559|ACh]] from binding and thus inhibiting muscle cell depolarization and contraction.
  • Clinical Use: Used as adjuncts in general anesthesia to induce skeletal muscle relaxation, facilitating endotracheal intubation and surgical procedures.
  • Reversal: The blockade can be overcome by increasing the concentration of ACh in the synapse. This is achieved by administering an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (e.g., neostigmine). An antimuscarinic (e.g., glycopyrrolate) is co-administered to prevent systemic muscarinic side effects. Sugammadex can also be used to reverse rocuronium and vecuronium.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from succinylcholine (a depolarizing blocker). Non-depolarizing blockade shows a 'fade' on train-of-four stimulation, and its effects are reversed by AChE inhibitors.
content.takeAway: Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers act like a key that fits in the lock (the ACh receptor) but doesn't turn, competitively preventing the real key (ACh) from opening the channel and causing muscle contraction. Their effects can be overcome by flooding the synapse with more ACh.

content.definition: Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) is the most common form of [[73b00ab0|diabetic retinopathy]], characterized by damage to the retinal blood vessels leading to leakage and ischemia, but without the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels (neovascularization).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Chronic hyperglycemia damages retinal capillaries, leading to loss of pericytes, basement membrane thickening, and breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier.
  • Funduscopic Findings:
    - Microaneurysms: Earliest sign. Small, saccular outpouchings of capillaries.
    - Dot and Blot Hemorrhages: Bleeding into the deeper layers of the retina.
    - Hard Exudates: Yellow lipid deposits resulting from chronic plasma leakage.
    - Cotton-Wool Spots: Fluffy white patches representing nerve fiber layer infarcts from capillary occlusion.
  • Major Cause of Vision Loss: The primary cause of vision loss in NPDR is macular edema, where fluid and lipids leak into the macula, causing central vision to become blurred.
  • Progression: NPDR can progress to the more severe proliferative form if retinal ischemia becomes widespread.
  • USMLE Tip: Be able to identify the funduscopic findings of NPDR. The presence of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and exudates without neovascularization defines this stage.
content.takeAway: Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy is a disease of leaky and occluded retinal vessels. The pathology is confined to the existing vasculature, and the main threat to vision is not from new vessel growth but from the chronic leakage of fluid into the macula, causing macular edema.

content.definition: Nonrhegmatogenous retinal detachment is a separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium that is not caused by a full-thickness retinal tear or hole. It is subdivided into tractional and exudative types.
content.atAGlance:
• Tractional Retinal Detachment: Occurs when fibrovascular membranes on the retinal surface contract and pull the retina away from the pigment epithelium. A classic cause is proliferative diabetic retinopathy, where neovascular membranes contract.
  • Exudative (Serous) Retinal Detachment: Results from the accumulation of fluid in the subretinal space due to damage to the retinal pigment epithelium or choroid, allowing fluid to leak underneath the retina. Causes include inflammatory conditions (e.g., posterior uveitis), tumors (e.g., choroidal melanoma), and severe hypertension.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients experience vision loss, which can be gradual or sudden, often described as a curtain or shadow in the visual field. Unlike rhegmatogenous detachment, it is not typically preceded by flashes or floaters.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the mechanisms. Rhegmatogenous = a tear lets fluid in. Tractional = membranes pull the retina off. Exudative = fluid leaks from damaged vessels underneath.
content.takeAway: Unlike the more common rhegmatogenous detachment caused by a retinal tear, nonrhegmatogenous retinal detachments are caused either by mechanical pulling forces (tractional) or by underlying fluid leakage (exudative), pointing to different underlying pathologies like diabetes or inflammation.

content.definition: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a cornerstone of abortive therapy for mild to moderate primary [[26661e34|headaches]], particularly tension-type and migraine headaches, by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen, diclofenac) reversibly inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) enzymes, which blocks the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are key mediators of inflammation and pain.
  • Tension-Type Headache: NSAIDs are often the first-line treatment for acute tension headaches.
  • Migraine Headache: Effective for mild to moderate migraine attacks. They can be used alone or in combination with triptans for more severe attacks.
  • Adverse Effects: Common side effects include GI upset and peptic ulcer disease. Chronic use can lead to renal injury (analgesic nephropathy) and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
  • USMLE Tip: While effective for acute attacks, overuse of NSAIDs and other analgesics for headaches (e.g., >10-15 days per month) can paradoxically lead to medication-overuse headaches.
content.takeAway: NSAIDs treat primary headaches by targeting the inflammatory component of pain, reducing the synthesis of prostaglandins that sensitize nociceptors, making them a fundamental first-line option for acute attacks.

content.definition: Norepinephrine (NE) is a catecholamine that functions as a major neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, where it is crucial for regulating attention, arousal, sleep-wake cycles, learning, memory, and mood.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Synthesized from [[90adc821|dopamine]] via dopamine β-hydroxylase. The primary site of NE synthesis in the brain is the locus coeruleus, a nucleus in the pons.
  • Function: As part of the ascending reticular activating system, the locus coeruleus projects widely throughout the CNS, modulating alertness and arousal. NE is a key neurotransmitter in the 'fight or flight' response.
  • Role in Mood Disorders: Decreased levels of norepinephrine are implicated in the pathophysiology of depression. Increased levels are associated with anxiety and panic disorders.
  • Pharmacological Targets: Many antidepressants, such as SNRIs (e.g., venlafaxine) and TCAs (e.g., amitriptyline), work by increasing synaptic levels of norepinephrine (and serotonin).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the locus coeruleus as the principal source of CNS norepinephrine. Its role in arousal and mood makes it a key target for drugs treating depression and ADHD.
content.takeAway: In the CNS, norepinephrine released from the locus coeruleus acts as a global 'alertness' signal, modulating attention and arousal across the brain, with dysregulation of this system being a cornerstone of the pathophysiology of mood and anxiety disorders.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Locus Coeruleus] --Synthesizes & Releases--> B(Norepinephrine); B --> C(Widespread CNS Projections); C --> D(Arousal & Attention); C --> E(Mood Regulation);

content.definition: The Nervous System is the body's primary communication and control network, divided into the Central Nervous System (CNS), consisting of the brain and spinal cord, and the Peripheral Nervous System (PNS), which includes all other nervous tissue. It is composed of specialized cells, primarily [[63fc3fe7|neurons]] and glial cells.
content.atAGlance:
• Central Nervous System (CNS): Comprises the brain and spinal cord. It is the main processing center for the nervous system.
  • Peripheral Nervous System (PNS): Includes cranial nerves (except I & II), spinal nerves, and ganglia. It connects the CNS to the limbs and organs.
  • Somatic Nervous System: Part of the PNS responsible for voluntary control of body movements via skeletal muscles.
  • Autonomic Nervous System: Part of the PNS that controls involuntary functions (e.g., heart rate, digestion), further divided into sympathetic and parasympathetic systems.
  • Cells of the Nervous System: [[63fc3fe7|Neurons]] are the signal-transmitting cells. Glial cells ([[8192f595|astrocytes]], [[a24f9747|oligodendrocytes]], microglia, ependymal cells in CNS; [[c65a8909|Schwann cells]], satellite cells in PNS) provide support and protection.
content.takeAway: The nervous system is a complex, integrated network responsible for coordinating actions and transmitting signals between different parts of the body. Its fundamental cellular components are neurons, which conduct electrical impulses, and glial cells, which provide essential support and maintenance.

content.definition: Neural crest cells are a transient, multipotent population of migratory cells that arise from the dorsal aspect of the neural tube during embryonic development and give rise to a diverse array of cell types throughout the body.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Arise from the neuroectoderm at the lateral edges of the neural plate (the neural crest).
  • Migration: These cells undergo an epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and migrate extensively to various locations in the embryo.
  • Derivatives (Nervous System): Give rise to most of the [[c44ae4c5|peripheral nervous system]], including dorsal root ganglia, autonomic ganglia (sympathetic, parasympathetic), [[c65a8909|Schwann cells]], and satellite cells.
  • Derivatives (Other): Also form melanocytes, chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid, odontoblasts, and craniofacial cartilage and bone.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the diverse derivatives of neural crest cells. A helpful mnemonic is MOTEL PASS: Melanocytes, Odontoblasts, Tracheal and laryngeal cartilage, Enterochromaffin cells, Leptomeninges (arachnoid and pia), Parafollicular cells, Adrenal medulla, Schwann cells, Spiral membrane.
content.takeAway: Neural crest cells are often considered the 'fourth germ layer' due to their remarkable multipotency and migratory capacity, giving rise to a vast and seemingly unrelated collection of tissues, from the peripheral nervous system to the melanocytes in the skin.

content.definition: Neural development is the complex process by which the nervous system forms during embryogenesis, beginning with the induction of the neural plate from the ectoderm and proceeding through neurulation, proliferation, migration, and differentiation of neurons and glial cells.
content.atAGlance:
• Induction: The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to differentiate into the neuroectoderm, forming the neural plate.
  • Neurulation: The neural plate folds to form the [[a87cbede|neural tube]], which will become the CNS, and the [[14c6f2a7|neural crest cells]], which will become the PNS and other structures. This process is critically dependent on folate.
  • Vesicle Formation: The rostral end of the neural tube develops into three primary brain vesicles (prosencephalon, mesencephalon, rhombencephalon), which then subdivide into five secondary vesicles.
  • Plate Differentiation: The neural tube differentiates along its dorsal-ventral axis into the alar plate (sensory functions, induced by BMPs) and the basal plate (motor functions, induced by Sonic hedgehog [SHH]).
  • USMLE Tip: Failure of the neural tube to close results in [[neural_tube_defects|neural tube defects]]. Failure of the rostral neuropore to close causes anencephaly; failure of the caudal neuropore causes spina bifida.
content.takeAway: Neural development is a highly orchestrated sequence of events, initiated by signals from the notochord, that transforms a simple sheet of ectodermal cells into the intricate structure of the brain and spinal cord. Errors in the earliest stages, like neurulation, can have devastating consequences.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ectoderm] --Notochord Induction--> B(Neural Plate); B --> C(Neural Tube); C --> D(CNS); B --> E(Neural Crest); E --> F(PNS);

content.definition: The Neural Tube is the embryonic precursor to the central nervous system (CNS), formed during neurulation by the folding of the neural plate. Its proper closure and differentiation are essential for normal brain and spinal cord development.
content.atAGlance:
• Formation: Develops from the neuroectoderm, which thickens to form the neural plate, then folds inward to create the neural tube. This process is complete by the 4th week of gestation.
  • Derivatives: Gives rise to the entire CNS, including the brain, spinal cord, [[63fc3fe7|neurons]], and most glial cells ([[8192f595|astrocytes]], [[a24f9747|oligodendrocytes]], ependymal cells).
  • Regionalization: The rostral part develops into the brain vesicles (prosencephalon, mesencephalon, rhombencephalon), while the caudal part forms the spinal cord.
  • Neural Tube Defects (NTDs): Failure of the neural tube to close properly leads to NTDs. Failure of the rostral (anterior) neuropore to close results in anencephaly. Failure of the caudal (posterior) neuropore to close results in spina bifida.
  • Folate: Maternal folate supplementation before and during early pregnancy is crucial for preventing NTDs.
content.takeAway: The Neural Tube is the foundational structure of the central nervous system, and its timely closure during the first month of gestation is a critical developmental event, the failure of which leads to severe congenital malformations like spina bifida and anencephaly.

content.definition: Trigeminal Neuralgia (also known as tic douloureux) is a chronic pain disorder characterized by recurrent, sudden, severe, shock-like episodes of unilateral facial pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve root as it enters the brainstem, often by the superior cerebellar artery. Demyelination (e.g., from [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]]) is another important cause, especially in younger patients.
  • Clinical Presentation: Paroxysms of excruciating, electric shock-like pain, lasting from a few seconds to minutes. The pain is unilateral and typically affects the V2 (maxillary) and/or V3 (mandibular) divisions.
  • Triggers: Pain can be triggered by innocuous stimuli in specific 'trigger zones,' such as light touch, chewing, talking, or a cold breeze.
  • Treatment: First-line medical treatment is carbamazepine. Other options include oxcarbazepine and gabapentin. For refractory cases, surgical microvascular decompression may be performed.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient describing sudden, severe, electric shock-like pain on one side of their face, triggered by brushing their teeth or feeling a breeze, is the classic presentation. The first-line treatment is carbamazepine.
content.takeAway: Trigeminal Neuralgia is a neuropathic pain syndrome where vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve root leads to hyperexcitability, causing trivial sensory stimuli to be misinterpreted as excruciating pain, with carbamazepine being the mainstay of treatment.

content.definition: Neurocutaneous disorders, also known as phakomatoses, are a group of congenital and hereditary diseases characterized by the growth of tumors in the brain, spinal cord, peripheral nerves, and skin. They arise from developmental abnormalities of the ectoderm.
content.atAGlance:
• Sturge-Weber Syndrome: Characterized by a facial port-wine stain ([[454a0eb8|nevus flammeus]]) in the V1/V2 distribution, ipsilateral leptomeningeal angioma (leading to seizures), and glaucoma. Caused by a somatic mosaic mutation in GNAQ.
  • Tuberous Sclerosis Complex: Autosomal dominant disorder (TSC1/TSC2 mutation) causing hamartomas in multiple organs. Neurological findings include seizures and intellectual disability. Cutaneous findings include ash-leaf spots, angiofibromas, and shagreen patches.
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1): Autosomal dominant (NF1 gene mutation). Presents with café-au-lait spots, cutaneous neurofibromas, Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas), and optic gliomas.
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2): Autosomal dominant (NF2 gene mutation). Characterized by bilateral vestibular [[03ecb69e|schwannomas]].
  • von Hippel-Lindau Disease: Autosomal dominant (VHL gene mutation). Characterized by [[73c63548|hemangioblastomas]] of the CNS and retina, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas.
content.takeAway: Neurocutaneous disorders are a classic example of the shared embryological origin (ectoderm) of the skin and nervous system; the presence of characteristic skin lesions serves as a vital clue to underlying neurological and systemic tumors.

content.definition: Neurodegenerative disease therapy encompasses pharmacological strategies aimed at managing symptoms and, in some cases, slowing the progression of diseases characterized by the progressive loss of neurons, such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's disease.
content.atAGlance:
• Alzheimer Disease: Treatment is symptomatic. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., [[47d0372e|donepezil]], rivastigmine, galantamine) are used to increase ACh levels. Memantine, an NMDA receptor antagonist, is used in moderate-to-severe disease to prevent excitotoxicity.
  • Parkinson Disease: Therapy focuses on increasing dopamine levels. [[541cd176|Levodopa/carbidopa]] is the mainstay. Dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors, and COMT inhibitors are also used.
  • Huntington Disease: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms. Tetrabenazine and deutetrabenazine, which inhibit the vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT), are used to treat chorea.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): Riluzole, which is thought to reduce glutamate excitotoxicity, may modestly increase survival.
  • USMLE Tip: For exams, focus on the primary neurotransmitter deficit and the corresponding drug mechanism: Alzheimer's = ↓ACh (use AChE inhibitors); Parkinson's = ↓Dopamine (use Levodopa).
content.takeAway: Current therapies for most neurodegenerative diseases are largely symptomatic and do not halt the underlying disease process; they work by compensating for the specific neurotransmitter deficiencies that result from neuronal loss.

content.definition: Neurodegenerative disorders are a heterogeneous group of chronic, progressive diseases characterized by the selective and symmetric loss of neurons in specific areas of the central nervous system, often associated with the intracellular or extracellular aggregation of misfolded proteins.
content.atAGlance:
• Dementias: Characterized by cognitive decline. The most common is [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] (Aβ plaques, tau tangles). Others include [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]] (α-synuclein) and [[5fff42cd|Frontotemporal dementia]] (tau or TDP-43).
  • Movement Disorders: Characterized by motor dysfunction. Includes [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] (α-synuclein Lewy bodies, loss of dopaminergic neurons) and [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]] (huntingtin aggregates, loss of GABAergic neurons).
  • Motor Neuron Diseases: Characterized by weakness and muscle atrophy. Includes [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]] (TDP-43 aggregates, loss of upper and lower motor neurons).
  • Prion Diseases: Such as [[86fe59ba|Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease]], characterized by rapidly progressive dementia and spongiform changes due to aggregation of misfolded prion protein (PrPSc).
  • USMLE Tip: For board exams, it is crucial to associate the major neurodegenerative diseases with their hallmark protein aggregate and the primary brain region affected.
content.takeAway: The unifying theme of neurodegenerative disorders is the relentless, progressive death of specific neuronal populations, often driven by the toxic aggregation of misfolded proteins, leading to distinct clinical syndromes of dementia, movement disorders, or paralysis.

content.definition: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a group of autosomal dominant genetic disorders that cause tumors to grow on nervous tissue. The two major types are Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2).
content.atAGlance:
• Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1): Caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. Characterized by café-au-lait spots, cutaneous neurofibromas, Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas), optic gliomas, and axillary/inguinal freckling. Mnemonic: 17 letters in 'von Recklinghausen'.
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2): Caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22. Characterized by bilateral vestibular [[03ecb69e|schwannomas]]. Also associated with meningiomas and ependymomas. Mnemonic: NF2 affects 2 ears (bilateral schwannomas) and is on chromosome 22.
  • Inheritance: Both are autosomal dominant with high penetrance, but NF1 has variable expressivity.
  • Pathophysiology: Both NF1 (neurofibromin) and NF2 (merlin) are tumor suppressor genes. Their inactivation leads to uncontrolled cell growth.
  • USMLE Tip: The distinction between NF1 and NF2 is high-yield. NF1 is characterized by skin findings (café-au-lait, neurofibromas) and Lisch nodules. NF2 is defined by bilateral vestibular schwannomas.
content.takeAway: Neurofibromatosis represents two distinct genetic disorders linked by their predisposition to nerve sheath tumors; NF1 is primarily a disease of skin and peripheral nerves, while NF2 is a disease of central nervous system tumors, most notably bilateral acoustic neuromas.

content.definition: Neurogenic bladder is a general term for bladder dysfunction (either flaccid or spastic) caused by damage to the nerves that control urination.
content.atAGlance:
• Spastic (Hyperreflexic) Bladder: Caused by an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion above the sacral spinal cord (e.g., spinal cord injury, [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]]). The sacral micturition reflex is intact but is no longer inhibited by the brain. Results in detrusor hyperreflexia, leading to urge incontinence.
  • Flaccid (Hypotonic) Bladder: Caused by a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion affecting the sacral micturition center or peripheral nerves (e.g., cauda equina syndrome, diabetic neuropathy). The bladder cannot contract effectively. Results in urinary retention and overflow incontinence.
  • Multiple Sclerosis: A common cause of neurogenic bladder. Patients often present with urge incontinence due to UMN lesions in the spinal cord.
  • Treatment: Management depends on the type. Spastic bladder is treated with antimuscarinic drugs (e.g., oxybutynin) or botulinum toxin injections. Flaccid bladder is managed with timed voiding and intermittent self-catheterization.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with [[45dd6d19|MS]] who develops urinary frequency and urgency has a spastic bladder due to a UMN lesion. A patient with diabetes and a large post-void residual volume has a flaccid bladder due to an LMN/autonomic neuropathy.
content.takeAway: The behavior of a neurogenic bladder directly reflects the level of the neurological lesion: UMN lesions lead to a spastic, hyperactive bladder (urge incontinence), while LMN lesions result in a flaccid, hypotonic bladder (overflow incontinence).

content.definition: The Neurohypophysis, or posterior pituitary, is the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland. It is composed of neural tissue and functions as a storage and release site for two hormones synthesized in the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]]: antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryology: Arises from a downward extension of neural ectoderm from the developing diencephalon.
  • Structure: Composed of the axons and nerve terminals of magnocellular neurons whose cell bodies are located in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]]. Also contains glial cells called pituicytes.
  • Hormones: It does not synthesize hormones. It stores and releases:
    - Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH/Vasopressin): Primarily synthesized in the supraoptic nucleus.
    - Oxytocin: Primarily synthesized in the [[e7b51f5c|paraventricular nucleus]].
  • Connection to Hypothalamus: Connected to the hypothalamus via the hypothalamo-hypophyseal tract, a bundle of axons. This is a direct neural connection, contrasting with the portal venous system of the anterior pituitary.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the posterior pituitary is essentially nerve tissue that stores and releases hypothalamic hormones. A lesion of the pituitary stalk or posterior pituitary can cause central diabetes insipidus due to lack of ADH release.
content.takeAway: The Neurohypophysis is not a true endocrine gland but rather a specialized neurosecretory terminal, acting as a storage depot for hypothalamic hormones and releasing them directly into the bloodstream upon neural command from the hypothalamus.
content.mermaid:
graph TD; A[Hypothalamus
(Supraoptic & Paraventricular Nuclei)] --Axonal Transport--> B(Neurohypophysis); B --Release into Blood--> C(ADH & Oxytocin);

content.definition: Neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptors are G-protein coupled receptors for the neuropeptide Substance P. They are found in the central and peripheral nervous systems and are critically involved in the pathways for pain and, most notably, emesis (vomiting).
content.atAGlance:
• Ligand: The primary endogenous ligand is Substance P.
  • Location in Emesis Pathway: NK1 receptors are highly concentrated in the area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) and the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS), which are key components of the central vomiting center in the brainstem.
  • Role in Vomiting: Activation of NK1 receptors by Substance P is a key step in inducing both acute and, particularly, delayed nausea and vomiting.
  • Pharmacology (NK1 Antagonists): Drugs that block NK1 receptors (e.g., aprepitant, fosaprepitant) are potent antiemetics. Their names often end in '-pitant'.
  • Clinical Use: NK1 antagonists are primarily used for the prevention of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), especially the delayed phase, and for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).
  • USMLE Tip: For chemotherapy-induced vomiting, remember the different receptor targets. Serotonin (5-HT3) antagonists (e.g., ondansetron) are best for acute CINV, while NK1 antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) are crucial for delayed CINV.
content.takeAway: NK1 receptors are the primary target for Substance P in the brain's vomiting center; blocking these receptors with '-pitant' drugs like aprepitant is a highly effective strategy for preventing the delayed nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chemotherapy] --> B(Release of Substance P); B --> C(Binds to NK1 Receptors in Area Postrema/NTS); C --> D(Emesis); E[Aprepitant] --|Blocks|--> C;

content.definition: Neurology and Special Senses is the field of medicine concerned with the diagnosis and treatment of disorders of the nervous system, which includes the brain, spinal cord, peripheral nerves, and the specialized sensory organs for vision, hearing, and balance.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryology: Focuses on the development of the nervous system from the [[a87cbede|neural tube]] and [[14c6f2a7|neural crest cells]].
  • Anatomy and Physiology: Covers the structure and function of neurons, glial cells, major brain regions, spinal cord tracts, and cranial nerves.
  • Pathology: Includes a vast range of disorders such as cerebrovascular disease (stroke), [[41ca6981|neurodegenerative disorders]], [[45dd6d19|demyelinating diseases]], infections, trauma, and tumors.
  • Ophthalmology: The subspecialty dealing with the anatomy, physiology, and diseases of the eye.
  • Otology: The subspecialty dealing with the anatomy, physiology, and diseases of the ear, including hearing and balance.
  • Pharmacology: Involves drugs acting on the nervous system, such as anticonvulsants, anesthetics, and psychotropic medications.
content.takeAway: The study of Neurology and Special Senses is fundamentally about understanding the intricate network that controls and perceives the body, and how disruptions in this network, from the molecular to the macroscopic level, manifest as clinical disease.

content.definition: Neuromuscular blocking drugs are agents that cause skeletal muscle paralysis by interfering with neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction. They are classified as either depolarizing or non-depolarizing agents.
content.atAGlance:
• Depolarizing Blockers: Succinylcholine is the only clinically used agent. It acts as an ACh receptor agonist, causing sustained depolarization (Phase I) followed by receptor desensitization (Phase II), leading to paralysis.
  • Non-Depolarizing Blockers: Act as competitive antagonists at the ACh receptor. Examples include rocuronium, vecuronium, and [[243d4db1|pancuronium]]. Their effects are reversible with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.
  • Clinical Use: Primarily used during anesthesia to facilitate endotracheal intubation and provide optimal surgical conditions by relaxing skeletal muscles.
  • Monitoring: The degree of blockade is monitored using a peripheral nerve stimulator to assess the train-of-four (TOF) response.
  • Adverse Effects: Succinylcholine can cause hyperkalemia and is a trigger for malignant hyperthermia. Non-depolarizing agents can cause histamine release (hypotension).
content.takeAway: Neuromuscular blocking drugs achieve paralysis through two opposing mechanisms at the acetylcholine receptor: succinylcholine by overstimulation (depolarizing) and drugs like rocuronium by competitive inhibition (non-depolarizing), a distinction critical for their clinical use and reversal.

content.definition: The Neuromuscular Junction (NMJ) is a highly specialized synapse between the axon terminal of a motor neuron and the motor end plate of a skeletal muscle fiber, responsible for converting the neuron's electrical signal into muscle contraction.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurotransmitter: The sole neurotransmitter at the NMJ is acetylcholine (ACh).
  • Receptor: ACh binds to nicotinic (NM) receptors on the postsynaptic muscle membrane (motor end plate).
  • Mechanism: An action potential arriving at the axon terminal triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. Ca2+ influx causes the release of ACh into the synaptic cleft. ACh binds to NM receptors, opening them to allow Na+ influx, which generates an end-plate potential and triggers a muscle action potential.
  • Pathology: The NMJ is the site of pathology in several diseases:
    - Myasthenia Gravis: Autoantibodies against postsynaptic ACh receptors.
    - Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: Autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
    - Botulism: Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, preventing presynaptic ACh release.
  • Pharmacology: Targeted by [[1aaaffd2|neuromuscular blocking drugs]] used in anesthesia.
content.takeAway: The Neuromuscular Junction is a high-fidelity synapse designed for obligatory one-to-one transmission, where every motor neuron action potential reliably leads to a muscle fiber action potential, a process that can be disrupted by autoantibodies or toxins, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Motor Neuron AP] --> B(Ca2+ Influx); B --> C(ACh Release); C --> D(Binds to Nicotinic Receptors); D --> E(Na+ Influx); E --> F(End-Plate Potential); F --> G(Muscle AP & Contraction);

content.definition: Myoclonic seizures are a type of generalized seizure characterized by sudden, brief, shock-like muscle jerks or twitches. They are typically bilateral and often affect the upper extremities, without a loss of consciousness.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Sudden, involuntary muscle contractions that may be isolated or occur in clusters. Consciousness is usually preserved, and there is no postictal state.
  • Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME): Myoclonic seizures are a hallmark of JME, a common epilepsy syndrome with adolescent onset. In JME, myoclonic jerks are most prominent in the morning shortly after awakening.
  • Other Associations: Myoclonus can also be a feature of other conditions, including metabolic encephalopathies (e.g., uremia), anoxic brain injury, and prion diseases like [[86fe59ba|Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease]] (startle myoclonus).
  • Treatment: Broad-spectrum anticonvulsants like [[valproic_acid|valproic acid]] are effective. Narrow-spectrum agents like carbamazepine and phenytoin can paradoxically worsen myoclonic seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: A teenager who reports dropping their coffee cup or toothbrush in the morning due to sudden arm jerks is a classic presentation for Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy.
content.takeAway: Myoclonic seizures are distinguished by their brief, shock-like muscle jerks without loss of consciousness. Their characteristic occurrence upon awakening in adolescents is a key diagnostic clue for Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy.

content.definition: Myoclonus is a clinical sign characterized by a sudden, brief, shock-like, involuntary muscle jerk or twitch. It can be a symptom of a wide range of underlying neurological disorders, including epilepsy, metabolic encephalopathies, and neurodegenerative diseases.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: A quick, involuntary muscle contraction. It can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. Examples range from benign hiccups to the severe jerks seen in certain epilepsies.
  • Epileptic Myoclonus: Occurs as part of a [[1c6cb12b|myoclonic seizure]], as seen in Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy.
  • Metabolic Myoclonus: Often seen in metabolic encephalopathies such as uremic or hepatic encephalopathy.
  • Post-hypoxic Myoclonus (Lance-Adams Syndrome): A debilitating action myoclonus that can occur after a severe hypoxic brain injury.
  • Neurodegenerative Disease: Prominent 'startle myoclonus' (jerks in response to loud sounds or touch) is a characteristic feature of [[86fe59ba|Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease]].
  • USMLE Tip: The clinical context is key to interpreting myoclonus. In an adolescent, think JME. In a patient with rapidly progressive dementia, think CJD. In a patient with renal failure, think uremic encephalopathy.
content.takeAway: Myoclonus is a non-specific sign of neuronal hyperexcitability that can originate from the cortex, brainstem, or spinal cord. Its diagnostic value lies in its association with other clinical features, which helps to pinpoint the underlying etiology.

content.definition: Myopia, commonly known as nearsightedness, is a refractive error of the eye in which parallel light rays from distant objects are focused in front of the retina, causing distant objects to appear blurry while near objects are seen clearly.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Occurs when the eye is either too long (axial myopia) or the cornea/lens system has too much refractive power (refractive myopia).
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients can see near objects clearly but have difficulty seeing distant objects (e.g., a chalkboard, road signs).
  • Correction: Corrected with a concave (diverging) lens (e.g., glasses or contact lenses with a negative diopter prescription). The diverging lens spreads out the light rays before they enter the eye, effectively moving the focal point backward onto the retina.
  • Complications: High myopia is a risk factor for [[38c092f9|retinal detachment]] and glaucoma.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the correction: Myopia (nearsightedness) requires a diverging (concave) lens. Hyperopia (farsightedness) requires a converging (convex) lens.
content.takeAway: Myopia is a mismatch between the eye's focusing power and its length, causing distant images to be focused in the vitreous humor instead of on the retina. This is corrected by using a concave lens to diverge the light rays and push the focal point back to its proper location.

content.definition: Ménière disease is a disorder of the inner ear characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus, caused by an increase in the volume and pressure of endolymph (endolymphatic hydrops).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by endolymphatic hydrops, an excessive accumulation of endolymph in the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear, leading to distention and potential rupture of these membranes.
  • Classic Triad:
    1. Episodic Vertigo: Spontaneous, recurrent episodes of spinning vertigo that can last from minutes to hours.
    2. Sensorineural Hearing Loss: Typically fluctuating and low-frequency in the early stages, becoming permanent over time.
    3. Tinnitus: Ringing or roaring sound in the affected ear, often low-pitched.
  • Associated Symptom: A feeling of aural fullness or pressure in the affected ear is also common.
  • Treatment: Management focuses on symptom control. A low-salt diet and diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) are used to reduce endolymphatic pressure. Antiemetics and vestibular suppressants are used for acute vertigo attacks.
  • USMLE Tip: The triad of episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss is the key to diagnosing Ménière disease.
content.takeAway: Ménière disease is essentially 'glaucoma of the inner ear,' where an excess of endolymphatic fluid increases pressure within the labyrinth, leading to a characteristic triad of episodic vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus due to dysfunction of both the vestibular and cochlear apparatus.

content.definition: Nitrous oxide (N2O), commonly known as laughing gas, is an inhaled general anesthetic with low potency but rapid onset and recovery, used for its analgesic and anxiolytic effects, often in combination with other anesthetics.
content.atAGlance:
• Pharmacokinetics: Has a low blood:gas partition coefficient, meaning it is poorly soluble in blood. This results in a very rapid onset of action and a rapid recovery upon discontinuation.
  • Potency: Has a high MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration), indicating low anesthetic potency. It cannot produce surgical anesthesia on its own and is typically used as an adjunct to more potent volatile anesthetics.
  • Effects: Provides good analgesia but is a weak anesthetic. It has minimal effects on the cardiovascular and respiratory systems compared to other inhaled agents.
  • Adverse Effects: The main concern is its tendency to diffuse into and expand gas-filled cavities in the body (e.g., pneumothorax, bowel obstruction, middle ear). Chronic exposure can lead to megaloblastic anemia by oxidizing vitamin B12.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that low blood solubility (low blood:gas coefficient) means fast induction and recovery. N2O is the classic example of this principle.
content.takeAway: Nitrous oxide is a fast-on, fast-off anesthetic due to its low blood solubility, but its low potency prevents its use as a sole agent for surgery. Its unique property of expanding gas-filled spaces makes it contraindicated in conditions like pneumothorax.

content.definition: Nalbuphine is a synthetic opioid analgesic with a mixed agonist-antagonist profile, acting as a κ-opioid receptor agonist and a μ-opioid receptor partial agonist or antagonist.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: It is a κ-opioid receptor agonist, which provides analgesia. It is also a μ-opioid receptor antagonist.
  • Clinical Use: Used for the management of moderate to severe pain. It can also be used as a supplement to balanced anesthesia.
  • Ceiling Effect: Due to its mixed agonist-antagonist properties, it exhibits a ceiling effect for respiratory depression, meaning that beyond a certain dose, further increases do not cause greater respiratory depression. This makes it potentially safer than full μ-agonists like morphine.
  • Precipitation of Withdrawal: Because it is a μ-antagonist, administering nalbuphine to a patient who is physically dependent on a full μ-agonist (e.g., heroin, morphine) can precipitate an acute opioid withdrawal syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mixed agonist-antagonist opioids (nalbuphine, butorphanol, pentazocine). Their key features are the ceiling effect on respiratory depression and the risk of precipitating withdrawal in opioid-dependent individuals.
content.takeAway: Nalbuphine offers analgesia primarily through κ-receptor agonism while its μ-receptor antagonism provides a safety advantage with a ceiling effect on respiratory depression, but this same property makes it dangerous to use in patients already dependent on full μ-agonist opioids.

content.definition: Naltrexone is a long-acting, orally available opioid antagonist used primarily for the management of alcohol and opioid use disorders by reducing cravings and blocking the euphoric effects of opioids.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at μ-opioid receptors (and to a lesser extent, κ and δ receptors).
  • Use in Opioid Use Disorder: Blocks the euphoric and sedative effects of opioids, helping to prevent relapse in highly motivated individuals who have already undergone detoxification. It will precipitate withdrawal if given to a patient currently using opioids.
  • Use in Alcohol Use Disorder: Reduces the rewarding effects of alcohol and cravings, likely by modulating the dopaminergic mesolimbic pathway via the endogenous opioid system.
  • Pharmacokinetics: It is long-acting and available in oral and long-acting injectable formulations.
  • Adverse Effects: Hepatotoxicity is a major concern, especially at high doses, requiring monitoring of liver function tests.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from naloxone: Naloxone is short-acting and used for acute opioid overdose reversal. Naltrexone is long-acting and used for relapse prevention (maintenance therapy).
content.takeAway: Naltrexone helps maintain abstinence in both alcohol and opioid dependence by blocking the 'reward' pathway; it competitively occupies opioid receptors, preventing opioids from producing euphoria and reducing the pleasurable effects of alcohol.

content.definition: Narrow-spectrum anticonvulsants are antiepileptic drugs that are primarily effective for treating focal seizures (both aware and impaired awareness) and may be ineffective or even worsen certain types of generalized seizures, such as absence or myoclonic seizures.
content.atAGlance:
• Examples: Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, Gabapentin, Pregabalin, Oxcarbazepine.
  • Primary Indication: First-line agents for [[e46906ba|focal seizures]]. They can also be used for focal seizures that secondarily generalize.
  • Mechanism: Many (like carbamazepine and phenytoin) work by blocking voltage-gated Na+ channels, which preferentially inhibits high-frequency firing characteristic of seizures.
  • Contraindication: These drugs can exacerbate absence and myoclonic seizures. Therefore, accurate seizure classification is crucial before initiating therapy.
  • USMLE Tip: For a patient with focal seizures, a narrow-spectrum agent like carbamazepine is an appropriate choice. For a patient with mixed seizure types (e.g., absence and tonic-clonic), a broad-spectrum agent like valproic acid is preferred.
content.takeAway: Narrow-spectrum anticonvulsants are specialized tools for focal epilepsy; their use requires a precise diagnosis, as their application in certain generalized epilepsies (like absence or myoclonic) can paradoxically worsen seizure control.

content.definition: Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that targets the α4-integrin, used as a disease-modifying therapy for relapsing forms of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and Crohn disease.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Binds to the α4-subunit of integrins (specifically α4β1-integrin, also known as VLA-4) on the surface of leukocytes. This blocks the interaction of leukocytes with vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) on endothelial cells.
  • Effect: By blocking this interaction, natalizumab prevents lymphocytes from migrating across the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]] into the CNS parenchyma, thereby reducing the inflammatory demyelinating lesions of [[45dd6d19|MS]].
  • Clinical Use: Highly effective for reducing relapse rates in patients with active relapsing-remitting [[45dd6d19|MS]]. Also used for moderate to severe Crohn disease.
  • Major Adverse Effect: The most serious risk is the development of Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML), a rare and often fatal brain infection caused by reactivation of the JC virus.
  • USMLE Tip: The association between natalizumab and PML is extremely high-yield. Patients must be tested for JC virus antibodies before starting therapy and monitored closely.
content.takeAway: Natalizumab acts as a 'gatekeeper' for the blood-brain barrier, preventing inflammatory lymphocytes from entering the CNS.
