While highly effective for MS, this powerful immunosuppressive mechanism carries the significant risk of allowing latent JC virus to reactivate, leading to PML.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lymphocyte] --α4-Integrin--> B(VCAM-1 on BBB); B --> C(CNS Infiltration); D[Natalizumab] --|Blocks|--> A;

content.definition: Nausea is the unpleasant sensation of the urge to vomit. It is a complex protective reflex coordinated by the vomiting center in the brainstem, which receives inputs from multiple sources.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurological Control: The vomiting center is located in the medulla and receives inputs from:
    - The chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the [[5dd343d3|area postrema]], which senses toxins in the blood.
    - The vestibular system (motion sickness).
    - The GI tract (via the vagus nerve).
    - The CNS (e.g., from increased intracranial pressure or psychological stimuli).
  • Migraine Headaches: Nausea is a key diagnostic criterion for [[26661e34|migraine headaches]], often accompanying the pulsating head pain.
  • Increased Intracranial Pressure: Nausea and vomiting, especially projectile vomiting without preceding nausea, are classic signs of elevated ICP.
  • Pharmacology: Antiemetic drugs target the various receptors in the vomiting pathways, including dopamine (D2), serotonin (5-HT3), histamine (H1), acetylcholine (M1), and neurokinin (NK1) receptors.
  • USMLE Tip: Nausea and vomiting associated with a headache that is worse in the morning or awakens the patient from sleep is a red flag for a brain tumor or other cause of increased ICP.
content.takeAway: Nausea is a centrally mediated sensation orchestrated by the brainstem's vomiting center, which integrates a wide array of inputs from the blood, gut, and brain itself to signal potential harm and trigger the urge to vomit.

content.definition: Nearsightedness, clinically known as myopia, is a common refractive error where light from distant objects is focused in front of the retina, causing distant vision to be blurry while near vision remains clear.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Occurs when the eyeball is too long (axial myopia) or the cornea and lens have too much focusing power (refractive myopia).
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients can see near objects clearly but have difficulty seeing distant objects (e.g., a chalkboard, road signs).
  • Correction: Corrected with a concave (diverging) lens (e.g., glasses or contact lenses with a negative diopter prescription). The diverging lens spreads out the light rays before they enter the eye, effectively moving the focal point backward onto the retina.
  • Complications: High myopia is a risk factor for [[38c092f9|retinal detachment]] and glaucoma.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the correction: Myopia (nearsightedness) requires a diverging (concave) lens. Hyperopia (farsightedness) requires a converging (convex) lens.
content.takeAway: Nearsightedness is a mismatch between the eye's focusing power and its length, causing distant images to be focused in the vitreous humor instead of on the retina. This is corrected by using a concave lens to diverge the light rays and push the focal point back to its proper location.

content.definition: Necrosis is a hallmark pathological feature of [[b6bbd0bc|Glioblastoma (GBM)]], the most aggressive primary brain tumor. It results from the tumor outgrowing its blood supply and is a key component of its characteristic histological and radiological appearance.
content.atAGlance:
• Histological Appearance: The necrosis in GBM is classically surrounded by a rim of hypercellular, malignant tumor cells, a pattern known as pseudopalisading necrosis. This is a pathognomonic finding.
  • Radiological Appearance: The central necrosis, combined with peripheral tumor cell proliferation and neovascularity, creates the typical ring-enhancing lesion seen on contrast-enhanced MRI. The center is necrotic (non-enhancing) while the viable, vascular tumor at the edge enhances brightly.
  • Pathophysiology: Rapid tumor growth leads to hypoxia and subsequent necrosis in the tumor core. Hypoxia, in turn, stimulates the production of angiogenic factors like VEGF, promoting microvascular proliferation at the tumor's edge.
  • Clinical Significance: The presence of necrosis is a key feature that distinguishes glioblastoma (WHO grade IV astrocytoma) from lower-grade astrocytomas.
  • USMLE Tip: The phrase "pseudopalisading necrosis" on a pathology report for a brain tumor is a buzzword for [[b6bbd0bc|glioblastoma]].
content.takeAway: In [[b6bbd0bc|glioblastoma]], necrosis is not just cell death but a driver of malignancy; the resulting hypoxia triggers aggressive angiogenesis, fueling the tumor's rapid growth and creating the characteristic and ominous ring-enhancing appearance on MRI.

content.definition: Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS) is a postnatal drug withdrawal syndrome that occurs in newborns who were exposed to addictive substances, most commonly opioids, in utero.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by the abrupt cessation of fetal exposure to substances like opioids (heroin, methadone, prescription painkillers), benzodiazepines, or SSRIs upon delivery.
  • Pathophysiology: The fetus develops physical dependence on the substance crossing the placenta. After birth, the supply is cut off, leading to a withdrawal syndrome.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms typically begin within 24-72 hours of birth. The infant exhibits signs of CNS hyper-excitability, autonomic dysfunction, and GI disturbances.
  • Key Symptoms: High-pitched, inconsolable crying, irritability, poor feeding, tremors, increased muscle tone, sweating, sneezing, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • Treatment: Management is primarily supportive (swaddling, quiet environment, frequent small feeds). Pharmacotherapy with opioids (e.g., morphine, methadone) is used for severe withdrawal, with doses gradually tapered.
  • USMLE Tip: A newborn who is irritable, has a high-pitched cry, is tremulous, and has diarrhea and vomiting should raise immediate suspicion for NAS, especially if there is a maternal history of substance use.
content.takeAway: Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome is a tragic consequence of in-utero drug exposure, where the newborn experiences a state of acute withdrawal characterized by profound CNS and autonomic hyper-excitability, manifesting as an inconsolably irritable and physically distressed infant.

content.definition: Neonatal neurological complications are injuries to the brain and skull that occur during the perinatal period, often related to the mechanical stresses of labor and delivery or the physiological vulnerabilities of prematurity.
content.atAGlance:
• Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH): Bleeding into the ventricles, most common in premature infants. Originates from the fragile germinal matrix. Can lead to hydrocephalus and long-term neurological deficits.
  • Extracranial Injuries:
    - Caput Succedaneum: Benign, edematous swelling of the scalp above the periosteum that crosses suture lines.
    - Cephalohematoma: Subperiosteal hemorrhage that is limited by and does not cross suture lines. Can increase risk of jaundice.
    - Subgaleal Hemorrhage: Potentially life-threatening bleed into the space between the periosteum and the scalp aponeurosis.
  • Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE): Brain injury due to oxygen deprivation during the perinatal period.
  • USMLE Tip: The key to differentiating scalp hematomas is their relationship to suture lines. Caput crosses cutures. Cephalohematoma is contained.
content.takeAway: The neonatal brain is uniquely vulnerable to both mechanical and ischemic insults during birth. Differentiating between benign findings like caput succedaneum and serious complications like intraventricular hemorrhage is critical for appropriate management and prognosis.

content.definition: Nerve fibers are the axons of neurons, classified based on their diameter, myelination status, and conduction velocity, which determines their specific sensory or motor function.
content.atAGlance:
• Aα fibers: Large diameter, heavily myelinated. The fastest conducting fibers. Function: proprioception (from muscle spindles, Golgi tendon organs) and somatic motor (alpha motor neurons).
  • Aβ fibers: Medium diameter, myelinated. Function: touch, pressure, vibration.
  • Aδ fibers: Small diameter, thinly myelinated. Function: transmit fast, sharp, well-localized pain and cold temperature.
  • C fibers: Smallest diameter, unmyelinated. The slowest conducting fibers. Function: transmit slow, dull, poorly-localized pain and warmth. Also include postganglionic autonomic fibers.
  • Clinical Relevance: Local anesthetics preferentially block small, myelinated fibers first, which is why pain sensation (Aδ and C fibers) is lost before touch (Aβ fibers).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the two types of pain fibers: Aδ for the initial 'ouch' and C fibers for the subsequent 'ache'.
content.takeAway: The structure of a nerve fiber dictates its function; large, myelinated fibers are built for speed to transmit motor commands and discriminative touch, while small, unmyelinated fibers are designed for the slower, more persistent signaling of dull pain and temperature.

content.definition: Motion sickness is a condition characterized by nausea, vomiting, and dizziness, caused by a mismatch between visually perceived movement and the vestibular system's sense of movement.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Occurs due to a conflict between the vestibular, visual, and proprioceptive systems. The brain receives contradictory information about the body's state of motion, which activates the [[74b651ab|vomiting center]] in the brainstem.
  • Key Neurotransmitters: The pathways involved in motion sickness heavily rely on histaminic (H1) and muscarinic cholinergic (M1) signaling.
  • Treatment (Antimuscarinics): Scopolamine, an antimuscarinic agent, is highly effective for prevention. It is often used as a transdermal patch.
  • Treatment (Antihistamines): First-generation antihistamines with anticholinergic properties, such as diphenhydramine, dimenhydrinate, and meclizine, are also effective.
  • USMLE Tip: The primary pharmacological targets for preventing motion sickness are H1 and M1 receptors in the brainstem. Scopolamine (antimuscarinic) and first-generation antihistamines are the mainstays of therapy.
content.takeAway: Motion sickness is a sensory conflict disorder where the brain's confusion about movement triggers the vomiting reflex; treatment is aimed at blocking the histaminic and cholinergic pathways that mediate this distressing response.

content.definition: The Motor Cortex is the region of the cerebral cortex involved in the planning, control, and execution of voluntary movements. It is located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Motor Cortex (M1): Located in the precentral gyrus. It is responsible for the execution of voluntary movements.
  • Topographic Representation (Homunculus): The primary motor cortex has a somatotopic organization, where different body parts are represented by distinct areas. The face and hands have disproportionately large representations. The legs and feet are represented on the medial surface of the hemisphere.
  • Blood Supply: The lateral portion (face, arm) is supplied by the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]]. The medial portion (leg) is supplied by the [[830c856c|Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)]].
  • Thalamic Relay: Receives major input from the ventral lateral (VL) nucleus of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]], which relays signals from the basal ganglia and cerebellum.
  • USMLE Tip: The vascular supply of the motor homunculus is a high-yield topic for localizing strokes. An ACA stroke causes contralateral leg weakness, while an MCA stroke causes contralateral face and arm weakness.
content.takeAway: The Motor Cortex is the final common pathway for the execution of voluntary movement, with its somatotopic map (homunculus) directly reflecting the fine motor control required for different body parts, a map whose vascular territories are critical for stroke localization.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Basal Ganglia & Cerebellum] --> B(VL Nucleus of Thalamus); B --> C(Motor Cortex); C --> D(Corticospinal Tract); D --> E(Voluntary Movement);

content.definition: Motor function refers to the body's ability to move, which is controlled by a complex network involving the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord, culminating in the contraction of skeletal muscles.
content.atAGlance:
• Upper Motor Neurons (UMNs): Originate in the motor cortex and descend to synapse on lower motor neurons. Lesions cause spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign.
  • Lower Motor Neurons (LMNs): Originate in the anterior horn of the spinal cord or brainstem cranial nerve nuclei and synapse directly on muscles. Lesions cause flaccid paralysis, atrophy, fasciculations, and hyporeflexia.
  • Abnormal Motor Posturing: Decorticate and decerebrate posturing are signs of severe brain injury, indicating damage at or above (decorticate) or below (decerebrate) the red nucleus.
  • Dysarthria: A motor speech disorder resulting from impaired movement of the muscles used for speech production.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiating between UMN and LMN signs is a fundamental skill in neurology. Remember: Upper = everything is Up (tone, reflexes, toes); Lower = everything is Lowered (tone, reflexes, muscle mass).
content.takeAway: The control of motor function is hierarchically organized, with upper motor neurons providing the command and lower motor neurons executing it; the clinical signs resulting from a lesion depend entirely on which level of this hierarchy is disrupted.

content.definition: Motor neuron signs are the clinical findings that result from damage to the motor nervous system, which are categorized into upper motor neuron (UMN) signs and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs, allowing for the localization of neurological lesions.
content.atAGlance:
• Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) Signs: Result from lesions of the corticospinal tracts. Include spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, and a positive Babinski sign. No significant muscle atrophy initially.
  • Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) Signs: Result from lesions of the anterior horn cells, spinal roots, or peripheral nerves. Include flaccid paralysis, significant muscle atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, and decreased muscle tone.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): A classic example of a disease that presents with a combination of both UMN and LMN signs.
  • Anterior Spinal Artery Occlusion: Causes damage to the anterior horns (LMN signs at the level of the lesion) and corticospinal tracts (UMN signs below the level of the lesion).
  • Brown-Séquard Syndrome: Causes ipsilateral UMN signs below the level of the hemisection.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of both UMN and LMN signs in the same patient is a strong clue for [[4ed629f9|ALS]].
content.takeAway: The distinction between upper and lower motor neuron signs is fundamental to clinical neurology; UMN signs reflect a loss of central inhibition leading to hyperreflexia and spasticity, while LMN signs reflect a loss of direct muscle innervation leading to flaccidity and atrophy.

content.definition: Movement disorders are a group of neurological conditions characterized by abnormalities in the quality and quantity of voluntary and involuntary movements, typically resulting from dysfunction of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]] or cerebellum.
content.atAGlance:
• Hypokinetic Disorders: Characterized by a poverty of movement (akinesia/bradykinesia), rigidity, and tremor. The classic example is [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
  • Hyperkinetic Disorders: Characterized by excessive, abnormal, involuntary movements. Examples include:
    - Chorea: Rapid, jerky, purposeless movements (e.g., [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]).
    - Athetosis: Slow, writhing movements (e.g., [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]).
    - Dystonia: Sustained muscle contractions causing twisting movements or abnormal postures.
    - [[004e0bd6|Hemiballismus]]: Wild, flinging movements of one side of the body.
  • Neurodegenerative Causes: Many movement disorders are manifestations of underlying [[41ca6981|neurodegenerative disorders]], such as [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].
  • Abnormal Posturing: [[c0b7a1ca|Decorticate and decerebrate posturing]] are specific types of abnormal movements seen in comatose patients with severe brain injury.
content.takeAway: Movement disorders represent a spectrum of dysfunction in the brain's motor control circuits, ranging from the 'too little' movement of Parkinsonism to the 'too much' movement of chorea and ballismus, all pointing to pathology within the basal ganglia and its connections.

content.definition: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic, autoimmune, inflammatory disease of the central nervous system characterized by the demyelination of axons, leading to a wide range of neurological deficits that are disseminated in space and time.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Autoreactive T-cells cross the blood-brain barrier and attack the myelin sheath produced by [[a24f9747|oligodendrocytes]], leading to inflammation, demyelination, and axonal damage.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms vary widely depending on the location of the demyelinating plaques. Common presentations include [[98a63a59|optic neuritis]], transverse myelitis, [[58c684bd|internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)]], and sensory or motor deficits. Symptoms often worsen with heat (Uhthoff's phenomenon).
  • Diagnosis: MRI is the gold standard, showing characteristic periventricular plaques (Dawson's fingers). CSF analysis reveals oligoclonal bands of IgG and an elevated IgG index.
  • Classic Triad (Charcot): A historical triad of Scanning speech, Intention tremor, and Nystagmus (SIN).
  • Treatment: Acute flares are treated with high-dose corticosteroids. Long-term management involves disease-modifying therapies like [[00e48ea3|interferon-β]], glatiramer acetate, and [[ae20a0ce|natalizumab]]. Symptomatic treatment for spasticity ([[1ddc3f08|baclofen]]), neuropathic pain, and bladder dysfunction is also important.
  • USMLE Tip: A young woman with relapsing and remitting neurological symptoms affecting different parts of the CNS (e.g., an episode of optic neuritis followed months later by leg weakness) is the classic vignette for MS.
content.takeAway: Multiple Sclerosis is defined by its pathological hallmark of CNS demyelination disseminated in space and time, leading to a highly variable clinical course of relapsing and remitting neurological deficits that reflect the multifocal nature of the autoimmune attack.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Autoimmune Attack] --> B(Destruction of Oligodendrocytes); B --> C(CNS Demyelination); C --> D(Plaque Formation); D --> E(Neurological Deficits);

content.definition: Muscarinic antagonists, also known as anticholinergics, are drugs that competitively block the action of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] at muscarinic receptors, thereby inhibiting the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Examples: Atropine, scopolamine, ipratropium, tiotropium, oxybutynin, tolterodine, [[383f6fbe|benztropine]], trihexyphenidyl.
  • Mechanism of Action: Competitively inhibit ACh at muscarinic receptors in the CNS and periphery.
  • Effects: Mydriasis, cycloplegia, tachycardia, bronchodilation, decreased GI motility, decreased secretions (salivary, gastric, bronchial), and urinary retention. Mnemonic for anticholinergic effects: "Hot as a hare, dry as a bone, blind as a bat, red as a beet, mad as a hatter."
  • Neurological Use (Parkinson's): Centrally acting agents like [[383f6fbe|benztropine]] and trihexyphenidyl are used to treat tremor and rigidity in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] by correcting the relative cholinergic excess.
  • Neurological Use (MS): Drugs like oxybutynin are used to treat spastic (hyperreflexic) bladder and urge incontinence in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]].
  • USMLE Tip: Be aware of the contraindications, especially in the elderly (risk of delirium, constipation, urinary retention) and in patients with [[9c80344d|angle-closure glaucoma]].
content.takeAway: Muscarinic antagonists act as a system-wide 'off switch' for the parasympathetic nervous system, producing a predictable constellation of anticholinergic effects that are therapeutically useful in conditions ranging from COPD to Parkinson's disease, but also responsible for their significant side effect profile.

content.definition: Muscarinic receptors are a type of G-protein coupled acetylcholine receptor that are the primary end-organ receptors for the parasympathetic nervous system. They are also found in the CNS and at sympathetic postganglionic synapses to sweat glands.
content.atAGlance:
• Ligand: [[6a005559|Acetylcholine (ACh)]].
  • Subtypes & Signaling:
    - M1 (Gq): CNS, enteric nervous system.
    - M2 (Gi): Heart (decreases heart rate and contractility).
    - M3 (Gq): Smooth muscle (contraction, e.g., bronchoconstriction, bladder contraction), glands (secretion), and endothelium (vasodilation via NO).
  • Vomiting Center Input: M1 receptors are present in the vestibular nuclei and nucleus tractus solitarius, and their blockade (e.g., by scopolamine) is effective for [[511db4d8|motion sickness]].
  • Pharmacology: Agonists (e.g., pilocarpine, bethanechol) mimic parasympathetic effects. Antagonists (e.g., atropine, ipratropium) block parasympathetic effects.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the G-protein coupling mnemonic: "QISS QIQ SIQ SQS" (Kiss kick six six). For muscarinic receptors: M1 (Q), M2 (I), M3 (Q).
content.takeAway: Muscarinic receptors are the workhorses of the parasympathetic nervous system, translating the signal of acetylcholine into diverse physiological effects—from slowing the heart (M2) to increasing secretions and smooth muscle contraction (M3)—via distinct G-protein signaling pathways.

46380156.title: Loss of Muscle Atonia in REM Sleep

content.definition: Loss of muscle atonia in REM sleep is the cardinal feature of REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD), a parasomnia where the normal paralysis that occurs during REM sleep is absent, leading patients to physically act out their dreams.
content.atAGlance:
• Normal REM Sleep: Characterized by rapid eye movements, dreaming, and near-complete muscle paralysis (atonia), which prevents individuals from acting out their dreams.
  • Pathophysiology of RBD: The loss of atonia is thought to be due to dysfunction in the brainstem nuclei (e.g., subcoeruleus nucleus) that normally inhibit motor neurons during REM sleep.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients (often older men) exhibit dream-enacting behaviors, which can be violent and result in injury to themselves or their bed partners. They can often recall the dream content that corresponds to their actions.
  • Strong Association with Neurodegeneration: RBD is a very strong predictor of future development of an α-synucleinopathy, such as [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]], or multiple system atrophy. It can precede the motor symptoms of these disorders by years or even decades.
  • USMLE Tip: An older male patient who reports punching or kicking his spouse in his sleep while having vivid dreams is the classic presentation for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder. This finding should raise high suspicion for an underlying or future neurodegenerative disease like Parkinson's.
content.takeAway: The loss of muscle atonia during REM sleep is not just a sleep disturbance but a significant prodromal marker for α-synuclein neurodegenerative diseases, representing one of the earliest clinical manifestations of these devastating conditions.

content.definition: Muscle spasm treatment involves the use of pharmacologic agents known as spasmolytics or muscle relaxants, which act either centrally in the CNS or peripherally at the muscle to reduce involuntary muscle contractions, tone, and spasticity.
content.atAGlance:
• Spasticity vs. Spasms: Spasticity is velocity-dependent increased muscle tone from a UMN lesion. Spasms are involuntary contractions from musculoskeletal injury. Different drugs are used for each.
  • Agents for Spasticity (UMN lesions):
    - [[1ddc3f08|Baclofen]]: A GABAB receptor agonist that acts in the spinal cord.
    - Tizanidine: A central α2-adrenergic agonist.
    - Diazepam: A benzodiazepine that facilitates GABAA action.
  • Agents for Acute Muscle Spasms:
    - Cyclobenzaprine: A centrally acting agent structurally related to TCAs.
  • Agent Acting Directly on Muscle:
    - Dantrolene: Blocks Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Used for malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome, as well as chronic spasticity.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the site of action. Baclofen and Tizanidine are central (spinal cord/brainstem). Cyclobenzaprine is central. Dantrolene is peripheral (directly on the muscle).
content.takeAway: The pharmacological treatment of muscle spasms and spasticity relies on either dampening CNS excitatory signals (e.g., with baclofen or tizanidine) or directly interfering with the muscle contraction machinery (e.g., with dantrolene), with the choice of agent depending on the underlying cause of the muscle hyperactivity.

content.definition: The muscles of mastication are four pairs of muscles responsible for the movements of the mandible at the temporomandibular joint, primarily for chewing. They are all innervated by the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
content.atAGlance:
• Muscles that Close the Jaw (Elevation):
    - Masseter
    - Temporalis
    - Medial pterygoid
    Mnemonic: M's Munch.
  • Muscle that Opens the Jaw (Depression):
    - Lateral pterygoid. Mnemonic: Lateral Lowers.
  • Innervation: All four muscles are innervated by the motor branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • Embryology: Derived from the first pharyngeal arch.
  • Clinical Relevance: A lesion of the motor root of CN V or the V3 branch will cause weakness of the muscles of mastication. On jaw protrusion, the jaw will deviate toward the side of the lesion due to the unopposed action of the contralateral lateral pterygoid muscle.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that all muscles of mastication are innervated by V3. Jaw deviation toward the lesion is a key sign of a V3 motor deficit.
content.takeAway: The four muscles of mastication are a functional group defined by their shared innervation from CN V3 and their origin from the first pharyngeal arch, working in concert to elevate, depress, and move the mandible from side to side during chewing.

content.definition: Mydriasis is the dilation of the pupil, which can be a physiological response to dim light or a pathological or pharmacological sign.
content.atAGlance:
• Physiology: Mediated by the sympathetic nervous system. Postganglionic sympathetic fibers release norepinephrine, which acts on α1-adrenergic receptors on the dilator pupillae muscle, causing it to contract.
  • Pharmacological Causes: Can be induced by sympathomimetic agents (e.g., epinephrine, phenylephrine) or anticholinergic/antimuscarinic agents (e.g., atropine, tropicamide), which block the parasympathetic constriction of the pupil.
  • Pathological Causes: A fixed, dilated ("blown") pupil is a classic sign of a compressive [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy]], as seen with an uncal herniation or a [[a1647fb2|posterior communicating artery aneurysm]].
  • Meperidine Exception: Unlike most opioids which cause miosis, meperidine can cause mydriasis due to its anticholinergic properties.
  • USMLE Tip: A unilaterally dilated and nonreactive pupil is a neurological emergency. It is a key sign of uncal herniation compressing CN III.
content.takeAway: Mydriasis results from either sympathetic activation (contraction of the dilator muscle) or parasympathetic blockade (relaxation of the sphincter muscle); its presence, especially when unilateral and fixed, is a critical sign of potential oculomotor nerve compression.

content.definition: The Myelencephalon is the most caudal of the five secondary brain vesicles that arise from the embryonic neural tube. It develops from the posterior part of the hindbrain (rhombencephalon) and gives rise to the medulla oblongata.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryonic Origin: Arises from the posterior portion of the rhombencephalon (hindbrain).
  • Adult Derivative: Differentiates into the medulla oblongata, the lowest part of the brainstem.
  • Associated Cavity: The cavity of the myelencephalon becomes the lower part of the fourth ventricle.
  • Cranial Nerves: The nuclei for cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII are located in the medulla, and thus originate from the myelencephalon.
  • Mnemonic for Vesicles: The five secondary vesicles in rostral to caudal order are Telencephalon, Diencephalon, Mesencephalon, Metencephalon, and Myelencephalon.
content.takeAway: The Myelencephalon is the final segment of the developing brain, forming the medulla oblongata, which serves as the critical connection between the higher brain centers and the spinal cord and contains the nuclei for vital autonomic functions.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Rhombencephalon (Hindbrain)] --> B(Metencephalon); A --> C(Myelencephalon); C --> D(Medulla Oblongata); C --> E(Lower Fourth Ventricle);

content.definition: A myelomeningocele is the most severe form of spina bifida, an open neural tube defect where both the meninges and the spinal cord herniate through a defect in the vertebral column, forming a cystic sac on the infant's back.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Results from the failure of the caudal neuropore of the [[a87cbede|neural tube]] to close during the 4th week of embryonic development.
  • Clinical Presentation: A visible sac-like protrusion on the back, typically in the lumbosacral region. It is associated with neurological deficits below the level of the lesion, including lower extremity paralysis and bowel/bladder incontinence.
  • Associated Condition: Almost always associated with a Chiari II malformation, which can lead to obstructive [[0bc2f200|hydrocephalus]].
  • Diagnosis: Can be diagnosed prenatally by ultrasound and elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from a meningocele, where only the meninges herniate and the spinal cord remains in the canal. Myelomeningocele involves herniation of the 'myelo' (spinal cord) itself, leading to severe neurological deficits.
content.takeAway: A myelomeningocele represents a catastrophic failure of neurulation, where the spinal cord itself is exposed and herniated, leading to inevitable and permanent neurological damage below the lesion and a near-universal association with Chiari II malformation and hydrocephalus.

content.definition: Myeloschisis (or rachischisis) is the most severe form of spina bifida, an open neural tube defect where the neural folds fail to fuse, resulting in a flattened, plate-like mass of nervous tissue that is directly exposed to the environment without any overlying meningeal or skin covering.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Represents a complete failure of primary neurulation in the affected region. The neural plate is open and exposed on the surface of the back.
  • Clinical Presentation: A raw, exposed plaque of neural tissue is visible on the infant's back. This leads to profound and complete neurological deficits below the level of the lesion.
  • Comparison to Myelomeningocele: It is more severe than a [[e9cd6754|myelomeningocele]], in which the herniated neural tissue is at least covered by meninges.
  • Prognosis: Carries a very poor prognosis due to the severe neurological impairment and high risk of infection.
  • USMLE Tip: This is the most severe form of neural tube defect. The key feature is the exposed, non-fused neural plate on the back.
content.takeAway: Myeloschisis represents the most fundamental failure of neural tube formation, where the neural folds do not even begin to fuse, leaving the primordial spinal cord exposed to the outside world and resulting in the most devastating neurological outcomes.

content.definition: Methemoglobinemia is a condition characterized by the presence of an abnormally high level of methemoglobin (MetHb) in the blood. Methemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin in which the iron in the heme group is in the ferric (Fe3+) state, rather than the ferrous (Fe2+) state, making it unable to bind oxygen.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The Fe3+ state not only prevents oxygen binding to that heme group but also causes a left shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve for the remaining normal hemoglobin, impairing oxygen release to tissues. This results in a functional anemia and tissue hypoxia.
  • Causes: Can be congenital (e.g., cytochrome b5 reductase deficiency) or acquired. Acquired causes include exposure to oxidizing agents such as dapsone, nitrites (found in some well water and as preservatives), and topical/local anesthetics like benzocaine and prilocaine.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients present with cyanosis that is unresponsive to supplemental oxygen, and blood that is classically described as "chocolate-brown" in color. Pulse oximetry is unreliable and often reads around 85%.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed by co-oximetry of an arterial blood gas sample.
  • Treatment: The antidote is methylene blue, which acts as an electron donor to reduce Fe3+ back to Fe2+ via the NADPH-MetHb reductase pathway.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who develops cyanosis and shortness of breath after a dental procedure or endoscopy (where benzocaine spray is used) with chocolate-brown blood is a classic vignette for acquired methemoglobinemia.
content.takeAway: Methemoglobinemia is a state of 'iron rust' within hemoglobin, where oxidizing drugs convert functional Fe2+ to non-functional Fe3+, leading to a profound tissue hypoxia that is uniquely treated with the reducing agent methylene blue.

content.definition: Meyer's loop is the inferior portion of the optic radiation, a bundle of nerve fibers that curves from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus, sweeps anteriorly into the temporal lobe, and then projects posteriorly to the lower bank of the calcarine sulcus in the occipital lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathway: Carries visual information from the inferior retina (which corresponds to the superior visual field).
  • Location: Travels through the temporal lobe, looping around the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.
  • Lesion Effect: A lesion of Meyer's loop results in a contralateral superior quadrantanopia (loss of the upper quadrant of the visual field on the opposite side). This is often referred to as a "pie in the sky" defect.
  • Causes of Lesions: Can be damaged by strokes involving the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]], temporal lobe tumors, or temporal lobectomy surgery.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic L-M-N-O-P: Lateral geniculate nucleus to Meyer's loop (No, that's wrong). Better mnemonic: Temporal lobe lesion = Top-quadrant defect ("Tea in the Treetops"). Contrast with the dorsal optic radiation in the Parietal lobe, which causes a "Pie on the Floor" (inferior quadrantanopia).
content.takeAway: Meyer's loop takes a detour through the temporal lobe to carry information from the inferior retina; therefore, a lesion in this specific location predictably causes a contralateral "pie in the sky" visual field defect, a key localizing sign in neuro-ophthalmology.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Inferior Retina] --> B(LGN); B --> C(Meyer's Loop in Temporal Lobe); C --> D(Lower Visual Cortex); A --Represents--> E(Superior Visual Field);

content.definition: Microglia are the resident immune cells of the central nervous system (CNS), acting as the primary phagocytic scavengers and mediators of the innate immune response within the brain and spinal cord.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryonic Origin: Unlike other glial cells (which are neuroectodermal), microglia are derived from the mesoderm (yolk sac myeloid progenitors) and migrate into the CNS during development.
  • Function: In the resting state, they constantly survey their microenvironment with motile processes. Upon activation by injury, infection, or inflammation, they transform into an amoeboid shape, become phagocytic, and release inflammatory mediators (e.g., cytokines, nitric oxide).
  • Role in Pathology: They are activated in response to any CNS injury, including stroke, trauma, and infection. They phagocytose cellular debris and dead neurons.
  • HIV-Associated Dementia: In HIV infection, microglia can become infected and fuse to form multinucleated giant cells, which is a pathognomonic finding in HIV-associated dementia.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the unique mesodermal origin of microglia, distinguishing them from all other CNS cells which are of ectodermal origin. Mnemonic: Microglia = Macrophages of the CNS, from Mesoderm.
content.takeAway: Microglia are the dedicated immune defenders of the CNS, originating from the mesoderm and acting as the brain's resident macrophages; their activation is a double-edged sword, essential for clearing debris but also capable of contributing to neuroinflammation.

content.definition: Midazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine with potent anxiolytic, amnestic, sedative, and anticonvulsant properties, commonly used for procedural sedation and as an induction agent for general anesthesia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Facilitates the action of [[5aa5cb91|GABA]] at the GABAA receptor, increasing the frequency of Cl- channel opening, which leads to CNS depression.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a rapid onset and short duration of action, making it ideal for procedural use. It is one of the benzodiazepines with minimal first-pass metabolism.
  • Clinical Use: Used for sedation before medical procedures (e.g., endoscopy, surgery), as an anxiolytic, and for the treatment of status epilepticus.
  • Adverse Effects: Can cause significant respiratory depression, especially when combined with other CNS depressants like opioids. Also causes hypotension and anterograde amnesia.
  • Reversal: The effects of midazolam can be reversed by the competitive antagonist flumazenil.
  • USMLE Tip: Midazolam is a go-to drug for procedural sedation because of its rapid onset, short duration, and potent amnestic effects. Remember that its respiratory depressant effects are additive with opioids.
content.takeAway: Midazolam is a fast-acting, short-duration benzodiazepine prized for its ability to induce sedation and amnesia for uncomfortable procedures, but its potent CNS depressant effects necessitate careful monitoring of respiratory status.

content.definition: The Midbrain (or mesencephalon) is the most superior part of the brainstem, connecting the pons and cerebellum with the forebrain. It is a crucial center for motor control, auditory and visual processing, and consciousness.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryology: Arises from the mesencephalon, one of the three primary brain vesicles.
  • Cranial Nerve Nuclei: Contains the nuclei for the [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]] and the [[bba6093a|trochlear nerve (CN IV)]].
  • Key Structures:
    - Tectum (Dorsal): Contains the superior colliculi (visual reflexes) and inferior colliculi (auditory reflexes).
    - Tegmentum (Ventral): Contains the red nucleus (motor coordination) and substantia nigra (motor control, dopamine production).
    - Cerebral Peduncles: Large bundles of descending motor fibers (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts).
  • Vascular Supply: Primarily supplied by branches of the [[b6a2cc31|Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)]].
  • Clinical Syndromes: Lesions can cause specific syndromes like Weber syndrome (CN III palsy + contralateral hemiplegia) and Parinaud syndrome (dorsal midbrain compression).
content.takeAway: The Midbrain is a compact but vital relay and processing center, housing the origins of the nerves that move the eyes and containing the substantia nigra, whose degeneration is the cause of Parkinson's disease.

content.definition: The Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) is the largest cerebral artery and a terminal branch of the internal carotid artery. It supplies a significant portion of the lateral cerebral hemispheres, and its occlusion is the most common cause of ischemic stroke.
content.atAGlance:
• Territory: Supplies the lateral surface of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. This includes the primary motor and somatosensory cortices for the face and upper limb, as well as the language centers (Broca's and Wernicke's areas) in the dominant hemisphere.
  • Stroke Effects: An MCA stroke classically causes contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss, predominantly affecting the face and arm more than the leg.
  • Dominant Hemisphere (usually Left) Stroke: Can cause [[6bc9a567|aphasia]] (Broca's, Wernicke's, or global).
  • Non-dominant Hemisphere (usually Right) Stroke: Can cause [[134828d8|hemineglect syndrome]].
  • Deep Branches (Lenticulostriate Arteries): Supply the basal ganglia and internal capsule. Occlusion of these small vessels causes lacunar strokes, such as a [[8aefcafe|pure motor stroke]].
  • USMLE Tip: Contralateral face and arm weakness/sensory loss is the hallmark of an MCA stroke. If speech is affected, the lesion is in the dominant hemisphere. If neglect is present, the lesion is in the non-dominant hemisphere.
content.takeAway: The Middle Cerebral Artery supplies the eloquent lateral aspects of the brain, including motor and sensory areas for the face and arm, and the language centers. Consequently, an MCA stroke produces some of the most devastating and classic neurological deficits.

content.definition: The Middle Ear is an air-filled cavity within the temporal bone, located between the tympanic membrane and the inner ear. It contains the auditory ossicles and is connected to the nasopharynx by the eustachian tube.
content.atAGlance:
• Components: The middle ear cavity contains the three [[3aea8cac|auditory ossicles]] (malleus, incus, stapes).
  • Function: Transmits and amplifies sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane (eardrum) to the oval window of the inner ear.
  • Eustachian Tube: Connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, allowing for pressure equalization between the middle ear and the atmosphere. Dysfunction is a key factor in [[a03641af|otitis media]].
  • Muscles: Contains the tensor tympani (innervated by CN V3) and stapedius (innervated by CN VII) muscles, which dampen loud sounds.
  • Pathology: The most common pathology is [[a03641af|acute otitis media]], an infection of the middle ear space, especially common in children. Other conditions include [[03ef3134|cholesteatoma]] and otosclerosis.
content.takeAway: The Middle Ear functions as a mechanical impedance-matching system, using the lever action of the ossicles to efficiently transfer sound energy from the low-impedance air of the external world to the high-impedance fluid of the inner ear.

content.definition: The Middle Meningeal Artery is the largest of the three arteries that supply the meninges. Its rupture, typically due to head trauma, is the classic cause of an epidural hematoma.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: It is a branch of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Course: Enters the skull through the foramen spinosum and runs in a groove on the inner surface of the temporal bone, between the dura mater and the skull.
  • Clinical Significance: Laceration of this artery, often associated with a fracture of the temporal bone at the pterion (the thinnest part of the skull), leads to an epidural hematoma.
  • Epidural Hematoma: An arterial bleed that accumulates rapidly in the potential space between the dura and the skull, creating a lens-shaped (biconvex) hematoma on CT scan.
  • USMLE Tip: Trauma to the side of the head (pterion) leading to a brief loss of consciousness, a 'lucid interval,' and then rapid neurological decline is the classic presentation for an epidural hematoma from a middle meningeal artery tear.
content.takeAway: The Middle Meningeal Artery's vulnerable course in a groove on the inner surface of the thin temporal bone makes it the primary culprit in epidural hematomas following lateral head trauma, leading to a rapidly expanding, life-threatening arterial bleed.

content.definition: Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent, moderate to severe headaches that are typically unilateral and pulsating, and are often associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. Some attacks are preceded by a sensory warning sign or aura.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Involves irritation of the [[0eb45a0a|trigeminal nerve (CN V)]], meninges, or blood vessels, leading to the release of vasoactive neuropeptides like calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and substance P.
  • Clinical Features (POUND mnemonic): Pulsatile, One-day duration (4-72 hrs), Unilateral, Nausea, Disabling.
  • Aura: A transient visual, sensory, or motor disturbance that precedes or accompanies the headache. The most common is a visual aura (e.g., scintillating scotoma).
  • Abortive Treatment: For acute attacks, treatments include NSAIDs, triptans (5-HT1B/1D agonists like sumatriptan), and dihydroergotamine.
  • Prophylactic Treatment: For frequent migraines, options include beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol), TCAs (e.g., amitriptyline), anticonvulsants (e.g., topiramate, valproate), and anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies.
  • USMLE Tip: Triptans are contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease or Prinzmetal angina due to their vasoconstrictive effects.
content.takeAway: Migraine is a complex neurovascular disorder, not just a simple headache. Its pathophysiology involves trigeminal nerve activation and CGRP release, making CGRP antagonists and 5-HT agonists (triptans) specific and effective treatments.

content.definition: Miosis is the constriction of the pupil, which can be a physiological response to bright light or a pathological or pharmacological sign.
content.atAGlance:
• Physiology: Mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system. Preganglionic fibers from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus travel with the [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]] to the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibers release ACh, which acts on M3 muscarinic receptors on the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing it to contract.
  • Pharmacological Causes: Can be induced by cholinomimetics (e.g., [[f54d873a|pilocarpine]]) or acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Opioids (e.g., morphine, heroin) characteristically cause pinpoint pupils by stimulating the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.
  • Pathological Causes: A key feature of [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]], which results from disruption of the sympathetic pathway to the eye, leading to unopposed parasympathetic tone.
  • Pupillary Control Pathway: The pupillary light reflex pathway involves CN II (afferent) and CN III (efferent), resulting in miosis.
  • USMLE Tip: The triad of coma, respiratory depression, and miosis is classic for opioid overdose. Remember that tolerance does not develop to the miotic effects of opioids.
content.takeAway: Miosis results from parasympathetic activation causing contraction of the pupillary sphincter muscle. Its presence can be a key diagnostic clue, pointing to conditions ranging from opioid overdose to Horner syndrome.

content.definition: Molecular mimicry is a pathogenic mechanism in which sequence similarities between foreign (e.g., microbial) peptides and self-peptides are sufficient to result in the cross-activation of autoreactive T or B cells by a pathogen-derived epitope, leading to an autoimmune response.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: An immune response is mounted against a pathogen. Due to structural similarity between a pathogen antigen and a self-antigen, the activated T cells or antibodies then attack the host's own tissues.
  • Rheumatic Fever: A classic example. Antibodies against the M protein of Streptococcus pyogenes cross-react with cardiac myosin, leading to myocarditis.
  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (AIDP): Often follows infection with Campylobacter jejuni. Antibodies against bacterial lipooligosaccharides cross-react with gangliosides on peripheral nerve myelin.
  • Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM): An autoimmune response following a viral infection or vaccination is thought to cross-react with myelin antigens in the CNS.
  • USMLE Tip: When a question describes an autoimmune condition that develops shortly after an infection, molecular mimicry is the likely underlying mechanism.
content.takeAway: Molecular mimicry is a case of mistaken identity by the immune system, where the fight against a foreign invader inadvertently turns into a civil war against the body's own tissues due to the unfortunate resemblance between microbial and self-antigens.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Pathogen with Antigen 'X'] --> B(Immune System Activation); B --> C(Produces Antibodies/T-cells against 'X'); D[Self-Tissue with Antigen 'X-like'] <-- Cross-reactivity --- C; D --> E(Autoimmune Disease);

content.definition: Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors are a class of drugs that increase the levels of monoamine neurotransmitters (norepinephrine, serotonin, dopamine) by inhibiting the enzyme responsible for their breakdown.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Inhibit monoamine oxidase, the enzyme that degrades monoamines in the presynaptic terminal. This increases the amount of neurotransmitter available for release into the synapse.
  • Types:
    - Non-selective MAOIs (inhibit both MAO-A and MAO-B): Tranylcypromine, Phenelzine, Isocarboxazid. Used for atypical depression.
    - Selective MAO-B inhibitors: [[2883864d|Rasagiline]], Selegiline. Used for [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] to increase dopamine levels.
  • Adverse Effects:
    - Hypertensive Crisis: Occurs when MAOIs are taken with tyramine-rich foods (e.g., aged cheeses, cured meats, red wine). Tyramine is normally broken down by MAO-A in the gut; its buildup causes a massive release of catecholamines.
    - Serotonin Syndrome: Risk is high when combined with SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, or other serotonergic agents. A washout period is required when switching antidepressants.
  • USMLE Tip: The risk of hypertensive crisis with tyramine-containing foods (the "cheese effect") is the most famous and feared side effect of non-selective MAOIs.
content.takeAway: MAO inhibitors boost levels of multiple neurotransmitters by blocking their degradation, but this powerful, non-specific mechanism comes with dangerous interactions, most notably the risk of a life-threatening hypertensive crisis if combined with tyramine-rich foods.

content.definition: Moraxella catarrhalis is a gram-negative diplococcus that is a common commensal of the upper respiratory tract and a frequent cause of otitis media, sinusitis, and exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
content.atAGlance:
• Microbiology: Aerobic, non-motile, gram-negative diplococcus. It is oxidase-positive.
  • Clinical Infections:
    - [[a03641af|Otitis Media]]: One of the top three bacterial causes in children, along with S. pneumoniae and non-typeable H. influenzae.
    - Sinusitis: A common cause of acute bacterial sinusitis in both children and adults.
    - COPD Exacerbations: A significant cause of bacterial exacerbations of chronic bronchitis and COPD.
  • Virulence: Produces beta-lactamase, making it resistant to penicillins like amoxicillin.
  • Treatment: Often treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate, cephalosporins, or macrolides to cover for beta-lactamase production.
  • USMLE Tip: When considering the causes of [[a03641af|otitis media]] or a COPD exacerbation, always include M. catarrhalis in the differential, and remember that it is typically beta-lactamase positive.
content.takeAway: Moraxella catarrhalis is a common respiratory pathogen that, along with S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae, forms the classic triad of bacteria responsible for otitis media and sinusitis, with its frequent production of beta-lactamase influencing antibiotic choice.

content.definition: The Moro reflex, also known as the startle reflex, is a primitive, involuntary reflex present in infants in response to a sudden loss of support or a loud noise, characterized by the spreading out and then pulling in of the arms.
content.atAGlance:
• Elicitation: Elicited by allowing the infant's head to suddenly but gently fall backward.
  • Response: The infant responds by symmetrically abducting and extending the arms, followed by adduction and flexion of the arms. The infant may also cry.
  • Developmental Timeline: Present at birth and should disappear by 4-6 months of age.
  • Clinical Significance: Its presence at birth indicates a normal, intact central nervous system.
    - Absence: A symmetric absence may indicate severe CNS damage.
    - Asymmetry: An asymmetric response suggests a focal peripheral lesion, such as a brachial plexus injury (e.g., Erb's palsy) or a fractured clavicle on the non-responsive side.
  • USMLE Tip: The persistence of the Moro reflex beyond 6 months of age is abnormal and suggests underlying neurological disease. An asymmetric Moro reflex is a key sign of a birth injury like a brachial plexus palsy.
content.takeAway: The Moro reflex is a critical component of the newborn neurological exam; its symmetric presence is a reassuring sign of CNS integrity, while its asymmetry or absence can be the first clue to a significant central or peripheral nervous system injury.

content.definition: Morphine is a potent opiate analgesic drug that is the prototypical μ-opioid receptor agonist, used for the management of severe pain.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a full agonist at μ-opioid receptors in the CNS, leading to hyperpolarization of neurons and inhibition of pain signal transmission.
  • Clinical Use: Management of severe acute and chronic pain (e.g., postoperative pain, cancer pain). Also used for [[d268ace0|acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema]] due to its anxiolytic and venodilating (preload reducing) effects.
  • Metabolism: Undergoes extensive first-pass metabolism in the liver to form active metabolites, including morphine-6-glucuronide (more potent analgesic) and morphine-3-glucuronide (associated with neuroexcitatory effects). These metabolites are renally cleared, so caution is needed in renal failure.
  • Adverse Effects: Respiratory depression, sedation, constipation, miosis, nausea, vomiting, hypotension, and potential for tolerance and dependence.
  • USMLE Tip: Morphine and its active metabolites accumulate in renal failure, increasing the risk of toxicity. Remember its use in pulmonary edema is for both analgesia/anxiolysis and preload reduction.
content.takeAway: Morphine is the gold standard opioid analgesic, providing powerful pain relief by activating μ-opioid receptors, but its utility is tempered by a significant side effect profile, most notably life-threatening respiratory depression.

content.definition: Memantine is a non-competitive NMDA receptor antagonist used for the symptomatic treatment of moderate to severe [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks the NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor, a glutamate receptor. In [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], excessive glutamate activity is thought to cause excitotoxicity and neuronal death. Memantine blocks this pathological activation while allowing for normal physiological synaptic transmission.
  • Clinical Use: Used to treat moderate to severe dementia in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]. It may provide modest benefits in cognition, daily function, and behavior.
  • Adverse Effects: Generally well-tolerated. Side effects can include dizziness, confusion, and hallucinations.
  • Combination Therapy: Often used in combination with an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (e.g., [[47d0372e|donepezil]]) for a dual-mechanism approach to treating Alzheimer's symptoms.
  • USMLE Tip: While acetylcholinesterase inhibitors are first-line for mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's, memantine is added for moderate-to-severe disease. Remember its mechanism is to prevent glutamate-induced excitotoxicity.
content.takeAway: Memantine works by protecting neurons from the chronic, low-level excitotoxicity caused by excessive glutamate in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], acting as a 'noise filter' for the NMDA receptor to improve cognitive function without blocking normal learning and memory processes.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Excess Glutamate] --> B(Overstimulation of NMDA Receptor); B --> C(Excitotoxicity); C --> D(Neuronal Death in Alzheimer's); E[Memantine] --|Blocks|--> B;

content.definition: Memory is a complex cognitive function involving multiple neural structures, primarily within the [[73ace357|limbic system]] and temporal lobes, responsible for encoding, storing, and retrieving information.
content.atAGlance:
• Hippocampus: A critical structure located in the medial temporal lobe. It is essential for the formation of new declarative (explicit) memories (facts and events). Bilateral damage to the hippocampus results in profound anterograde amnesia.
  • Amygdala: Located adjacent to the hippocampus, the amygdala is crucial for processing the emotional significance of memories, particularly fear-related memories.
  • Mammillary Bodies: Part of the [[73ace357|limbic system]] that receives input from the hippocampus via the fornix. Damage to the mammillary bodies, as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, leads to severe memory deficits and confabulation.
  • Cerebral Cortex: Long-term memories are thought to be stored in a distributed fashion across the cerebral cortex, in the same areas that were involved in the initial perception and processing of the information.
  • USMLE Tip: Bilateral hippocampal damage causes anterograde amnesia (can't make new memories), while bilateral mammillary body damage (Wernicke-Korsakoff) also causes anterograde amnesia plus confabulation.
content.takeAway: The formation of new long-term memories is a process critically dependent on the integrity of the medial temporal lobe, especially the hippocampus, which acts as a temporary storage and consolidation hub before memories are distributed to the cortex for permanent storage.

content.definition: The Meninges are three layers of protective connective tissue membranes that envelop the brain and spinal cord, providing support, protection, and a space for the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
content.atAGlance:
• Layers (from superficial to deep):
    1. Dura Mater: The tough, outermost layer.
    2. Arachnoid Mater: A web-like middle layer.
    3. Pia Mater: The delicate, innermost layer that adheres to the brain surface.
  • Mnemonic for Layers: D-A-P (Dura, Arachnoid, Pia).
  • Spaces:
    - Epidural Space: A potential space between the skull and dura mater. Site of [[epidural_hematoma|epidural hematomas]].
    - Subdural Space: A potential space between the dura and arachnoid. Site of [[subdural_hematoma|subdural hematomas]].
    - Subarachnoid Space: The space between the arachnoid and pia, filled with CSF. Site of [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhages]].
  • Clinical Relevance: The meninges are the site of inflammation in [[meningitis]]. Tumors arising from the meninges are called [[e98ea0ba|meningiomas]].
content.takeAway: The meninges create a series of crucial real and potential spaces around the CNS; understanding these layers and spaces is fundamental to diagnosing and localizing intracranial hemorrhages and infections.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Skull] --> B(Epidural Space); B --> C(Dura Mater); C --> D(Subdural Space); D --> E(Arachnoid Mater); E --> F(Subarachnoid Space); F --> G(Pia Mater); G --> H(Brain);

content.definition: A Meningioma is a typically benign, slow-growing tumor that arises from the meningothelial (arachnoid cap) cells of the [[805d0677|meninges]]. It is the second most common primary brain tumor in adults.
content.atAGlance:
• Epidemiology: More common in females. Risk factors include prior radiation to the head and Neurofibromatosis type 2.
  • Location: Occurs along any dural surface, often on the convexities of the cerebral hemispheres, parasagittal region, or skull base. It is an extra-axial tumor, meaning it is external to the brain parenchyma.
  • Imaging: Appears as a well-circumscribed, dural-based mass that enhances brightly and uniformly with contrast. A characteristic "dural tail" of enhancing dura may be seen.
  • Histology: Characterized by spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern and the presence of psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications).
  • Clinical Presentation: Often asymptomatic and found incidentally. If symptomatic, it causes focal neurological deficits or seizures due to compression of the underlying brain.
  • USMLE Tip: A well-demarcated, dural-based tumor with a dural tail on MRI, and psammoma bodies on histology, is pathognomonic for a meningioma.
content.takeAway: A Meningioma is a classic 'outside-in' brain tumor, arising from the protective meningeal layers and causing symptoms by compressing, rather than invading, the adjacent brain parenchyma, which is reflected in its well-circumscribed appearance on imaging.

content.definition: A meningocele is a type of spina bifida, a neural tube defect, where the meninges herniate through a defect in the vertebral column, forming a fluid-filled sac on the infant's back, but the spinal cord itself remains within the spinal canal.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Results from the failure of the caudal neuropore of the [[a87cbede|neural tube]] to close, with a subsequent defect in the overlying vertebral arches.
  • Clinical Presentation: A visible, membrane-covered sac protruding from the back, typically in the lumbosacral region.
  • Neurological Function: Because the spinal cord is not displaced into the sac, neurological function is often normal or only mildly affected.
  • Distinction from Myelomeningocele: This is the key distinction. In a [[e9cd6754|myelomeningocele]], both the meninges and the spinal cord herniate into the sac, resulting in severe neurological deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: The key difference between a meningocele and a myelomeningocele is the contents of the sac. If the spinal cord is not in the sac, it's a meningocele, and the prognosis is much better.
content.takeAway: A meningocele is a 'best-case scenario' for an open neural tube defect, as the herniation is limited to the meninges and CSF, sparing the spinal cord itself from displacement and severe damage.

content.definition: Meperidine is a synthetic opioid analgesic that acts as a μ-opioid receptor agonist, used for short-term management of moderate to severe pain. Its use is limited due to its toxic metabolite and drug interactions.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Agonist at μ-opioid receptors. It also has significant antimuscarinic (anticholinergic) effects.
  • Metabolism: Metabolized in the liver to normeperidine, a neurotoxic metabolite. Normeperidine accumulation can cause CNS excitation, tremors, and seizures.
  • Clinical Use: Use is generally discouraged due to its toxic metabolite. It was historically used for pain in pancreatitis (thought to cause less sphincter of Oddi spasm than morphine, though this is debated) and to treat rigors/shivering.
  • Adverse Effects: In addition to standard opioid side effects, it can cause seizures due to normeperidine accumulation, especially in patients with renal failure or those on high doses. Unlike other opioids, it can cause mydriasis (pupil dilation) due to its anticholinergic effects.
  • Contraindication: Absolutely contraindicated with MAO inhibitors, as the combination can precipitate life-threatening [[serotonin_syndrome|serotonin syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the two unique features of meperidine compared to other opioids: it can cause seizures (via normeperidine) and mydriasis (anticholinergic effect), and it is contraindicated with MAOIs.
content.takeAway: Meperidine is an opioid with a dangerous secret: its neurotoxic metabolite, normeperidine, which accumulates in renal failure and can cause seizures, making it a poor choice for long-term or high-dose pain management.

content.definition: Mepivacaine is an intermediate-acting local anesthetic of the amide class, used for local or regional anesthesia via infiltration, nerve block, or epidural techniques.
content.atAGlance:
• Class: Amide local anesthetic. Mnemonic: Amides have two 'i's in their name (mepivacaine).
  • Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels on the inner portion of the nerve cell membrane, preventing the propagation of [[832463e6|action potentials]] and thus blocking nerve conduction.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has an intermediate duration of action. It is not effective as a topical anesthetic.
  • Adverse Effects: Systemic toxicity can occur with accidental intravascular injection or overdose, leading to CNS excitation (seizures) followed by depression (coma, respiratory arrest), and cardiovascular toxicity (hypotension, arrhythmias, bradycardia).
  • USMLE Tip: Know how to differentiate amide from ester local anesthetics. Allergic reactions are much more common with esters (due to PABA metabolite) than with amides.
content.takeAway: Mepivacaine is a workhorse amide local anesthetic that provides reliable nerve blockade by blocking sodium channels, with a safety profile typical of its class, where systemic toxicity is the primary concern.

content.definition: Merkel discs (or Merkel cell-neurite complexes) are specialized mechanoreceptors in the skin responsible for sensing fine, discriminative touch, such as pressure, shape, and texture.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Consist of a Merkel cell (a specialized epithelial cell) in close apposition with an enlarged nerve terminal.
  • Location: Found in the basal layer of the epidermis, particularly abundant in fingertips, lips, and other highly sensitive areas.
  • Function: They are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors, meaning they fire continuously as long as a stimulus is present. This property makes them ideal for encoding static features like sustained pressure and the shape/texture of objects.
  • Nerve Fibers: Transmitted by large, myelinated Aβ fibers.
  • Pathway: Signals travel via the [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway]].
  • USMLE Tip: Associate slowly adapting receptors with static qualities. Merkel discs = sustained pressure/shape. Ruffini corpuscles = sustained stretch. Rapidly adapting receptors (Meissner's, Pacinian) detect changes and vibration.
content.takeAway: Merkel discs are the high-fidelity touch receptors of the skin, providing the brain with a continuous stream of information about the precise shape and texture of objects being touched, a function enabled by their slowly adapting nature.

content.definition: The Mesencephalon, also known as the midbrain, is the middle of the three primary brain vesicles that form during early embryonic development. It persists as a distinct structure in the adult brain, forming the most superior part of the brainstem.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryonic Origin: One of the three primary brain vesicles, situated between the prosencephalon (forebrain) and rhombencephalon (hindbrain). It does not subdivide into secondary vesicles.
  • Adult Derivative: Differentiates into the midbrain.
  • Associated Cavity: The cavity of the mesencephalon narrows to form the cerebral aqueduct, which connects the third and fourth ventricles.
  • Cranial Nerves: The nuclei for the [[68c66997|oculomotor nerve (CN III)]] and the [[bba6093a|trochlear nerve (CN IV)]] are located in the midbrain.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the developmental pathway: Mesencephalon (primary vesicle) → Mesencephalon (secondary vesicle) → Midbrain (adult structure).
content.takeAway: The Mesencephalon is the developmental precursor to the midbrain, a critical brainstem region that retains its name from embryology into adulthood and houses the vital conduit for CSF flow, the cerebral aqueduct.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Primary Vesicles] --> B(Mesencephalon); B --> C[Secondary Vesicles]; C --> D(Mesencephalon); D --> E[Adult Structures]; E --> F(Midbrain); E --> G(Cerebral Aqueduct);

content.definition: The Mesocortical Pathway is a dopaminergic tract that projects from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) in the midbrain to the prefrontal cortex. It is critically involved in cognitive functions, motivation, and emotion.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA) in the midbrain.
  • Termination: Prefrontal cortex (especially the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex).
  • Neurotransmitter: [[90adc821|Dopamine]].
  • Function: Plays a key role in executive functions, such as working memory, planning, and attention, as well as motivation and emotional regulation.
  • Pathology (Schizophrenia): Hypoactivity (decreased dopamine) in the mesocortical pathway is thought to be responsible for the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., apathy, flat affect, cognitive deficits).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the two key VTA pathways in schizophrenia: the mesocortical pathway is underactive (negative symptoms), while the [[f4381654|mesolimbic]] pathway is overactive (positive symptoms).
content.takeAway: The Mesocortical Pathway is the dopaminergic connection to the brain's 'CEO,' the prefrontal cortex. Its underperformance is a leading hypothesis for the debilitating negative and cognitive symptoms of schizophrenia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ventral Tegmental Area VTA] --Dopamine--> B(Prefrontal Cortex); B --> C(Executive Function & Motivation);

content.definition: The Mesolimbic Pathway is a key dopaminergic tract that projects from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) in the midbrain to various structures of the [[73ace357|limbic system]], most notably the nucleus accumbens. It is the primary reward pathway in the brain.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA) in the midbrain.
  • Termination: [[8092ce8a|Nucleus accumbens]], amygdala, hippocampus, and other limbic structures.
  • Neurotransmitter: [[90adc821|Dopamine]].
  • Function: Mediates reward, pleasure, motivation, and reinforcement learning. It is central to behaviors that are evolutionarily advantageous, such as eating and sex.
  • Pathology (Addiction): This pathway is the final common pathway for addiction. All drugs of abuse (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines, opioids, nicotine) directly or indirectly increase dopamine release in the [[8092ce8a|nucleus accumbens]], leading to reinforcement of drug-taking behavior.
  • Pathology (Schizophrenia): Hyperactivity (increased dopamine) in the mesolimbic pathway is thought to be responsible for the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions). Antipsychotic drugs exert their therapeutic effect by blocking D2 receptors in this pathway.
content.takeAway: The Mesolimbic Pathway is the brain's fundamental reward circuit, driven by dopamine. Its overactivation is responsible for the positive symptoms of psychosis, and its hijacking by drugs of abuse is the neurobiological basis of addiction.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ventral Tegmental Area VTA] --Dopamine--> B(Nucleus Accumbens); B --> C(Reward & Pleasure);

content.definition: Metachromatic Leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A, leading to the accumulation of sulfatides and subsequent destruction of myelin in both the central and peripheral nervous systems.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • Enzyme Deficiency: Deficiency of arylsulfatase A.
  • Accumulated Substrate: Cerebroside sulfate (a sulfatide) accumulates in the lysosomes of oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells.
  • Pathophysiology: The buildup of sulfatides is toxic to myelin-producing cells, leading to progressive demyelination throughout the CNS and PNS.
  • Clinical Presentation: Presents with progressive neurological decline. The late infantile form is most common, with initial findings of gait disturbance (ataxia) and loss of motor milestones, followed by cognitive decline, spasticity, and peripheral neuropathy, eventually leading to a vegetative state.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed by measuring arylsulfatase A activity in leukocytes or cultured skin fibroblasts. Nerve biopsy shows demyelination.
  • USMLE Tip: For lysosomal storage diseases, always link the disease name, the deficient enzyme, and the accumulated substrate. Metachromatic Leukodystrophy = Arylsulfatase A deficiency = Cerebroside sulfate accumulation.
content.takeAway: Metachromatic Leukodystrophy is a devastating demyelinating disorder where the inability to break down sulfatides due to arylsulfatase A deficiency leads to the toxic destruction of myelin sheaths, causing a relentless decline in motor and cognitive function.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cerebroside Sulfate] --Arylsulfatase A--> B(Degradation); C[Enzyme Deficiency] --x B; A --> D(Accumulation in Lysosomes); D --> E(Demyelination); E --> F(Progressive Neurologic Decline);

content.definition: Metamorphopsia is a type of visual distortion in which straight lines appear wavy or bent. It is a key symptom of macular disease.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by disruption of the normal arrangement of photoreceptors in the macula, the central part of the retina responsible for high-acuity vision.
  • Classic Association: It is a hallmark symptom of wet (exudative) age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The leakage of fluid and blood from choroidal neovascularization beneath the macula elevates and distorts the retinal layers.
  • Other Causes: Can also be seen in other macular pathologies, such as epiretinal membrane, macular pucker, and central serous chorioretinopathy.
  • Diagnosis: Can be subjectively tested by the patient at home using an Amsler grid. The patient looks at the grid, and if the lines appear wavy, distorted, or have blank spots, it suggests macular pathology.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient, especially an elderly one, who complains that straight lines (like on a door frame or telephone pole) suddenly appear wavy has metamorphopsia and should be evaluated urgently for wet AMD.
content.takeAway: Metamorphopsia is a specific visual distortion that acts as a sensitive alarm bell for macular pathology, particularly the neovascularization of wet AMD, signaling a disruption in the precise architecture of the central retina.

content.definition: The Metencephalon is one of the five secondary brain vesicles, arising from the anterior part of the embryonic hindbrain (rhombencephalon). It develops into the pons and the cerebellum.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryonic Origin: Arises from the rostral (anterior) portion of the rhombencephalon (hindbrain).
  • Adult Derivatives: Differentiates into the pons and the cerebellum.
  • Associated Cavity: The cavity of the metencephalon becomes the upper part of the fourth ventricle.
  • Mnemonic for Vesicles: The five secondary vesicles in rostral to caudal order are Telencephalon, Diencephalon, Mesencephalon, Metencephalon, and Myelencephalon.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the two components of the hindbrain (rhombencephalon) are the metencephalon (pons and cerebellum) and the myelencephalon (medulla).
content.takeAway: The Metencephalon is the developmental precursor to the pons and cerebellum, two structures that are anatomically and functionally linked to form a critical hub for motor control and sensory relay in the adult brainstem.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Rhombencephalon (Hindbrain)] --> B(Metencephalon); A --> C(Myelencephalon); B --> D(Pons); B --> E(Cerebellum); B --> F(Upper Fourth Ventricle);

content.definition: Methadone is a long-acting, synthetic μ-opioid receptor agonist used for the management of chronic pain and, most notably, as a maintenance therapy for opioid use disorder.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: A potent, long-acting full agonist at μ-opioid receptors. It also has antagonist activity at the NMDA receptor, which may contribute to its efficacy in neuropathic pain.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a long and variable half-life (typically 24-36 hours), which allows for once-daily dosing and prevents the rapid peaks and troughs associated with short-acting opioids like heroin, thereby reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Opioid Maintenance Therapy: The primary use. Reduces illicit opioid use, mortality, and criminal activity.
    - Chronic Pain: Effective for chronic pain, including neuropathic pain.
    - [[b95e97eb|Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome]]: Used to treat withdrawal in newborns exposed to opioids in utero.
  • Adverse Effects: Similar to other opioids (respiratory depression, constipation, sedation). A major unique risk is QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes.
  • USMLE Tip: Methadone's long half-life is its key feature for maintenance therapy. The risk of QT prolongation is a high-yield adverse effect to remember.
content.takeAway: Methadone treats opioid addiction by substituting a long-acting, orally administered opioid for a short-acting, often injected one. This stabilizes the patient by preventing withdrawal and reducing cravings, allowing them to disengage from the cycle of illicit drug use, but it carries its own risks, including QT prolongation.

content.definition: Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is a severe, invasive, and potentially life-threatening infection of the external auditory canal and skull base, typically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The infection begins in the external ear canal and aggressively spreads, causing osteomyelitis of the temporal bone and skull base.
  • Risk Factors: Almost exclusively seen in elderly patients with diabetes mellitus and other immunocompromised individuals.
  • Causative Organism: The most common pathogen is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Clinical Presentation: Presents with exquisite, severe otalgia (ear pain) that is often worse at night, purulent otorrhea, and the presence of granulation tissue at the floor of the ear canal at the bone-cartilage junction.
  • Complications: Can progress to involve cranial nerves, most commonly the [[dea9755f|facial nerve (CN VII)]] as it exits the stylomastoid foramen, leading to facial paralysis. Further spread can cause meningitis or brain abscess.
  • USMLE Tip: An elderly diabetic patient with severe ear pain, drainage, and granulation tissue in the ear canal is the classic vignette for malignant otitis externa.
content.takeAway: Malignant otitis externa is a misnomer as it is not a malignancy but a severe infection; it represents Pseudomonas aeruginosa invading from the ear canal into the skull, a process facilitated by the microangiopathy and immunosuppression of diabetes.

content.definition: Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a rare, life-threatening, hypermetabolic state of skeletal muscle triggered by exposure to volatile inhaled anesthetics (e.g., halothane, sevoflurane) or the depolarizing neuromuscular blocker succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Most commonly an autosomal dominant condition with variable penetrance, associated with mutations in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) gene.
