content.definition: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is a neurotropic virus that can cause several neurological conditions, most notably a severe, focal encephalitis. HSV-1 is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis in the US, while HSV-2 is a common cause of viral meningitis.
content.atAGlance:
• HSV-1 Encephalitis: Has a characteristic predilection for the temporal lobes. Presents with fever, headache, altered mental status, seizures, and focal neurological deficits (e.g., aphasia). Can lead to [[c6292526|Klüver-Bucy syndrome]] if bilateral temporal lobes are damaged.
  • HSV-2 Meningitis: A common cause of recurrent aseptic (viral) meningitis.
  • Bell's Palsy: Reactivation of HSV-1 is the presumed cause of most cases of Bell's palsy, a peripheral [[a1a54523|facial nerve (CN VII) palsy]].
  • Diagnosis: PCR of the CSF for HSV DNA is the gold standard for diagnosis of CNS infection.
  • Treatment: Intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of choice and should be started empirically in any patient with suspected HSV encephalitis.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with fever, confusion, seizures, and an MRI showing temporal lobe enhancement has HSV encephalitis until proven otherwise. Start acyclovir immediately.
content.takeAway: Herpes Simplex Virus has a distinct neurotropism, with HSV-1 targeting the temporal lobes to cause a devastating encephalitis, and HSV-2 more commonly causing a self-limited meningitis, both of which are treatable with acyclovir.

content.definition: The Hippocampus is a complex brain structure embedded deep in the medial temporal lobe. It is a major component of the [[73ace357|limbic system]] and plays a critical role in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory, and in spatial navigation.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Essential for the formation of new declarative (explicit) memories (facts and events).
  • Lesion Effects: Bilateral damage to the hippocampus results in profound anterograde amnesia, the inability to form new long-term memories. Remote memories and procedural memory (skills) are typically preserved.
  • Pathology: The hippocampus is one of the first regions of the brain to be affected in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]], which explains why memory loss is an early symptom. It is also highly vulnerable to hypoxic-ischemic injury.
  • Limbic System: It is a key part of the Papez circuit, connecting to the [[f02cfaa1|mammillary bodies]] via the fornix.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic case of H.M., who had his hippocampi surgically removed to treat epilepsy, demonstrated the hippocampus's crucial role in forming new memories.
content.takeAway: The Hippocampus acts as the brain's memory 'save button,' crucial for converting the experiences of the present moment into lasting declarative memories; its destruction leads to a state of being permanently stuck in the past, unable to form new personal or factual knowledge.

content.definition: Histamine H1 receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that play a significant role in the central pathways of nausea and vomiting, particularly in the context of motion sickness. They are a key target for certain antiemetic drugs.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: H1 receptors involved in emesis are located in the vestibular nuclei and the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the brainstem.
  • Role in Motion Sickness: The vestibular system detects motion and sends signals to the vestibular nuclei. This pathway, which involves both H1 and M1 muscarinic receptors, then projects to the [[74b651ab|vomiting center]] (which includes the NTS).
  • Pharmacology (Antihistamines): First-generation H1 receptor antagonists (e.g., diphenhydramine, dimenhydrinate, meclizine) are effective in preventing and treating [[511db4d8|motion sickness]]. Their efficacy is due to their ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and block central H1 receptors. They also have significant anticholinergic effects, which contribute to their antiemetic action.
  • USMLE Tip: For [[511db4d8|motion sickness]], the key neurotransmitters to block are acetylcholine (M1) and histamine (H1). This is why both scopolamine (antimuscarinic) and first-generation antihistamines are effective.
content.takeAway: Histamine H1 receptors in the brainstem are a crucial link in the pathway from the vestibular system to the vomiting center, making their blockade by first-generation antihistamines an effective strategy for combating motion sickness.

content.definition: Neuropathology histology involves the microscopic examination of brain and nerve tissue to identify characteristic changes associated with various neurological diseases, which are often pathognomonic.
content.atAGlance:
• Ischemic Stroke: The earliest change (12-24 hours) is the appearance of "red neurons" (eosinophilic cytoplasm, pyknotic nuclei). This is followed by neutrophil infiltration and then macrophage/microglial cleanup, leading to [[4945aa8c|liquefactive necrosis]].
  • Glioblastoma: Characterized by pseudopalisading necrosis, where tumor cells line up around a central area of necrosis, and microvascular proliferation.
  • Parkinson Disease: Eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions called Lewy bodies (composed of α-synuclein) in the neurons of the substantia nigra.
  • Alzheimer Disease: Extracellular senile plaques (Aβ amyloid) and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (hyperphosphorylated tau).
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease: Spongiform encephalopathy, showing widespread vacuolation in the gray matter.
  • USMLE Tip: Being able to recognize these classic histological findings and associate them with the correct disease is a very high-yield skill for pathology questions.
content.takeAway: The microscopic appearance of brain tissue provides a definitive diagnosis for many neurological disorders, with specific inclusions and cellular reactions like 'red neurons' or 'Lewy bodies' serving as the pathological fingerprints of their respective diseases.

content.definition: HIV-Associated Dementia (HAD), also known as AIDS dementia complex, is a subcortical dementia that occurs in the late stages of HIV infection, characterized by cognitive, motor, and behavioral abnormalities.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by the HIV virus infecting CNS cells, primarily microglia and macrophages. Neurons are not directly infected but are damaged by inflammatory cytokines and viral proteins (e.g., gp120, Tat) released by infected glial cells.
  • Risk Factors: Occurs in patients with advanced immunosuppression, typically with a CD4 count < 200 cells/mm³.
  • Histopathology: The pathognomonic finding is the presence of multinucleated giant cells (formed by the fusion of infected microglia) and microglial nodules in the white matter and deep gray matter structures.
  • Clinical Presentation: A subcortical dementia, it presents with cognitive slowing (bradyphrenia), memory problems, apathy, and social withdrawal. Motor symptoms include ataxia, poor balance, and tremors.
  • Treatment: The incidence and severity of HAD have dramatically decreased with the advent of effective antiretroviral therapy (ART).
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of multinucleated giant cells in the brain of an AIDS patient with dementia is the classic histological finding for HAD.
content.takeAway: HIV-Associated Dementia is not caused by direct neuronal infection but rather by an inflammatory 'bystander effect,' where HIV-infected microglia release neurotoxic substances that damage neurons, leading to a characteristic subcortical dementia.

content.definition: Holoprosencephaly is a severe congenital brain malformation resulting from the failure of the embryonic forebrain (prosencephalon) to divide into two distinct cerebral hemispheres during early gestation (weeks 3-4).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A developmental field defect involving incomplete cleavage of the prosencephalon. It is associated with mutations in genes involved in the Sonic hedgehog (SHH) signaling pathway.
  • Spectrum of Severity: Ranges from alobar (most severe, single ventricle and no hemispheric separation) to semilobar and lobar (less severe).
  • Associated Midline Facial Defects: The severity of the brain malformation often correlates with the severity of midline facial defects. These can range from a single maxillary incisor or cleft lip/palate to severe anomalies like cyclopia (a single eye).
  • Associated Conditions: Can be seen in genetic syndromes like Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) and as a feature of fetal alcohol syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of a severe midline facial defect (like cyclopia or a single nostril) and a major brain malformation is characteristic of holoprosencephaly. Think of SHH pathway mutations and Trisomy 13.
content.takeAway: Holoprosencephaly is a fundamental failure of the brain to divide into left and right hemispheres, a process intimately linked to the development of the midline face, such that the 'face predicts the brain'—severe facial anomalies often signal an underlying undivided brain.

content.definition: Homeostasis is the process by which biological systems maintain a stable internal environment despite changes in external conditions. The hypothalamus is the primary control center for maintaining homeostasis in the body.
content.atAGlance:
• Hypothalamic Function: The [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] acts as a thermostat and regulator, monitoring and controlling numerous physiological parameters to keep them within a narrow range.
  • Parameters Regulated: Key homeostatic functions controlled by the hypothalamus include:
    - Temperature Regulation: Anterior hypothalamus for cooling, posterior for heating.
    - Water Balance: Osmoreceptors trigger thirst and ADH release.
    - Energy Balance: Lateral nucleus for hunger, ventromedial for satiety.
    - Autonomic Control: Regulates both sympathetic and parasympathetic output.
    - Endocrine Function: Controls the pituitary gland.
  • Feedback Loops: Homeostasis is maintained through negative feedback loops, where a change in a variable triggers a response that counteracts the initial change.
  • USMLE Tip: Many questions in physiology and endocrinology are based on understanding the homeostatic feedback loops controlled by the hypothalamus.
content.takeAway: The hypothalamus is the master coordinator of homeostasis, acting like a sophisticated control panel that constantly adjusts the body's autonomic, endocrine, and behavioral outputs to maintain a stable internal milieu essential for survival.

content.definition: Homer-Wright rosettes are a characteristic histological finding in several small round blue cell tumors, where tumor cells arrange themselves in a circular pattern around a central space filled with fibrillary material (neuropil).
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: A ring of small, dark tumor cell nuclei surrounding a central, eosinophilic, fibrillary core that is devoid of a blood vessel or lumen.
  • Associated Tumors: They are a classic feature of several neuroblastic tumors, including:
    - Medulloblastoma: The most common malignant pediatric brain tumor.
    - Neuroblastoma: A common extracranial solid tumor of childhood, arising from neural crest cells.
    - Pineoblastoma and Ewing sarcoma (less commonly).
  • Distinction from Other Rosettes:
    - Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes: Have a true central lumen; seen in retinoblastoma.
    - Perivascular pseudorosettes: Tumor cells are arranged around a central blood vessel; seen in ependymomas.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of Homer-Wright rosettes in a cerebellar tumor from a child is pathognomonic for [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]].
content.takeAway: Homer-Wright rosettes are a histological sign of primitive neuroblastic differentiation, where undifferentiated tumor cells attempt to form a rudimentary synapse-like structure, creating a distinctive circular pattern that is a key diagnostic feature of tumors like medulloblastoma and neuroblastoma.

content.definition: The Homunculus (Latin for "little man") is a distorted, topographic representation of the human body located in the primary motor cortex and the primary somatosensory cortex. The disproportionate size of body parts in the homunculus reflects the density of innervation and functional importance of those areas.
content.atAGlance:
• Motor Homunculus: Located in the precentral gyrus (frontal lobe). Represents the origin of the corticospinal tracts. Areas with fine motor control, like the hands and face, have a very large representation.
  • Sensory Homunculus: Located in the postcentral gyrus (parietal lobe). Represents the termination of sensory pathways. Areas with high tactile sensitivity, like the lips and fingertips, have a very large representation.
  • Somatotopic Arrangement: The body is represented in an upside-down and inverted fashion. The feet and legs are located on the medial surface of the hemisphere, while the trunk, arm, hand, and face are located along the lateral convexity.
  • Vascular Supply and Clinical Correlation: This arrangement is clinically significant for localizing strokes:
    - Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) stroke: Affects the medial cortex, causing contralateral leg and foot deficits.
    - Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) stroke: Affects the lateral cortex, causing contralateral face and arm deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: The vascular supply of the homunculus is a very high-yield concept for stroke localization questions.
content.takeAway: The Homunculus is a neural map that illustrates the brain's prioritization of function over physical size, with the vast cortical real estate devoted to the hands and face underscoring their critical roles in motor dexterity and sensory perception.

content.definition: A hordeolum, commonly known as a stye, is an acute, painful, purulent inflammation of an eyelid gland, typically caused by a bacterial infection.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - External Hordeolum: An infection of a sebaceous gland of Zeis or an apocrine gland of Moll, located at the eyelid margin. This is the more common type.
    - Internal Hordeolum: An infection of a meibomian gland, located within the tarsal plate of the eyelid.
  • Etiology: Most commonly caused by an infection with Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Clinical Presentation: A localized, painful, red, swollen lump on or within the eyelid. It may have a central point of pus (pustule).
  • Treatment: The mainstay of treatment is warm compresses to promote drainage. Topical antibiotics may be used. Incision and drainage may be required if it does not resolve.
  • Distinction from Chalazion: A [[chalazion]] is a granulomatous inflammation of a meibomian gland, not an acute infection. It is typically painless, harder, and located further from the eyelid margin than an external hordeolum.
  • USMLE Tip: The key differentiating feature between a hordeolum and a chalazion is pain. Hordeolum = Hurts. Chalazion = Chronic and non-tender.
content.takeAway: A hordeolum is essentially a small abscess of an eyelid gland, presenting as a tender, red bump, which distinguishes it from the painless, chronic granulomatous nodule of a chalazion.

content.definition: Horner syndrome is a clinical triad of symptoms resulting from the disruption of the oculosympathetic pathway, which provides sympathetic innervation to the eye and face.
content.atAGlance:
• Classic Triad:
    1. Ptosis: Mild drooping of the upper eyelid due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle.
    2. Miosis: A constricted pupil due to unopposed parasympathetic tone to the sphincter pupillae muscle.
    3. Anhidrosis: Decreased sweating on the ipsilateral side of the face.
  • Pathophysiology: Caused by a lesion anywhere along the three-neuron [[84b5e4f6|oculosympathetic pathway]]:
    - First-order (Central): Brainstem stroke (e.g., [[07656b4a|lateral medullary syndrome]]), spinal cord lesion above T1 (e.g., [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard syndrome]], syringomyelia).
    - Second-order (Preganglionic): A Pancoast tumor (apical lung tumor) compressing the sympathetic chain.
    - Third-order (Postganglionic): Carotid artery dissection (painful Horner's), [[9a089fd7|cavernous sinus syndrome]].
  • Diagnosis: Can be confirmed with pharmacological eye drop tests (e.g., apraclonidine, cocaine).
  • USMLE Tip: A smoker presenting with shoulder pain, arm weakness, and the triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis likely has a Pancoast tumor causing Horner syndrome.
content.takeAway: Horner syndrome is the clinical manifestation of a sympathetic blackout to one side of the face, and its presence should trigger a search for an underlying lesion along the long and vulnerable oculosympathetic pathway, from the hypothalamus down to the chest and back up to the eye.

content.definition: Hunger and satiety regulation is a complex homeostatic process controlled primarily by the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]], which integrates peripheral hormonal signals from the gut and adipose tissue with central neuronal circuits to control food intake and energy expenditure.
content.atAGlance:
• Hypothalamic Centers:
    - Lateral Nucleus: The hunger center. Stimulation induces hunger. It is inhibited by leptin and stimulated by ghrelin. Lesion → anorexia.
    - Ventromedial Nucleus: The satiety center. Stimulation induces satiety. It is stimulated by leptin. Lesion → hyperphagia and obesity.
  • Key Hormones (Peripheral):
    - [[c8515469|Leptin]]: Secreted by adipose tissue; signals satiety (long-term).
    - Ghrelin: Secreted by the stomach; stimulates hunger (short-term).
    - Insulin: Secreted by the pancreas; signals satiety.
    - CCK: Secreted by the duodenum; signals satiety.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the opposing roles of the hypothalamic nuclei: Lateral nucleus makes you Lean (lesion). Ventromedial nucleus makes you Very Massive (lesion).
content.takeAway: The regulation of hunger and satiety is a delicate balance orchestrated by the hypothalamus, which acts as a central processor for a host of peripheral signals like leptin and ghrelin to ensure energy homeostasis.

content.definition: Huntington Disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder characterized by a triad of motor, cognitive, and psychiatric symptoms, caused by an expansion of a CAG trinucleotide repeat in the huntingtin (HTT) gene.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Autosomal dominant inheritance with anticipation (disease becomes more severe and appears at an earlier age in successive generations). Caused by a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 4. Mnemonic: Caudate loses ACh and GABA.
  • Pathophysiology: Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen (striatum). This leads to atrophy of the striatum, visible on imaging as enlargement of the lateral ventricles.
  • Neurotransmitter Changes: Marked decrease in [[5aa5cb91|GABA]] and [[6a005559|acetylcholine]], with a relative excess of [[90adc821|dopamine]].
  • Clinical Presentation: Onset typically between ages 30-50. Presents with chorea (involuntary, dance-like movements), progressing to dementia and psychiatric disturbances (depression, aggression).
  • Treatment: There is no cure. Symptomatic treatment for chorea includes dopamine antagonists (e.g., haloperidol) or VMAT inhibitors (e.g., tetrabenazine).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient in their 40s with new-onset chorea and personality changes should make you think of Huntington disease. The key pathology is atrophy of the caudate nucleus.
content.takeAway: Huntington Disease is a fatal genetic disorder where an expanded CAG repeat leads to the progressive destruction of GABAergic neurons in the striatum, resulting in a devastating clinical triad of uncontrollable movements (chorea), cognitive decline (dementia), and psychiatric illness.
